了解专业程序员

Understanding the Professional Programmer

经过

by

杰拉尔德·M·温伯格

Gerald M. Weinberg

热门词版

了解专业程序员

Understanding the Professional Programmer

亲爱的读者： 唉，即使有很多层的编辑，错误也可能会被漏掉。但是，我们可以一起消除令人讨厌的滋扰。如果您在本书中遇到拼写错误或错误，请将它们发送给我：< hardpretzel@earthlink.net > 谢谢！—Jerry Weinberg

Dear Reader: Even with many layers of editing, mistakes can slip through, alas. But, together, we can eradicate the nasty nuisances. If you encounter typos or errors in this book, please send them to me at: Thank you!—Jerry Weinberg

1944 年，当我十一岁时，我读到 时代 杂志一篇关于计算机的文章！在那个年龄，我的头脑一片空白，正在寻找一支粉笔，所以这篇文章给人留下了深刻的印象。我记得坐在客厅的高背靠背椅上， 时间 在我腿上，时间在我手上，决定我要成为一个“计算机人”。（“程序员”这个头衔直到几年后才出现。）自 1944 年以来，计算机发生了很多变化。我们的生活因计算机而发生了很多变化——尤其是我的生活。但至少有一件事没有改变。过了一辈子，现在我正在写计算机文章而不是阅读它们。然而，即使在今天，也没有人了解“计算机人”是什么、他们真正做什么以及他们应该做什么。

In 1944, when I was eleven, I read a Time magazine article about computers! At that age, my mind was a clean slate looking for a piece of chalk, so the article made a great impression. I recall sitting in the high wing-backed chair in the living room, Time in my lap and time on my hands, deciding I was going to become a "computer person." (The title of "programmer" didn't exist until years later.) Much has happened to computers since 1944. Much has happened to our lives because of computers—especially to my life. But one thing, at least, hasn't changed. It's a lifetime later, and now I'm writing the computer articles instead of reading them. Yet even today nobody understands what "computer people" are, what they really do, and what they ought to be doing.

我不应该说没有人知道。今天的问题是 每个人都 知道——但每个人都知道一些不同的事情。经过一生的计算，尘埃仍未落定。计算机人仍然可以自由 选择 他们可能做什么——同时也可以自由选择计算机可能做什么。或许再过五十年或一百年，计算机人将终生陷入死板的牢笼，但今天我们的命运似乎仍掌握在自己手中。

I shouldn't say nobody knows. The problem today is everybody knows—but everybody knows something different. After a lifetime of computing, the dust still hasn't settled. Computer people still have the freedom to choose what they might do—and with it the freedom to choose what computers might do. Perhaps in another fifty or one hundred years, computer people will be slotted into rigid pigeonholes for life, but today our fate still seems to be in our own hands.

迄今为止，计算业务一直依赖于思想的自由流动。在过去，你可以每月参加一次会议，并与来自洛杉矶等地每个重要设施的至少一个人交谈。现在一些老前辈去XCC，试图在全世界75000人中重建以前的环境，但还是不一样。

The computing business until now has depended on the free flow of ideas. In the old days you could go to a meeting once a month and talk to at least one person from every important installation in, say, Los Angeles. Now some old-timers go to the XCC and try to reestablish the former environment among 75,000 people from till over the world, but it's not the same.

它永远不会是一样的。我们曾经通过某种旅鼠本能自然完成的事情，现在必须通过更明确的结构来完成。例如，在大型会议上没有小想法的余地。在小型会议上，小人物没有空间，小人物会来听大人物的智慧之珠。

And it will never be the same. What we once accomplished naturally, by some sort of lemming instinct, now has to be accomplished by more explicit structures. For instance, at big meetings there's no room for little ideas. And at little meetings there's no room for the little shot, who's come to hear what pearls of wisdom the big shots might cast.

过去，我们依靠会议，因为写下来的很少。当我 1956 年开始为 IBM 工作时，我 在旧金山分部办公室用了不到一周的时间阅读了每一本技术文献（包括整个 SHARE 库）！ 那个壁橱里的图书馆几乎是 IBM 在 1956 年拥有的所有技术文献。

In the past, we depended on meetings because little was written down. When I started working for IBM in 1956, I read every piece of technical literature (including the entire SHARE library) in the San Francisco branch office in less than one week! That library-in-a-closet was pretty much all the technical literature IBM possessed in 1956.

今天，我们被技术文献淹没了，几乎没有时间进行面对面的交流，而且似乎根本没有时间进行“非正式”阅读。因此，世界各地的计算机人都在彼此失去联系，失去了技术不足以写入手册或教科书的想法。在失去这些想法时，我们正在失去与现实的重要部分的联系。我们的工作受到影响。

Today, we are so swamped with technical literature we have little time for face-to-face exchanges and seemingly no time at all for "informal" reading. So computer people everywhere are losing contact with one another, losing the flow of ideas not sufficiently technical to put in manuals or textbooks. In losing those ideas, we're losing contact with a significant portion of our reality. Our work suffers.

当我读到我的常规专栏——“美国”、“第二阶段” 和 “来自内布拉斯加州伊格尔”的读者来信时，我最强烈地感受到这种失去联系的感觉。 迪比克、都柏林、德里和但尼丁都有计算机人，他们分享了很多，但永远没有机会面对面交流。如果他们真的见面了，他们会立即认出对方是“计算机人”——就像他们在这些文章中认出自己一样。“计算机人”是什么意思？我指的是那种阅读这些文章并时不时说“是的，我这样做”或“我有这种感觉”或“我希望我的经理理解这一点”或“我可以使用该技术， ”甚至“温伯格这个人已经与我工作的环境失去了联系。”

I sense this loss of contact most strongly when I read the letters from readers of my regular columns—Stateside, Phase 2, and From Eagle, Nebraska. There are computer people in Dubuque, Dublin, Delhi, and Dunedin who share so much but who will never have the opportunity to meet face to face. If they did meet, they would instantly recognize one another as "computer people"—just as they have recognized themselves in these essays. What do I mean by a "computer person"? I mean the kind of person who reads these essays and says now and then, "Yes, I do that," or "I feel that way," or "I wish my manager understood that," or "I can use that technique," or even "This guy Weinberg has lost touch with the kind of environment I work in."

这些文章是为那些想要更好地了解计算机人员的人准备的——程序员、分析师、经理、设计师、培训师、测试人员、维护人员、操作员、管理员、架构师、主管，或者他们所谓的任何人。我试图让这些文章变得有趣，以免浪费普通计算机人非常宝贵的阅读时间。只要有五分钟的空闲时间（比如在等待某个网站回复时），你就可以拿起我的一本书，随意打开它，阅读一个完整的想法。它可能不是世界上最伟大的想法，但它就在那里，而且它可能会带来一些好处。如果不。它可能会给你一些快乐——它会以自己的方式带来一些好处。

These essays are for people who want a better understanding of computer people—programmers, analysts, managers, designers, trainers, testers, maintainers, operators, administrators, architects, chiefs, or whatever they're called. I've tried to make the essays interesting, so as not to waste any of the very scarce reading time of the average computer person. You can pick up one of my books whenever you have five minutes to spare (like while you're waiting for some website to respond), open it at random, and read a complete idea. It may not be the world's greatest idea, but it's all there and it might do some good. And if not. it might give you some pleasure—which will do some good in its own way.

前言

Preface

专业 这个词有几个明确定义的含义以及沉重的含义包袱。为了让读者更好地定义本书的范围，我想探讨一下我在书名中想要表达的含义。

The word professional carries several well-defined meanings as well as a heavy baggage of implications. To give the reader a better definition of the scope of this book, I'd like to explore which of those meanings I intend in my title.

我的 美国传统词典 说 专业的 意思是“属于、涉及、从事或适合某种职业”，这只会使职业的定义倒退 。 这将导致我们争论编程是否是一种职业，它是否应该是，以及如何成为一种职业。我不打算让读者参与这些论点，尽管毫无疑问，这里的许多文章都会对这个主题有所启发或影响。

My American Heritage Dictionary says professional means "of, related to, engaged in, or suitable for a profession," which only throws the meaning back on the definition of profession. This would lead us into arguments of whether programming is a profession, whether it should be, and how it is to become one. I do not intend to engage the reader in these arguments, though no doubt many of the essays here will throw some light or shadow on the subject.

第二和第三个定义强调了工作报酬的收取。从我的意图来看，专业程序员可能会因编程工作而获得报酬，但不一定。此外，还有许多因编程工作而获得报酬的人我不认为他们 是 专业人士，阅读这些文章的人会明白其中的原因。

The second and third definitions emphasize the receipt of pay for work. The professional programmer, in the sense I intend, probably receives pay for programming work, but not necessarily. Moreover, there are many who receive pay for programming work who I would not regard as professionals, for reasons that will become clear to those who read these essays.

最接近我对专业意义的定义是：“在特定活动领域拥有出色的技能或经验。”

The closest definition to my meaning of professional is this: "Having great skill or experience in a particular field of activity."

这本书是关于那些在计算机编程方面具有高超技能或经验的人的。

This book is about the people who have great skill or experience in computer programming.

与我早先的书《 计算机程序设计心理学》不同， 本书并不试图囊括所有归入“程序设计”标题下的活动。这里的重点是技术娴熟、经验丰富的表演者——如何成为一个人，以及如何在危险的环境中保持一个人。

Unlike my earlier book, The Psychology of Computer Programming, this book does not attempt to encompass all the activities subsumed under the title "programming." The focus here is on the skilled and experienced performer—how to become one and how to remain one in a treacherous environment.

我的老朋友兼对手菲尔·克拉夫特 (Phil Kraft) 让我为《计算机程序设计心理学》 一书的书名负责。据我理解他的论点，从字面上看，并没有活动的心理这样的东西，只有一个人或几个人的心理。Phil 可能更喜欢 Understanding the Professional Programmer 作为标题（尽管我怀疑他会被某些内容激怒）。我在这个标题中强调了个人，因为个人是本书的重点。

My old friend and adversary Phil Kraft took me to task for the title The Psychology of Computer Programming. As I understand his argument, there is no such thing, literally, as the psychology of an activity, but only the psychology of a person or persons. Phil may be happier with Understanding the Professional Programmer as a title (though I suspect he'll be enraged by some of the contents). I have emphasized the individual person in this title because the individual is the focus of the book.

Understanding the Professional Programmer 主要是作为专业程序员的自我检查练习。一位非常睿智的顾问尤金·肯尼迪 (Eugene Kennedy) 说：

Primarily, Understanding the Professional Programmer is intended as an exercise in self-examination for the professional programmer. A very wise counselor, Eugene Kennedy, says:

有些人出于恐惧和不想被发现缺乏的需要而相当严厉地检查自己。大多数传教士和筹款人都知道，唤起人们的内疚感并不难。. . . 提出不必要的内疚会给自我检查带来坏名声，这可能是许多人回避或推迟它的原因，因此永远不会意识到它的价值。

Some persons examine themselves rather harshly out of motives that are a mixture of fearfulness and a need not to be found wanting. It is not difficult to raise guilt feelings in people, as most preachers and fund-raisers know. . . . Raising unnecessary guilt gives self examination a bad name and may be the reason that many people shun it or postpone it and, therefore, never realize its values.

我无意引起专业程序员的负罪感。恰恰相反; 我相信程序员作为主要关注兜售硬件和软件的商业媒体的传统和方便的目标而遭受了太多的痛苦。对于最不周到的记者来说，程序员只是获得更大的硬件/软件销售和广告收入的障碍。

It's not my intention to raise guilt feelings among professional programmers. Quite the contrary; I believe programmers have suffered too much from being the conventional and convenient target of a trade press primarily concerned with peddling hardware and software. To the least thoughtful journalists, programmers are merely an impediment to ever greater hardware/software sales and advertising revenues.

肯尼迪很好地描述了我的观点，他接着说：

My point of view here is well described by Kennedy when he goes on to say:

还有另一种看待我们自己的方式；它更像是专业人士——无论是医生还是运动员——接受特定学科的需要，以解放自我，稳步提高表现。换句话说，这是健康的专业人士所做的一部分，不是惩罚而是改善自己。

There is another way to look at ourselves; it is more the way a professional does it—whether a doctor or an athlete—accepting the need for a particular discipline in view of freeing the self for a steadily improving performance. It is part, in other words, of what healthy professionals do, not to punish but to improve themselves.

如果您想成为这个意义上的专业程序员，那么 《了解专业程序员》 就是专门为您编写的。

If you'd like to be a professional programmer in this sense, then Understanding the Professional Programmer is written especially for you.

致谢

Acknowledgments

我要感谢以下同事，他们的通信被本书引用：David Coan、Jo Edkins、Bob Finkenaur、David Flint、DA Martin 和 Barbara Walker。我还要感谢许多其他记者，他们启发了我，但无法直接确定他们的身份。

I wish to thank the following colleagues whose correspondence has been quoted in this book: David Coan, Jo Edkins, Bob Finkenaur, David Flint, D. A. Martin, and Barbara Walker. I also wish to thank the many other correspondents who inspired me but who could not be directly identified.

我特别感谢那些阅读了我考虑收录的许多文章并对其进行排名的同事。他们的意见和建议再次证明了评论对创意工作的重要性。我的“专家小组”由 Jim Fleming、Mason C. Gibson、Tim Gill、Bill Hetzel、Roger House、Bob Marcus 和 Paul Mellick 组成。没有他们我做不到。

I am especially grateful to those colleagues who read and ranked the many essays I considered for inclusion. Their comments and suggestions demonstrate once again how important reviews are to creative work. My "panel of experts" consisted of Jim Fleming, Mason C. Gibson, Tim Gill, Bill Hetzel, Roger House, Bob Marcus, and Paul Mellick. I couldn't have done it without them.

如果没有我当地的专家小组 Dani 和 Judy，我也无法做到这一点，他们从不害怕让我回到现实。

Nor could I have done it without my local panel of experts, Dani and Judy, who are never afraid to bring me back down to earth.

第一章 哪些问题对专业人士来说很重要？

Chapter I. What Questions Are Important to the Professional?

成为一名程序员需要多长时间？

How Long Does It Take to Make a Programmer?

有些主题每个人都是专家。教学就是一个很好的例子。任何智商超过 80 且了解某学科或其他学科的人都应该能够教书。至少那是美国大学系统建立的理论。在美国，只要有人建议 世界上任何人都可以向他展示任何可以改善他的课堂教学的东西，一位教授就会受到侮辱、愤怒，并且可能会采取法律行动。

There are some subjects on which everyone is an expert. Teaching is a good example. Anyone with an IQ over 80 and knowledge of some subject or other is supposed to be able to teach. At least that's the theory on which the American university system is founded. In the United States, a professor is insulted, outraged, and likely to start legal action at the mere suggestion anybody in the world could show him anything to improve his classroom teaching.

同样在美国，每个人都是等候台方面的专家。一个欧洲服务员可能要经过十年或二十年的培训，才能获准在一流餐厅服务。在美国，您通过回答广告并将毛巾放在前臂上来成为服务员。

Also in the United States, everyone is an expert on the subject of waiting tables. A European waiter may train for ten or twenty years before being allowed to serve in a first-class restaurant. In America, you become a waiter by answering an advertisement and putting a towel over your forearm.

编程是另一个不乏专家的学科。六周的“培训”通常被认为比将一个人提升到“专家”水平所必需的要多，因为有人不需要学习任何新东西，但有资格设计在线生命支持系统。当您看到“有经验的”程序员的广告时，通常意味着大约 一年 或两年的经验。事实上，任何拥有 15 年编程经验的人都被认为是某种智力侏儒。如果她有一点点智慧，她会在十四年前学会所有关于编程的知识。然后她会变得非常无聊，她会在管理或销售中寻找一席之地。

Programming is another subject with no shortage of experts. Six weeks of "training" is typically considered more than necessary to elevate one to the "expert" level, as someone above the need for learning anything new, yet qualified to design online life-support systems. When you see an advertisement for "experienced" programmers, it often means about one year or perhaps two years of experience. Indeed, anyone with fifteen years in programming is considered some sort of mental midget. If she had the least bit of intelligence, she would have learned all there was to know about programming fourteen years ago. Then she would have become so bored she would have sought a place in management or sales.

然而，在我们过分嘲笑持有这种观点的人之前，我们应该承认，15 年的经验本身不需要教给您 任何 有关编程的知识。我知道有十五年“经验”的美国服务员不知道如何在用餐者面前的桌子上摆盘子。我认识有十五年“经验”的美国大学教授，他们无法教狗如何摇尾巴。同样，我认识一些拥有 15 年“经验”的美国程序员，他们仍然在更新多道程序系统中的直接访问主文件之前对事务文件进行排序。

Yet before we go too far in ridiculing those who hold this view, we ought to acknowledge that fifteen years of experience, in and of itself, need not teach you anything about programming. I know American waiters who have fifteen years of "experience" and don't know how to set a plate on the table in front of the diner. And I know American college professors with fifteen years of "experience" who couldn't teach a dog how to wag its tail. Similarly, I know some American programmers with fifteen years of "experience" who still sort the transaction file before updating the direct-access master file in a multiprogrammed system.

以防前面的例子太微妙，让我列出一些我在一天中发现的项目，阅读“有经验”的程序员的程序：

Just in case the previous example is too subtle, let me list a few items I found in one day, reading the programs of "experienced" programmers:

1.使用整数除法时不知道余数是什么的人！

1. Someone who didn't know what a remainder was when using integer division!

2. 有人使用五个 IF 语句和五个赋值语句将范围为 0-5 的变量转换为范围为 1-6 的变量（对于 FORTRAN 下标）！

2. Someone who converted a variable with range 0-5 to a variable with range 1-6 (for FORTRAN subscripting) using five IF statements and five assignment statements!

3. 不在 COBOL 程序中使用 ELSE 子句的人，因为“它们并不总是有效”。

3. Someone who didn't use ELSE clauses in COBOL programs because "they don't always work."

4. 从不在 PL/I 中使用 VARYING 字符串的人，因为“它们效率不高”。

4. Someone who never uses VARYING strings in PL/I because "they aren't efficient."

5. 根本不使用子程序的人，因为“它们太复杂了”。

5. Someone who doesn't use subroutines at all because "they're too complicated."

该名单可以无限期地延长。关键不仅在于存在作为专业程序员的人——让我们所有人感到羞耻的人——还在于 存在无法分辨他们是在与他们中的一个人还是在与我们中的一个人交谈的经理人。

The list could be extended indefinitely. The point is not merely the existence of people out there passing as professional programmers—people who shame us all—but the existence of managers who have no way of telling if they're talking to one of them or one of us.

这很像美国服务员的情况。在美国，很少有人吃过专业服务员的饭菜，因此他们无法在看到一个时就知道是什么。或者，更确切地说，他们无法知道他们典型的服务员是不专业的。

It's very much like the situation with waiters in the United States. Few people in the United States have ever been served a meal by a professional waiter, so they have no way of knowing one when they see one. Or, rather, they have no way of knowing their typical waiter is subprofessional.

同样，除非您自己是称职的程序员，否则衡量程序员工作质量的方法也很少。世界上的许多设施 从未 有过一位真正称职的程序员，他待了足够长的时间来建立一套专业期望。每个装置都陷入了自己的平庸标准。这些标准因地而异，甚至在同一装置内的组与组之间也有很大差异。

Similarly, there are very few ways of measuring the quality of a programmer's work unless you are a competent programmer yourself. Many installations in the world have never had a really competent programmer who stayed around long enough to establish a set of professional expectations. Each installation drifts into its own standard of mediocrity. These standards differ quite widely from place to place and even from group to group within a single installation.

当我去一个新的组织开始咨询时，我要求经理们提前给我一些 典型的代码。 通常他们不相信我真的想看代码，我必须坚持几次才能得到任何东西。通过一小段代码示例，我通常能够非常准确地了解商店的环境。有时我可以做出非常具体的预测，以至于管理层认为我一直在秘密地与一些员工交谈。

When I go to a new organization to begin consulting, I ask the managers to give me, in advance, some typical code. Usually they cannot believe I really want to see code, and I must insist several times before getting anything. From a small sample of code I am usually able to form a pretty accurate picture of the environment in the shop. Sometimes I can make marvelously specific predictions, so striking the management thinks I've secretly been talking to some of the employees.

经理们自己 从不 看代码。代码之于编程经理就像脏盘子之于领班。一旦你从垃圾堆毕业，你就 再也不会 碰垃圾了——即使是开玩笑。

The managers themselves never look at code. Code is to programming managers what dirty dishes are to a headwaiter. Once you have graduated from the garbage heap, you never touch the garbage again—even in jest.

有一次，在大学期间，我们学生建议采用教授与学生同考的硕士考试程序，以建立合格标准。超过三分之二的教授都吓得退缩了。经受了二十年的科举之辱，他们不打算再回到一个 低贱 的位置。

Once, while at college, we students suggested a Master's examination procedure in which the professors take the same examination as the students, to establish qualifying standards. More than two-thirds of the professors recoiled in genuine horror. After subjecting themselves to the humiliation of examinations for twenty years, they were not about to return to a position even suggesting their former lowly status.

我们业务中的这种态度表明，编写代码在人类价值等级中占有一席之地，高于盗墓，低于管理。按照这种思维方式，编写代码不可能是一项单独的技能、才能或职业，并有自己的排名——无法与盗墓和管理在同一尺度上进行衡量。只要这种态度在数据处理环境中盛行，就会有 6 周的编程专家和经理不听他们高薪 15 年的程序员的意见。

This attitude in our business suggests writing code has a place in the hierarchy of human worth somewhere above grave robbing and beneath managing. To this way of thinking, it's not possible writing code could be a separate skill, or talent, or profession, with a ranking all its own—not measurable on the same scale with grave robbing and managing. As long as this attitude prevails in a data-processing environment, there will be six-week programming experts and managers who don't listen to their highly paid fifteen-year programmers.

教学、服务员和编程有什么共同点？是什么让每个人都相信他们可以像专业人士一样做这些事情？首先，这项工作 似乎是 可以理解的，因为许多普通人都经历过。每个人都教过别人 一些东西。 每个人都端过一个盘子到桌上或帮忙收拾脏盘子。但并不是每个人都对活脑进行过手术，或者在陪审团面前辩论过案件。

What do teaching, waiting tables, and programming have in common? What makes everyone believe they can do these things as well as a professional? First, the work seems understandable, because it has been experienced by many ordinary people. Everyone has taught somebody something. Everybody has carried a platter to the table or helped clear away the dirty dishes. But not everybody has done surgery on a living brain, or argued a case before a jury.

但是编程呢？当然，不是每个人都写过程序，是吗？也许不是每个人，但几乎每个经理、会计师、工程师或其他受过大学教育的专业人士都有。编程课程在大学里风靡一时，成为许多专业课程的必修课。例如，几十年来，IBM 过去常常举办高管研讨会，其中包括一些“编程经验”。

But what of programming? Surely, not everyone has written a program, have they? Not everyone, perhaps, but just about every manager, accountant, engineer, or other university-educated professional has. Programming courses have become all the rage in universities and are required in many professional curricula. For decades, for example, IBM used to give executive seminars including some "programming experience."

我不知道 IBM 高管研讨会目前的内容，但多年来研讨会都将著名的“曼哈顿问题”作为唯一的编程练习。对于那些在文化上被剥夺的人，我将重复美国最流行的 DP 入门教科书中印制的曼哈顿问题：

I don't know the present content of IBM's executive seminars, but for many years the seminars included the famous "Manhattan Problem" as the one and only programming exercise. For those of you who are culturally deprived, I'll repeat the Manhattan problem as printed in the most popular introductory DP textbook in the United States:

问题是要确定在 1627 年为曼哈顿岛支付的 24 美元，如果以 4.5% 的年利率存入储蓄账户，今天的价值是多少。

The problem is to determine how much the $24 supposedly paid for Manhattan island in 1627 would be worth today if it had been placed in a savings account at 4.5 percent annual interest.

（如果 4.5% 看起来有点低，那是因为这个问题至少从 1956 年就开始使用，并且被一代又一代的教科书作者抄袭。）

(If 4.5 percent seems a bit low, that's because the problem has been used since 1956 at least and has been copied by one generation of textbook writers after another.)

这个问题的“解决方案”消除了一些不必要的问题，是以下 FORTRAN 循环：

The "solution" to this problem, eliminating some inessentials, is the following FORTRAN loop:

我 = 1627

I = 1627

普林斯 = 24.00

PRINC = 24.00

2 普林斯 = 普林斯*1.045

2 PRINC =PRINC*1.045

我=我+1

I=I+1

IF(I-IYEAR)2,1,1

IF(I-IYEAR)2,1,1

1 写 (3,601) 王子

1 WRITE(3,601) PRINC

这个“解决方案”已经教给了至少三四百万学生，从高管到大学新生。对于许多人来说，这是他们曾经“编写”过的唯一一个程序，但它使他们有资格判断操作系统、劳动力分配、零件需求计划模拟器、在线过程控制器或仅仅是关于任何你能说出的名字。当然，在行政课程中，学生们会得到一名专业助理，“在细节方面提供帮助”。

This "solution" has been taught to at least 3 or 4 million students, from executives to college freshmen. For many, it is the one and only program they have ever "written," but it qualifies them to judge the difficulty of programming an operating system, a labor distribution, a parts requirement plan simulator, an on-line process controller, or just about anything you can name. And, of course, in the executive courses, the students are given a professional assistant, "to help with the details."

实际上，曼哈顿问题 可能 是向高管们传授他们需要了解的关于编程专业的最重要课程的绝佳工具。假设他们被允许编写这个小宝石并接受它作为问题的“解决方案”。然后，您向他们展示编写所需的时间以及执行所需的时间，并询问他们认为这些数字有多“好”。

Actually, the Manhattan problem could be an excellent vehicle for teaching executives the most important lesson they need to know about the programming profession. Suppose they are allowed to compose this little gem and to accept it as the "solution" to the problem. You then show them how much time it took to write, and how much time it took to execute, and ask them how "good" they think those figures are.

一旦他们做出承诺，您就可以向他们展示可以从以下程序中获得相同的结果：

Once they have committed themselves, you show them the same result could be obtained from a program reading:

PRINC = 24.00*(1.045**(IYEAR-1627))

PRINC = 24.00*(1.045**(IYEAR-1627))

写 (3,601) 王子

WRITE (3,601) PRINC

您比较编程时间和执行时间。根据具体情况，您可能会发现该程序只需要 1/5 的工作量和 1/100 的执行时间。然后你会问，“如果可以用成本相差 5 倍或 100 倍的两种方式来编程可以想象的最微不足道的问题，那么专业和业余的操作系统编程工作之间必须有什么区别？”

You compare programming time and execution time. Depending on circumstances, you might find the program takes 1/5 the effort and 1/100 the execution time. Then you ask, "It the most trivial problem imaginable can be programmed in two ways differing in cost by factors of 5 or 100, what must the difference be between a professional and an amateur job of programming an operating system?"

有了这样的课程，编程素养或欣赏课程可能会利大于弊。就目前而言，这些课程的主要教训（尽管从未明确说明）是：“编程并不难。经过几周的练习，我什至可以成为一名专家级程序员。”

With such a lesson, a programming literacy or appreciation course might be made to do more good than harm. As it now stands, the principal lesson of these courses, although never explicitly stated, is this: "Programming isn't so hard. With a few weeks of practice, even I could become an expert programmer."

不知何故，如果要将编程视为一种职业，就必须对公众以及程序员本身进行教育。他们必须意识到即使十五年也不足以完成一个人的编程知识——除非一个人的思想非常封闭。

Somehow, if programming is ever to be treated as a profession, the public—and the programmers themselves—will have to be educated. They must realize even fifteen years will not suffice to complete one's knowledge of programming—unless one has a very closed mind.

残疾人能成为程序员吗？

Can the Handicapped Succeed as Programmers?

每当编程人才市场变成卖方市场时，买方就会试图扩大他们的供应来源。面对刚毕业的要求高于管理级别的见习工资的刚毕业的、灰头土脸的老经理，他们开始面试女性。盎格鲁-撒克逊、新教徒的经理们求助于那些皮肤不是粉红色斑点的人，他们的教会甚至连发音都不太好。在足球场上成功攀登前三级的稳健经理们开始问我“雇用残疾人”是否“安全”。

Whenever the market for programming talent becomes a seller's market, buyers attempt to broaden their source of supply. Hardened, grizzly old managers, when confronted by recent graduates demanding trainee salaries above the managerial scale, begin to interview women. Anglo-Saxon, Protestant managers turn to people whose skin isn't splotchy pink and whose church isn't even pronounceable. And robust managers who climbed the first three rungs of success on the football field start asking me whether it's "safe" to "hire the handicapped."

当特权阶层表现出对被剥夺阶层的无知时，他们很容易被他们激怒。弱势群体”是我不忍在这种情况下使用的特权的委婉说法。也很容易拿起明显被剥夺的旗帜，知道没有人敢质疑你的正义。另一方面，如果你说“以严格的商业术语而非“商业社会的社会责任”来雇用残疾人，你将自己暴露在粗鲁的商业主义和缺乏感情的指责之中。尽管如此，我还是想尝试理性地看待这个问题残障程序员。如果这种待遇冒犯了你，你可能会成为残障人士或至少是你标记为“残障人士”的人的糟糕雇主。

It's easy to be annoyed with the privileged classes when they display ignorance of the deprived classes. Underprivileged" is a euphemism of the privileged which I can't bear to use in this context. It's also easy to pick up the banner of the obviously deprived, knowing nobody dares question your righteousness. On the other hand, if you speak of "hiring the handicapped" in strictly business terms, rather than in terms of the "social responsibility of the business community," you expose yourself to accusations of crass commercialism and lack of feeling. Nevertheless, I would like to attempt a rational approach to the issue of handicapped programmers. If this type of treatment offends you, you will probably make a poor employer of handicapped persons or at least of persons you label "handicapped."

残障人士 最终是一个标签——一种精神状态而不是一种存在状态。这个观点大家可能比较陌生，那我举几个残疾人在编程之外的一个领域的表现的例子，那就是体育。

Handicapped is, in the end, a label—a state of mind rather than a state of being. This point of view may be unfamiliar, so let me give a few examples of the performance of handicapped people in a field outside of programming, namely, sports.

一天晚上，我们在电视上观看了捷克手枪冠军在第二次世界大战中失去右臂的故事，我们都同意这对右撇子射手来说是一种障碍。但这人对手枪比赛的认同，比他的手臂还要深一些，所以他自学了用左臂射击。并继续赢得金牌！

One night we watched the televised story of a Czech pistol champion who lost his right arm in World War II, which we'd all agree is a handicap to a right-handed shooter. But this man's identification with pistol competition ran a bit deeper than his arm, so he taught himself to shoot with his left arm. And proceeded to win a gold medal!

另一部电视专题片讲述了美国短跑运动员威尔玛鲁道夫的故事。当她还小的时候，她病得很重，据说她永远无法走路。我不记得她最终获得了多少奥运金牌，但比你我多了好几枚，而且从来没有人告诉 我 我永远不能走路。

Another television feature told the story of Wilma Rudolph, the American sprinter. When she was small, she was so sickly it was declared she would never walk. I don't remember how many Olympic gold medals she ultimately won, but it was several more than you or I have won, and nobody ever told me I'd never be able to walk.

当然，威尔玛·鲁道夫 (Wilma Rudolph) 的故事可能只是讲述了美国医学的现状，这位前英里纪录保持者的表现强化了这一观点，他小时候患有小儿麻痹症，还被告知他永远不会走路。（另一方面，美式橄榄球最近出现了几位先天性足部畸形、脚趾截肢，并且在一个案例中安装了假腿的顶级踢球专家；所以也许美国医学毕竟不是那么糟糕。）

Of course, Wilma Rudolph's story may simply say something about the state of American medicine, an idea that's reinforced by the performance of the former record holder in the mile, who had polio as a child and was also told he'd never walk. (On the other hand, American football has recently been graced by several top kicking specialists who had congenitally deformed feet, amputated toes, and in one case an artificial leg; so perhaps American medicine isn't so bad after all.)

实际上，我怀疑这些故事与医学有任何关系，但它们确实与雇用残疾人有很大关系。从这些故事和其他故事中，以及通过观察盲人、聋人、截瘫、四肢瘫痪和各种残疾程序员的表现，我得出结论，成功在于头脑，而不是眼睛、耳朵、手臂或腿。当残障人士决定向世界证明她与其他人没有什么不同时，她往往会过度补偿并成为冠军，无论是编程还是跑步。

Actually, I doubt any of these stories have anything to do with medicine, but they do have a lot to do with hiring the handicapped. From these and other stories, and from watching the performance of blind, deaf, paraplegic, quadriplegic, and various handicapped programmers, I've concluded success is in the mind, not in the eyes, ears, arms, or legs. When the handicapped person decides to prove to the world she's no different from other people, she often overcompensates and becomes a champion, in programming as easily as in running.

对我来说，这种克服看似无法克服的障碍的能力讲述了一个重要的故事。要成为一名冠军踢球者，每条腿都需要大约一百份动力。毕竟，腿是可以训练的，但是我们对训练动机了解多少呢？我们知道如果我们截掉几个脚趾，我们可能会产生强烈的踢球动机，但我们愿意走这样的极端吗？你愿意为了成为更好的程序员而去掉你的一部分大脑吗？如果是这样，您可能已经拥有足够的动力，因此可以跳过手术。

To me, this ability to surmount a seemingly insurmountable handicap tells an important story. To be a champion kicker requires about one hundred parts motivation to every one part leg. The leg, after all, can be trained, but what do we know about training motivation? We know if we amputate a few toes, we might produce a strongly motivated kicker, but are we willing to go to such an extreme? Are you willing to remove part of your brain just to become a better programmer? If so, you're probably blessed with sufficient motivation already, so you can skip the surgery.

想想你认识的程序员。他们中有多少人似乎拥有所有的福气、所有的脑力和体力的原材料，但似乎从未超越平庸？你会怎么做才能让他们意识到他们是多么幸福？对于我们大多数人来说，我们必须先失去我们的祝福，然后才能计算它们。

Think about the programmers you know. How many of them seem to have all the blessings, all the raw materials of brain and brawn, yet never seem to rise above mediocrity? What would you do to make them realize how blessed they are? For most of us, we have to lose our blessings before we can count them.

就个人而言，我总是认为我的手是理所当然的，直到关节炎甚至使电子打字变得痛苦。我曾经对此抱怨很多——这对一个作家来说是多么可怕的障碍——直到我遇到了一个没有 手的程序员 。我什至不必 尝试 用绑在头上的手写笔打字。他启发我写了一个关于一个没有手的女孩的故事， 上帝之手。）

Personally, I always took my hands for granted until arthritis made even electric typing painful. I used to complain a lot about it—what a terrific handicap for a writer—until I met a programmer who didn't have hands. I didn't even have to try typing with a stylus strapped to my head. He inspired me to write a story about a girl without hands, The Hands of God.)

在编程中，有一种特殊的障碍似乎无法克服，无论一个人的积极性如何。自然地，我说的是缺乏完成程序员工作所必需的智力。当然，我并不是说低智商是一种心理状态——我是吗？是的，我承认世界上有些人不具备成为计算机程序员的智慧，哪怕只是因为他们不具备了解什么是计算机或程序员的智慧。但我认为这样的人并不像大多数读者想象的那么多。

In programming, there's a particular kind of handicap seemingly impossible to overcome, no matter how motivated one might be. I'm speaking, naturally, of the lack of intelligence necessary to do the programmer's job. Certainly, I'm not saying low intelligence is a state of mind—or am I? Yes, I'll freely admit there are some people in the world who haven't the intelligence to be computer programmers, if only because they haven't the intelligence to understand what a computer or a programmer is. But I don't think such people are nearly as large a population as most readers might imagine.

为计算机编程确实需要智能。事实上，它需要如此多的智慧，以至于没有人真正做得很好。当然，有些程序员比其他程序员更好，但我们都像长大的婴儿一样颠簸和崩溃。为什么？因为计算机编程是 迄今为止 人类尝试过的最艰巨的智力任务。曾经。

Programming a computer does require intelligence. Indeed, it requires so much intelligence that nobody really does it very well. Sure, some programmers are better than others, but we all bump and crash around like overgrown infants. Why? Because programming computers is by far the hardest intellectual task human beings have ever tried to do. Ever.

根据您的宗教信仰，您可能认为人类是

Depending on your religious persuasion, you may believe human beings were

(1) 设计用来从一个肢体摆动到另一个肢体吃香蕉；

(1) designed to swing from limb to limb eating bananas;

(2) 设计住在伊甸园吃苹果；或者

(2) designed to live in the Garden of Eden eating apples; or

(3) 根本不是为任何东西而设计的。

(3) not designed for anything at all.

据我所知，没有人的宗教认为人类是被设计来编写正确、紧凑、高效、可维护且廉价的计算机程序的。因此，如果有人缺少几条肢体，或者缺少一两种感觉，那么他们在编程能力上与我们其他人并没有明显的不同。残疾人可能需要一件特殊的设备，这可能不是很昂贵，但我们都用我们认为有助于我们表现的特殊魔法标记来装饰我们的办公室。了解动机的狡猾经理会把这些为残障人士所做的小投资视为花得值，因为残障程序员的表现总是优于那些本应完全掌握其能力的程序员。

Nobody's religion, to my knowledge, says human beings were designed to write correct, compact, efficient, maintainable, and cheap computer programs. Therefore, if someone is missing a few limbs, or a sense or two, they're really not noticeably different from the rest of us in programming ability. The handicapped may need a special piece of apparatus, which is probably not very expensive, but we all decorate our offices with special magical tokens we feel help our performance. The crafty manager who understands motivation will regard these little investments for the handicapped as money well spent, for handicapped programmers always outperform those programmers who are supposed to have full command of their faculties.

不过，一些经理担心残疾人会对办公室的其他员工产生影响。根据我所听到或观察到的一切，主要的影响是让人们意识到他们对所得到的东西所做的是多么微不足道。诚然，这样的认识通常会导致编程工作组织的变化，但是不能处理这种变化的管理者不应该进行管理。

Some managers, though, worry about the effect a handicapped person will have on other workers in the office. According to everything I've heard or observed, the major effect is to make people realize how little they're doing with what they've been given. True, such a realization often leads to changes in the organization of programming work, but a manager who can't handle such changes ought not to be managing.

说到编程，我们都是有缺陷的，尽管我们可能不知道。因为我们通常会使用我们有限潜能中如此微小的一部分，所以当我们要向世界证明一些事情时，我们常常会超越自己。 因此，拥有公认和接受的差点是一种优势。 如果我们能够让我们普遍的 智力 障碍得到承认和接受，也许编程可以成为一项奥运项目。

When it comes to programming, we're all handicapped, though we may not know it. Because we ordinarily use such a minuscule part of our limited potential, we often outperform ourselves when we have something to prove to the world. Therefore, it's an advantage to have a recognized and accepted handicap. If we could only get our universal mental handicap recognized and accepted, perhaps programming could become an Olympic event.

专业程序员的范例是什么？

What Are the Paradigms for a Professional Programmer?

1978 年 ACM 图灵奖颁发给了斯坦福大学的 Robert W. Floyd。他的获奖感言题为“编程的范式”，发表在 1979 年 8 月的 ACM 通讯杂志上。 我鼓励每一位读者——每一位与编程相关的人——阅读弗洛伊德的演讲。我也想在另一个方向上推进他的一些想法。

The 1978 ACM Turing Award was presented to Robert W. Floyd of Stanford University. His acceptance speech, entitled "The Paradigms of Programming," was published in the August 1979 issue of Communications of the ACM. I encourage every reader—everyone connected with programming—to read Floyd's speech. I would also like to advance some of his ideas in another direction.

范式是一种模式——在这种情况下是一种思维模式。弗洛伊德详细阐述了一些范例，包括

A paradigm is a pattern—in this case a pattern of thought. Floyd elaborates on a number of paradigms, including

结构化编程

Structured programming

动态规划

Dynamic programming

递归协程

Recursive coroutines

基于规则的系统

Rule-based systems

非确定性系统

Nondeterministic systems

编程语言

Programming languages

他谈到“计算机编程的最新技术”中的混乱局面，并说，

He speaks of the mess in "the state of the art in computer programming" and says,

我们最大的希望是提高我们自己的能力。我相信我们必须改进编程的一般实践的最佳机会是关注我们的范例。

Our best hope is to improve our own capabilities. I believe the best chance we have to improve the general practice of programming is to attend to our paradigms.

弗洛伊德本人和其他任何计算机人一样，在发明新范式、改进现有范式以及向后代程序员清楚地传达范式方面所做的工作。我相信他因这项工作当之无愧地获得图灵奖。我特别高兴他借此机会揭示了他思想的一些内在运作——元范式，如果你愿意的话，他创造了如此丰富的知识流露。

Floyd himself has done as much as any other computer person to invent new paradigms, refine existing paradigms, and communicate paradigms clearly to succeeding generations of programmers. I believe he richly deserves the Turing Award for this work. I'm especially pleased he's taken the occasion of the award to reveal something of the inner workings of his mind—the meta-paradigms, if you will, by which he's created such a bountiful intellectual outpouring.

我从文章中提取的元范式包括以下内容：

The meta-paradigms I've extracted from the essay include the following:

1. 类比的使用，例如将计算机进程与人类组织中的进程相关联。

1. Use of analogy, as in relating computer processes to processes in human organizations.

2.追溯和追溯自己解决难题的思路，而不是满足于解决问题本身。

2. Tracing and retracing his own thought processes in solving difficult problems, rather than merely resting content with the solution itself.

3. 从具体案例归纳出一般规则，并在其他具体案例中检验这些一般规则。

3. Induction from specific cases to general rules, and testing these general rules on other specific cases.

4.看别人的程序。

4. Reading other people's programs.

5. 故意扩大他的知识分子圈子，包括那些坚持“外星人惯例”的人，因此阅读节目成为一种更有成效的职业。

5. Deliberately widening his circle of intellectual associates to include those who adhere to "alien conventions," so reading programs becomes a more fruitful occupation.

6. 试图与（教导）他人交流范式，作为澄清自己思想的一种方式。

6. Attempting to communicate with (teach) others about paradigms, as a way of clarifying his own thought.

7.积极寻求了解别人以前做过什么，而不是重新发明一切。

7. Actively seeking to know what others have done before, rather then reinventing everything.

8. 以其他人所做的为出发点，提出“我怎么能发明这个？”这个问题

8. Using what others have done as a starting point for the question "How could I have invented this?''

正如弗洛伊德自己总结的那样：

As Floyd himself summarizes:

我对认真的程序员的信息是：花一部分工作时间检查和完善自己的方法。尽管程序员总是在努力满足未来或过去的最后期限，方法论抽象是一项明智的长期投资。

My message to the serious programmer is: spend a part of your working day examining and refining your own methods. Even though programmers are always struggling to meet some future or past deadline, methodological abstraction is a wise long term investment.

如果你是一个认真的程序员，你应该听从弗洛伊德的建议。您甚至可能想要扩展 范式 或 方法论抽象的隐式定义。 本质上，Floyd 的所有示例都涉及程序员从他或她收到明确定义的问题时所做的事情。知道如何处理定义明确的问题是很重要的，但这还不够。为什么不？因为工作的专业程序员花更多的时间在定义不明确的问题上，就像什么时候

If you are a serious programmer, you should heed Floyd's advice. You may even want to extend the implicit definition of paradigm or methodological abstraction. Essentially, all Floyd's examples concern what a programmer does from the time he or she receives a well-defined problem. It is essential to know what to do with well-defined problems, but it's not enough. Why not? Because the working professional programmer spends much more time on ill-defined problems, as when

1.有一个用户不知道是什么问题。

1. There is a user who doesn't know what the problem is.

2.有一个用户知道是什么问题，但问题真的是别的。

2. There is a user who knows what the problem is, but the problem is really something else.

3.有一个用户知道问题是什么，但是程序员不理解，不相信，不听用户的，

3. There is a user who knows what the problem is, but the programmer doesn't understand, or believe, or listen to the user,

4. 用户不止一个，且每个用户都存在以上三种情况中的一种或多种。

4. There is more than one user, and each is in one or more of the above three situations.

5. 用户群体随时间变化。

5. The user population changes with time.

6. 问题随时间变化。

6. The problem changes with time.

7. 每个人都在尖叫，失去理智。

7. Everyone is screaming and losing presence of mind.

在定义不明确的情况下，计算机程序员倾向于接管定义工作并定义他们想要 解决 的问题。弗洛伊德引用了斯坦福大学研究生办公室的一幅涂鸦：

In ill-defined situations, computer programmers tend to take over the definition job and define a problem they'd like to solve. Floyd quotes a graffito from a Stanford University graduate student office:

“我宁愿写程序帮我写程序，也不愿意写程序。”

"I would rather write programs to help me write programs than write programs."

在这里，我们看到了与疾病接壤的健康活动或方法论抽象——一种避免我们不想处理的问题的方法。

Here we see the healthful activity or methodological abstraction bordering on a disease—a way of avoiding problems on which we don't want to work.

专业程序员的方法论词汇中包含丰富的此类问题回避范例。我们将它们强加给任何粗心的客户，他们胆敢带着定义不明确或无趣的问题进入我们神圣的编程办公室。很快有一天，我肯定会听到一个程序员说：“一旦我们制定出正确的范式，我们就会有那个程序，就像弗洛伊德教授教我们做的那样。与此同时，不要用你的问题来打扰 我们 。 “

The professional programmer's methodological vocabulary is rich in such problem-avoidance paradigms. We foist them on any unwary customer with the gall to enter our sacred programming office with an ill-defined or uninteresting problem. Someday soon I'm sure to hear a programmer say, "We'll have that program as soon as we work out the proper paradigm, as Professor Floyd taught us to do. In the meantime, don't bother us with your problems."

在我看来——我怀疑 Floyd 会不同意——解决定义明确的问题的范例只是程序员责任的一部分。至少同样重要的是关于编程工作本身性质的更深入、更模糊的范例。

In my opinion—and I doubt that Floyd would disagree—the paradigms for solving well-defined problems are only part of the programmer's responsibility. At least as important are the deeper, fuzzier paradigms about the nature of programming work itself.

对我来说，所有范例中最全球化的是：

For me, the most global of all paradigms is this:

专业的程序员是一个人

The professional programmer is a person

谁为其他人解决问题——不惜一切代价。

who solves problems for other people—whatever that takes.

专业程序员应该使用的一些方法是：

Some of the methods the professional programmer should be working on are these:

1. 对于一个我认为根本不应该解决的明确定义的问题，我应该怎么办？

1. What should I do about a program for a well-defined problem I don't believe should be solved at all?

2. 如何确定是否应该使用计算机？

2. How do I determine whether a computer should be used at all?

3. 如何设计计算机程序必须运行的人机整体环境？

3. How do I design the overall environment of people and machines in which the computer programs will have to operate?

4. 我如何设计计算机程序，才不会对其运行的整体环境产生意想不到的影响？

4. How do I design the computer programs so they don't have unintended effects on the overall environment in which they operate?

5. 我如何与那些问题没有明确定义、不像我对计算机了解得那么多、对许多其他事情比我了解更多、动机与我不同的人有效地工作？

5. How do I work effectively with people whose problems are not well defined, who don't understand as much about computers as I do, who understand more about many other things than I do, and whose motivations are different from mine?

6. 作为专业程序员，我如何改变无法有效工作的情况？

6. How do I change situations in which I cannot work effectively as a professional programmer?

7. 我如何创建在充满不确定性的未来仍然是好的解决方案的程序——未来问题会改变，人们会改变，而我不会在其中？

7. How do I create programs which will continue to be good solutions in a future full of uncertainty—a future in which problems change, people change, and in which I won't be around?

8. 我如何确定在任何特定时刻最好采用哪种方法级别？

8. How do I determine which methodological level is the best to be working on at any particular moment?

9. 我如何处理自己个性和解决问题方法的这些方面，这些方面是如此个人化，我什至看不到它们，尽管它们可能是我作为程序员效率的最重要因素？

9. How do I work on those aspects of my own personality and problem-solving approach so personal I can't even see them, even though they may be the most important factor in my effectiveness as a programmer?

不过，也许这些不是“计算机科学家”关心的问题，他们“宁愿编写程序来帮助编写程序”。如果不是，那么他们关心的是谁？似乎没有大军急于解决 这些 问题——更重要的是认真的程序员应该亲自解决这些问题，作为一项明智的长期投资。

Perhaps, though, these are not the concerns of the "computer scientist," who would "rather write programs to help write programs." If not, then whose concerns are they? There seems to be no great army rushing to work on these problems—all the more reason why the serious programmer should be working on them personally, as a wise long-term investment.

专业人士能在这份工作中快乐吗？

Can a Professional Be Happy in This Job?

我经常遇到一位程序员或分析师，他们对信息系统专业人员的工作的影响深感困扰。我们今天使用计算机所做的事情可能会影响未来许多年成千上万人的生活。此外，这些人中的大多数无法将他们生活中的不适与我们今天所做的联系起来。他们可能不好意思地接受“这就是计算机必须这样做的方式”或更阴险的“事情就是这样”的解释。

I frequently meet a programmer or analyst who is deeply troubled by the implications of the work of a information systems professional. What we do today with computers may affect the lives of thousands or millions of people for many years to come. Moreover, most of those people won't have any way to relate a discomfort in their lives to what we are doing today. They may sheepishly accept the explanation "That's the way the computer must do it" or the even more insidious "That's the way things are."

我认识的一些专业人士，尤其是在没有人检查其他人的工作的商店工作的程序员，通过破坏雇主的信息系统来弥补他们的良心。在许多情况下，很难判断这是有意还是无意。但在某些情况下，这是毫无疑问的。

Some professionals I know, particularly programmers working in shops where nobody inspects anyone else's work, salve their conscience by sabotaging their employer's information systems. In many cases it's difficult to tell whether this is intentional or unintentional. But in some cases there is no doubt.

许多程序员和分析师向我抱怨，说他们的工作对他们没有意义。他们不知道他们编写的程序或规范正在做什么，或者他们知道但不赞成。他们的反应是继续工作，领薪水，并在每一个安全的机会上说雇主的坏话。

Many programmers and analysts have complained to me, saying their work holds no meaning for them. They don't know what is being done with the piece of program or specification they write, or they do know and don't approve. Their response is to stay on the job, draw the salary, and bad-mouth their employer at every safe opportunity.

我认为是时候让我们站出来接受统计了。对于生活将受到我们系统影响的人们，我们负有巨大的责任。如果我们不相信我们的雇主在做什么，或者我们不理解它，那么我们为什么要在那里工作？难道只是为了抽个丰厚的薪水？如果是这样，它使我们成为什么？

I think it's time we stood up to be counted. We have an enormous responsibility to the people whose lives will be affected by our systems. If we don't believe in what our employer is doing, or we don't understand it, then why are we working there? Is it just to draw a fat salary? If so, what does it make us?

多年来，我为正在寻找新工作的程序员和分析师发布了一份原则清单。许多人对这些原则作出回应，称它们不仅有助于找工作，而且有助于考虑是否离开目前的工作或尝试改变某些就业条件。

For some years, I published a list of principles for programmers and analysts who are seeking a new job. Many people have responded to these principles, saying they were helpful not only in seeking a job, but in considering whether to leave a present job or in trying to change some conditions of employment.

有这些问题的人数似乎在增加。为了帮助这些人，我将原则修改为以下一组问题，用于评估新工作或您目前的工作。

The number of people with these problems seems to be on the increase. To help these people I've revised the principles into the following set of questions to be used in evaluating a new job—or your present job.

1. 这个组织的目标与我个人的信念一致吗？

1. Are the goals of this organization consonant with my own personal beliefs?

2. 我所在组织的目标是否明确？我同意他们的看法吗？

2. Are the goals of my part of the organization clear? Do I agree with them?

3. 管理层是否为我的职业发展提供足够的时间和资源？这只是偶然，还是有明确的、持续的承诺提供时间和资源？

3. Does management provide adequate time and resources for my professional development? Is this just by chance, or is there an explicit, continuing commitment to provide both time and resources?

4. 是否通过与同事较量来评价我？是否鼓励我全力合作以帮助他人充分发挥潜能，是否期望其他人对我这样做？

4. Am I evaluated by being pitted against my co-workers? Am I encouraged to cooperate totally to help others achieve their full potential, and are others expected to do so toward me?

5. 我真的明白我应该做什么吗？我明白为什么我应该这样做吗？组织中是否鼓励这种理解？

5. Do I really understand what I am supposed to be doing? Do I understand why I'm supposed to be doing it? Is this kind of understanding encouraged in the organization?

6. 我的工作和其他人的工作是否公开并可供同行评论？我是否应该参与提供和接收此类批评性反馈？

6. Is my work and the work of others open and available for critical comments by peers? Am I expected to participate in giving and receiving such critical feedback?

7、我是否真的能够像同事对我的期望那样，为这个组织和这个项目尽心尽力？

7. Am I really able to devote myself to this organization and this project to the extent my co-workers expect of me?

提出这些问题并认真考虑答案的人不会从事让他们痛苦的工作。

People who ask these questions and consider the answers seriously don't wind up in jobs making them miserable.

提出问题并不总是那么容易。有时你得到一个你不喜欢的答案，你被迫做出决定。做出决定不一定是坏事，但可能很难。我的一位同事决定他不相信他的项目的目标，但因为高薪而接受了这份工作。他为了一份薪水较低的工作而离职，他的家人虽然更穷一些，但对这份工作给他们带来的幸福感到欣喜若狂。

Asking the questions is not always easy. Sometimes you get an answer you don't like, and you are forced to make a decision. Making decisions is not necessarily bad, but it can be hard. One of my colleagues decided he didn't believe in the goals of his project but had taken the job because of the high pay. He left for a lower-paying job, and his family, though a bit poorer, was ecstatic with the happiness it brought them.

好几次，人事经理都被其中一个问题激怒了。那些人很快意识到愤怒是未来麻烦的明确标志。不管怎样，他们给自己找到了新的管理者。

Several times, people's managers were enraged by one of these questions. Those people quickly realized the rage was a sure sign of future trouble. One way or another, they found themselves new managers.

当我在专栏中发表其中一些问题时，我收到了许多深思熟虑的回复。特别引人注目的是乔·埃德金斯 (Jo Edkins) 的一封信。我想与其他人分享这封信，并随着它的展开逐个部分地发表评论。

When I published some of these questions in a column, I received many thoughtful replies. Particularly striking was a letter from Jo Edkins. I'd like to share the letter with others and to comment on it part by part, as it unfolds.

在奉承一番之后，为了给药丸涂上黄油，乔开始说：

After some flattery, to butter the pill, Jo begins:

我完全同意这种态度，但有点愤世嫉俗，我看不出细节是实用的。找出组织或项目目标的想法对于 20 人或更少的组织来说是好的。我属于一家跨国公司，我怀疑是否有人知道它的目标。

I agree completely with the attitude, but being rather cynical, I cannot see the details being practical. The idea of finding out the goals of an organization or project is fine, for organizations of 20 people or less. I belong to a multi-national company, and I doubt if anyone knows its goals.

我同意在某些情况下很难或不可能知道一个组织的目标，但让我们从我们确实知道目标的地方开始。我与烟草公司的员工进行了多次深入讨论。他们可能不知道他们组织的真正目标，但他们对这些公司在世界上所做的事情有一个清晰的认识。这些知识使他们感到不舒服。 这种情况下，他们在组织内部 实在是没有办法让他们安心。

I agree there are cases in which it's difficult or impossible to know an organization's goals, but let's begin where we do know the goals. I've had several deep discussions with employees of tobacco companies. They may not know the true goals of their organizations, but they have a fair idea of what the companies are doing in the world. The knowledge makes them uncomfortable. Under the circumstances, there's really nothing they can do within the organization to ease their minds.

当然，并不是每个为这些公司工作的人都有这种感觉。许多人认为烟草是人类的一大幸事——多年来，我的妻子恰好是其中之一。问题不是谁的价值观是正确的，而是你是否可以在这样一种情况下工作，在这种情况下，你的出色工作会延续你不相信的价值观。如果你离开，你将为自己的健康做出最大可能 的 贡献-存在，你可能会帮助传播你的价值观。最终，如果没有人愿意为一家烟草公司工作，公司将因高昂的劳动力成本而被迫停业。

Of course, not everyone working for these companies feels this way. Many people think tobacco is a great blessing to the human race—for many years, my wife happened to be one of them. The question is not whose values are correct, but whether you can work in a situation where good work on your part will perpetuate values you don't believe in. If you leave, you'll be making the greatest possible contribution to your own well-being, and you just might help propagate your values. Eventually, if nobody is willing to work for a tobacco company, the companies will be forced out of business by the high cost of obtaining labor.

在许多目标不明确的情况下，也许有一个简单的答案：如果目标不明确，也许它并不重要。 但如果你参与的价值体系对你来说 很重要，那么你最好的解决方案可能是加入一家“20 人或更少”的公司。这正是我所做的，我认识的许多程序员也是这样做的，正是出于这个原因。

In many cases where the goals are not clear, perhaps there's a simple answer: If the goals are not clear, perhaps it doesn't matter. But if it does matter to you what value system you're participating in, your best solution may be to join a company with "20 people or less." That's what I did, and so have many programmers I know, for precisely that reason.

如果有足够多的人离开繁琐的大型组织，以至于他们不知道自己的目标，这将增加庞大和模糊的成本惩罚。最终，它可以塑造我们的社会。这并不多，但它可能比为一个你怀疑你表现越好的组织工作要好，世界就会越糟。

If enough people leave large organizations so cumbersome they don't know their own goals, this will add a cost penalty to bigness and fuzziness. In the end, it could shape our society. It's not much, but it's probably better than working for an organization in which you suspect the better you perform, the worse the world will be.

但是，并不是所有的大公司都那么模糊或有如此糟糕的目标。这让我想到乔的下一个反对意见：

But then, not all large companies are quite that fuzzy or have such terrible goals. Which brings me to Jo's next objection:

即使在较低的层次上，管理规则也是“知识的状态与传授知识的愿望成反比，尤其是传授给下级”。这只是生活中的事实。我们都可以建立自己的软件公司，但是，天哪！雇用我们的公司会有好的目标吗？他们会告诉我们这些目标吗？

Even on a lower level, a rule of management goes "state of knowledge is inversely proportional to desire of imparting same, especially to inferiors." This is just a fact of life. We could all set up our own software companies, but, oh dear!, will the companies that hire us have good goals—and will they tell us about them?

我绝对同意。我的朋友吹嘘自己的目标纯洁，但与制造毒气的组织签订了合同，或者恐吓那些不了解电话费并因此迟交的好老太太。

I agree absolutely. Friends of mine brag about their own purity of goals but have contracts with organizations manufacturing poison gas or terrorizing nice old ladies who don't understand their phone bills and therefore pay late.

如果你从事软件行业，甚至是培训行业，你仍然需要考虑你的行为的后果。如果您的考虑范围足够大，您可能会发现一些您不喜欢的东西。基于此我拒绝了许多合同，但我确实在我的课程中接受来自中央情报局和类似组织的人员，即使我不会与雇用他们的组织协商。我的理由是：我在课程中的客户是 人， 而不是组织。

If you are in the software business, or even in the training business, you still have to consider the consequences of your actions. And if you stretch your consideration far enough, you may find something you don't like. I've refused many contracts on this basis, but I do accept people from the CIA and similar organizations in my courses, even though I won't consult with the organizations that hire them. My rationalization: my client in a course is the person, not the organization.

而且，确实，在完成我的一门课程后，我的一定数量的学生立即离开了组织并支付了学费。有趣的是，尽管我总是在这种情况下提出退还学费，但到目前为止，每家公司都认识到，如果不支付不满意的员工，情况会更好——无论该员工作为技术人员有多好。（作为一个并非完全无关紧要的旁白，听到人们说他们“属于”一家公司或听到用于描述两个工人之间关系的“高级/劣等”术语让我感到困扰。我相信这些术语最终会影响我们的思维，并且我们实际上开始相信我们（或其他人） 低人一等 ，我们（或他们）或多或少是奴隶。）

And, indeed, immediately upon completing one of my courses, a certain number of my students leave the organization paying their tuition. Interestingly, although I always offer to return the tuition in such cases, every company so far has recognized it was better off without the dissatisfied employee on the payroll—no matter how good the employee was as a technical person. (As a not altogether irrelevant aside, it bothers me to hear people say they "belong" to a company or to hear "superior/inferior" terminology used to describe the relationship between two workers. I believe such terminology eventually influences our thinking, and we actually begin to believe we (or others) are inferior, and that we (or they) are more or less slaves.)

乔继续解决我自己最喜欢的目标之一，即大学：

Jo goes on to tackle one of my own favorite targets, the universities:

我们可以成为学者，但我们维护的计算机是否用于保存学生的政治档案，并将信息提供给公司？（无论如何，该死的傻瓜都用于计算机。）我更喜欢在我发现自己的环境中工作。

We could become academics, but is the computer that we are maintaining being used for keeping political files on its students, and giving the information to companies? (Damn fool use for a computer anyway.) I prefer to work within the environment I find myself.

再一次，我完全同意。学者特别容易对雇主的所作所为产生危险的自欺欺人。我在一所美国大学留下了一个终身教席，正是因为这所大学正在用它的计算机做乔建议的事情——甚至更糟。计算机人员特别擅长发现雇主的既定目标与雇主的实际目标或实践之间的差异。但 如果你真的不首先相信公共目标，那就不行了。 正如甘地曾经说过的那样，“如果你不相信酒吧间的存在，那么就没有必要参与关于酒吧间种族隔离的争论。”

Again, I agree completely. Academics are particularly liable to dangerous self-delusion about what their employers are doing. I left a tenured chair in an American university precisely because the university was doing such things as Jo suggests with its computer—and worse. Computer people are in a particularly good position to spot discrepancies between the stated goals of their employers and the employers' actual goals or practices. But not if you really don't believe in the public goals in the first place. As Gandhi once said, "If you don't believe in barrooms, then there's no sense getting involved in arguments about segregation in barrooms."

一旦您与组织的目标建立了这种基本一致，那么 Jo 的建议就非常有道理：

Once you have established this basic agreement with the goals of your organization, then what Jo proposes makes perfect sense:

离开的威胁，即使缺乏编程，也是一种非常生硬的工具，可能会完全失误。

The threat of leaving, even with a shortage of programming, is a very blunt instrument, which may miss its mark altogether.

正如理查德尼克松所说，我在我最初的文章中感到内疚，让自己“完全清楚”。我绝对不会建议任何人 威胁 要离开他们的工作。如果你觉得这个职位不可接受，那么要么努力让它可以接受，要么干脆离开。不要威胁。威胁不仅可能会错过目标，而且几乎 肯定 会错过目标。充其量你的雇主会相信你只是想赚更多的钱，而且无论如何你都会了解到 没有人 对大型组织来说是不可或缺的。

I was guilty in my original article of not, as Richard Nixon said, making myself "perfectly clear." I'm quite definitely not proposing anyone threaten to leave their job. If you find the position unacceptable, then either work to make it acceptable or simply leave. Don't threaten. A threat not only may miss its mark, it's almost guaranteed to miss its mark. At best your employer will believe you're just trying to get more money, and in any case you'll learn nobody is indispensable to large organizations.

如果你离开一个地方，你离开它的情况会比以前更糟（因为一位积极的评论家离开了）。如果你留下来抱怨、大喊大叫、批评、建议和说服，你就会发现问题，你会让其他人知道发生了什么，而且，你可能会略微改善设置。

If you leave a place, you leave it worse off than before (since an active critic has left). If you stay, and complain, and shout, and criticize, and suggest, and persuade, you will find out things, you will make others aware of what is going on, and, just possibly, you might slightly improve the set-up.

我无法改进那个请求，但我可以指出乔建议的道路可能非常困难和孤独。而且，如果你最终没有产生哪怕是一点点影响，你很可能会崩溃，再也无法集中精力。出于这个原因，绝对有必要首先确定您是否可以在组织的价值体系中舒适地生活。您不希望处于尝试进行改进的境地，却突然发现您一直在为某些东西做出贡献——例如毒气或秘密档案——您宁愿销毁这些东西。

I can't improve on that plea, but I can point out the path Jo proposes can be mighty difficult and lonely. And, if you ultimately fail to have even a slight influence, you may very well crack up and never be able to muster the effort again. For that reason, it is absolutely essential you first determine whether you can live comfortably within your organization's value system. You do not want to be in the position of attempting to make improvements only to suddenly discover you have been contributing to something—like poison gas or secret dossiers—you would rather have destroyed.

同样重要的是，您的微小改进至少有可能影响事物的整体计划。无论计划多么美妙，在成功的希望破灭后继续工作只会扼杀你内心的火花——你需要为下一场战斗点燃自己的火花。

It's also essential there is at least a possibility your slight improvement has a chance of influencing the overall plan of things. No matter how wonderful the plan is, to keep working after hope of success has died will only kill that spark within you—the spark you will need to ignite yourself for the next battle.

我写下这个问题清单的主要原因之一是：在过去的几十年里，我看到许多优秀的男人和女人在徒劳的事业中毁灭了自己——因为他们从一开始就知道这是徒劳的。这么多年过去了，我从来没有学会对那些人不屑一顾。每个故事都和第一个故事一样痛苦。

One of the principal reasons I wrote down that list of questions is this: Over the past several decades, I've seen many good men and women destroy themselves working in futile causes—causes they really knew were futile from the beginning. After all these years, I've never learned to shrug off those people. Each story hurts as much as the first.

所有这些斗士都开始表达 Jo 所表达的那种关于他们的工作和编程专业的情绪：

All of these crusaders started out expressing the kind of sentiment Jo expresses, about their job and the programming profession generally:

现在对计算的两个主要恐惧是“隐私”和可能的失业。有时我只是害怕糟糕的编程或系统设计。斯旺西的 DLVC 为这个国家的技术进步事业做了什么，我不愿去想。但如果所有最优秀的人都离开了，情况也不会更好。天啊！直到最近几年，在编写程序之前设计程序的“革命性概念”才开始慢慢渗透到商业编程中。这是由试图从内部改善事物的人们完成的。

The two main fears about computing now are "Privacy'' and possible unemployment. I am sometimes afraid of just plain bad programming or system design. What DLVC at Swansea has done to the cause of technological advancement in this country, I hate to think. But it wouldn't have been better if all the best people had left. Good grief! It's only in the last couple of years that the "revolutionary concept" of designing a program before you write it has begun to creep slowly into commercial programming. It was done by people trying to improve things from within.

我见过的计算灾难不止于此。在他们中的大多数人中，如果所有最优秀的人都离开了，结果会有所改善——越早越好。我见过许多构思不当的项目，最优秀的人离开了，从而导致项目在影响到公众之前就崩溃了。当组织内部的所有其他方法都失败时，如果您“用脚投票”，这对世界来说可能是最好的事情。

I've seen more than my share of computing disasters. In most of them, outcomes would have improved if all the best people had left—the earlier the better. I have seen many ill-conceived projects on which the best people have left and have thereby caused the project to collapse before it affected the general public. When all else fails from within an organization, it can be the best thing for the world if you "vote with your feet."

这样看。注定要失败的项目的经理们可能对技术状况一无所知，只能通过他们的“下级”的建议才能知道。其中一个下级告诉他们，公司绝对会走上灾难之路，但当经理们什么都不做时，下级继续工作并领取工资。在这种情况下，管理人员怎么会相信这个“​​下等”人要告诉他们的话呢？你会？

Look at it this way. The managers of the doomed project probably know nothing about the technical state of affairs and can know only through the advice of their "inferiors." One of these inferiors tells them the company is absolutely committed to a disaster path, but when the managers do nothing, the inferior keeps on working and drawing pay. In such a situation, how can the managers believe what this "inferior" person is trying to tell them? Would you?

再一次，我同意乔的说法：

Again, I agree with Jo in saying:

我认为保护公众免受不良计算影响的最好方法是教育公众，使其不接受不良计算。我们也可以在自己的小势力范围内做自己的事情，但最终对一个行业的保障必须来自该行业之外。. . . 这并不免除分析师或程序员的责任。他必须尽力而为，但他一个人不可能解决整个问题。

I think the best way to protect the public against bad computing is to educate the public so that it does not accept bad computing. We too can do our piece in our own small sphere of influence, but ultimately safeguards concerning a profession must come from outside that profession. . . . This does not absolve the analyst or programmer from his responsibility. He must do the best he can, but he, alone, cannot possibly tackle the entire problem.

最后，如果我们自己接受不良计算，我们就无法“教育公众使其不接受不良计算”。 在我们让自己在经济和情感上陷入这些情况之前， 我们必须学会识别注定会产生不良计算的情况。

In the end, there's no way we can "educate the public so that it does not accept bad computing" if we ourselves accept bad computing. We must learn to recognize situations destined to produce bad computing before we allow ourselves to become entangled in those situations, financially and emotionally.

自然，没有人能够准确预测未来。我们能做的最好的事情就是回顾我们的过去，并尝试提取一些一般原则——如果我们在遇到麻烦之前应用它们，这些原则旨在让我们远离麻烦。我们当然会犯错误，但生命太短暂，无法通过痛苦的经历来学习一切。计算机有很多真正有价值的事情可以做，所以我们不必害怕放弃一些愚蠢、悲惨或彻头彻尾的讨厌工作。有什么更好的方法可以说服公众尊重我们的职业，而不是像现在很多人那样拆毁和嘲笑它？正如乔所说：

Naturally, nobody can predict the future with certainty. The best we can do is look to our past and try to extract some general principles—principles designed to keep us out of trouble if we apply them before we're in trouble. We will certainly make our share of mistakes, but life is too short to learn everything by bitter experience. And there are plenty of truly worthwhile things to do with computers, so we need not fear leaving some stupid, miserable, or downright nasty job undone. What better way to persuade the public to respect our profession, rather than tear it down and mock it as so many people do now? As Jo says:

我同意你的观点，DP 人员应该超越他们的薪水包和晋升前景，去关注他们的工作职责。祝你在尝试让他们这样做时好运！

I do agree with you that DP people should look beyond their pay packets and promotion prospects to the responsibilities of their jobs. Good luck in your attempts to make them do so!

祝 你好运 ！

Good luck in your attempts!

不耐烦的精神病医生：一个寓言

The Impatient Psychiatrist: A Fable

一位 精神科医生整天都在为她的病人找麻烦，但乔治特别不合作。精神科医生开始怀疑她的专业能力，并在她的记忆中寻找可能对顽固的乔治使用的行之有效的交易技巧。

A psychiatrist had been having trouble with her patients all day, but George was particularly uncooperative. The psychiatrist was beginning to doubt her professional competence and searched her memory for tried-and-true tricks of the trade that might be used on the recalcitrant George.

她决定尝试自由联想。“乔治，”她解释说，“我要你把脑子里所有的想法都清空。让它完全空白。然后当我敲击铅笔时，我要你告诉我你脑海中第一个想到的事情。”

She decided to attempt free association. "George," she explained, "I want you to clear your mind of all thoughts. Make it completely blank. Then when I tap my pencil, I want you to tell me the first thing that comes into your mind."

听到信号，乔治说：“我要你吻我，医生。”

At the signal, George said, "I want you to kiss me, doctor."

心理医生很生气，但是。因为这不是一个适当的职业姿势，所以抑制了她的愤怒。“这并不令人满意，乔治，”回答说。“你在重复一个旧模式，我们知道你应该试图抹去它。我希望你再试一次。把你的想法从脑海中清除，然后告诉我你在想什么。”

The psychiatrist was furious but. as this was not a proper professional pose, subdued her anger. "That's not satisfactory, George," came the reply. "You're repeating an old pattern, which we know you should be trying to erase. I want you to try again. Just clear that thought out of your mind and then tell me what you're thinking."

乔治试了试，却又用可怜兮兮的语气说道：“对不起，医生，不管我怎么努力，我能想到的就是要你吻我。”

George tried, but then said in a pitiful tone, "I'm sorry, doctor. No matter how hard I try, all I can think of is that I want you to kiss me."

现在医生的愤怒开始蔓延到反应中。“那不行，乔治。想想别的办法吧。”

Now the doctor's anger began to creep into the response. "That won't do, George. Just think of something else."

“我想不出别的，就是想让你亲亲我。” 失去了所有的控制，精神科医生尖叫道：“如果我告诉过你一次，我已经告诉过你一千次，我不会吻你的。所以把这个想法从你的脑海中抹去。”

"I can't think of anything else. I just want you to kiss me." Losing all control, the psychiatrist screamed, "If I've told you once, I've told you a thousand times, I'm not going to kiss you. So get that thought out of your mind."

“可是你为什么不亲我？” 乔治恳求道。

"But why won't you kiss me?" pleaded George.

“我为什么不吻你？为什么，我什至不应该和你一起躺在沙发上！”

"Why won't I kiss you? Why, I shouldn't even be here on the couch with you!"

寓意：一旦你们一起躺在沙发上，再担心接吻就来不及了。

moral: Once you're on the couch together, it's too late to worry about the kissing.

或者：当你发现自己永远被职业生涯中的小问题激怒时，也许问题是你之前回答错误的一些更大的问题。

alternatively: When you find yourself perpetually angered by little questions in your professional life, perhaps the problem is some bigger question you answered wrong earlier.

第二章专业人士如何做到这一点？

Chapter II How Do Professionals Get That Way?

程序员太有价值了，不能信任计算机

Programmers Are Too Valuable to Be Trusted to Computers

选择教学语言

Choosing a Teaching Language

每四年，随着县选举，当地的计算机科学教授会提出正确的编程教学语言问题。有很多关于将流氓赶出去的勇敢言论，有很多专门用于竞选的午餐，选举前的信心浪潮，然后是暴发户的最终失败。最终，FORTRAN 和 sheriff 都连任了。他们可能腐败。他们可能不称职。他们可能会随着年龄的增长而吱吱作响，但至少他们很熟悉。

Every four years, along with county elections, the local computer science professors raise the question of the correct teaching language for programming. There's a lot of brave talk about throwing the rascals out, many lunches devoted to campaigning, a wave of confidence just before the election, and then the ultimate defeat of the upstart. In the end, both FORTRAN and the sheriff are reelected. They may be corrupt. They may be incompetent. They may be creaking with age, but at least they're familiar.

和县里的选民一样，教授们也准备好合理化结果。随着 1956 年以来岁月的累积，这些争论的要点已经一点一点地消失了。然而，年复一年，仍然有一个人成为各地保守主义的支柱。引用一位真正的教授的话：

Like the county voters, professors are quite ready to rationalize the result. As the years since 1956 have accumulated, the points in these arguments have, one by one, withered away. And yet one remains, year after year, the backbone of conservatism everywhere. To quote a genuine professor:

我决定将这门课程建立在 WATFIV 编程语言的基础上，这不仅是基于对现实世界应用程序的认识，也是基于我们安装时计算机成本的原始经济学。

My decision to base this course on the WATFIV programming language was founded not only on a recognition of real-world applications but also on the raw economics of computer costs at our installation.

现实世界 和 原始经济学 是严肃的词——不是你的象牙塔文件夹。因此，让我们看一下现实世界中用于培训的计算机成本的一些原始经济学。

Real-world and raw economics are no-nonsense words—none of your ivory-tower folderol. Let's look, therefore, at some of the raw economics of computer costs for training in the real world.

五十年前，计算机真的 很贵 ——所以昂贵的 FORTRAN 必须排除在编程课程中使用的语言之外。事实上，即使是最富有的人也认为在编程课程中使用计算机是一种轻浮的奢侈。

Fifty years ago, computers were really expensive—so expensive FORTRAN had to be ruled out of consideration for the language used in a programming course. In fact, even the richest of the rich thought using a computer in a programming course was a frivolous extravagance.

五十年对于治安官来说是一段很长的时间，对于编程行业来说则更长。很少有人记得那些日子，甚至不相信可以在没有计算机的情况下教授编程。很快，以个人计算机的普及速度，很少有人会记得跟老师学习计算机是什么感觉 。 在 WATFIV 决定合理化后的几年里，原始经济学发生了巨大变化，一些大学可以负担得起给每个学生一台个人电脑。在这个现代时代，用单数形式说“我们的装置”听起来很陈旧。哪所值得认可的大学没有像返校节传单一样散落在校园各处的数十台计算机？

Fifty years is a long time in a sheriff's life, and even longer in the life of the programming profession. Few remember those days, or even believe it was possible to teach programming without a computer. Soon, at the rate personal computers are spreading, few will remember what it was like to learn computing with a teacher. In the few years since the WATFIV decision was rationalized, the raw economics have changed so sharply some colleges can afford to give each student a personal computer. In this modern age, it sounds archaic to say "our installation" in the singular. What university worth accreditation hasn't got dozens of computers scattered around the campus like homecoming handbills?

尽管如此，FORTRAN 的论点在最近硬件成本的降低中仍然存在。根据一些教授的说法，现在 PC 无法运行其他任何东西——除了 BASIC。这种保守主义起源于哪里？它会在哪里结束？它会传播多远？为什么它会抵抗语言设计者和实现者对其进行分解的反复努力？

Still, the FORTRAN argument has survived the latest reduction in hardware costs. According to some professors, now PCs can't afford to run anything else—except, heaven forbid, BASIC. Where does this conservatism originate? Where will it end? How far will it spread? Why does it resist the repeated efforts of language designers and implementers to break it down?

使用软件工具

Using Software Tools

编程语言只是最古老、最熟悉的软件工具，而大学只是社会变革最古老、最熟悉的工具。对于所有其他机构的所有其他工具，在采用新工具方面同样保守。如果我们能够回答我们的问题，回报可能是惊人的。

The programming language is merely the oldest and most familiar software tool, and universities are merely the oldest and most familiar tools for social change. The same conservatism in the adoption of new tools is found for all other tools in all other institutions. If we can answer our questions, the payoff could be staggering.

在不使用新工具的众多原因中，最明显的可能是缺乏对培训的关注。大量资金用于软件工具的开发——目前的速度每年超过数十亿美元。相比之下，用于培训人们使用这些工具的资金微乎其微。

Of the many reasons for nonuse of new tools, perhaps the most obvious is the lack of attention given to training. An elephantine sum of money has been spent on the development of software tools—the current rate exceeds billions of dollars a year. In contrast, a microscopic sum of money has been spent on training people to use those tools.

也许由于开发和培训之间的这种差异，大多数工具从未或几乎从未使用过。人们不仅继续使用 FORTRAN，而且他们继续使用它，例如，甚至没有获得他们程序变量的交叉引用列表。即使他们的 FORTRAN 编译器提供了这样的交叉引用，安装也会将其禁用，通常作为“标准”，因为“它的成本太高”。即使在常规生产的地方，90% 的程序员也从不看它。然而，交叉引用列表是最简单的软件工具之一——使用起来最直接、最方便、最古老的工具之一。

Perhaps as a consequence of this disparity between development and training, most of the tools are never, or hardly ever, used. Not only do people continue to use FORTRAN, but they continue to use it without, for instance, even getting cross-reference listings of their program variables. Even when their FORTRAN compiler provides such a cross-reference, the installation disables it, usually as a "standard," because "it costs too much." Even where it is routinely produced, 90 percent of the programmers never look at it. Yet the cross-reference listing is one of the simplest software tools—one of the most direct in its use, one of the most convenient, and one of the most ancient.

在大多数已放弃 FORTRAN 转而使用“高级”语言的安装中，情况并没有好多少。作为正式审查技巧的练习，我们的客户和学生研究已发布的程序，这些程序可能被举为新手可以遵循的示例。在对两位计算机科学教授编写的程序的典型审查中，我们研究了 PL/I 的使用。尽管规范为使用它们中的每一个提供了理想的情况，但没有使用以下 PL/I 设施：

The situation is little better in the majority of installations where FORTRAN has been abandoned for "higher" languages. As an exercise in formal review techniques, our clients and students study published programs, which presumably are held up as examples for novices to follow. In a typical review of a program written by two professors of computer science, we studied the use of PL/I. Although the specifications offered ideal situations for employing each of them, none of the following PL/I facilities were used:

1.存储的动态分配

1. Dynamic allocation of storage

2. 横截面符号

2. Cross-section notation

3.数组表达式

3. Array expressions

4. 属性分解

4. Factoring of attributes

5.下标表达式

5. Subscript expressions

6.类型转换的控制

6. Control of type conversions

7. 位串

7. Bit strings

人们几乎可以删除分号，实际上可以在 FORTRAN 编译器上编译程序。

One could almost have removed the semicolons and, in effect, compiled the program on a FORTRAN compiler.

通常，对该程序的进一步检查表明，多年来的讨论对编程风格没有影响。以下是我们发现的更可怜的文体实践：

As is typical, further examination of the program revealed no impact of the years of discussion on programming style. The following are among the more pitiful stylistic practices we found:

1. 复杂的分支，包括进入和退出循环

1. Intricate branching, including into and out of loops

2. 基于对先前陈述作用的不完全理解的多余陈述

2. Superfluous statements based on incomplete understanding of the action of earlier statements

3. 退出使用它们的循环时变量的初始化

3. Initialization of variables upon exit from loops that used them

4. K、R等单字符名称的使用

4. Use of single-character names such as K and R

5. 在不紧迫存储的程序中使用和重用标量变量

5. Use and reuse of scalar variables in a program not pressed for storage

6. 使用具有两种不同含义的名称，一种在程序中，一种在解释其含义的注释中

6. Use of a name with two different meanings, one in the program and one in a comment explaining its meaning

7. 在最容易混淆的上下文中使用关键字 PTR 作为数据名称

7. Use of the keyword PTR as a data name in a most confusing context

8. 变量命名普遍不一致

8. General inconsistency in the naming of variables

9. 在大量使用指针“提高效率”的程序中，循环中的计算效率低下，但优化器无法访问

9. Computations inefficiently placed within loops, yet rendered inaccessible to an optimizer, in a program that heavily used pointers "for efficiency"

在设计层面，该计划再次没有受到行业近期讨论的影响，更不用说设计工具和概念了。我们找到

At the level of design, the program again showed no influence of recent discussion in the industry, let alone design tools and concepts. We found

1. 不检查任何有效输入——无论是边界还是值

1. No checking whatsoever for valid input—either bounds or values

2. 未经检查的输入用于控制计算，如在计算分支中

2. Unchecked input used to control calculations, as in computed branches

3. 完全未经设计且容易出错的输入格式

3. A completely undesigned and error-prone input format

4. 一种算法，除了少量的输入之外，其他方面都是低效的

4. An algorithm that was inefficient for all but small eases of input

5. 没有监控算法的性能，这可能向用户表明性能损失

5. No monitoring of performance of the algorithm, which might have indicated loss of performance to the user

6.无法理解的错误信息

6. Incomprehensible error messages

7. 错误或误导的可理解错误信息

7. Comprehensible error messages that were wrong or misleading

在我的工作中，我审查了来自数十个安装的数百个程序。这些程序显示出大致相同范围的问题，并且安装显示大致相同的未使用工具。至少 75% 的安装例行调试使用未格式化的十六进制转储。至少 90% 的人从未使用过预处理器。程序库开始投入使用，但仍未在超过 50% 的安装中找到。测试数据生成很少见。测试数据的归档更是少之又少。即使是最基本的数据集比较也几乎从未使用过。

In my work, I have reviewed hundreds of programs from dozens of installations. The programs display approximately the same range of problems, and the installations display approximately the same non-use of tools. At least 75 percent of the installations routinely debug using unformatted hexadecimal dumps. At least 90 percent have never used a preprocessor. Program libraries are coming into use, but are still not found in more than 50 percent of installations. Test data generation is rare. Archiving of test data is even more rare. Even a rudimentary data-set comparison is hardly ever used.

我们说的不是搁置在架子上、积满灰尘和租金的这些工具的数量。如果 有人 使用该工具，我们会将其计为已使用，即使是其功能的一小部分。因此，这些数字高估了实际的专业用途。既然我们在培训上花钱，我们能教程序员什么？

We're not speaking of the number of these tools sitting on the shelf, accumulating dust and rent. We are counting the tool as used if anyone uses it, even if for a minor part of its capabilities. Consequently, these figures overestimate real professional use. Since we are spending money on training, what can we possibly be teaching programmers?

计算机作为教师

The Computer as Instructor

鉴于我们昂贵的工具使用不当，很明显我们没有教程序员在他们的编程工作中充分使用计算机。结论似乎很明显——我们必须在课堂上花更多的钱在电脑上，而不是更少。

In view of the inadequate use of our expensive tools, it is obvious we are not teaching programmers to use the computer adequately in their programming work. The conclusion seems obvious—we must spend more on computers in our classes, not less.

明显的？看起来是这样，直到我们了解计算机在课堂上的使用方式。事实上，我们根本没有在教学生——计算机正在为我们背负重担。结果，我们发现自己站在同一个栅栏的两边。这是本节的双论点：

Obvious? It would seem so, until we look at the way the computer is being used in classes. Indeed, we are not teaching the students at all—the computer is carrying the burden for us. As a result, we find ourselves standing on both sides of the same fence. This is the double thesis of this section:

(1)计算机在程序员教育中使用不足

(1) the computer is insufficiently used in programmer education

(2)计算机在程序员教育中被过度使用。

(2) the computer is overused in programmer education.

让我们来看看计算机是如何在典型的大学编程课程中使用的。可以通过类比来最好地理解这种用途的性质。假设我们已经成功地为高中英语课程开发了一个“paper-grader”程序，并且我们已经成功地通过以下方式在高中使用该程序：

Let's examine how the computer is used in a typical university course in programming. The nature of this use may best be understood in terms of an analogy. Suppose we have succeeded in developing a "paper-grader" program for high school English courses and we have succeeded in getting the program used within the high schools in the following way:

1. 教师针对 50 至 500 名学生讲授一个或另一个主题。

1. The teacher lectures on one topic or another to 50 to 500 students.

2. 老师布置作业写一篇作文。

2. The teacher gives an assignment to write an essay.

3. 学生写一篇作文，严令不帮助别人，也不接受别人的帮助。

3. The students write an essay, under strict orders not to help anyone else or to receive help from anyone else.

4. 我们的计算机程序根据拼写错误和语法错误对论文进行评分。

4. The essay is graded by our computer program on the basis of spelling errors and grammatical errors.

5. 论文与成绩一起退还给学生。

5. The paper is returned to the students with a grade.

你认为学生会学到什么？

What do you suppose the students will learn?

这个类比之所以有效，是因为我们不必猜测学生将学习什么。我们已经知道了。即使没有电脑，这也是许多高中英语老师教授作文课的方式，而且结果是出了名的。许多学生学习拼写；有些人学会避免不正确的语法；基本上没有人学会书面交流。（幸运的是，一些人从其他经历中学到了这些东西。）

This analogy works because we don't have to guess what the students will learn. We already know. Even without the computer, this is the way many high school English teachers conduct their classes in composition, and the results are notoriously had. Many of the students learn to spell; some learn to avoid incorrect grammar; essentially none learn to communicate in writing. (Fortunately, a few learn these things from other experiences.)

在编程教育中，编译器中已经内置了“打卷机”。因为编程作业必须通过评分器循环使用，直到消除所有“拼写和语法”错误，所以对这些方面的强调更加强烈。在许多课程中，教授没有时间或胃口阅读实际的程序。有时甚至不读取输出。在这样的课程中，学生提交错误的输出永远不会从教师那里发现这一点。 讲师 永远不会发现学生提交虚假输出。

In programming education, the "paper grader" is already built into the compiler. Because programming assignments must be recycled through the grader until all "spelling and grammar" errors are eliminated, the emphasis on these aspects is all the stronger. In many classes the professor has no time or stomach for reading the actual programs. Sometimes not even the outputs are read. In such classes, students turning in wrong outputs never find this out from the instructor. Students turning in fake outputs are never found out by the instructor.

为了解决未读输出的问题，先进的学校开发了“评分器”程序来使用测试输入和评分结果输出来练习学生程序。评分者肯定会提高计算机辅助水平——但主要是为了忙碌的教师，而不是学生。毕竟，对于有数百名新手的班级来说，还有什么方法可以经济地处理或根本处理大量温暖的尸体呢？

To solve the problem of unread output, sophisticated schools have developed "grader" programs to exercise the student programs using test inputs and scoring the resultant outputs. Graders definitely raise the level of computer assistance—but mostly to the harried instructor, not to the student. After all, for classes with hundreds of neophytes, how else can the legions of warm bodies be handled economically, or handled at all?

为了给他们应有的待遇，评分程序实际上可以代表大多数学校仍在使用的简单编译器检查的进步。但是，再一次，他们教的是什么？通过回顾这些学生在课堂上和多年后编写的程序，您可以了解计算机教授的编程知识：

To give them their due, grader programs actually can represent an advance over the simple compiler checking most schools still use. But, again, what is it they teach? By reviewing programs produced by these students, in class and years later, you can learn what the computer teaches about programming:

1. 精确键控，在批处理环境中

1. Accurate keying, in a batch environment

2. 在在线环境中使用文本编辑器来克服不准确的键入

2. Use of a text editor to overcome inaccurate keying, in an online environment

3.关键词的拼写

3. Spelling of keywords

4. 程序员选择的单词拼写一致

4. Consistent spelling of programmer-chosen words

5. 编程语言的语法子集

5. A subset of the syntax of a programming language

但除了这些重要的课程之外，以这些方式使用的计算机还教授了一个更深刻的课程，这个课程肯定会在 WATFIV 语法被遗忘后长期存在。那个教训是

But beyond these important lessons, the computer—used in these ways—teaches a much deeper lesson, one sure to remain long after the WATFIV syntax is forgotten. That lesson is

程序通过测试被证明是正确的。

Programs are shown to be correct by testing them.

这是一个奇怪的（也是错误的）教训。引用 Edsger Dijkstra 关于结构化编程的原始布道：

This is a curious (and wrong) lesson. To quote the original sermon on structured programming by Edsger Dijkstra:

程序正确性的建立程度不仅仅取决于功能或程序的外部规范和行为，还主要取决于其内部结构。

The extent to which the program correctness can be established is not purely a function or the program's external specifications and behavior but depends critically on its internal structure.

简而言之，计算机所教授的内容与自汇编程序发明以来最强烈的改进编程运动的主要课程恰恰相反。它每天都在全国每所学校向成千上万的现有和潜在程序员教授这一课。

In short, what the computer is teaching is precisely antithetical to the principal lesson of the strongest movement for improved programming since the invention of the assembler. It is teaching this lesson every day, in every school in the country, to thousands and thousands of present and potential programmers.

但是还有第二个高级课程——实际上是元课程——关于学习本身的课程：

But there is a second high-level lesson—a meta-lesson, actually—a lesson about learning itself:

我们通过将垃圾扔进计算机并观察结果来学习编程。

We learn to program by throwing garbage into a computer and seeing what comes out.

这个教训就像我们青年时代的成见一样，根深蒂固，难以改变。更重要的是，它被教授得更早、更深入，因为个人电脑很容易获得。我们将如何对待下一代程序员？

This lesson is like the prejudices of our youth—deeply set and hard to change. What's more, it's being taught earlier and deeper, because personal computers are so readily available. What are we going to do with the next generation of programmers?

呈现给计算机。. .

Render unto the Computer . . .

计算机在教学方面非常出色——关于计算机。再多的语法错误讲座似乎也不会给大多数学生留下丝毫印象——除非是轻微的负面印象。然而，编译器耐心而无情地向一个又一个顽固的学生教授语法。如果巧妙地使用，作为老师的编译器甚至可以激发一些学生记住语法原则，尽管他们必须从其他地方获得这些原则。

Computers are excellent at teaching—about computers. No amount of lecturing about syntax errors seems to make the slightest impression on the majority of students—unless it is a slightly negative one.
