A compiler, though, patiently and mercilessly teaches syntax to one recalcitrant student after another. Cleverly used, the compiler as teacher can even motivate some students to remember principles of syntax, though they have to obtain those principles elsewhere.

一些工具制造者说语法和拼写是不重要的课程，因为可以构建工具来纠正任何错误。我只能部分同意他们的观点，因为没有任何系统能够纠正任何类型的 所有 错误。因此，即使是最聪明的程序员有时也必须学习语法和拼写方面的艰苦课程——否则会浪费数百个令人沮丧的时间。

Some toolmakers say syntax and spelling are unimportant lessons because tools can be built to correct any errors. I can agree with them only partially, for no system will ever be able to correct all errors of any type. Consequently, even the most brilliant programmer must at some time learn the hard lessons of syntax and spelling—or else waste hundreds of frustrating hours.

此外，即使将最复杂、最仔细的证明技术应用到结构最宏伟的程序中，计算机也可能会发现两种可能被漏掉的错误：

Furthermore, even when the most sophisticated and careful proof techniques are applied to the most magnificently structured program, the computer may reveal two kinds of error able to slip through:

1. 简单的校对错误——困扰着最先进的数学期刊和最不起眼的程序的错误。

1. simple proofreading errors—errors plaguing the most advanced mathematics journals as well as the most humble programs.

2.对问题的完全误解。

2. the complete misunderstanding of the problem.

尽管程序员可以证明程序做了她认为应该做的事情，但她永远无法证明她认为应该做的事情是正确的——也就是说，她的客户希望它做什么。从某种意义上说，没有错误的程序，只有 不同的 程序。我们发现是否解决了正确问题的唯一希望是将建议的解决方案返回给发起者。

Though a programmer may prove the program does what she thinks it should do, she can never prove what she thinks it should do is correct—namely, what her customer wants it to do. In one sense, there are no wrong programs, only different programs. The only hope we have of discovering if we've solved the right problem is to give the proposed solution back to the originator.

考虑以下典型示例。一位考古学教授正在教授一门大型入门课程，辅以计算机打印从一堆问题中随机抽取的个性化考试。计算机科学系的一名高年级学生接到了编写打印试卷的程序的任务，但该程序有一个小缺陷。相当频繁的是，一次考试会包含相同的问题两次，甚至三次。该程序不是“无放回”地对问题池进行抽样，而是“有放回”地抽样。

Consider the following typical example. A professor of archaeology was teaching a large introductory course, assisted by a computer printing individualized examinations drawn at random from a pool of questions. An advanced student in the computer science department had been given the job of writing the program to print the exams, but the program had one slight flaw. Rather frequently, one exam would contain the same question twice, or even three times. Rather than sampling the question pool "without replacement," the program was sampling "with replacement."

教授注意到了这个缺陷并与学生对质。他被告知该程序可以在不更换的情况下进行采样，但这个过程“效率非常低”。他确信教授不会愿意支付额外的费用，所以他认为打印 14 个问题会更好，以确保得到 10 个独特的问题。只需告诉学生们回答“前十个独特的问题”。

The professor noticed this defect and confronted the student. He was told the program could sample without replacement, but the process was "very inefficient." He was sure the professor would not want to pay the extra cost, so he figured it would be better to print, say, fourteen questions to be sure of getting ten unique ones. The students just had to be told to answer "the first ten unique questions."

教授对这个答案不满意，于是程序员编写了一个新程序来生成没有重复的试卷。您可能希望推测这位学生程序员选择了众多糟糕算法中的哪一种。事实上，他的技术在概念上非常简单，但非常愚蠢。为了在不放回的情况下进行抽样，该程序生成了一个试探性的测试，然后进行测试以查看它是否包含任何重复的问题。在程序的第一次测试中，从 20 个问题中抽取了 10 个问题，这意味着必须抽取大约 30 个考试才能得到一个没有重复的问题！

The professor was not satisfied with this answer, so the programmer wrote a new program to produce exams without duplicates. You may wish to speculate just which of the many poor algorithms this student programmer chose. In fact, his technique was conceptually very simple, but incredibly stupid. To perform sampling without replacement, the program produced a tentative exam and then tested to see if it contained any repeated questions. During program's first test, ten questions were being drawn from a pool of twenty, which meant about thirty exams had to be drawn to get one without duplicates!

但情况变得更糟。在第一次实际运行中，教授创建了一个包含 20 个问题的数据库，并希望制作 20 个问题的考试。他希望所有测试都包含相同的 20 个问题，但为了防止作弊而进行了排列。当程序试图这样做时，它进入了一个循环。至少 看起来 进入一个循环，但它实际上是随机抽取 20 个问题（有替换），然后测试它是否没有重复。根据我的粗略计算，五千万分之一的抽签是20道题的排列。（我的计算可能有误。它可能是五百万分之一或五十亿分之一，但结果是一样的：程序似乎在循环中，这也难怪。估计每次抽取 1/10 秒，每个考试需要两天以上的时间才能完成——班上有 600 名学生！）

But the story grows worse. On the first real run, the professor created a data base of 20 questions, and wanted to produce 20-question exams. He wanted all the tests to contain the same 20 questions, but permuted in order to prevent cheating. As the program attempted to do this, it went into a loop. At least it seemed to go into a loop, but it was really drawing 20 questions at random (with replacement), then testing to see if it was free of duplicates. According to my rough calculation, about one draw out of fifty million would be a permutation of the 20 questions. (My calculation might be off. It could be one out of five million or five billion, but the result is the same: The program seemed to be in a loop, and no wonder. At an estimated 1/10 second per draw, each exam would take more than two days to produce—and there were 600 students in the class!)

小心从这个故事中得出正确的寓意。大多数计算机科学教授都会为这个学生对算法的无知感到悲哀。尽管这种无知令人难过，但我们可以学会在“现实世界”中忍受它。我们不能容忍的是这个学生对程序员在生活中的角色的无知。

Be careful to draw the correct moral from this tale. Most professors of computer science would lament this student's miserable ignorance of algorithms. Although this kind of ignorance is sad, we could learn to live with it in the "real world." What we can't live with is this student's ignorance of the programmer's role in life.

教授想在考试上花多少钱不是程序员的事。他对教授想要什么的第一个猜测导致他授权印刷 600 份试卷，所有这些都不得不被丢弃。他的第二次尝试产生了一个不是循环的循环。该程序错过了最后期限（当然），并且必须使用打字考试的旧系统。除非你是为了自己的娱乐而编程，否则关于程序是否正确的最终决定不在于计算机，也不在于程序员（你），而在于有问题的客户。

It was not the programmer's place to decide how much the professor wanted to spend on exams. His first guess about what the professor wanted led him to authorize printing six-hundred exams, all of which had to be discarded. His second try produced the loop that wasn't a loop. The program missed the deadline (of course), and the old system of a typed exam had to be used. Unless you're programming for your own amusement, the final decision about whether a program is correct rests not with the computer, not with the programmer (you), but with the customer with the problem.

当然，另一个相关的问题是，程序员丝毫没有意识到他的第一个程序是错误的。从效率的角度来看，他甚至不知道第二个程序是错误的。计算机和教授都无法教授这样的课程。

Another relevant point, of course, is that the programmer had not the slightest idea his first program was wrong. He didn't even know the second program was wrong from an efficiency point of view. Neither the computer not the professor could teach such a lesson.

最后，要成为一名真正的专业程序员，您必须学习大量的课程。每个这样的课程都有其独特的学习方式。在设计编程课程时，我们必须确保每节课都以最有效的方式教授，而不仅仅是保证一定数量的学生可以“处理”整个学期而不要求退还学费。

In the end, there is a multitude of lessons you must learn to become a truly professional programmer. Each such lesson has its own characteristic ways of being learned. In designing programming courses, we must ensure each lesson is taught in the most effective way and not merely ensure a certain number of students can be "processed" for a whole semester without demanding a tuition refund.

如何使用或不使用计算机教授编程课程

How to Teach a Programming Course With or Without a Computer

我们如何才能设计出如此有效的编程课程？一般模式现在应该很清楚了：

How could we design such an effective programming course? The general pattern should now be clear:

1.用电脑教只有电脑能教的东西。

1. Use the computer to teach what only the computer can teach.

2. 用人来教只有人才能教的东西。

2. Use people to teach what only people can teach.

3. 只有在计算机和人能以同等效率完成工作的情况下，才能在计算机和人之间做出经济选择。

3. Make the economic choice between computer and people only in those cases where either can do the job with equal effectiveness.

毫无疑问，入门课程应该从与机器的一两次接触开始：

No doubt an introductory course ought to begin with one or two encounters with the machine to teach:

1. 程序创建的总体过程

1. The overall process by which programs are created

2. 计算机器的挑剔本质

2. The finicky nature of computing machines

3. 挑剔的机器之间的不匹配和我们在精确方面的困难。

3. The mismatch between finicky machines and our difficulty in being precise.

学生学习完这些课程后，至少在入门级，他们应该转向人力资源学习更难的课程。典型的任务可能涉及以下内容：

After the students learn these lessons, at least on an introductory level, they should turn to human resources to learn more difficult lessons. A typical assignment might involve the following:

1. 教师作为“用户”提出问题，但考虑到某些课程

1. A problem is posed by the instructor acting as "user" but with certain lessons in mind

2. 每个学生在纸上做一个试题

2. Each student make a trial solution, on paper

3.每个学生评价另一个学生的试题

3. Each student evaluates the trial solution of another student

4. 小组学生，有时在导师的监督下，得出一个综合的解决方案

4. Small groups of students, sometimes with instructor supervision, arrive at a composite solution

5.那些学生在机器上试复合

5. Those students try the composite on the machine

6. 小组交流解决方案候选人要更正式地审查，有时由讲师在全班面前指导

6. Groups exchange solution candidates to be more formally reviewed, sometimes guided by the instructor in front of the entire class

在这样的课堂上，学生们吸收了更丰富、更有意义的编程信息。他们避免在句法和拼写上浪费时间，这些是正式评估的副产品，可以通过机器进行纠正，但通过复习实际上更便宜、更有效。从老师到学生，从学生到学生，传递关于风格、语言、算法、设计、工具的知识，以及数百个编程智慧的小片段，共同将专业人士与业余爱好者区分开来。有时，知识甚至会从学生传给老师。

In such a class, the students ingest a much richer and more meaningful diet of programming information. They avoid time wasted on syntax and spelling, which are corrected as a by-product of the formal evaluations and which can be taught by machine—except it's actually cheaper and more effective to do it through reviews. From teacher to student, and from student to student, passes knowledge about style, language, algorithms, design, tools, and hundreds of little pieces of programming wisdom collectively setting apart the professional from the amateur. And once in a while, knowledge even passes from student to teacher.

但是“原始经济学”呢？我对此进行了推测。我已经试验过了。我的实验甚至超过了我最疯狂的猜测。当然，第一个节省是因为五名学生组成的 小组 通过计算机完成的作业数量仅为五分之一。然而，给每个学生的教训远远超过旧的秘密方法，因为每个学生看到许多方法，而不仅仅是一个。

But what of the "raw economics"? I've speculated about this. I've experimented with it. My experiments surpass even my wildest speculations. Of course, the first saving comes because teams of five students run only one-fifth the number of assignments through the computer. Yet the lessons for each student are far greater than the old secretive method, for each student sees many approaches, not just one.

其次，生成正确程序（而不仅仅是“工作”程序）的运行次数大大减少。减少的幅度在某种程度上取决于问题的大小，但学生问题的典型数字是从平均 20 次编译到平均 2 次。实际上，大多数程序第一次在机器上就可以正确运行——学生们可以进行演示。他们最好能够——如果不能，其他团队会把他们的程序撕成碎片。

Second, the number of runs to produce a correct program (and not just a "working" program) is drastically reduced. The magnitude of reduction depends somewhat on the size of the problem, but a typical figure for student problems is from an average of twenty compiles to an average of two. Actually, most programs run correctly the first time on the machine—and the students can demonstrate it. They had better be able to—if not, the other teams cut their program to pieces.

第三，一旦学生将注意力集中在设计而不是语法和拼写上，程序本身通常会更有效地运行。教授的程序员损失 30 的因素并不少见，但假设我们谦虚地将此因素视为 2。将所有三个因素放在一起（程序数量的 5 倍；编译次数减少 10 倍；程序运行速度提高两倍） ，我们将机器成本降低了大约 100 倍。当然，100 倍的原始节省量足以让我们根据它们将教授的内容而不是它们的成本来选择我们的编程工具。

Third, the programs themselves typically run more efficiently once students focus attention on design rather than on grammar and spelling. The factor of 30 lost by the professor's programmer would not be untypical, but suppose we modestly take this factor as 2. Putting all three factors together (5 times the number of programs; 10 times fewer compiles; and programs that run twice as fast), we reduce machine costs by a factor of about 100. Certainly a factor of 100 is enough raw savings to permit us to choose our programming tools on the basis of what they will teach, not what they will cost.

但教育的好处并不止于机器经济学。当我们要教授的语言没有编译器，甚至根本没有编译器，甚至没有类时，我们都可以非常成功地使用这种方法。当一个程序第一次运行的概率如此之高时，在许多情况下，从实际运行该程序中可以学到的东西并不多。摆脱计算机，或者至少控制它通常引入的令人难以置信的差异，使我们能够更有信心地计划并在学期展开时坚持计划。事实上，一旦摆脱了机器的限制，课程经济学主要取决于教师和课堂的可用性。一旦超越了最简单的介绍，任何一组程序员都可以通过这种方式自学，无论是在工作中还是在工作之外。

But the benefits to education do not stop with machine economics. We can use this method quite successfully when there is no compiler for the language we want to teach, when there is no compiler at all, and even when there is no class. When the probability a program will work the first time is so high, in many circumstances there is not much to be learned from actually running the program. Getting rid of the computer, or at the very least controlling the incredible variance it usually introduces, permits us to plan with more confidence and stick with the plan as the semester unfolds. Indeed, once freed of the constraints of the machine, the course economics depend mostly on the availability of teacher and classroom. Once beyond the barest introduction, any group of programmers can teach themselves in this way, on the job or off .

实际上，在职培训的经济学与通常的大学假设相反。学生的薪水很可能比教师高，当全班的薪水加在一起时，他们肯定是这样。将专业程序员运送到跨城校区进行编程讲座根本不划算。通过检查彼此的工作，他们可以在更短的时间内学到更多。

Actually, the economics of on-the-job training reverses the usual college assumptions. The students are likely to be making higher salaries than the instructor, and they certainly are when the whole class's salaries are added together. It simply doesn't pay to transport professional programmers to a crosstown campus for programming lectures. They can learn much more in less time by inspecting each other's work.

对于想要远离失业线的专业教师来说，这里有一个隐含的挑战。有了合适的领导者，一小群程序员可以通过复习技巧来增加他们的学习。领导者必须帮助他们将在讲座和机器时间上节省的资金投资于富有成效的替代方案，例如允许他们使设计和算法比较难以分析执行的仪器化执行。

There is an implicit challenge here to the professional teacher who wants to stay out of the unemployment lines. With the right leader, a small group of programmers can multiply their learning through review techniques. The leader has to help them invest the money saved on lectures and machine time in fruitful alternatives, such as instrumented executions permitting them to make design and algorithm comparisons difficult to perform analytically.

领导者可以给他们更多的问题，让他们在同样的时间内完成，或者引导他们探索更多的解决方案来解决同样的问题。通过这种方式，学生可以沿着设计的道路轻推，而不是更晦涩的位。工具可以在实际使用中进行评估，或许可以为我们投入的数十亿美元带来一些回报。但是，要在这样的环境中保持领先地位，教练将需要大量奔跑。

The leader can give them more problems to do in the same amount of time or guide them in exploring more alternatives to the same problems. In this way, the students can be nudged along the path to design rather than to even more obscure bit-twiddling. Tools can be evaluated in actual use, perhaps giving some return for the billions we've invested in them. But it will take a lot of running for an instructor to stay ahead in such an environment.

这种新环境可能不适合老式的老师，他们将讲师的工作视为一种劳伦斯·奥利维尔 (Laurence Olivier) 在挤满睡觉的学生的房间里扮演哈姆雷特 (Hamlet) 的角色。它可能不适合典型的计算机骑师，他们狭隘的头脑和顽强的毅力在通常的编程课程中获得了一蒲式耳的 A。如果一种新的课程方式鼓励这样的人离开编程行业，那也算是对这种专业体验式教育体系的加分项。

This new environment may not suit the old-fashioned teacher who sees the instructor job as a kind of Laurence Olivier playing Hamlet to packed houses of sleeping students. And it may not suit the typical computer jockey whose narrow mind and dogged persistence have served to earn a bushel of A's from the usual programming classes. If a new style of class encourages such people to leave the programming profession, it can be counted as another plus for this system of professional experiential education.

一些未来的历史

Some Future History

如果我们研究电气工程、机床、电话、蒸汽动力和印刷等其他高科技领域的发展，我们会发现计算并不是独一无二的。我们可能会更快地经历这些阶段，但我们正在经历它们。我们的第一个四分之一世纪节奏很快，几乎完全由技术需求驱动。硬件销售是我们狭隘世界的始作俑者。任何不能促进更多硬件销售的东西都被抛在技术丛林中求生存的急流中。

If we study the development of other high-technology fields such as electrical engineering, machine tools, telephonics, steam power, and printing, we see computing is not unique. We may be going through the stages faster, but we are going through them. Our first quarter century was fast paced and driven almost entirely by the technological imperative. Hardware sales were the alpha and omega of our narrow world. Anything that didn't promote the sale of more hardware was left behind in the rush for survival in the technology jungle.

在硬件大热潮之后，自从 IBM 将软件从硬件中“拆分”出来后，销售经理开始明白，软件是一种产品，就像硬件一样——但具有更大的潜在市场。Software Rush 现在正处于青春期，它正在以更快的速度重复整个硬件历史。

After the Great Hardware Rush, since IBM "unbundled" software from hardware, the sales managers have come to understand that software is a product, just like hardware—but with an even greater potential market. The Software Rush is now in its adolescent stage, and it is repeating the entire hardware history at an even faster pace.

然而今天，在硬件和软件方面投入了大约 1 万亿美元之后，取得的成就相对较小。相对于什么？如果历史可以作为指导，相对于未来的前景。

Yet today, after an investment of perhaps a trillion dollars in hardware and software, the achievements are relatively small. Relative to what? If history is any guide, relative to what the future holds in store.

我们不成熟的一个衡量标准是缺乏任何真正的编程专业。今天程序员选择的职业道路是“上进出出”。大多数程序员在掌握了语法和拼写之后就没有什么可学的了，因此当新培训的初学者以初学者的薪水获得时，公司几乎没有经济动机来留住高薪“有经验”的程序员。

One measure of our immaturity is the lack of any true programming profession. The career path of choice for programmers today is "up and out." Most programmers have nothing to learn after mastery of grammar and spelling, so there is little economic incentive for companies to retain a higher-paid "experienced" programmer when a freshly trained beginner is available at a beginner's salary.

当一个人确实超越了这种狭隘的训练时，管理层中没有人认识到这样一个专业人士的真正价值。毕竟，经理们曾经上过“编程”课程。他们“知道”编程是不专业的、肤浅的和难以管理的。他们知道花在培训上的钱是浪费，最好投资于一些新硬件，或者承诺取代一些程序员的软件工具。

And when an individual does surpass this narrow training, nobody in management recognizes how valuable such a professional truly is. The managers, after all, once took a "programming" course. They "know" programming is unprofessional, shallow, and unmanageable. They know money spent on training is wasted and would be better invested in some new hardware, or a software tool promising to replace a few programmers.

我们所有人都被由谬误的“原始经济学”和虚幻的“真实世界”组成的连续推销所催眠。我们在工具上花费了数十亿美元，但没有花一分钱来了解需要什么来培养真正使用这些工具的专业技术领导者。

All of us have been hypnotized by a running sales pitch consisting of fallacious "raw economics" and illusory "real worlds." We have spent billions for tools, but not pennies on understanding what is needed to create the professional technical leaders who will actually use those tools.

我们在“学校教育”上花费了数百万美元，但在真正的学习上却吝啬。结果，我们的工具被束之高阁，被误解并且很少使用。我们的系统似乎成本太高，但一次又一次的会议只是重复其前任的销售口号——多买 东西！我们的系统无法令人满意，但我们所听到的只是口头禅：“人们不了解计算机的挑剔本质——下一代 将 解决所有这些问题！”

We've spent millions on "schooling" but have skimped on real learning. As a result, our tools lay on the shelf, misunderstood and little used. Our systems seem to cost too much, but conference after conference merely repeats the sales pitch of its predecessor—buy more things! Our systems fail to satisfy, but all we hear is the mantra: "People don't understand the finicky nature of computers—the next generation will solve all that!"

当我们摆脱青春期对玩具的迷恋并培养出对人的成人兴趣时，下一代就会到来。然后我们将开始，就像其他技术所做的那样，掌握形成成功技术背后真正力量的社会和心理力量——首先是技术的真正原因。一个很好的起点是将计算机培训从计算机手中解放出来——并将其置于人的大脑中。

The next generation will come when we outgrow our adolescent fascination with toys and develop an adult interest in people. Then we will begin, as other technologies have done, to master the social and psychological forces forming the real power behind successful technology—and the real reason for technology in the first place. An excellent starting point would be to take computer training out of the hands of computers—and put it in the brains of people.

灵活性训练

Training for Flexibility

我收到了另一封来自我最激动人心的通讯员 Jo Edkins 的来信。在其中，乔提出了当今我们许多人感兴趣的以下问题：

I have another letter from my most stimulating correspondent, Jo Edkins. In it, Jo poses the following problem of interest to many of us today:

培训是我工作的重要组成部分，目前我正在培训一些毕业生成为 COBOL 程序员。. . . 学校和大学充斥着各种形状、大小、品牌和可靠性的计算机。主要语言是BASIC，其次是FORTRAN，紧随其后的是PASCAL和ALGOL。十六名毕业生中只有两人从未编写过计算机程序。跟几年前比起来！然而，只有三个人写过 COBOL，没有人写过 PL/I。这种教育本应“使他们适应计算机世界”，但他们却发现自己的知识是一种障碍、缺陷或混乱。那些没有计算机经验的人似乎接受了概念，而其他人则试图让他们适应他们已经知道的概念。当然，我们试图帮助他们调和他们不同的知识，但是您尝试同时处理 BASIC、FORTRAN、ALGOL、PASCAL、APL 等！最后两个我都不知道！

Training is quite a substantial part of my job, and I am training some graduates to be COBOL programmers at the moment. . . . Schools and universities are being flooded with computers of all shapes, sizes, makes, and reliability. The main language is BASIC, FORTRAN is second, with PASCAL and ALGOL in hot pursuit. Out of sixteen graduates only two had never written a computer program. Compare this with a few years ago! Yet only three had written COBOL and none had written PL/I. This education is supposed to "fit them for the world of computers" and yet they found their knowledge a handicap, a drawback, or a confusion. The ones with no computer experience seemed to accept concepts as they came, while the others were trying to fit them in with concepts they already knew. Of course, we tried to help them reconcile their differing knowledge, but you try coping with BASIC, FORTRAN, ALGOL, PASCAL, APL, etc., simultaneously! I don't even know the last two!

更令人担忧的是，他们中的不少人都觉得数据和文件的概念难以理解。许多人抱怨计算机行业往往需要有经验的程序员，并奇怪为什么他们不能使用其中一些“学”过计算机的人！大多数公司只是无力承担金钱或时间，不仅要应对必要的学习，还要应对必须先于学习的忘却。我不是在责怪毕业生自己（我不敢——他们会瞒着我）。老实说，他们在大学里尽了最大的努力学习计算机，然后不得不忘掉它并学习不同的概念。

What was more worrying was that quite a few of them found the concepts of data and file hard to understand. Many people complain that the computer industry tends to want experienced programmers, and wonder why they can't use some of these people who have "learnt" about computers! Most firms just cannot afford the money or time to cope with not only the necessary learning, but, now, the unlearning that must precede it. I'm not blaming the graduates themselves (I wouldn't dare to—they'd have my hide). They have honestly tried their hardest to learn about computers at college, and then had to unlearn that and learn different concepts.

你怎么看待这件事？

What do you think about this?

碰巧的是，大约五十年前，我跌跌撞撞地找到了这个问题的解决方案。Herb Leeds 和我写了一本非常成功的书。 计算机程序设计基础， 关于汇编语言程序设计。到了第二版的时候，出版商问我们是否不能“用 FORTRAN 编写一些东西”，这是未来的新兴语言。我们对降低自己去教授除了“最好的”语言——汇编程序之外的任何语言——的前景感到震惊，但我们最终想出了一种让我们的手保持干净的方法。我们 同时教授 FORTRAN 和汇编程序，展示了用两种语言开发的每个示例。我相信我们私下认为任何看到这两种方法的人都会自然而然地选择汇编程序而不是异教徒 FORTRAN。

As it happens, I tumbled backward into a solution for this problem about fifty years ago. Herb Leeds and I had written a highly successful book. Computer Programming Fundamentals, on assembly-language programming. When it came time for a second edition, the publisher asked if we couldn't "write something on FORTRAN," which was the up and coming language of the future. We were appalled at the prospect of lowering ourselves to teach any but the "best" language—assembler—but we finally hit upon a method of keeping our hands free of stain. We taught FORTRAN in parallel with assembler, showing each example developed in both languages. I believe we secretly thought anybody seeing both approaches would naturally choose assembler over the infidel, FORTRAN.

写这本书教会了我们很多东西——我把这些教训带到了我的课堂作业中。最终，我们的方法发展成为一种成熟的方法。该方法不仅可以防止 Jo 的问题，而且还有一些重要的额外好处。

Writing the book taught us many things—lessons I carried over into my classroom work. Eventually our approach was developed into a full-blown method. The method not only prevents Jo's problem but has some important extra benefits.

该方法的本质不是教授一种语言，而是教授一对对 比鲜明的 语言。最初它是汇编程序和 FORTRAN，尽管尝试了许多语言对并且运行良好。最终我选择了 APL 和 PL/I 以获得最大对比度。大多数重要的编程概念都可以使用这两种语言来说明。在 APL 和 PL/I 没有说明概念的情况下，它们至少让学生清楚地了解没有一种语言是“正确”的编程方式。

The essence of the method was teaching not a language, but a contrasting pair of languages. Originally it was assembler and FORTRAN, though many language pairs were tried and worked well. Eventually I settled on APL and PL/I for maximum contrast. Most of the important programming concepts can be illustrated using those two languages. In situations where APL and PL/I don't illustrate a concept, they at least give the student a clear understanding that no single language is the "right" way to program.

1. 每个课堂练习，从一开始就必须用两种语言 进行。

1. Each classroom exercise, right from the beginning, had to be done in both languages.

2. 除了这两个练习，学生还必须提交一份关于为什么程序在两种语言中的结果不同的讨论。在编写这些讨论时，学生经常会“发现”新的编程概念，而不是用任何一种语言。

2. Along with the two exercises the student had to submit a discussion of why the program turns out differently in the two languages. Quite often in writing these discussions, students "discover" new programming concepts not in either language.

3. 在每个练习中，每个学生都复习另一个学生的解决方案。通过复习，学生不仅学习了语言，还学习了不同的编程风格。

3. On each exercise, every student reviewed another student's solution. By reviewing, students learned not only languages, but different programming styles as well.

4. 我们意识到团队编写的程序比个人编写的程序要好得多（当团队运作良好时），所以在前几节课后，我们开始要求以团队的形式解决问题，而不是个人解决问题。早在 1960 年，我们就已经知道专业编程是一项团队运动，我们希望学生们学会成为团队合作者。

4. We realized that team-written programs were much better than individual work (when the team functioned well), so after the first few classes, we began requiring the problems be solved in teams, not by individuals. Back in 1960, we already knew that professional programming is a team sport, and we wanted the students to learn to be team players.

5. 在一个团队的解决方案的课堂展示之后，其他学生被邀请展示解决方案的变体或完全不同的解决方案。当只看自己的作品时，大多数人学得很慢——而且学得很少。在看别人的作品时，他们学得很快，而且学得很深。

5. After a classroom presentation of one team's solution, other students were invited to present variations of the solution or entirely different solutions. When looking only at their own work, most people learned slowly—and learned very little. When looking at the work of others, they learned quickly—and deeply.

当我们在大学里使用这种“双语”方法时，我们避免了乔描述的那种语言沙文主义。第一语言很容易学习。如果您不相信，请听听三岁的中国孩子喋喋不休。第三种语言也很容易，第四种和第十四种几乎是微不足道的。这是 杀死我们的第二个。 当我们使用双语策略时，没有第二语言，只有两种第一语言——所以问题往往会消失。

When we used this "bilingual" method in the university, we avoided the kind of language chauvinism Jo describes. A first language is easy to learn. If you don't believe that, listen to three-year-old Chinese kids chattering up a storm. A third language is easy, too, and the fourth and fourteenth are almost trivial. It's the second one that's killing us. When we use the bilingual strategy, there is no second language, just two first languages—so the problem tends to disappear.

双语策略可以在商业环境中使用吗？是的，如果学生是真正的新手。但是那些已经知道一种语言的人呢？第一步必须是让学生相信他们已经知道的东西对于他们的新环境来说是不够的。

Can the bilingual strategy be used in a commercial environment? Yes, if the students are truly novices. But what about those who already know one language? The first step must be to convince the students what they already know is not sufficient for their new environment.

有几种方法可以说服他们，但我更喜欢以挑战的形式。我们声称一个真正专业的程序员应该能够在两周的自学中掌握一门新的编程语言并变得富有成效。当我们的双语学生完成学业并找到工作时，他们就能够做到这一点。如果学生真的能做到这一点，他们就可以免除正式课程，这就解决了乔的问题。如果他们做不到——他们可能不得不尝试并失败——那么他们就准备好接受双语培训了。

There are several ways to convince them, but the one I prefer is in the form of a challenge. We claim a truly professional programmer should be able to pick up a new programming language and become productive in two weeks of self-study. When our bilingual students finished school and took jobs, they were able to do this. And if students are actually able to do this, they can be excused from the formal class, which solves Jo's problem right there. If they can't—and they may have to try and fail—then they are ready to receive bilingual training.

为了成功地使用这种双语策略，教师最好能够展示多语言能力。事实上，如果老师能够流利地使用学生可能知道的 所有 语言，那将是最好的。（没错，乔，给自己买一本关于 APL 的书，另一本关于 PASCAL 的书。）否则学生会试图通过展示他们的“高超”知识来恐吓你。熟练的老师不会被吓倒，而是会利用这些先验知识并将其转化为每个人的优势。首先承认编程是困难的。解释程序员如何需要他们可以获得的所有帮助，因此来自 任何人的见解 语言对课堂总是有价值的。鼓励学生分享思考课堂问题的方式——他们可能从接触其他语言中学到的方式。每次他们这样分享时，指出它如何说明了解不止一种方法的重要性。

To use this bilingual strategy successfully, the teacher had better be able to demonstrate multilingual proficiency. Indeed, it would be best if the teacher is fluent in all the languages the students might know. (That's right, Jo, get yourself a book on APL, and another on PASCAL.) Otherwise the students will try to intimidate you by displaying their "superior" knowledge. Instead of being intimidated, the proficient teacher will harness this prior knowledge and turn it to everyone's advantage. Start by acknowledging programming is difficult. Explain how programmers need all the help they can get, so insights from any language will always be valuable to the class. Encourage students to share ways of thinking about the class problems—ways they may have learned from their exposure to other languages. Each time they share like this, point out how it illustrates the importance of knowing more than one approach.

起初，一些学生会抱怨 BASIC 没有 COBOL 所缺少的一些“简洁”功能。当发生这种情况时，要坚定地断言，尽管 BASIC 可能会深入了解 COBOL 编程，但它们是来学习成为 专业人士的。 专业人士用指定的语言制作程序，而不是抱怨他们不能完成这项工作的借口。当出现这样的对抗时，我总是用古老的观察来挑战抱怨的学生：“责怪他/她的工具是一个可怜的工人。”

At first, some students will whine about not having some "neat" feature of BASIC that's lacking in COBOL. When this happens, be firm in asserting that although BASIC may give insights into COBOL programming, they are here to learn to be professionals. Professionals produce programs in the assigned language, not whining excuses why they can't do the job. When such confrontations arise, I always challenge the whining student with the ancient observation: "it's a poor worker who blames his/her tools."

教师最想保持的形象是专业人士的形象。您不是在教学生 COBOL，而是在教他们成为可能在不久的将来使用 COBOL 工作的专业程序员。如果他们已经是专业人士，您就不会出现这种第二语言综合症，并且教授必要数量的 COBOL 应该是轻而易举的事。

The image the teacher wants to keep uppermost is that of the professional. You're not teaching the students COBOL, you're teaching them to be professional programmers who might, in the immediate future, work in COBOL. If they are already professionals, you won't have this second-language syndrome, and teaching the requisite amount of COBOL should be a snap.

从业余到专业的转变，老师可以看到解决很多其他问题的方法，比如数据和文件的问题。学生们抛开业余时间，也在从小系统过渡到大系统。这种差异最容易在数据设计和文件中表现出来，但它也会出现在许多其他地方：

In the light of the transition from amateur to professional, the teacher can see the way to solve many other problems, such as the issue of data and files. The students, in leaving their amateur days behind, are also making the transition from small systems to big systems. This difference shows most easily in data design and files, but it also appears in many other places:

1. 我们遇到程序从一个人到另一个人的可交流性问题。

1. We run into the problem of communicability of a program from one person to another.

2. 许多“学校”语言缺乏构建大型系统所需的那些特性。

2. Many of the "school" languages lack just those features needed for constructing large systems.

3. 这些语言无法轻松处理来自多个来源的大量数据。

3. These languages can't readily handle large amounts of data from many sources.

4. 当系统必须由许多不同的人共同工作时，他们也不会成功。

4. Nor do they succeed when the system must be worked on by many different people.

如果您有几个学生都知道一种学校语言，例如 BASIC 或 PASCAL，您可以让他们为一个相对较大的案例问题构造一个并行解决方案。如果您采用生产程序并让他们将其翻译成他们最喜欢的语言，他们会学到很多东西。最重要的是，他们会了解到专业程序员必须比业余程序员灵活得多。

If you have several students who know one school language, such as BASIC or PASCAL, you might have them construct a parallel solution to a relatively large case problem. If you take a production program and have them translate it into their favorite language, they'll learn many things. Most of all, they'll learn a professional programmer must be much more flexible than an amateur.

想打板球的蟋蟀：一个寓言

The Cricket Who Wanted to Play Cricket: A Fable

一天晚上，一只 相当年轻而浮躁的蟋蟀坐在他的炉边，听一些人讨论英格兰和澳大利亚之间的测试赛。 他不知道英格兰是什么，更不用说澳大利亚了，因为他经常在地理课上逃学，但当他听到板球 这个词时，他就非常注意了。他发现板球是一项非常受重视的活动，因此他立即决定这一定是他的命运。他还了解到这场精彩的比赛将于下周四在伯恩茅斯开始，尽管他知道星期四是哪一天，但他对伯恩茅斯的位置一无所知。所以他立即动身去见他的地理教授。

A rather young and impetuous cricket was sitting on his hearth one evening, listening to some people discussing the test matches between England and Australia. He didn't know what England was, let alone Australia, for he usually played hooky from his geography class, but he paid a lot of attention when he heard the word cricket being bandied about. He figured out that cricket was a very highly regarded activity, and so he immediately decided that this must be his destiny. He also learned that the great match was to begin the following Thursday at Bournemouth and, although he knew what Thursday was, he didn't have any idea where Bournemouth might be. so he set off immediately to see his geography professor.

教授很高兴看到他最穷的学生产生了兴趣，但是当他发现蟋蟀为什么对地理感兴趣时，至少可以说他很失望。“听着，小伙子，”他说，无法摆脱他对学生一贯采用的居高临下的语气。（那种居高临下的语气是这只蟋蟀无法上学的原因之一 。 ） cricket 这个名字的词源并不确定，它可能是 wicket 这个词的变体。 另一方面，你的名字不是词源学的问题，而是昆虫学的问题。因此，你想打板球的愿望只是一个拼写错误的结果，如果你受过更好的教育，那肯定会消失。为什么不留在你有权享受免费教育的地方呢？与在运动场上冒险相比，这样的教育肯定会更好地为您服务，而且成本更低。”

The professor was delighted to see a spark of interest in his poorest pupil, but when he found out why the cricket was interested in geography he was disappointed, to say the least. "Look here, young fellow," he said, unable to drop the patronizing tone he always adopted with students. (That patronizing tone was one of the reasons the cricket could not abide school.) "Look here. If you think you are cut out for playing cricket because you happen to be a cricket, you are making a serious error in scholarship. Although the etymology of the name cricket is not known for certain, it is probably a corruption of the word wicket. Your name, on the other hand, is not a matter of etymology, but one of entomology. Thus, your desire to play cricket is merely the result of a spelling error and would surely disappear if you were better educated. Why not stay here where you are entitled to a free education? Such an education would certainly serve you better and cost less than adventures on the playing fields."

但是蟋蟀对这种奖学金没有耐心。因此，在提取了他想要的关于伯恩茅斯的信息后，他立即出发前往计划于下周四开始的行动（因为蟋蟀的速度并不快）。的确，当他到达时，比赛已经开始，澳大利亚队正在击球。他没有在观众中坐下，而是立即开始将自己置于行动的中心，似乎靠近场地中央设置的一些木桩。由于他个子很小，他能够在不影响比赛的情况下够到树桩，但由于他的体型，他无法看清发生了什么。他对板球一无所知——至少不知道什么是三柱门——他决定爬到树桩上以获得更好的视野。

But the cricket had no patience for this kind of scholarship. So, after extracting the information he wanted about Bournemouth, he set off immediately for the action scheduled to begin next Thursday (for crickets don't travel very fast). Indeed, by the time he arrived, the match had already begun, and Australia was batting. Rather than take a seat among the spectators, he set out immediately to put himself into the center of the action, which seemed to be close to some wooden stumps set up in the middle of the field. As he was very small, he was able to reach the stumps without disturbing the match, but because of his size he was not able to see very well what was going on. Not knowing anything about cricket—least of all what a wicket was—he decided to climb up on top of the stumps to obtain a better view.

因此，当英国投球手击败最好的澳大利亚击球手时，他恰好坐在三柱门上。当检票口从树桩上掉下来，把倒霉的蟋蟀带到地上时，人群中爆发出巨大的欢呼声。蟋蟀自然而然地认为这是为他欢呼，但他并没有享受多久，因为膝盖骨折的疼痛很快使他失去了知觉。等他醒来时，天已经黑了，一天的戏结束了。在漫长、寒冷、痛苦的归途中，蟋蟀自言自语道：“能有人群为我的勇敢坠落而欢呼，那感觉真是太棒了，但我想我还是放弃蟋蟀吧，因为我已经达到了巅峰。的成功。”

And thus he happened to be sitting on top of the wicket when the English bowler stumped the best Australian batsman. As the wicket tumbled off the stumps, carrying the hapless cricket to a hard knock on the ground, an enormous cheer went up from the crowd. The cricket naturally thought the cheer was for him, but he didn't enjoy it for long, as the pain of his broken knee soon rendered him unconscious. When he awoke, it was already dark and the day's play was finished. All through the long, cold, and painful journey home, the cricket thought to himself, "It was certainly a marvelous feeling to have the crowd cheering my brave fall, but I think I will give up cricket, as I have already reached the pinnacle of success."

道德：艰苦的学校学费昂贵，但有些人不会在任何便宜的学校学习。

Moral: The school of hard knocks has a dear tuition, but some won't learn in any cheaper school.

想打棒球的蟋蟀：一个寓言

The Cricket Who Wanted to Play Baseball: A Fable

从他的蟋蟀受伤中恢复过来，蟋蟀无法做其他事情，参加了他的地理课。在那里，他了解了美国，那里的国家比赛不是板球，而是板球的衍生品，叫做棒球。没有学术倾向，尽管他有经验，但他很快就向往遥远的地方，并且对人群的欢呼声比膝盖的疼痛更清楚，他一有能力就动身前往美国再次跳跃。

Recovering from his cricket injuries, the cricket, not being able to do much else, attended his geography class. There he learned about America, where the national game was not cricket, but a derivative of cricket called baseball. Not being of a scholarly bent, and in spite of his experiences, he soon took a longing for faraway places and, remembering the roar of the crowd much better than the pain in his knee, he set off for America as soon as he was able to jump once again.

“我相信我会为勇士队效力，”他在漫长的旅途中自言自语，“因为我确实在英格兰的板球场上展示了我的勇敢。另一方面，我必须提防红雀队，因为每个人知道红衣主教喜欢用蟋蟀做什么。” 所以，最后，在勇士队和巨人队之间的一场重要比赛的下午，他来到了勇士队体育场。

"I believe I shall play for the Braves," he thought to himself during the long journey, "for I have certainly demonstrated my bravery on the cricket fields of England. On the other hand, I must be wary of the Cardinals, for everyone knows what Cardinals like to do with crickets." And so, finally, he found himself in Braves Stadium on the afternoon of a big game between the Braves and the Giants.

仍然渴望成为行动的中心，他拒绝在看台上坐下，而是直接走向本垒。“这一次，”他想，“我会远离树桩，靠近地面。我可能看不太清楚，但防患于未然。” 因此，他选择了他能找到的最平坦的座位，恰好是本垒板本身。

Still longing to be in the center of the action, he refused to take a seat in the grandstand but went directly toward home plate. "This time," he thought, "I will stay off the stumps, and near to the ground. I may not be able to see so well, but forewarned is forearmed." Thus he betook himself of the flattest seat he could find, which happened to be home plate itself.

在那里，他一直很安全，直到第 9 局下半时，比分打平，一名跑垒员试图从二垒单打得分。比赛势均力敌：球、接球手和跑垒员都在一团尘土中到达本垒，当裁判大喊“安全”时，人群中响起了巨大的欢呼声。许多小时后，当他躺在空荡荡的体育场的本垒板上时，那声咆哮仍在蟋蟀的耳边回响——这次他的双膝都骨折了。“我选择了艰难的生活，”他想，“但说到底，得到这样的掌声，难道不值得吗？”

There he was safe enough until the bottom of the ninth inning when, with the score tied, a runner tried to score from second base on a single. The play was close: the ball, the catcher, and the runner all arrived at home plate in a single cloud of dust and, as the umpire shouted "Safe," an enormous roar arose from the crowd. That roar was still echoing in the cricket's ears many hours later, as he lay on home plate in the empty stadium—this time with both knees broken. "It's a hard life I've chosen," he thought, "but after all is said and done, isn't it worth it, to have such applause?"

道德：经验不一定教任何东西。

Moral: Experience doesn't necessarily teach anything.

第三章 为什么程序员会这样做？

Chapter III Why Do Programmers Behave the Way They Do?

个人化学与健康的身体

Personal Chemistry and the Healthy Body

许多IT 专业人士都渴望成为高管，但每次晋升失败时都感到困惑。也许问题出在他们的“个人化学反应”上。

Many IT professionals aspire to executive careers yet are mystified each time they are passed over for promotion. Perhaps the problem is in their "personal chemistry."

我有一份剪报引用了猎头公司 Handy Associates 总裁 J. Gerald Simmons 的话。（抛开你对那些使用名字首字母和中间名的人的偏见，比如 J. Edgar Hoover 或 G. Marvin Weinberg，听听他的看法。）西蒙斯强调“个人化学”在选择其他同样合格的候选人时的重要性. 个人化学的成分包括外表、个性、风格、口齿伶俐、活力、态度、体贴、沉着、闪耀、广泛的兴趣和领导光环。这些令人向往的品质听起来有点像童子军法，但我们不要放弃。

I have a newspaper clipping quoting J. Gerald Simmons, president of Handy Associates, an executive search firm. (Put aside your prejudice against people who use their first initial and middle name, like J. Edgar Hoover or G. Marvin Weinberg, and hear the man out.) Simmons emphasizes the importance of "personal chemistry" in choosing among otherwise equally qualified candidates. Among the ingredients of personal chemistry are appearance, personality, style, articulateness, energy, attitude, thoughtfulness, composure, sparkle, breadth of interest, and an aura of leadership. These desirable qualities sound a bit like the Boy Scout Law, but let's not give up yet.

西蒙斯断言，个人化学反应是可以培养的，这给渴望成为高管的陷入困境的大众带来了希望。但他关于如何开发这种化学物质的建议往往带有假币的假象。例如：

Simmons asserts personal chemistry can be developed, lending hope to the troubled masses yearning to be executives. But his advice on how to develop this chemistry often has the ersatz ring of a counterfeit coin. For instance:

外貌： 明显肥胖或极度消瘦是负面标志。（建议：减肥或增重。）

Appearance: Conspicuous obesity or extreme emaciation are negative marks. (Advice: lose or gain weight.)

精力、干劲、雄心： 培养快步、清新的外表和极好的身体健康的基调。

Energy, drive, ambition: Cultivate the quick stride, fresh appearance, and tone of superb physical health.

沉着冷静： 咬指甲的人、头发缠绕的人、脚踏实地的人、老抽烟的人或颤抖的人很少能通过一次面试。（建议：尽量消除分散注意力的习惯。）

Composure: The nail-biter, hair-twirler, foot-tapper, chain-smoker, or twitcher rarely gets past one interview. (Advice: try to eliminate distracting habits.)

领袖气场： 身姿挺拔、昂首挺胸、举止和蔼、眼神交流、有一定的自信，都具有领袖气质。

Aura of leadership: An erect carriage, a head held high, an agreeable manner, eye contact, and a certain amount of self-confidence connote leadership qualities.

当我读到这些文章时，我想起了妈妈唠叨我“坐直”或老师吼叫“不要嚼口香糖”。这些建议，在我看来，似乎一点用处都没有。担心自己是否散发出领导光环很容易让你咬指甲、塞满嘴巴，或者简单地让你精神崩溃。

When I read such items, I'm reminded of my mother nagging me to "sit up straight" or my teacher bellowing "don't chew gum." The advice, when given, seems to me to be less than useless. Worrying about whether you emit an aura of leadership is apt to drive you to nail-biting, mouth-stuffing, or simple mind-squashing.

然而毫无疑问西蒙斯是正确的。我们都喜欢和长相漂亮、精力充沛但沉着冷静、随和的人在一起。问题是如果像我一样，你不是那样的话该怎么办。

Yet there's no doubt Simmons is correct. We'd all prefer to be in the presence of people who are nice-looking, energetic but composed, and agreeable. The problem is what to do about it if, like me, you're not that way.

如果你对生活感到沮丧，世界上最简单的事情就是吸引建议：“不要沮丧。”

If you're depressed about life, the easiest thing in the world is to attract advice: "Don't he depressed."

或者你肥胖吗？那么这个建议怎么样：“不要吃那么多。”

Or are you obese? Then how about this advice: "Don't eat so much."

Ambrose Bierce 将建议定义为“最小的当前硬币”。建议通常是免费的——而且物有所值。在我看来，大多数关于“个人化学”或其他成功公式的建议只会掩盖真正幸福和成功的极少数深层原则。 伯特兰·罗素 (Bertrand Russell) 在他的经典著作《征服幸福》(The Conquest of Happiness) 中写到了这些，我每年都会重读这本书，让自己回到简单的轨道上。我说“尝试”是因为我的副本总是被借出并且往往不会归还。（注意：现在我在家里或办公室找不到副本，但罗素的第一点不需要任何提醒。

Ambrose Bierce defined advice as "the smallest current coin." Advice is usually free—and worth every penny. To my mind, most of the advice about "personal chemistry" or other success formulas merely serves to becloud the very few deep principles of true happiness and success. Bertrand Russell wrote about these in his classic book The Conquest of Happiness, a book I try to reread every year to restore me to the simple track. I say "try" because my copies are always out on loan and tend not to return. (Note: Just now I can't find a copy around the house or office, but Russell's number-one point doesn't need any reminding.

根据罗素（也许是我们这个时代最伟大的哲学家）的说法，在产生幸福方面， 健康 高于一切。或许情况恰恰相反——缺乏健康会破坏任何其他有希望取得成功的公式。想想西蒙斯的“个人化学反应”。如果你很健康，你就不会看起来肥胖或消瘦。你的步伐自然会很快。无需用一千种难以发音的成分喷洒身体，您就会看起来和闻起来清新。您可能不会咬指甲、捻头发、踢脚或敲击手指。你会很少抽搐，可能根本不会抽烟。你会坐直，而且你可能不会因为消化午餐没有困难而看起来像是在消化午餐。

According to Russell, perhaps the greatest philosopher of our times, health comes before all else in producing happiness. Or perhaps it goes the other way—lack of health destroys any other formula promising success. Consider Simmons's "personal chemistry." If you're healthy, you won't look obese or emaciated. Your stride will naturally be quick. You'll look and smell fresh without spraying your body with a thousand unpronounceable ingredients. You'll probably not bite nails, twirl hair, tap your foot, or drum your fingers. You'll do very little twitching and probably no smoking at all. You'll sit up straight and you probably won't look like you're having trouble digesting your lunch simply because you're not having trouble digesting your lunch.

巧合的是，根据现代观点，健康在很大程度上取决于身体化学（吃什么）和活动（做什么）。如果是这样，那么也许“个人化学”只不过是“真正的”化学和物理——你能学到的最基本的东西。但是，与其给你建议，不如让我简单地讲一些故事。

By curious coincidence, according to the modern view, health is largely a matter of body chemistry (you are what you eat) and activity (you are what you do). If so, then perhaps "personal chemistry" is no more than "real" chemistry and physics—about as basic as you can get. But rather than give you advice, let me simply relate some stories.

我们都知道 Gary Gulper，他是一个专注于用垃圾食品填满自己脸的程序员。他认为自己在午餐时间工作，只吃一块糖果和自动售货机的可乐，以此来给老板留下深刻印象。

We all know a Gary Gulper, the dedicated programmer who's dedicated mostly to stuffing his face with junk food. He thinks he's impressing the boss by working through lunch and eating only a candy bar and a Coke from the vending machine.

然后是苏珊·西特 (Susan Sitter)——她成功的秘诀是每天工作 16 小时，希望老板能在她因缺乏锻炼而死或因屁股上的老茧而行动不便之前注意到她。

Then there's Susan Sitter—her secret formula for success is to work sixteen hours a day, hoping the boss will notice before she dies for lack of exercise or is immobilized from calluses on the butt.

我很熟悉这些人，因为我展示了他们所有的品质。我们分享的是对我们工作的诚实奉献——如此多的奉献，我们会在必要时滥用自己的身体来完成工作。现在，诚实的奉献并没有错——除非它发展到破坏我们有效工作能力的地步。如果加班加班导致我们的工作质量下降，那还有什么意义呢？为什么要跳过午餐去吃块糖来完成一项我们在大脑得到适当营养和身体放松的情况下可以更快完成的任务呢？

I'm well acquainted with such people because I display all their qualities. What we share is an honest dedication to our work—so much dedication we abuse our own bodies, if necessary, to finish the work. Now there's nothing wrong with honest dedication—until it's carried to the point where it destroys our ability to work effectively. What's the sense of working over-over-overtime if in so doing we cause the quality of our work to deteriorate? Why skip lunch for a candy bar to accomplish a task we'd accomplish much more quickly with a properly nourished brain and relaxed body?

好吧，让我们对自己诚实。 偶尔虐待我们的身体很有趣。 谁能诚实地否认糖果盛宴、狂饮狂欢或通宵狂欢的诱惑？所以，因为我们可以说我们这样做是出于对工作的奉献，所以我们有一个完美的借口来满足我们内心深处的愿望。此外，一点点过度不会伤害任何人，不是吗？有时这份工作确实需要全力以赴、自我牺牲的努力。正确的？

Well, let's be honest with ourselves. It's fun to abuse our bodies once in a while. Who can honestly deny the seductiveness of a candy feast, a beverage binge, or an all-night work orgy? So, because we can argue we're doing it out of dedication to our work, we have a perfect excuse for fulfilling our innermost desires. And besides, a little excess never hurt anyone, did it? And sometimes the job really does require an all-out, self sacrificing effort. Right?

好吧，道德说教来了。太多的专业人士——包括我——养成了为工作牺牲身体的习惯。他们在年轻时养成了这种习惯，那时他们的身体更有弹性。然后有一天，他们发现自己的身体不再像以前那样迅速或轻松地恢复原状。但是当他们发现这种缺陷时，通常为时已晚，原因如下：

Okay, so here comes the moralizing. Too many professionals—including me—develop the habit of sacrificing their bodies to their work. They develop this habit when they are young, when their bodies are much more resilient. Then one day they discover their bodies don't snap back as quickly or as easily as they once did. But when they discover this deficiency, it's usually far too late, for several reasons:

1. 习惯根深蒂固，不容易改掉。

1. The habit is too ingrained to be gotten rid of easily.

2. 在严重到让他们注意到之前，缺陷已经存在了很长时间。但其他人早就注意到了，所以他们的职业生涯已经受到了影响。

2. The deficiency has existed for a long time before it's bad enough for them to notice. But others have been noticing for a long time, so their career has already suffered.

3. 他们太老了，无法轻易学习新习惯。

3. They're too old to learn new habits readily.

4. 他们的健康问题可能成倍增加，我们都知道处理两个相互作用的系统错误是多么困难。

4. The troubles with their health are likely to multiply, and we all know how hard it is to deal with two interacting system errors.

5. 即使他们开始减少过度的工作量并花时间进行适当的饮食和锻炼，结果也不会立即出现——这意味着直接的影响是工作产出减少，并可能失去工作或 职位。

5. Even if they do start cutting back on excessive workloads and spending time on proper eating and exercise, the results won't be immediately forthcoming—which means the immediate effect is less output at work and possible loss of job or position.

这一切听起来像是在说教。我知道，因为我年轻的时候肯定是这么想的，年长的人告诉我这样的话。在某些情况下，道德只是阻止你为了短期幸福而牺牲长期幸福的智慧。因为当我们的健康恶化时，我们的大脑是第一个退化的器官，所以我们需要一些 关于健康的简单道德。 我们不仅感觉不好，而且我们无法用大脑解决感觉不好的问题，因为它也感觉不好。但是因为它有麻烦了，大脑不太可能知道它有麻烦了。当大脑开始出现问题时，主人总是最后知道的。

All this sounds like moralizing. I know, because I certainly thought so when I was young and older people told me such things. In some cases, morality is simply wisdom that stops you from sacrificing long-term happiness for short-term happiness. Because our brain is the first organ to degrade when our health deteriorates, we need some simple morals about health. We not only feel bad, but we can't apply our brain to the problem of feeling bad because it's feeling bad too. But because it's in trouble, the brain is unlikely to know it's in trouble. When the brain starts to falter, the owner is always the last to know.

然而，当道德凝结成其目的早已被遗忘的规则时，它就失败了。有趣的是，道德就像 IT 标准一样。我不认为人们应该出于他们不理解的原因做事——比如看起来健康、吃菠菜或避免使用 GO TO 语句。没有理由的规则注重事物的 表象 ，而不是实质。这就是为什么我从来不敢建议人们尝试通过在表面上工作来改善他们的个人化学反应。

Morality fails, though, when it congeals into rules whose purpose has long been forgotten. Interestingly, morality is just like IT standards. I don't believe people should do things for reasons they don't understand—things like looking healthy, eating spinach, or avoiding GO TO statements. Rules without reasons focus on the appearance of things, not the substance. That's why I'd never dare suggest people try to improve their personal chemistry by working on the surface.

相反，我提倡在表面之下工作。所有细节的基础是一个简单的观察：

Instead, I advocate working underneath the surface. Underlying all the details is a simple observation:

许多专业人士过于专注于他们的工作，以至于破坏了他们的健康——他们“个人化学”的真正实质。

Many professional people become so devoted to their work they destroy their health—the true substance of their "personal chemistry."

一旦你理解了这个概念，就有许多通往健康的道路；但我不会对你行医。我是另一种医生。我是那种治愈 组织的医生，组织可以采取一些步骤来建立健康的健康氛围。我建议信息处理经理通过以下方式为员工树立好榜样

Once you understand this concept there are many paths to health; but I won't practice medicine on you. I'm a different kind of doctor. I'm the kind of doctor who heals organizations, and there are steps an organization can take to establish a healthy climate for health. I advise information-processing managers to set a good example for their employees by

1.大部分 时间按正常时间工作

1. working regular hours most of the time

2. 花时间适当地吃东西，以免设定一个标准来完成工作或匆忙吃完午餐（或晚餐，如果你违反了第一条规则）

2. taking time to eat properly, so as not to set a standard of working through or hurrying through lunch (or supper, if you're violating rule number 1)

3. 永远不要奖励工作时间过长或不吃饭的人

3. never rewarding people for working excessive hours or for skipping meals

4.奖励组织得很好的人在正常的一天完成正常的一天的工作

4. rewarding people for being sufficiently well organized to finish a normal day's work in a normal day

为了工作而工作或为了别人的看法而工作的模式太容易了。但是您可以通过提醒自己您的身体是您的头号专业设备来打破这些模式。如果它倒塌了，国王的所有马匹和国王的所有士兵都无法重新启动并运行。事实上，我什至怀疑 IBM 的现场工程师是否会对你有多大帮助。

It's all too easy to adopt the patterns of work for work's sake or work for the sake of how it looks to others. But you can break these patterns by reminding yourself your body is your number-one piece of professional equipment. If it goes down, all the king's horses and all the king's men can't get it up and running again. In fact, I doubt whether even IBM's field engineers would do you much good.

程序员需要什么才能改变

What a Programmer Needs in Order to Change

温伯格双胞胎定律

Weinbergs' Law of Twins

曾几何时，我写了一本名为《 计算机程序设计心理学》的书。 虽然这本书让我变得富有和出名，但 书名中的心理学这个词让很多人认为我是一名心理学家。 我想纠正这个严重的错误，现在。

Once upon a time, I wrote a book entitled The Psychology of Computer Programming. Although the book has made me rich and famous, the word psychology in the title makes many people consider me a psychologist. I'd like to correct this gross mistake, right now.

我没有心理学家的证书。我没有心理学学位。我无法治愈抑郁症，甚至是轻微的盗窃癖。事实上，当我上大学时，我刻意避免参加 任何 心理学课程，甚至避免与心理学教授见面。

I have no certification as a psychologist. I have no degree in psychology. I can't cure a case of depression or even a mild case of kleptomania. In fact, when I went to college, I studiously avoided taking any psychology course or even being seen with a psychology professor.

坦率地说，我一直怀疑整个心理学领域有 50% 的错误和 50% 的虚假。然而，随着我的成熟，我开始更加尊重 一些 心理学家的工作。最终，我开始意识到他们向公众推销自己是多么困难的工作。毕竟，每个调酒师都是人类行为方面的专家，不需要任何执照、学位、课程、书籍或培训——而且没有一个调酒师会为 50 分钟一小时收取 1,000 美元的费用。

Quite frankly, I always suspected that entire field of psychology was 50 percent error and 50 percent fake. As I matured, however, I began to have more respect for the work of some psychologists. Eventually, I came to appreciate what a difficult job they have selling themselves to the public. After all, every bartender is an expert in human behavior, without any license, degree, course, book, or training—and no bartender charges $1,000 for a fifty-minute hour.

事实上，大多数人类行为都非常容易预测。我们从气象学家那里了解到一个有趣的事实：三分之二的情况下，您可以通过说明天的天气与今天的天气相同来正确预测明天的天气。这一事实使每个人都成为天气专家——只有 66% 是正确的。想象一下有多少心理学专家，我们可以预测 99% 的人类行为——用一个叫做温伯格双胞胎定律的简单定律。

Indeed, most of human behavior is ridiculously simple to predict. From meteorologists we learn an interesting fact: two-thirds of the time you can predict tomorrow's weather correctly by saying it will be the same as today's. This fact makes everyone an expert on the weather—with only 66 percent correct. Imagine how many experts there are in psychology, where we can predict 99 percent of human behavior—with a simple law called Weinbergs' Law of Twins.

你的心理学教授从来没有教过你温伯格双胞胎定律，但你必须原谅他们。没有人愿意泄露专业秘密。如果你知道心理学课程只涵盖了该主题的 1%，而你可以在一分钟内轻松学习其余部分，你还会参加吗？

Your psychology professors never taught you Weinbergs' Law of Twins, but you must forgive them. Nobody wants to give away professional secrets. Would you take psychology courses if you knew they covered only 1 percent of the subject and you could learn the rest in one painless minute?

像许多真正伟大的法律一样，这部法律的开端最卑微。温伯格一家坐在 14 路公共汽车上。在冬季高峰时段的黑暗中前往百老汇，当时一位憔悴但漂亮的年轻女子带着八个孩子登机。

Like many truly great laws, this one had the most humble beginnings. The Weinbergs were sitting on the Number 14 bus. heading up Broadway in the gloom of a winter rush hour, when a haggard but pretty young woman boarded with eight children in tow.

“费用多少？” 她问司机。

"How much is the fare?" she asked the driver.

“成人三十五美分，五岁以下儿童免费。” （价格告诉你这是多久以前发生的。）

"Thirty-five cents for adults, and children under five ride free." (The price tells you how long ago this happened.)

“好吧，”她说，把她抱在怀里的两个最小的孩子中的一个移开，这样她就可以拿到她的钱包了。她将两枚硬币扔进收费箱，然后带着她的随行人员走下过道。

"Okay," she said, shifting one of the two tiniest kids she carried under her arms, so she could access her purse. She dropped two coins into the fare box and started with her entourage down the aisle.

“请稍等，女士！” 司机发出命令，只有纽约的公交车司机才能做到。“你别指望我相信他们八个孩子都不满五岁！”

"Just a minute, lady!" the driver commanded, as only a New York bus driver can. "You don't expect me to believe that all eight of them children is under five!"

“他们当然是，”她愤愤不平地说。“这两个是四个，女孩是三个，蹒跚学步的孩子是两个，而这些小家伙是一个。”

"Of course they are," she said indignantly. "These two are four, the girls are three, the toddlers are two, and these little ones are one."

司机目瞪口呆，满脸歉意。“哎呀女士，对不起。你 总是 生双胞胎吗？”

The driver was dumbfounded and apologetic. "Gee lady, I'm sorry. Do you always have twins?"

“哦，不，”她说，设法拉直了一缕棕色的头发。“大多数时候我们没有 。”

"Oh, no," she said, managing to straighten a wisp of brown hair. "Most of the time we don't have any."

就在那儿，一闪而过，同时出现在我们俩面前。大多数时候，对于世界上的大多数系统来说，没有任何重要的事情发生。事实上，如果你前一分钟再看下一分钟，大多数时候你会看到几乎完全相同的东西。对于任何类型的大多数系统，您可以对下一时刻做出的最佳预测是它们将按照它们在前一时刻所做的事情进行操作。

And there it was, in a flash, to both of us at once. Most of the time, for most systems in the world, nothing of any significance happens. Indeed, if you look one minute and then look the next, most of the time you see almost exactly the same thing. For most systems of any kind, the best prediction you can make for the next instant of time is they will be doing just what they were doing in the previous instant of time.

不用说，丹妮和我都很高兴。发现了必须成为所有定律中最重要的东西，超越了任何学科、数学和哲学本身的发现，从而确保了我们的名声。然后，就像兴高采烈一样突然，忧郁降临了。 因为尽管新法律确实重要到足以冠以温伯格定律的名称，但它就像早期的温伯格定律一样，是关于双胞胎生育频率的 定律。因此，它不能被赋予其正确的名称：温伯格双胞胎定律。这个专有名词早已载入科学史册。

Needless to say, Dani and I were elated. Our fame was assured by the discovery of what had to become the most important of all laws, transcending the discoveries of any discipline, of mathematics, of philosophy itself. And then, just as suddenly as the elation had come, gloom descended. For although the new law was certainly important enough to carry the name Weinbergs' Law, it was, like an earlier Weinbergs' Law, a law about the frequency of twin births'. It could not, therefore, be given its proper name: Weinbergs' Law of Twins. This proper name was already inscribed in the history of science.

我们非常伤心，以至于多年来我们没有告诉任何人我们的法律。当我们终于鼓起勇气时，我们的朋友们只是笑了笑。“为什么不傻，”他们责备我们。“你可以遵循许多先例。为什么，想想牛顿的第一和第二运动定律。”

We were heartbroken, so much so we didn't tell anybody about our law for many years. When we finally screwed up the courage, our friends merely laughed. "Why don't be silly," they chided us. "There are any number of precedents you can follow. Why, just think of Newton's First and Second Laws of Motion."

因此，我们重生了登上科学英灵殿的机会。在那里，刻在某个大理石宝座上的是温伯格双胞胎定律和温伯格双胞胎第二定律。撇开花哨的数学不谈，在一般系统术语中，双胞胎第一定律说：

And so our chance for ascending to the Valhalla of Science was reborn. There, etched in some marble throne, are Weinbergs' Law of Twins and Weinbergs' Second Law of Twins. Leaving aside the fancy mathematics, in general systems terms the First Law of Twins says:

在所有的出生中，双胞胎是非常罕见的，三胞胎更是少之又少。

Among all births, twin births are pretty rare, and triplets are rarer still.

第二定律——我们的 定律——说：

The Second Law—our Law—says:

尽管双胞胎出生在所有出生中是罕见的，但出生本身几乎比没有出生要罕见得多。

Even though twin births are rare among all births, births themselves are almost infinitely rarer than no births at all.

与牛顿运动定律一样，这里的第二定律，如果我们必须自己这么说的话，是两者中更重要的一个，尽管第二这个词有任何含义 。 这很重要，因为它确实可以预测 99% 的人类行为，以及大约相同数量的其他系统的行为。想想美国的普通女性。她活到 70.7 岁，生了 2.1 个孩子。这意味着在她生命中随机选择的任何一天，她分娩的几率都低于 0.01%。（当然，对于男性来说，几率更低。）另一方面，如果她 真的 在某一天分娩，她生双胞胎或更好的几率约为 1.5%。因此，第二定律至少比第一定律强大一百倍。

As with Newton's laws of motion, the Second I.aw here, if we must say so ourselves, is by far the more important of the two, in spite of any implications of the word second. It is important because it does indeed predict 99 percent of human behavior, and about the same amount of the behavior of other systems as well. Consider the average woman in the United States. She lives to be 70.7 years and gives birth to 2.1 children. This means that on any day of her life, chosen at random, her chance of giving birth at all is less than .01 percent. (For men, of course, the odds are even lower.) On the other hand, if she does give birth on a certain day, her chance of having twins or better is about 1.5 percent. Therefore, the Second Law is at least 100 times more powerful than the first.

由于某些我们不明白的原因，我们并没有像我们预期的那样出名。似乎大多数人都声称已经知道这条定律，尽管没有人可以参考权威期刊上的出版物。也许人们对法律的期望太高了。人们需要对社会连续性的 解释 ，而不仅仅是宣布其普遍性的法律。好吧，事实证明，解释这种现象并不是那么容易。如果我们要解释为什么大多数时候什么都没有发生，那将需要一整本书，然后是一些。

For some reason we don't understand, we haven't become as famous as we expected. It seems most people claim to have known this law already, though nobody can give reference to a publication in a respectable journal. Perhaps people expect too much of a law. People want an explanation of social continuity, not just a law proclaiming its universality. Well, as it turns out, explaining this phenomenon is not so easy. If we're going to explain why most of the time nothing much happens, it will take a whole book, and then some.

Dani Weinberg 和我在我们的书中进行了解释： 被动 调节：通用系统设计原则 （我们通用系统系列的第 2 卷）和 主动调节：通用系统设计原则 （第 3 卷）。 我不会在这里重复我们的解释。相反，我将研究这种社会连续性对那些试图改进专业程序员开发计算机应用程序的方式的人的一些影响。

Dani Weinberg and I have undertaken the explanation in our books: Passive Regulation: General Systems Design Principles (Volume 2 of our General Systems Series) and Active Regulation: General Systems Design Principles (Volume 3). I won't attempt to repeat our explanations here. Instead, I'll examine some of the consequences of this social continuity for those who are trying to improve the way a professional programmer develops computer applications.

惯性第一定律

The First Law of Inertia

一旦你明白不变是规则，改变是罕见的例外，你就会开始怀疑：如果不变如此普遍，它怎么会发生任何变化呢？这个问题是理解变化的一个很好的起点。你必须开始将变化视为美妙、罕见且值得观察的事物。如果您想掌握富有成效的变革的艺术，就必须停止将变革视为理所当然。

Once you understand non-change is the rule, and change the rare exception, you begin to wonder: If non-change is so universal, how does it happen anything changes at all? This question is an excellent starting point for understanding change. You must begin to see change as something wonderful, rare, and worth observing. You must stop taking change for granted if you wish to master the art of productive change.

但人们确实认为改变是理所当然的。如果不改变是规则，而改变是例外，那怎么可能呢？显然，变化对我们来说并不陌生。当我们了解最常见的变革原因时——变革的原因并不少见——我们就在掌握变革的道路上走得很好。

But people do take change for granted. If non-change is the rule, and change is the exception, how can this be? Evidently, change is not so rare it's foreign to us. When we understand the most common reasons for change—the reasons change isn't a rare experience—we're well along the path of mastering change.

想象你是一名职业高尔夫球手——最好的球员之一。假设您在奖金榜上排名第 14 位，每年的奖金约为 387,000 美元，外加同等金额的代言和边注。进一步想象一下，您已经掌握了自己的技术，可以非常连贯地演奏。在一个又一个的锦标赛中，在一个又一个的球场上，你的总成绩在四轮比赛中都接近标准杆。

Imagine you are a professional golfer—one of the best. Let's say you are fourteenth on the money list, earning about $387,000 a year in prize money plus a comparable sum in endorsements and side bets. Imagine further you have mastered your technique to the point that you can play with great consistency. In tournament after tournament, on course after course, you finish with a total score near par for four rounds.

现在如果你回顾一下过去几十年的高尔夫胜率，你会发现胜率越来越低。一些体育记者将这一变化归因于更简单的课程。有人说这是改进的设备、更好的技术或更高的奖金，让更好的玩家有更多机会留在游戏中并获得成功的职业生涯。其实这些因素都有，也许还有很多更微妙的因素。

Now if you examine winning golf scores over the past several decades, you'll discover that the winning scores have gradually become lower and lower. Some sportswriters attribute this change to easier courses. Some say it's improved equipment, or better technique, or higher prize money allowing the better players more chances to stay in the game and have a successful career. Actually, all these factors are involved, and perhaps many more subtle factors are involved as well.

但无论出于何种原因，这种趋势仍在继续。因此，如果你的比赛保持绝对稳定，你的职业生涯会发生什么变化？

But whatever the reasons, the trend is continuing. Therefore, if your game remains absolutely constant, what will happen to your professional career?

今年你赢得了 387,000 美元。明年你会赢得什么？显然，如果分数在提高，你的平均成绩就会降低。除非奖金增加，否则您的收入将会减少。此外，您将赢得更少的赌注和获得更少的认可。简而言之，无论 你多么 不变，如果你的环境改变了，你自己的处境也可能会改变。

This year you won $387,000. What will you win next year? Obviously, if scores are improving, your average finish is going to be lower. Unless prize money increases, your income will decrease. Also, you'll win fewer bets and get fewer endorsements. In short, no matter how unchanging you can be, if your environment changes, your own situation will probably change.

如果你开车沿着街道直行，街道变成码头，如果你不改变你的速度或方向，你的环境会为你改变它们。我们称之为 惯性法则：“无法改变最终会导致戏剧性或灾难性的变化。”

If you drive a car straight down the street and the street changes into a pier, and if you don't change your speed or direction, your environment will change them for you. We call this the Law of Inertia: "Inability to change eventually leads to dramatic or catastrophic change."

惯性第二定律

The Second Law of Inertia

在一个不改变最终会导致灾难的世界里，不学会优雅地改变的系统不会持续太久。持久系统已经开发出复杂的技术来抵制变化或将变化引导到更可接受的渠道。

In a world where failure to change eventually leads to catastrophe, systems not learning to change gracefully don't last long. Long-lasting systems have developed sophisticated techniques for resisting change or for steering change into more acceptable channels.

例如，考虑一下当有人试图将新技术介绍给具有既定技能的人时会发生什么。为了避开任何人的脚趾，让我们以职业高尔夫球手为例。现在是淡季，您刚刚赢得了 387,000 美元。您正在与一家体育用品公司的代表共进午餐，他正试图向您推销一套截然不同的全新球杆。该代表声称，使用这些球杆，您可以在比赛中每轮减少一杆。此外，如果您为这些球杆背书，您甚至不必为它们付费。事实上，公司会付给 你 10,000 美元来使用它们。你的反应是什么？

As an example, consider what happens when someone attempts to introduce a new technology to a person with an established skill. To keep clear of anyone's toes, let's stick to the example of the professional golfer. It's the off-season, and you've just won $387,000. You're having lunch with the representative of a sporting goods company who is trying to sell you a new and radically different set of clubs. Using these clubs, the representative claims, you can cut one stroke per round off your game. In addition, if you endorse the clubs, you won't even have to pay for them. Indeed, the company will pay you $10,000 to use them. What's your reaction?

如果你是正常人，你会听一会儿然后拒绝这个提议。他们是谁来告诉你如何改进你的游戏？他们不知道你在奖金榜上排名第十四吗？

If you're the normal person, you'll listen for a while and then refuse the offer. Who are they to tell you how to improve your game? Don't they know you're fourteenth on the money list?

或许你是一个真正开放、富有创新精神的人，愿意尝试任何事情。您要了一套球杆，并在一天清晨将它们带到您的家庭球场进行练习。你注意到俱乐部感觉很奇怪，不平衡。你的挥杆变形了，你开始削球了。几个洞之后，您过度修正了右曲球并将您的发球区击入小溪。你绕过球场，暗自庆幸现在没有人在外面看着你还为时过早。在俱乐部会所，您对卡片进行总计，发现您的得分为 83！高于标准杆十一杆！更糟糕的是，你的信心动摇了，你怀疑你的时机已经被打乱了，即使你回到了你经常去的俱乐部。你打电话给销售代表并礼貌地说，“谢谢，但不用谢。”

Or perhaps you're a truly open, innovative person, willing to give anything a try. You ask for a set of clubs and take them onto your home course early one morning to practice. You notice the clubs feel strange, unbalanced. Your swing is distorted and you start slicing. After a few holes, you've over-corrected the slice and hooked your tee shot into the creek. You hack your way around the course, secretly glad it's too early for anybody to be out watching you. In the clubhouse, you total your card and find you've scored an 83! Eleven over par! Even worse, your confidence is shaken and you suspect your timing has been thrown off even if you go back to your regular clubs. You call the sales rep and say politely, "Thanks, but no thanks."

销售代表已准备好论据：开始时预计会出现轻微恶化。一个赛季，或者可能只有半个赛季，你会比上一场比赛少打几杆，但很快你就会再次低于标准杆。为了使论证具有说服力，代表列出了去年锦标赛的结果，并展示了每轮减少一杆对您有何影响。在三场比赛中，这足以让你成为赢家。总体而言，它会将您的直接收入从 387,000 美元提高到 630,000 美元。多出来的钱不值得一开始有点麻烦吗？

The sales rep has arguments prepared: A little deterioration is to be expected in the beginning. For one season, or maybe only half a season, you'll be off a few strokes from your previous game, but soon you'll be under par again. To make the argument convincing, the rep lays out the results of last year's tournaments and demonstrates what a decrease of one stroke per round would have done for you. In three tournaments, it would have been enough to make you the winner. Overall, it would have raised your direct earnings from $387,000 to $630,000. Isn't the extra money worth a little trouble at the beginning?

但你并没有真正在听。相反，您计算的是每轮增加一划会产生什么影响：您的收入会从 387,000 美元下降到 145,000 美元。更糟糕的是，你不会赢得你赢得的那两个锦标赛，所以你会失去大部分的支持。事实上，如果你没有赢得那两个锦标赛，这位销售代表甚至不会在这里和你交谈。如果你使用这些 cockamamie 俱乐部，你肯定不会赢得任何东西。

But you're not really listening. Instead, you're calculating what an increase of one stroke per round would have done: your earnings would have dropped from $387,000 to $145,000. Even worse, you wouldn't have won the two tournaments you did win, so you'd have lost most of your endorsements. Indeed, this sales rep wouldn't even be here talking to you if you hadn't won those two tournaments. And if you'd used these cockamamie clubs, you surely wouldn't have won anything.

如果体育用品公司了解他们的业务，他们一开始就不会来找您了。相反，他们会选择一些刚刚因为没有参加足够多的比赛而被淘汰出局的职业选手，或者一个根本还没有参加过巡回赛的年轻职业选手。 他们的 收入不是 387,000 美元。事实上，他们今年的净利润可能为负。他们会非常感激这 10,000 美元，但也许他们会更感激这种关注。

If the sporting goods company knew their business, they wouldn't have come to you in the first place. Instead, they'd have picked some pro who's just been dropped from the tour for not making the cut in enough tournaments, or a young pro who hasn't yet made the tour at all. Their income isn't $387,000. In fact, their net is probably negative for the year. They will really appreciate the $10,000, but perhaps they'll appreciate the attention even more.

但最重要的是，即使他们的球技下降几杆，他们的收入也不会下降，因此他们尝试新球杆或任何其他创新不会有什么损失。相反，如果他们确实提高了几杆，那就意味着继续打高尔夫球和成为球童之间的区别。

But most important, they aren't going to suffer a drop in income if their game falls off by a few strokes, so they have little to lose by trying new clubs or any other innovation. Conversely, if they do improve by a few strokes, it means the difference between remaining a golfer and becoming a caddy.

我是否必须阐明与计算机编程的相似之处？还是用我们通常尝试引入一些新技术的方式？让我总结一下我所说的关于两个变化规律的变化：

Do I have to spell out the parallels with computer programming? Or with the way we usually try to introduce some new technique? Let me summarize what I've said about change in two laws of change:

1. 当环境变化迫使人们改变时，人们就会改变。这就是惯性第一定律。

1. People change when forced to change by changes in their environment. This is the First Law of Inertia.

2. 当被迫改变时，人们会努力以牺牲次要的东西为代价来保留对他们来说最重要的东西。这就是惯性第二定律。

2. When forced to change, people struggle to preserve the things that are most important to them at the expense of things that are less important. This is the Second Law of Inertia.

罗默规则

Romer's Rule

惯性第一定律和惯性第二定律哪个更强大？最大和持续时间最长的变化从何而来？这些问题有一个有趣的答案，首先由古生物学家阿尔弗雷德罗默提出来解释他在化石记录中发现的变化。罗默问道：当海洋生物如此适应水而空气对它们有毒时，它们怎么会从水中出来并开始呼吸空气并在陆地上生活呢？

Which is the more powerful force of change, the First Law of Inertia or the Second Law of Inertia? Where do the biggest and longest-lasting changes originate? These questions have an interesting answer, first formulated by paleontologist Alfred Romer to explain the changes he found in the fossil record. Romer asked: How could it happen that sea creatures would come out of the water and begin to breathe air and live on land, when they were so well adapted to the water and the air was poisonous to them?

罗默设想了水中条件变得拥挤的情况。也许由于气候干燥，一个湖泊正在缩小。也许新型鱼类开始在食物竞争中击败旧品种。不管是什么原因，水中的食物有限，因此任何能够从其他来源获得额外食物的物种都会比其他物种更受欢迎。在这种情况下，一个物种可能会不小心采取从水中爬出或跳出水面片刻的做法——可以说是屏住呼吸——以便啃食生长在水边的植物。从其他鱼的角度来看，这个物种正在进入第四维度。从自身来看，

Romer envisioned the situation in which conditions in the water were becoming crowded. Perhaps a lake was shrinking because of a dry turn in the climate. Perhaps new types of fish were beginning to beat the older varieties in the competition for food. Whatever the reason, there was limited food in the water, so any species able to obtain additional food from some other source would be favored over the others. Under such conditions, one species might accidentally adopt the practice of creeping or leaping out of the water for a few moments—holding its breath, so to speak—in order to nibble at the plants growing at the water's edge. From the point of view of the other fish, this species was moving into a fourth dimension. From its own point of view, it was temporarily moving out of its favored environment in order to permanently survive in such an environment.

简而言之，我们最早的陆上爬行祖先是 为了留在水中而从水中出来的。但是，一旦他们迈出那微小的第一步，命运就注定了，他们的一些后代最终到达了以土地而非水为主要环境的地步。那么，这就是罗默法则：

In short, our first land-crawling ancestors came out of the water in order to stay in the water. But once they made that first tiny step, the die was cast, and some of their descendants eventually reached the point where the land, not the water, was their primary environment. This, then, is Romer's Rule:

最大和持续时间最长的变化通常源于试图保护最终变化最大的事物。

The biggest and longest-lasting changes usually originate in attempts to preserve the very thing that ultimately changes most.

信息处理领域充满了罗默法则的例子。大多数公司一开始就开始使用计算机，并不是为了改变他们的业务，而是为了让他们的业务几乎保持原样。例如，随着交易量的增长，旧的交易处理方式开始不堪重负。企业的生命受到威胁，除非它能找到应对增长的方法。一台电脑被带进来，并启动了一系列不可逆转的事件，就像第一条鱼爬出水面啃食蕨类植物所引起的变化一样。

The world of information processing abounds with examples of Romer's Rule. Most companies started using computers in the first place not so their business would change, but so their business would remain pretty much the same as it always had been. For instance, as the volume of transactions grows, old methods of transaction processing begin to collapse under the burden. The life of the business is threatened unless it can develop a method of coping with the increase. A computer is brought in—and sets in motion a chain of events as irreversible as the change caused by the first fish creeping out of the water to nibble a fern.

根据罗默法则，想要管理变革过程的人不会与系统保护自身的尝试作斗争，而是会 利用 这些尝试来实现预期的变革过程。 不改变的 决心通常是最强大的力量。如果直接和它战斗，几乎是必败无疑。如果你利用它来实现你想要的变化，以这样一种方式，系统将努力保留它最看重的东西，你就有合理的成功机会。这是过去的重要教训之一，无论是适用于国家、公司还是同事。

In the light of Romer's Rule, the person who wants to manage the course of change will not fight the system's attempts to preserve itself but will harness those attempts to the desired course of change. The determination not to change is usually the most powerful force available. If you fight it directly, you are almost sure to lose. If you harness it to the changes you want, in such a way so the system will struggle to preserve what it values most, you have a reasonable chance of success. That is one of the great lessons of the past, whether applied to countries, companies, or co-workers.

编程生产力的变化

The Changes in Programming Productivity

让我们把这些想法带回家。在过去的 30 年中，高尔夫的获胜分数以数百杆为单位下降了几杆（可能下降 1% 或 2%），但整个职业比赛已经发生了革命性的变化。在同一时期，计算机的速度和容量发生了 数百万或数十亿的变化。 这些变化对专业计算机人员（程序员）产生了什么影响？

Let's bring these ideas closer to home. In the course of three decades, winning golf scores dropped a few strokes in several hundred (perhaps 1 or 2 percent), yet the entire professional game has been revolutionized. During that same period, the speed and capacity of computers has changed by millions or billions. What must those changes have done to the professional computer person—the programmer?

从表面上看，并没有太大的变化，这就是为什么我们听到断言人类生产力没有提高的原因。我在 1979 年用我的 IBM 5110 进行的一项实验使我确信生产力没有变化是一种错觉，至少在某些情况下是这样。1956 年我离开学校，到旧金山的 IBM 工作。我被允许玩新的 650 电脑自学编程，因为当时没有课。在一些练习题之后，我受委托为我的同事们教授一门编程课程，这是一次最具教育意义的经历——对我来说，如果不是对他们来说的话。然后我有机会编写我的第一个真正的应用程序。我与一位年轻的土木工程师 Lyle Hoag 合作，编写了一个程序来分析水力网络——满足城市用水需求的系统。 美国水务协会杂志。

On the surface, there hasn't been that much change, which is why we hear assertions that human productivity is not increasing. An experiment I performed with my IBM 5110 in 1979 convinced me the lack of change in productivity is an illusion, at least in some cases. In 1956 I left school and went to work for IBM in San Francisco. I was allowed to play with the new 650 computer to teach myself programming, as there were no classes at that time. After a few practice problems, I was commissioned to teach a programming course to my colleagues, a most educational experience—for me, if not for them. Then I had a chance to write my first real application program. Working with a young civil engineer, Lyle Hoag, I wrote a program to analyze hydraulic networks—the systems serving the water needs of a city. Computers were very new (that 650 was the first computer in San Francisco), so the application was a great innovation, worthy of my first publication—in the Journal of the American Water Works Association.

从那时起，我编写了数百个应用程序并协助了数千个，几乎所有这些我都忘记了。但是因为第一个碰巧发表了，我可以在几十年后读到它，并获得关于我当时的生产力方式的非常可靠的信息。

Since that time, I've written hundreds of application programs and assisted on thousands more, almost all of which I've forgotten. But because the first one happened to result in publication, I could read about it decades later and get pretty reliable information about my productivity way back then.

1979 年，我使用我的 5110 和 APL 编程，重现了过去的应用程序，以查看我作为程序员的生产力是否有所提高。1956 年，我们两个人全职工作了四个多星期，外加大量加班来编写和测试我们的系统。23 年后，我用大约两个半小时的时间制作了该程序的第 2 版，生产率提高了 200 多倍。这相当于每年超过 25%，这肯定超过了我所知道的任何其他劳动密集型职业的增长。

In 1979, using my 5110 and programming in APL, I reproduced the application from the past in order to see if my productivity as a programmer had increased. In 1956, two of us had worked more than four weeks full-time plus lots of overtime to write and test our system. Twenty-three years later, I produced version 2 of the program in about two and a half hours of work, an increase in productivity of over 200 times. That amounts to over 25 percent per year, which certainly exceeds the increases in any other labor-intensive occupation I know about.

当然，作为一个整体的编程并没有跟上这 25% 的年增长率，这主要是因为我们不断地从编程队伍中移除或驱逐我们最有生产力的人。而且，这种巨大的改进甚至跟不上计算机本身速度和容量的提高，所以程序员的队伍膨胀了——抹去了任何留下来的优秀老前辈提高的生产力。而更多的程序员意味着更多的管理、更多的沟通损失、更多的开销——所有这些都进一步降低了明显的生产力。最后，我们对旧软件和软件工具的巨大投资已经成为每个程序员在追求提高质量或数量的过程中必须拖延的沉重负担。

Of course, programming as a whole has not kept pace with this 25 percent annual increase, largely because we keep removing or driving our most productive people from the programming ranks. Also, this great improvement hasn't even kept pace with the increased speed and capacity of the computers themselves, so the ranks of programmers have swelled—wiping out the increased productivity of any outstanding old timers who have remained. And larger numbers of programmers means more management, more communications loss, more overhead—all of which further reduce apparent productivity. Finally, our gargantuan investment in old software and software tools has acted as a dead weight each programmer has to drag along in the quest for increasing quality or quantity of output.

如果从不同的角度看待程序员，这一切都不会是什么大问题。正如一位程序员对我说的那样，“为什么我的经理对我的工作效率每年提高 5% 不满意？她的工作效率十年来根本没有提高。”

None of this would be much of a problem if programmers were regarded in a different light. As one programmer expressed it to me, "Why isn't my manager satisfied with a 5 percent increase in my productivity each year? Her productivity hasn't increased at all in ten years."

我向他解释说，经理的生产力是以不同的方式衡量的——通过她所管理的人的生产力。然后他提出了一个非常尖锐的问题：“那么，为什么我的生产力不是以同样的方式衡量的——通过我编写的程序的生产力？” 为什么真的？

I explained to him that a manager's productivity is measured in a different way—by the productivity of the people she manages. He then asked a very penetrating question: "Why, then, isn't my productivity measured in the same way—by the productivity of the programs I write?" Why indeed?

程序员和经理一样，不是直接的生产者，而是间接的生产者。如果您不理解这种观察的后果，请问问自己，您认为以下两个程序员中的哪一个更好：

The programmer, like the manager, is not a direct producer, but an indirect one. If you don't understand the consequences of this observation, ask yourself which of the following two programmers you would consider better:

一个。多萝西现在写了 110 行代码，而她以前写 100 行代码的时间是一样的，但她的程序和以前完全一样。

a. Dorothy, who now writes 110 lines of code in the same time she used to write 100 lines of code, but whose programs are exactly the same as they always were.

b. Herbert，写 100 行代码仍然需要同样多的时间，但他的程序帮助使用它们的 1000 名职员提高了 1% 的工作效率。

b. Herbert, who still takes the same amount of time to write 100 lines, but whose programs help the thousand clerks who use them increase their productivity by 1 percent.

当我在 1979 年重写水力管网分析程序时，我做了很多改进，尤其是在输入和输出格式方面，但这些都没有算在我对生产力增长的估计中。然而，旧程序被数百名土木工程师使用——他们是高技能和高薪的人，他们浪费了很多时间并犯了许多代价高昂的错误，因为旧的输入格式准备起来很乏味，输出格式也很难阅读。

When I rewrote the hydraulic network analysis program in 1979, I made numerous improvements, especially in the input and output formats, but these were not counted in my estimate of productivity increase. Yet the old program was used by hundreds of civil engineers—highly skilled and highly paid people who wasted many hours and made many costly mistakes because the old input format was tedious to prepare and the output format was hard to read.

然而，传统上，大多数 IT 组织在心理上将程序员与文员一起分类，他们的生产率是直接计算的，而不是根据其产品的生产率。因此，许多程序员通过执行此措施所暗示的方式来应对生产力压力——增加代码 量 而不是 代码质量。 我们得到我们测量的东西。

Traditionally, however, most IT organizations have mentally classified the programmers along with the clerks, whose productivity is counted directly, not according to the productivity of their product. As a consequence, many programmers have responded to the pressure for productivity by doing just what this measure implies—increasing the amount of code rather than the quality of code. We get what we measure.

事实上，真正的编程工作是文书工作和创造性工作的结合，就像真正的管理一样。某个时间在一个组织中重要的事情在另一时间或在另一个组织中将是次要的。因此，程序员不仅被要求生产更多，而且还被要求决定他们应该生产什么样 的 “更多”。信息处理管理人员也感受到了这些相同的压力，这些压力从高层管理人员反馈下来，并在转化为 IT 管理人员当前青睐的惯用语后传递给程序员。新的结果是程序员感觉他们比以往任何时候都更有效率，但也感受到他们的管理：

In fact, real programming work is a combination of clerical and creative work, just as real management is. What's important in one organization at one time will be secondary at another time or in another organization. Thus programmers are not only being asked to produce more, but they are also being asked to decide what kind of "more" they should produce. These same pressures are felt by information-processing management, fed down from upper management, and passed along to the programmers after being translated into IT management's currently favored idiom. The new result is programmers who sense they are more productive than they've ever been, but feel their management:

1.不知道他们想要什么

1. Doesn't know what they want

2. 施压要求提高“生产力”，即使他们不知道“生产力”这个词是什么意思

2. Is pressuring for an increase in "productivity" even though they don't know what they mean by the word

3. 不欣赏已经完成的事情

3. Doesn't appreciate what has already been accomplished

4. 设置了大部分阻碍程序员提高任何形式生产力的障碍

4. Has put up most of the barriers that prevent the programmers from increasing productivity of any kind

程序员需要什么

What the Programmer Needs

根据惯性第一定律，我们知道程序员应该感受到压力。根据第二定律，我们知道程序员对挤压的反应将取决于程序员要保留的重要内容。因此，我们必须问，“这些变化以何种方式威胁到程序员的价值观？”

By the First Law of Inertia we know the programmer should feel the squeeze. By the Second Law we know the programmer's response to the squeeze will depend on what's important for the programmer to preserve. Therefore, we must ask, "In what way do these changes threaten what the programmer values?"

心理学家告诉我们人类有一个需求层次。这意味着某些需求被置于其他需求之前——直到它们得到满足。然后它们不再是需求，并被层次结构中的下一级需求所取代。例如，最关键的需求是生理需求。如果你精疲力尽，你就不会很想获得经理的尊重。一般来说，在当今的发达社会中，尤其是在程序员中，

Psychologists tell us human beings have a hierarchy of needs. This means certain needs are placed before other needs—until they are satisfied. Then they cease being needs and are replaced by the next level of needs in the hierarchy. For instance, the most crucial needs are physiological.
