If you're running out of air, you're not very interested in obtaining your manager's esteem. Generally, in today's developed societies, and particularly among programmers,

1. 空气、水或食物没有太大的动力，因为这些通常都很充足。

1. There's not much motivational force in air, water, or food, as all these are generally plentiful.

2. 计算能力的大幅提升并没有真正威胁到任何程序员的饥饿。

2. The great rise in computational power has not really threatened any programmer with starvation.

3. 法律障碍阻止经理们威胁说，“如果你不更快地编码，我就让你窒息！”

3. Legal obstacles prevent managers from threatening, "If you don't code faster, I'll suffocate you!"

在其他领域，如果生产力没有更快地提高，管理层可能会在层次结构的下一级——安全级别上运作。说“如果你不加快编码速度，我就解雇你！”当然是合法的。但是这种方法会产生程序员改变的必要动力吗？

In other fields, if productivity doesn't increase faster, the management may be able to operate on the next level of the hierarchy—the level of security. It's certainly legal to say, "If you don't code faster, I'll fire you!" But will this approach produce the necessary motivation for programmers to change?

在当今的商业环境中，解雇威胁对大多数程序员来说并不是很有效。首先，在许多大型组织中，威胁本质上是空洞的，因为将人们逼入绝境并继续支付薪水比解雇他们更容易。但是，即使解雇是可行的，只要看一眼“招聘程序员”的广告，您就会明白为什么这种威胁缺乏说服力。

In today's business environment, the threat of firing is not very effective with most programmers. First, in many large organizations the threat is essentially hollow, for it's easier to put people in a corner and keep on paying them than it is to fire them. But even if firing is feasible, one glance at the "programmers wanted" ads will show you why the threat lacks conviction.

四十多年来，我一直在听关于编程消亡的预测。经理们喜欢听到这些预测，因为他们知道如果编程工作变得更加稀缺，程序员会对解雇威胁做出更快的反应。我没有足够的篇幅来证明我自己的预测是正确的，但是我向实际的经理提供了这样的建议：“不要等到编程的消亡来解决你的问题。”

For more than forty years, I've listened to forecasts of the demise of programming. Managers like to hear these forecasts because they know if programming jobs were scarcer, programmers would be more responsive to threats of firing. I lack the space to justify my own forecasts, but to the practical manager I offer this advice: "Don't wait for the demise of programming to solve your problems."

实际上，解雇的威胁似乎比招聘广告所暗示的更具威力，但这并不是因为程序员担心安全问题。下一个层次的需求是属于某个社会群体的需求。这是受失业威胁最大的需求。许多经理对办公室的“社交生活”感到烦恼和抱怨，不明白这种“社交生活”是如何隔开他们的员工和另一份薪水更高的工作的。

Actually, the threat of firing seems to carry more force than the want ads would suggest, but it's not because the programmer is worried about security. On the next level of needs is the need to belong to some social group. This is the need most threatened by the loss of a job. Many managers fret and moan about the "social life" at the office, not understanding how this "social life" is all that stands between their employees and another job at a higher salary.

在达到相对安全和舒适的生活之后，普通程序员正在寻求满足这种更高的需求，心理学家将其列为：

Having reached a relatively secure and comfortable existence, the average programmer is seeking to fulfill such higher needs, which the psychologists list as:

1. 归属感——成为群体的一部分

1. Belonging—being part of a group

2. 尊重——被他人高度评价

2. Esteem—being highly regarded by others

3. 自我实现——被自己看重

3. Self-actualization—being highly regarded by oneself

这些是程序员可能被惯性第一定律挤压的区域，因此这些是程序员将根据惯性第二定律努力保留的区域。让我们看看他们在我的几个客户的案例中的工作情况。

These are the areas in which the programmer may be squeezed by the First Law of Inertia, so these are the areas the programmer will strive to preserve according to the Second Law of Inertia. Let's see them at work in cases from several of my clients.

案例 1： 金钱作为尊重的衡量标准

case 1: Money as a Measure of Esteem

Manuel 已经编程五年了，他可以感觉到自己编程能力的增强。当实习生带着问题来找他时，他意识到自己编写程序的时间是实习生的三分之一。曼努埃尔正在满足他的归属感，因为实习生来找 他， 这让他扮演了一个家庭之父的角色。同样的角色满足了他被尊重的需要，因为受训者显然尊重他的技能。最后，他对自己力量的私人感觉满足了他的最高需要——自我实现的需要。他正在做一些有价值的事情，而且他知道自己很擅长。

Manuel has been programming for five years and he can sense his increased programming powers. When a trainee comes to him with a problem, he realizes he would write the program himself in one-third the time it takes the trainee. Manuel is satisfying his need to belong because the trainee comes to him, which puts him in something of a father-of-the-family role. This same role satisfies his need to be esteemed, for the trainee obviously respects his skills. Finally, his private sense of his own powers satisfies his highest need—the need for self-actualization. He is doing something worthy and he knows he's good at it.

几天后，曼纽尔碰巧得知实习生的收入为 50,000 美元，而他的工资为 60,000 美元。6万块钱满足他的生理需求绰绰有余，工作固然稳妥，但他心里不安。“为什么，”他想，“当我的工作效率至少是原来的三倍时，我的薪水 却只 增加了 20%？也许我的经理不欣赏我的技能。” 他的自尊受到威胁，所以他有动力为此做点什么。

A few days later, Manuel happens to learn that the trainee is earning $50,000, compared to his salary of $60,000. The $60,000 is more than enough to satisfy his physical needs, and his job is certainly secure, but he feels uneasy. "Why," he thinks, "do I get only 20% more money when I'm at least three times as productive? Perhaps my manager doesn't appreciate my skill." His esteem is threatened, so he's motivated to do something about it.

他看着报纸来验证他的感觉。他了解到，没有人会仅仅因为他们的 产量是原来的三倍而赚取 三倍的收入——这让他恢复了一些自尊。他了解到薪资差异的价值更多是象征性的，而不是直接的。

He watches the newspaper to verify his feeling. He learns nobody earns three times as much just because they produce three times as much—which restores some of his esteem. He's learned the value of salary differences is more symbolic than direct.

但他也看到，代理机构的广告承诺为具有他经验的人提供远高于 60,000 美元的薪水，因此他的焦虑并没有完全减轻。他没有辞职的念头，因为他的朋友都在这里工作，但他决定在年度考核时提出薪资问题。

But he's also seen that the agency ads are promising well above $60,000 for someone with his experience, so not all his anxiety is relieved. He doesn't think of quitting, because all his friends work here, but he decides to raise the question of salary during his annual appraisal.

在评估中，曼努埃尔的经理让 (Jean) 很不高兴。她一直承受着通过引入新方法和控制人员成本来提高生产率的压力。她计划给曼纽尔加薪——比她愿意给的要少——她觉得她必须告诉他他没有采用新方法来证明给这么少的钱是合理的。此外，如果有机会，她无法衡量曼努埃尔的工作效率或可能的工作效率。

At the appraisal, Jean, Manuel's manager, is grouchy. She's been under pressure to raise productivity by introducing new methods and keeping the lid on personnel costs. She's planned a tiny raise for Manuel—less than she'd like to give—and she feels she must justify giving such a small amount by telling him he hasn't been adopting new methods. Besides, she has no way of measuring just how productive Manuel has been or could be if given a chance.

压力在她身上，因为计算能力的大幅提升也导致了管理层期望值的上升。一旦我们编写了一些程序，门就会打开，用户就会带着他们真正想要解决的问题前进。结果，Manuel 每年提高的生产力大部分都被吸收到更复杂的应用程序中，作为程序员，他几乎没有得到任何荣誉。

The pressure is on her because the great rise in computing power has also led to a rise in management expectations. Once we program something, the door opens and in march the users with the problems they really wanted to solve. As a result, much of Manuel's annual productivity increase has been absorbed into more sophisticated applications for which he, as programmer, gets hardly any credit at all.

更糟糕的是，Jean 没有时间亲自检查 Manuel 的工作，看看他是否真的在使用新方法。即使她做到了，她也不再具备曾经让她晋升到这个管理职位的技术技能。曼纽尔知道这一点，所以如果珍试图批评他的作品，他就会觉得她不公平。然而，如果她试图表扬她的作品，他就会将她的表扬价值打到他的自尊心上。曼努埃尔当然知道让不再属于他所属的程序员小组。通过担任管理工作，她表明她不再重视他们的同志情谊。

To make matters worse, Jean doesn't have time to examine Manuel's work personally to see whether he's actually using the new methods. Even if she did, she no longer has the technical skills that once earned her the promotion to this management job. Manuel knows this, so if Jean tries to criticize his work, he feels she's being unfair. Yet if she tries to praise the work, he'll discount the worth of her praise to his self-esteem. Certainly Manuel knows that Jean is no longer part of the group of programmers to which he belongs. By taking the management job, she's indicated she doesn't value their comradeship any longer.

这样的评估会议不太可能让曼努埃尔或让都非常满意，这可能就是为什么他们都会避免下一次评估。如果曼努埃尔能够避免与吉恩有太多接触，他可能会对自己的工作感到满意，尤其是如果他与同事保持联系的话。如果没有，他很快就会回复其中一则广告，或者听一位招聘人员说他的名字是从三个月前离职的一名前雇员那里得到的。有一位老朋友作为通往新工作的桥梁，Manuel 最大的恐惧得到了缓解，因为他将在新环境中立即归属于一个群体

It's unlikely such an appraisal meeting can be terribly satisfactory to either Manuel or Jean, which is probably why both will avoid the next appraisal. If Manuel can avoid too much contact with Jean, he may remain satisfied with his job, especially if he maintains contact with his peers. If not, he'll soon be answering one of those ads or listening to a recruiter who got his name from a former employee who left three months ago. With an old friend as a bridge to a new job, Manuel's greatest fears are relieved, for he will immediately belong to a group in the new environment

但这个故事最重要的寓意是：曼努埃尔从未真正有动力采用新方法来提高工作效率，至少没有通过任何管理措施。事实上，管理层试图联系曼努埃尔并提供动力的每一次尝试都往往会适得其反。曼纽尔可能有动力，但不是为了提高生产力。相反，他可能会选择以下方法来解决他的工作情况：

But the most important moral of this story is this: Manuel was never really motivated to adopt new methods to work more productively, at least not by any management action. Indeed, every attempt by management to reach Manuel and provide motivation tended to work backward. Manuel might be motivated, but not to increase productivity. Instead, he might choose among the following as solutions to his work situation:

1. 离开去寻找新工作

1. Leaving for a new job

2. 尽量避开经理的视线

2. Avoiding his manager's eye as much as possible

3. 减少工作以补偿他的“欠薪”

3. Working less to compensate for his "underpayment"

即使曼努埃尔真的觉得他需要更多的钱，他也不太可能试图通过提高生产率来获得钱。相反，他可能会尝试以下途径

And even if Manuel really felt he needed more money, he's not likely to try to get it by increasing productivity. Instead, he may try such avenues as

4.争取管理职位

4. Pushing for a management job

5. 为当地的 CPA 编写一些夜间工作。

5. Taking on a little night work writing programs for the local CPA.

这些方法中的每一种实际上都会降低 Jean 所在组织的生产力——一个是因为失去了一个有经验的人，另一个是因为失去了一个有经验的人的时间和奉献精神。

Each of these approaches will actually lessen the productivity of Jean's organization—one through loss of an experienced person and the other through loss of an experienced person's time and dedication.

案例 2：作为激励因素的技术审查

case 2: Technical Reviews as Motivators

现在让我们考虑另一种 激励方法 。工作五年后，Muriel 和 Manuel 一样成为了一名相当出色的程序员，尽管她对自己缺乏信心。因此，当她的经理克劳德宣布要引入正式代码审查系统时，她非常担心。因为 Muriel 是她项目中最有经验的人，所以她的作品被选中进行第一次审查。她太紧张了，前一天晚上睡不着觉。当她辗转反侧时，她认真地考虑过请病假——并花一天时间拨打招聘广告中的一些电话号码。

Now let's consider another approach to motivation. After five years on the job Muriel, like Manuel, was a pretty good programmer, although she lacked confidence in herself. Consequently, she was quite worried when Claude, her manager, announced he was introducing a system of formal code reviews. Because Muriel was the most experienced person on her project, her work was chosen for the first review. She was so nervous she couldn't sleep the night before. As she tossed and turned, she seriously considered calling in sick—and spending the day calling some of the numbers in the employment ads.

最后，穆里尔来上班了，主要是因为她不想让朋友们认为她是个胆小鬼。随着审查的开始，她开始意识到自己最担心的事情。第一轮评论中提出了三个相当严重的错误。她想为自己辩护，但她知道其他人是对的。最后，她询问是否可以终止审查并有另一次机会修复她的代码。

In the end, Muriel came to work, mostly because she didn't want her friends to think she was a coward. As the review started, she began to realize her worst fears. Three rather serious bugs were brought up in the first round of comments. She wanted to defend herself, but she knew the others were right. Finally, she asked if she could terminate the review and have another chance to fix her code.

审查负责人——他已经为他的任务做好了充分的准备——和蔼而坚定地解释说，终止审查不是穆里尔的决定。只有审查小组可以决定，但如果她愿意，他会投票给他们。她做到了，所以这件事被讨论了。令 Muriel 惊讶的是，她听到一位评论者说如果这些错误是程序的全部错误，那么它比他在这个开发阶段见过的任何程序都要好。当其他人都同意他的判断并评论说他们从 Muriel 那里学到了多少新技术时，她更加惊讶。

The review leader—who had been well prepared for his task—kindly but firmly explained that terminating the review was not Muriel's decision. Only the review group could decide, but he would poll them if she wished. She did, so the matter was discussed. To Muriel's surprise, she heard one reviewer say if these bugs were everything wrong with the program, then it was better than any program he had ever seen at this stage of development. She was even more surprised when the rest of the group agreed with his judgment and remarked on how much they had learned about new techniques from Muriel.

评审组长随后温和地斥责了小组以如此完全消极的方式开始评审，并提醒他们 Muriel 是该项目中第一个接受 任何 评审的人。他说，她自然会对批评很敏感，不知道对她的节目期望有多好。最后，小组投票决定继续审查。又过了 20 分钟——其中 Muriel 的一些技术受到了赞扬——他们终止了审查，并决定在纠正了三个错误并成功运行了两个附加测试后接受代码。

The review leader then gave the group a mild rebuke for starting the review in such a completely negative fashion, reminding them Muriel was the first person on the project to have anything reviewed. Naturally, he said, she would be sensitive to criticism, not knowing just how good a program was expected of her. Finally, the group voted to continue the review. After another twenty minutes—in which a number of Muriel's techniques were praised—they terminated the review with a decision to accept the code after the three bugs were corrected and two additional tests were run successfully.

这次经历一个月后，穆里尔成为了我的一个工作室的学生，在那里她告诉了我她的故事。她说她永远不会忘记在回顾之后的那一天剩下的时间，尽管她几乎记不起任何具体的事情。她记得最深的是她所说的“发光”或“刺痛感”，有几个人在她的隔间停下来祝贺她，因为他们听到的是一项杰出的工作。

A month after this experience, Muriel was a student in one of my workshops, which is where she told me her story. She said she would never forget the rest of the day, following the review, though she could hardly remember anything specific about it at all. What she remembered most was what she described as a "glow" or "tingling feeling," and several people stopping by her cubicle to congratulate her on what they had heard was an outstanding piece of work.

Muriel 的经理克劳德 (Claude) 在同一个车间，他告诉我，他首先选择了 Muriel，因为他知道她的作品是车间里最好的，但当他试图告诉她时，她从不相信他。他一举满足了她的三个最高需求——归属感、同事的尊重和自尊。

Muriel's manager, Claude, who was in the same workshop, told me he had chosen Muriel first because he knew her work was the best in the shop, but she never believed him when he tried to tell her. In one fell swoop, he had managed to satisfy all three of her highest needs—for a sense of belonging, for the esteem of her colleagues, and for her self-esteem.

在研讨会的讨论中，Muriel 成为正式审查的坚定支持者。当她用自己店里的一个又一个例子给全班带来欢乐时，很难想象她会害怕来上班进行第一次复习。

During our discussions at the workshop, Muriel emerged as a staunch supporter of formal reviews. As she regaled the class with example after example from her own shop, it was hard to imagine her being afraid to come to work for her first review.

福特的基本反馈公式

Ford's Fundamental Feedback Formula

在 Manuel 和 Muriel 的这两种情况下，经理们都试图完成同样的事情——激励程序员使用新方法来提高工作效率，或许还可以帮助其他人提高工作效率。然而，一个案例彻底失败，而另一个则完全成功。为什么不同？

In both cases, Manuel's and Muriel's, the managers were trying to accomplish the same thing—motivating the programmer to use new methods to work more productively and perhaps to help others work more productively. Yet one case was an utter failure and the other a complete success. Why the difference?

我相信第一位经理失败了，因为她认为她必须直接与每个员工互动才能管理变革。尽管直接干预有时是正确的策略，但有效的管理者会采用更广泛的方法。特别是，Muriel 的经理非常有效，因为他利用办公室的社交流程来服务于组织的生产力目标。

I believe the first manager failed because she thought she had to interact directly with each employee in order to manage change. Although direct intervention is sometimes the correct tactic, the effective manager works with a far broader spectrum of approaches. In particular, Muriel's manager was effective because he harnessed the social processes of the office to serve the organization's productivity goals.

为了理解这是如何工作的，让我们使用另一个比喻。缺乏生产力就像污染——人们不想要的东西，就像工厂将有毒化学品倾倒在河里一样。回到 20 年代，国会正在调查河流污染，并邀请亨利·福特 (Henry Ford) 作为顶级实业家作证。当福特出庭作证时，他指责国会在复杂的反污染法律上浪费了大笔税收。“你所需要的，”他说，“只是一部简单的法律来清理所有被污染的河流。”

To understand how this worked, let's use another metaphor. Lack of productivity is like pollution—something unwanted in people's output, like poisonous chemicals a factory is dumping in the river. Back in the 1920s Congress was investigating river pollution and invited Henry Ford, as a top industrialist, to testify. When Ford took the stand, he chided the Congress for wasting good tax money on complicated antipollution laws. "All you need," he said, "is one simple law to clear up all polluted rivers."

委员会成员难以置信地听着，最终没有听从福特的建议。但如果他们有，那么毫无疑问，福特的法律就会奏效。你可以自己判断，因为他提出的是这样的：

The members of the committee listened in disbelief and ultimately didn't follow Ford's advice. But if they had, there's no question but that Ford's law would have worked. You can judge for yourself, for what he proposed was this:

任何人都可以出于任何目的从任何河流中取取任意数量的水，只要他们将水 从取水的地方返回上游即可。

Anyone can take any amount of water from any river for any purpose whatsoever, as long as they return the water upstream from where they took it out.

你看，人可能愿意喝别人的污水，但他们永远不会愿意喝自己的。如果他们必须将水域返回上游，你可以肯定他们会做任何必要的事情来净化他们的产出。

You see, people may be willing to drink other people's sewage, but they'll never be willing to drink their own. If they have to return their waters upstream, you can be sure they'll do whatever is necessary to purify their output.

我相信这个原则是管理军械库中最深刻的武器之一，所以我给它起了一个名字，以纪念有史以来最深刻的管理者之一——福特的基本反馈公式。简而言之，福特的公式说：

I believe this principle is one of the most profound weapons in the management armory, so I've given it a name honoring one of the most profound managers of all time—Ford's Fundamental Feedback Formula. Simply put, Ford's Formula says:

如果你想让人们改变他们正在做的事情，

If you want people to change what they're doing,

确保他们反馈他们正在做的事情的后果。

make sure they are fed back the consequences of what they're doing.

我相信，我们在提高编程生产力方面遇到的许多问题都源于管理层未能应用这一原则。许多程序员——可能 是大多数 程序员——在这样的环境中工作，在这种环境中，他们基本上没有从经理那里收到关于他们所做事情的后果的真实反馈。缺乏这种反馈，他们就缺乏尝试改变的动力，也缺乏 做出正确改变所需的信息 。

I believe that many of the problems we have in improving the productivity of programming stem from a failure of management to apply this principle. Many programmers—probably most programmers—work in environments in which they receive essentially no real feedback from their managers embodying the consequences of what they do. Lacking this feedback, they lack the motivation to attempt changes, and they also lack the information needed to make the correct changes.

鉴于福特的公式，我们可以理解曼努埃尔和穆里尔案例之间的真正区别。首先，Manuel 的经理并不确切知道 Manuel 在做什么，因此她直接反馈的尝试注定要失败。即使曼努埃尔相信琼所说的话，他也没有真正的信息可以用来提高他的工作效率。事实上，如果他试图听从她关于他应该做什么和不应该做什么的意见，很可能会让事情变得更糟。

In the light of Ford's Formula, we can understand the real difference between the cases of Manuel and Muriel. Manuel's manager, first of all, didn't know precisely what Manuel was doing, so her attempt to direct feedback was doomed to failure. Even had Manuel believed what Jean was saying, he had no real information to use to improve his productivity. Indeed, he might well have made things worse by attempting to follow her opinions about what he should and should not be doing.

Jean 的方法是编程经理非常常用的方法。Jean 是自己晋升的，在正式成为经理之前，她负责管理三名实习生一年多。在与受训者一起工作时，她应用了直接方法并取得了巨大的成功——她获得了晋升。但作为一群经验丰富的程序员的经理，她无法成功地应用与学员相同的方法。

Jean's method is very commonly used by programming managers. Jean came up through the ranks herself, and before officially becoming a manager she was put in charge of three trainees for more than a year. Working with the trainees, she applied the direct method with great success—so much success she was promoted. But as manager of a group of experienced programmers, she couldn't successfully apply the same method she used with the trainees.

Jean 认为她正在使用相同的方法，但她不再有信息可以反馈给 Manuel。当她的全部责任是三个实习生时，她没有时间检查每个人的工作。没有时间检查实际工作，她很快就失去了检查工作的能力，即使她有时间。此外，她从来没有能力独自检查有经验的程序员的工作并记录其优点和缺点。然而，这对吉恩来说并不是缺点，因为装置中没有人比其他人好得多。

Jean thought she was using the same method, but she no longer had the information to feed back to Manuel. She didn't have time to examine everyone's work as she had when her total responsibility was three trainees. Not having time to examine actual work, she soon lost the competence to examine work even when she had the time. Moreover, she never had the competence, all by herself, to examine the work of experienced programmers and note everything good and bad about it. That was no shortcoming in Jean, however, because nobody in the installation was that much better than everyone else.

在穆里尔的店里，情况也差不多。然而，通过审查程序，克劳德 汇集了 技术知识，得出的结果优于任何一个人的贡献。此外，进行审查的人员有足够的时间。每个审阅者通过在每次审阅中学习相关内容而直接受益，这很容易回报他们花费的时间，并像野火一样传播好的新技术。通过审查，反馈比 Muriel 的经理或任何经理可能提供的反馈更相关、更可信、更完整。

In Muriel's shop, the situation was much the same. Through the review procedures, however, Claude pooled the technical knowledge, giving a result superior to any one particular person's contribution. Moreover, the people doing the reviewing had adequate time. Each reviewer benefited directly by learning relevant things in each review, which easily repaid them for the time they spent and which spread good new techniques like wildfire. Through the review, the feedback was more relevant, more believable, and more complete than Muriel's manager, or any manager, could possibly have given.

技术审查有多种形式，经理可以通过许多其他方式利用社会力量为福特的基本反馈公式服务。我选择以审查为例，因为我相信审查是 当今任何编程经理都可以采取的最直接有效的步骤。 更重要的是，如果没有审查，编程经理就不可能对 任何项目的实施充满信心 生产力技术。我去过许多吹嘘他们实施结构化编程、特殊测试工具、新形式的文档、新标准或你拥有的东西的商店。在大多数这些商店中，实地调查与经理的幻想相矛盾。程序员根本没有在很大程度上使用这些技术。而且，由于缺乏评论，经理没有可靠的方法来消除这种错觉。

There are many forms of technical reviews, and there are many other ways a manager can harness social forces in the service of Ford's Fundamental Feedback Formula. I chose to make an example of reviews because I believe reviews are the one most immediately productive step any programming manager can take today. Even more important, without reviews there is no way in the world a programming manager can be confident in the implementation of any productivity technique. I have been in dozens of shops that bragged about their implementation of structured programming, special testing tools, new forms of documentation, new standards, or what have you. In most of these shops, an on-the-ground investigation contradicted the manager's illusions. The programmers simply were not using the techniques to any great extent. And, lacking reviews, the manager had no reliable way of dispelling this illusion.

概括

Summary

1. 大多数时候变化不会发生。

1. Most of the time change doesn't happen.

2. 当许多力量都在积极努力保持稳定时，变化就不会发生。

2. Change doesn't happen when many forces are actively working to keep things stable.

3. 要将变革导向生产渠道，您必须了解促进稳定的力量。

3. To direct change toward productive channels, you must understand the forces working for stability.

4、人之所以会变，是因为环境在变，所以即使保持不变，也会变。他们的环境在变化，所以他们改变一件事来保护对他们个人来说更重要的东西。

4. When people do change, it's because their environment is changing, so they change even if they stay the same. Their environment is changing, so they change one thing to preserve something even more important to them personally.

5. 最大的改变最终来自试图保留改变的事物。

5. The biggest change ultimately results from trying to preserve the thing that changes.

6. 人们试图保存的东西按以下需求层次排列：

6. The things people are trying to preserve are ranked in the following hierarchy of needs:

生理需求

Physical needs

安全

Security

一种归属感

A feeling of belonging

他人的尊重

Esteem from others

自尊或自我实现

Self-esteem or self-actualization

7. 在今天的环境中，很少有程序员是出于身体需要或安全感。

7. In today's environment, few programmers are motivated by physical needs or security.

8. 如果人们对他们正在做的事情的结果进行反馈，从而感觉到什么是好的，什么是坏的，他们就会确保他们改变以增加好的，减少坏的。

8. If people are fed back the results of what they're doing, so that they feel what's good and what's bad, they will see to it that they change to increase the good and decrease the bad.

9. 经理的工作不一定是反馈这些信息，而是安排事情以便可靠和定期地进行反馈。

9. The manager's job is not necessarily to feed back this information, but to arrange matters so the feedback takes place, reliably and regularly.

10. 因为程序员的身体需求和安全需求都得到了很好的满足，所以更成功的管理策略将是满足下一个更高需求的安排——尤其是社会需求。

10. Because programmers' physical needs and security needs are pretty well satisfied, the more successful management strategies will be arrangements working to satisfy the next higher needs—in particular, social needs.

程序员同行的技术审查是利用这些更高需求来反馈有关程序员绩效的可靠信息的策略的一个突出例子。

Technical reviews by a programmer's peers are one outstanding example of a strategy harnessing these higher needs to feed back reliable information on programmer performance.

技术评审有多种形式，可以适用于任何组织。如果没有某种形式的技术审查——技术人员对技术问题的可靠反馈——你可能会浪费你花在其他生产力技术上的大部分钱。

There are many forms of technical reviews, and they can be adapted to any organization. Without technical reviews of some sort—reliable feedback on technical issues from technical staff—you're probably wasting most of the money you spend on other productivity techniques.

愚弄规则

Fooling with Rules

“什么是绿色的，有轮子，长在房子周围？”

"What is green, has wheels, and grows around the house?"

“我放弃了。答案是什么？”

"I give up. What's the answer?"

“草……我在轮子上撒了谎。”

"Grass ... I lied about the wheels."

通过这个小小的转折，波尔·安德森笔下的一位英雄激怒了一个邪恶的巨人，并在一场猜谜比赛中击败了他。他会打败你吗？你的反应是否意味着你是一个邪恶的巨人？或者这是否意味着您就像典型的计算机程序员一样？

By this little twist, one of Poul Anderson's heroes sends a wicked giant into a rage and defeats him in a riddling contest. Would he have defeated you? Does your response mean you are a wicked giant? Or does it mean you're just like the typical computer programmer?

当程序员必须在不知道所有规则的情况下玩游戏时，他们会非常烦恼。当他们知道有 规则 （其中一些规则没有说明）时，大多数程序员会更加努力地工作——试图发现隐藏的规则。但是一旦他们觉得没有规则，或者规则可以任意改变，程序员往往会产生敌意并退出游戏。

Programmers are terribly bothered when they must play a game without knowing all the rules. When they know there are rules, some of which are not stated, most programmers will work much harder—trying to discover the hidden rules. But once they feel there are no rules, or that the rules can be arbitrarily changed, programmers tend to get hostile and quit the game.

心理学家会说这种行为表明对控制感的强烈需求。这种感受会影响程序员寻找和保留的工作类型、他们是否愿意承担管理责任、他们对管理风格的整体态度、他们对团队编程和技术审查的感受，以及编程生活方式的许多其他方面.

Psychologists would say this behavior indicates a strong need for a feeling of control. Such feelings influence the kinds of jobs programmers seek and keep, their desire or lack of desire to assume management responsibilities, their entire attitude toward styles of management, their feelings about team programming and technical reviews, and many other aspects of the programming life-style.

程序员喜欢在 受规则约束的情况下玩耍，因为他们擅长于此：在这种情况下不成功的人通常不会进入编程行业。如果你在管理程序员并且你希望工人快乐，你必须建立一个规则清晰且为所有人所知的环境。您可以确定他们会按照您明确制定的任何规则进行游戏。不过要小心。如果一些游乐设施没有经过深思熟虑，您可能会得到意想不到的结果。

Programmers like to play in rule-bound situations because they're good at it: People who aren't successful in such situations usually don't enter the programming business. If you're managing programmers and you want the workers to be happy, you have to establish an environment in which the rules are clear and known to all. You can be sure they'll play by any rules you set down clearly. Be careful, though. If some rides aren't carefully thought out, you may get surprising results.

例如，如果你要求程序员编写更多的代码行来赚取更多的薪水，程序员就会像吃坚果的松鼠一样反应并开始编写代码库。如果游戏规则发生改变，从而产生更少的代码行会带来更高的薪水，他们会很高兴地转换风格并产生宝贵的更少代码行数。

For instance, if you mandate programmers producing more lines of code earn more salary, programmers will react like squirrels with nuts and start producing hoards of code. If the game is changed so producing fewer lines of code results in a higher salary, they'll happily switch styles and produce precious fewer lines of code.

我曾经和一位程序员交谈过，他很满足于为一位我认为很糟糕的经理工作。我问这个程序员，他怎么能容忍为一个看起来完全武断、愿意为任何人做任何事情来提升自己职业生涯的人工作。程序员解释说：经理的行为正是让情况可以忍受的原因。经理并不像我想的那样专横，但他遵循一个非常简单的规则：

I once talked with a programmer who was quite content working for a manager whom I considered an awful person. I asked this programmer how he could tolerate working for a guy who seemed to be completely arbitrary and willing to do anything to anybody to advance his career. The programmer explained: The manager's behavior was exactly what made the situation tolerable. The manager wasn't arbitrary, as I had thought, but he lived by one very simple rule:

我从不在背后捅人一刀，除非这会促进我的职业发展。

I never stab anybody in the back unless it will advance my career.

如果你避开他的路，那么他就无法通过以某种方式伤害你来获益，那么他就永远不会给你带来任何麻烦。这使得经理完全可以预测，至少对于这个没有渴望晋升到更高管理级别的特定程序员而言。程序员很满意——他有一套他非常了解的规则。

If you kept out of his path, so he couldn't benefit by knifing you in some way, then he never gave you any trouble. This made the manager perfectly predictable, at least for this particular programmer, who had no aspirations to advance to higher levels of management. The programmer was quite content—he had a set of rules he understood only too well.

最近，Dani 和我受邀研究新软件工具对大型编程组织的心理影响。关于软件工具中的一个或另一个故障，有很多大大小小的抱怨，但我们从每个人那里听到的只有一个真正暴力的抱怨：维护工具的系统组在任意时间改变了工具的工作方式，没有任何提前警告。

Recently, Dani and I were invited to study the psychological effects of new software tools on a large programming organization. There were many complaints, large and small, about one glitch or another in the software tools, but there was only one truly violent complaint we heard from everyone: The systems group maintaining the tools changed the way the tools worked at arbitrary times, without any advance warning.

程序员在讨论这种行为时变得勃然大怒。我们可以很容易地理解他们的愤怒，因为他们需要和渴望在受规则约束的情况下工作。 如果规则发生变化，他们 本来可以接受的，只要他们提前得到通知。如果规则改变就好了，只要他们给出与更高规则相关的理由。但是，我们采访的每个人都完全不能接受系统组任意和反复无常的规则更改。

The programmers became livid when they discussed this behavior. We can easily understand their anger in terms of their need and desire to work in a rule-bound situation. It would have been acceptable to them if rules changed, if only they were notified in advance. It would have been fine if rules changed, if only they were given reasons related to higher rules. But arbitrary and capricious rule changes by the systems group were completely unacceptable to everyone we interviewed.

随着程序员在职业生涯中的进步，他们确实在他们认为的规则方面变得更加成熟。例如，年轻的程序员经常被客户在编程工作中更改规格所激怒。随着经验的积累，程序员开始推导出一个更高层次的规则：客户 总是 在编程工作中途更改规范。

As programmers advance in their careers, they do grow more sophisticated, in what they consider to be rules. For example, young programmers are often enraged by customers changing specifications in the middle of a programming job. As they gain experience, programmers begin to deduce a higher-level rule: Customers always change the specifications in the middle of a programming job.

在这个更大的规则中抓住了问题的本质，程序员能够与改变主意的客户一起工作。他们很生气，但并不愤怒。一旦程序员通过将其置于规则范围内来保护自己免受不稳定行为的影响，许多新策略就会变得可用。当相同的行为发生在规则之外时，它会导致毫无成效。

Having captured the essence of the matter in this larger rule, programmers are able to work with customers who change their minds. They're annoyed but not outraged. Once programmers protect themselves against erratic behavior by bringing it within the bounds of rules, many new tactics become available. When the same behavior occurs outside of the rules, it leads to nothing productive.

就像孩子测试父母或宠物测试主人一样，每当引入一套新规则时，程序员可能会大发雷霆。但如果规则是明确的，程序员很快就会根据新规则适应并制定出新的成功模式。例如，如果大张旗鼓地将标准添加到标准手册中，最初程序员会大喊大叫。一段时间后，如果他们注意到标准得到定期执行，大多数程序员就会遵循这些标准。

Much like children testing parents or pets testing owners, programmers may throw tantrums any time a new set of rules is introduced. But if the rules are explicit, programmers soon adapt and work out new patterns of success within the new rules. For example, if standards are added to the standards manual with a great deal of fanfare, initially programmers will scream and shout. After a while, if they notice the standards are enforced regularly, most programmers will follow the standards.

另一方面，如果程序员了解到标准没有得到执行，他们会引入一个更高级别的规则：这些规则（标准）并不真正重要（“我在轮子上撒了谎”）。然后很容易忽略那些并不真正重要的标准。每个人都很舒服，因为规则恢复了。

On the other hand, if the programmers learn the standards are not being enforced, they induce a higher-level rule that says: Those rules (standards) don't really count ("I lied about the wheels"). It's then easy to ignore the standards that don't really count. Everyone is comfortable, because rule by rule is restored.

多年来，程序员从生活的其他领域采纳了规则，并开发了许多自己的规则。这里列出了我最喜欢的十个，我们可以称之为 Weinberg 的宝贵编程原则：

Over the years, programmers have adopted rules from other areas of life and have developed many of their own. Here s a list of ten of my favorites, which we might call Weinberg's Precious Programming Principles:

1.标准不是标准。

1. Standards aren't standard.

2. 总是有一个错误，即使在那个错误被删除之后。

2. There's always one more bug, even after that one is removed.

3. 任何可能发生的事情都会发生，除非您的测试计划规定它会发生。

3. Anything that can happen will happen, unless your test plan provides for it happening.

4. 当有人用手指指着代码的某个部分时，看看其他地方是否有问题——很可能是其他三个手指指向的地方。

4. When someone points a finger at some part of the code, look somewhere else for the trouble—most likely where the other three fingers are pointing.

5. 预防胜于治疗，但管理层不会为此支付一分钱。

5. An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure, but management won't pay a penny for it.

6. 规格说明、设计和编码可以以任何速度完成——只有调试需要时间。

6. Specifications, design, and coding can be done at any speed—only debugging takes time.

7. 没有代码太大、扭曲或复杂到维护不能使它变得更糟的程度。

7. There is no code so big, twisted, or complex that maintenance can't make it worse.

8. 每个人都在谈论文档，但从来没有人为此做过任何事情。

8. Everyone talks about documentation, but nobody ever does anything about it.

9. 你可能会缺少硬件，但你永远不会缺少硬件销售人员。

9. You may run short of hardware, but you'll never run short of hardware salespeople.

10. 每个程序员至少有十个个人原则，但只有千分之一的程序员愿意不厌其烦地写下哪怕一个。

10. Every programmer has at least ten personal principles, but only one programmer in a thousand is willing to take the trouble to write down even one.

通过与数百名程序员交谈，我知道规则 10 是正确的。程序员有规则，因为他们喜欢规则。他们特别喜欢元规则——关于规则的规则，比如规则 1。元规则构成了程序员最喜欢的游戏，但就像任何递归游戏一样，它必须结束。当我拜访一位客户寻找一些管理困难的根源时，我学到了元规则的终极意义。一位程序员在普遍的动荡中显得平静而快乐。我问他是如何活下来的，以及他是否可以帮助其他人应对这种情况。

I know rule 10 is true from talking to hundreds of programmers. Programmers have rules because they love rules. They particularly like meta-rules—rules about rules, like rule 1. Meta-rules constitute a favorite programmer game, but like any recursive game it must come to an end. I learned the ultimate in meta-rules when I visited a client looking for the source of some management difficulties. One programmer seemed calm and happy amid the widespread turmoil. I asked him how he survived, and if he could help others to cope with the situation.

“哦，很简单，”他说，“这里只有一条规矩。”

"Oh, it's simple," he said, "there's only one rule around here."

“那是什么？” 我问。

"What's that?" I asked.

“这里唯一的规则就是这里没有规则。”

"The only rule here is that there are no rules here."

有了这样的规则，一切都解释清楚了，他非常舒服。也许他的想法是对的。也可能是草，毕竟是那种没有轮子的。

With a rule like that, everything was explained, and he was perfectly comfortable. Perhaps he had the right idea. Or perhaps it was grass, after all—the kind without wheels.

我要的只是一点尊重！

All I Want Is a Little Respect!

在接受Computerworld采访时，James Martin 讲述了一个关于一家政府航空公司的故事。他描述了如果你是一名乘客并且......

In an interview with Computerworld, James Martin told a story about a government airline. He described how, if you are a passenger and ...

……你太侮辱空姐了，他们把你拉进了黑名单。然后使用黑名单，因此当您尝试再次预订航空公司时，计算机会拒绝给您安排座位。

... you are exceptionally insulting to the air hostess, they put you on a blacklist. The blacklist is then used so when you try to make a booking on the airline again, the computer refuses you a seat.

碰巧的是，我的客户中有一家航空公司。在研究他们的预订系统时，我坐在他们的一个终端机旁，并向我展示了如何显示他们的黑名单。有趣的是，黑名单上有多少人是你知道的人！我想知道这是否会发生在营利性航空公司中。

As it happened, I had an airline among my clients. In studying their reservation system, I sat at one of their terminals and was shown how to display their blacklist. The amusing thing was how many of the people on the blacklist were people whose names you would know! I wonder if that would happen in a profit-making airline.

关于这个轶事引起我注意的第一件事是吉姆将一家政府航空公司与一家营利性航空公司进行了对比。最近，美国的许多私有线路都在报告亏损。当我住在瑞士时，我了解到完全由政府所有的瑞士航空公司是世界上最稳定盈利的航空公司。

The first thing that caught my eye about this anecdote was Jim's contrasting a government airline with a profit-making airline. A lot of the privately owned lines in the United States have been reporting losses recently. When I lived in Switzerland, I learned that Swissair—which is completely government owned—was the most consistently profitable airline in the world.

我在瑞士学到的另一件事是从一位朋友那里学到的，他拥有日内瓦最好的餐厅之一。一天晚上，我们正在享受我们平常的大餐时，被两桌外一群吵闹的醉汉打扰了。在几次非常礼貌地试图让他们安静下来之后，我的朋友放弃了。他亲自向其他每一位用餐者道歉，因为他无法控制这些粗鲁的小丑。那天晚上晚些时候，餐厅空无一人后，他告诉我他在餐厅生意中最讨厌的一件事就是辱骂酒鬼。在他担任领班和老板的这么多年里，他从来没有学会一种有效的方式来应对他们，一旦他们进入餐厅。但是，他透露说，我可以肯定这群流氓再也不会光顾他的店面了。他的妻子接受了预订，保留所有类似 churls 的黑名单。如果他们打电话预订，他们会被礼貌地告知没有空位。

Another thing I learned in Switzerland was from a friend who owns one of the best restaurants in Geneva. One evening, while enjoying our usual supreme meal, we were disturbed by a gang of rowdy drunks two tables away. After several utterly courteous attempts to quiet them, my friend gave up. He personally apologized to each of the other diners for his inability to control such rude buffoons. Later that evening, after the restaurant had emptied, he told me the one thing he hated most about the restaurant business was abusive drunks. In his many years as head waiter, and then as proprietor, he had never learned an effective way of dealing with them once they were in the restaurant. But, he confided, I could be sure this particular bunch of hooligans would never again grace his premises. His wife, who took reservations, kept a blacklist of all similar churls. If they phoned for reservations, they were politely informed no space was available.

瑞士人具有高度发达的适当行为意识，因为这关系到其他人在公共场所的舒适度。英国人也有这种感觉——至少在英国是这样。但是，当他们离开他们狭窄的小岛时，英国人可能比美国人更粗鲁。这就是为什么，当我有选择的时候，我从不乘坐英国或美国的航空公司。

The Swiss have a highly developed sense of appropriate behavior as it concerns the comfort of other people in public places. The English, too, have this sense—at least in England. But when they are away from their tight little island, the English can be even more rude than Americans. That's why, when I have a choice, I never fly on English or American airlines.

但是，用一支画笔描绘两个伟大国家的所有公民也许是不公平的。吉姆确实说过“黑名单上的许多人都是你知道名字的人。” 也许操作因素不是原籍国，而是某种国际地位。也许“名人”觉得他们可以粗鲁无礼，因为这样对他们的同行者来说不那么冒犯？

But perhaps it's unfair to paint with a single brush all citizens of two great nations. Jim did say that "many of the people on the blacklist were people whose names you would know." Perhaps the operational factor is not nation of origin but some kind of international status. Perhaps "famous" people feel they can be rude, because it's somehow less offensive to their fellow travelers?

吉姆神秘的航空公司很可能是瑞士航空公司。我从来没有见过一个瑞士人对名人印象深刻。我敢肯定，瑞士航空公司不会因为将一些名人从其乘客名单中剔除而害怕损失利润。我的餐厅朋友当然不怕将日内瓦的一些著名笨蛋列入黑名单，他们很可能是联合国政要！人们来他的餐厅不是为了看名人，而是为了在宜人的环境中享用美味佳肴。

Jim's mysterious airline could well be Swissair. I've never seen a Swiss who was terribly impressed with famous people. I'm sure Swissair wouldn't be the least afraid of losing profits because it bumped a few celebrities off its passenger manifest. My restaurant friend certainly wasn't afraid to blacklist some of Geneva's famous louts, who might well have been U.N. dignitaries! People didn't come to his restaurant to see celebrities, but to enjoy exceptional food in pleasant surroundings.

所有这些都引出了一个问题：使用计算机将那些让其他人痛苦的人列入黑名单有什么错？吉姆似乎在暗示，不管它是否错误，这都是一种愚蠢的商业策略——尤其是因为有这么多人都是名人。也许我被瑞士的生活宠坏了，但当我在长途飞行中时，我对名人一点也不在乎。我想要的是在禁烟航班上安静且不吸烟的其他乘客。

All of which leads to the question: What's wrong with using the computer to blacklist people who make other people miserable? Jim seems to imply that regardless of whether it's wrong, it's a stupid business tactic—especially because so many of the boors are celebrities. Perhaps I've been spoiled by living in Switzerland, but when I'm on a long flight, I couldn't care less about celebrities. What I want is fellow passengers who are quiet and don't smoke on a nonsmoking flight.

但我的观点是相当有限和有偏见的。对于那些正在度过千载难逢的假期的人来说，也许忍受冒犯行为是为与好莱坞明星或一位伟大的计算机思想家坐在过道对面的快感付出的小代价。事实上，如果没有这些冒犯行为，旅客可能无法知道他们的同行乘客有多出名！

But my view is rather limited and prejudiced. For those who are taking a once-in-a-lifetime vacation, perhaps putting up with offensive behavior is a small price to pay for the thrill of being seated across the aisle from a Hollywood star or one of the great minds of computing. In fact, without the offensive behavior, perhaps travelers wouldn't have any way of knowing just how famous their fellow passenger was!

我想我不应该对名人太苛刻。我们生活在一个粗鲁的社会。在拥挤的环境中，似乎很难得到任何普通人应得的简单尊重。我们中的许多人出于挫败感，寻求职业尊重来代替社会尊重。

I suppose I shouldn't be too hard on celebrities. We live in a rude society. In crowded conditions, it seems difficult to receive the simple respect that is the right of any ordinary person. Many of us, out of frustration, seek professional respect as a substitute for the social kind.

当我还是个孩子的时候，我经常被当作低于人的东西来对待。这种待遇在几个方面扭曲了我的想法。这让我着迷于通过我的专业工作寻求尊重。“毕竟，”我推理道，“如果我是周围最好的程序员，他们就必须体面地对待我。” 我确实取得了一些职业上的成功，但它并没有真正弥补那些童年的缺陷。一方面，无论我有多好，我都不是完美的，也不是不可或缺的，所以没有人 会 尊重我。

When I was a child, I was often treated as something less than a human being. This kind of treatment warped my thinking in several ways. It made me obsessed with seeking respect through my professional work. "After all," I reasoned, "if I'm the best programmer around, they'll have to treat me decently." I did achieve some professional success, but it never really made up for those childhood deficiencies. For one thing, no matter how good I was, I was never perfect and never indispensable, so nobody had to respect me.

但即使当人们确实欣赏我的好工作并体面地对待我时，我仍然不满意。我真正想要的是简单的个人尊重。实际上，我对自己说，“他们并不是真正尊重我这个人；他们尊重我是因为我所做的出色工作。”

But even when people did appreciate my good work and treated me decently, I still wasn't satisfied. What I really wanted was simple personal respect. I said to myself, in effect, "They don't really respect me as a person; they respect me because of the good work I do."

最终，我开始明白，我真正想要的是他能够尊重 我自己。 没有其他人可以给我那个，尽管其他人已经能够把它拿走。当我终于能够彬彬有礼地对待自己时，我和空乘人员相处得更好——他们甚至对我的专业成就一无所知！

Eventually, I came to understand that what I truly wanted was to he able to respect myself. Nobody else could give me that, though other people had been able to take it away. When I finally was able to treat myself courteously, I got along much better with airline attendants—and they don't even know anything about my professional accomplishments!

我也觉得我现在对粗鲁行为有了更好的理解，即使是针对我的。粗鲁的人，在他们粗鲁的时候，很少尊重 自己。 有时我们都会有这种感觉，就像我们在长途飞行中被关起来一样。但有些人几乎一直都很粗鲁——他们就是我的黑名单上的人。

I also feel I now have a better understanding of rude behavior, even when it is directed at me. Rude people, at the time they're being rude, have very little respect for themselves. We all feel that way sometimes, as when we are sitting cooped up on a long flight. But some people are rude almost all the time—and they're the ones who go on my blacklist.

名人对自己缺乏尊重的原因有很多。他们可能像我一样寻求成功，以弥补童年的虐待。或者，在成名之后，他们可能对仰慕者的梦想与自己内心现实之间的差异非常敏感。

There are many reasons why celebrities may feel little respect for themselves. They may have sought success, as I did, to make up for childhood abuse. Or, having found fame, they may be acutely sensitive to the discrepancies between their admirers' dreams and their own inner realities.

如果你擅长你所选择的职业，你将不得不面对关于你自己的这些事实。由于我们的社会经济体系奖励职业成功的方式，人们很容易相信外在的成功等于内在的价值。但你的一部分永远不会被愚弄。随着你内在的价值感与外在的成功标志之间的差异越来越大，紧张情绪将蔓延到航空公司的女服务员身上。或者告诉任何其他碰巧见证你令人痛苦的秘密的人。

If you're good at your chosen profession, you'll have to confront such facts about yourself. Because of the way our socioeconomic system rewards professional success, it's all too easy to believe outward success equals inner worth. But part of you is never fooled. As the discrepancy grows between your inner feelings of worth and your outer trappings of success, the tension will spill over onto the airline hostess. Or onto anyone else who happens to be witness to your distressing secret.

所以不要太担心你是否在航空公司的计算机化黑名单上。担心你是不是一个人！

So don't worry too much about whether you're on the airline's computerized blacklist. Worry about whether you're on your own!

蝴蝶与毛茛：一个寓言

The Butterfly and the Buttercup: A Fable

从前，一只蝴蝶遇到了一株孤零零地生长在长满青草的山丘上的毛茛属植物。蝴蝶说：“你是我见过的最美丽的蝴蝶，因为你的翅膀非常漂亮。”

Once upon a time, a butterfly came upon a buttercup growing alone on a grassy hill. The butterfly said, "You are the most beautiful butterfly I have ever seen, for the delicacy of your wings is a sight to behold."

毛茛回答说：“我所知道的任何一朵花都没有你这样自由自在的精神，因为你的动作似乎几乎不受微风的影响。” 于是他们相爱了。

The buttercup replied, "No other flower I have known has such a free spirit as you, for your motion seems almost independent of the breezes." And so they fell in love.

一只停在附近叶子上的甲虫看着这朵浪漫的花朵，向这对恋人喊道：“你们这些笨蛋，你们不知道不同物种的成员不能生育可育的后代吗？睁大眼睛，理性地对待自己的所作所为。”

A beetle resting on a nearby leaf observed the blossoming romance and called out to the lovers, "You ninnies, don't you know that members of different species cannot produce fertile offspring. Open your eyes and be rational about what you are doing."

但是蝴蝶和毛茛爱得要死，耳朵和眼睛都闭着，甲虫的劝告他们一个字也听不进去。因此，他们在余下的夏天生活中一直幸福地相爱——尽管没有孩子。另一方面，甲虫在接下来的几年里产下了 38,312 个卵，其中 8,729 个卵孵化了。最终，甲虫被一个爬山看蝴蝶和毛茛的年轻女孩脚下压扁了。

But the butterfly and the buttercup were so much in love their ears as well as their eyes were closed, and they did not hear a word of the beetle's advice. Consequently, they remained happily in love—though childless—for the remainder of their summer's life. The beetle, on the other hand, laid 38,312 eggs in the next few years—8,729 of which hatched. Eventually, the beetle was squashed under the foot of a young girl climbing the hill to look at the butterflies and buttercups.

寓意：做一只不育的蝴蝶或一只破烂的毛茛，总比做一只聪明、丰富的甲虫要好。

Moral: It's still better to be a barren butterfly or a battered buttercup than a brilliant, bountiful beetle.

换句话说：那些受生产力驱动的人几乎不可能理解那些受质量驱动的人，反之亦然。

In other words: It's well nigh impossible for those who are motivated by productivity to understand those who are motivated by quality—and vice versa.

第四章 更有效地思考是否可能？

Chapter IV Is It Possible to Think More Effectively?

为什么人们不思考？

Why Don't People Think?

我从伦敦的大卫·弗林特收到一封 发人深省的信，开头是这样的：

A thought-provoking letter I received from David Flint of London begins:

我怀疑 SP [结构化编程] 遭受的最大缺陷是 Dijkstra 原信的标题。自从人们假设他们只是通过避免 GOTO 就可以执行结构化编程并且他们已经改进了他们的代码。当我试图向 Post Office 的其他程序员和分析师解释 SP 概念时，我对此感到非常震惊。

I suspect that the greatest disability from which SP [structured programming] suffers is the title of Dijkstra's original letter. Ever since people have supposed that simply by avoiding GOTOs they are performing structured programming and that they have improved their code. I was very struck by this when attempting to explain the SP concepts to other programmers and analysts in the Post Office.

在我看来，SP 的关键不在于程序应该结构化。每个程序都有一个结构，但 SP 说它们应该结构良好。人们抵制它，因为它听起来很主观，而且它比简单地消除 GOTO 更困难。程序员，至少在商业商店中，太急于编码而不愿思考——也许你应该写一篇文章，说明为什么会这样，以及可以采取什么措施。（实际上，我认为原因很明显。）

In my view the key to SP is not that programs should be structured. Every program has a structure, but SP says they should be well-structured. People resist this because it sounds subjective and because it is more difficult than simply banishing GOTOs. Programmers, at least in commercial shops, are too eager to code and too reluctant to think—perhaps you should write an article on why this is so and what might be done about it. (Actually the causes are fairly obvious I think.)

在这件事上，我一直和大卫弗林特在一起，直到 显而易见这个词。 我在学习数学的过程中学会了提防 “明显” 或 “明显”这两个词。 它们是旨在让您的思维沉睡的词语，而这正是我们不想做的。所以这里有一个很好的规则——也许比“消除所有 GOTO”更好：

I was with David Flint all the way in this, up to the word obvious. I learned in the study of mathematics to beware of the words obvious or obviously. They are words designed to lull your thinking to sleep, which is just what we don't want to do. So here's a good rule for you—better perhaps than "eliminate all GOTOs":

每当您发现“摇篮曲词”时，请醒来！

Whenever you spot a "lullaby word," wake up!

Daniel Freedman 和我在我们的演练、检查和技术审查手册 中列出了几页摇篮曲。我们在阅读/审查规范时将它们用作触发器。它们包括这样的可爱之处： 所有，所有曲调，每个，可能，唯一，相同，应该，也，将，当然，因此，清楚，显然， 或者 任何傻瓜都能清楚地看到。 在我们的语言中存在这样的摇篮曲词暗示了大卫可能一直在暗示人们不思考的一些原因：

Daniel Freedman and I have listed several pages of lullaby words in our Handbook of Walkthroughs, Inspections, and Technical Reviews. We use them as triggers when we're reading/reviewing specifications. They include such lovelies as: all, all the tune, every, may, only, same, should, too, will, certainly, therefore, clearly, obviously, or as any fool can plainly see. The existence of such lullaby words in our language suggests some of the reasons David might have been hinting at why people don't think:

1. 某人不希望他们思考，并且以不鼓励思考的方式写作或讲话。

1. Somebody doesn't want them to think and is writing or speaking in such a way as to discourage thinking.

2. 没有人关心他们是否思考，但我们的说话习惯很容易让我们听起来非常自信，而实际上我们可能并不如此，从而阻碍了思考。

2. Nobody cares whether they think or not, but our habits of speech easily discourage thinking by making us sound very sure of ourselves when we may not be.

为什么语言会阻止我们思考？好吧，大多数时候（当然是在编程之外）思考会让你陷入很多麻烦。在大多数工作环境中，如果你想得太多，你就是在拿你的工作冒险，因为工作已经常规化了。思考被认为是管理的特权，就像书柜旁边的橡胶厂一样。

Why would language discourage us from thinking? Well, most of the time (outside of programming, certainly) thinking gets you into a lot of trouble. In most work environments, you're risking your job if you think very much, because work has been routinized. Thinking is believed to be a privilege of management, like a rubber plant next to your credenza.

即使在你的私人生活中，思考也是昂贵的。如果你不得不考虑你吃的每一口食物，或者每次你过马路，你就没有时间做其他事情了。因此，您将生活例行公事，以避免思考并节省时间用于其他事情——可能用于思考需要 思考的事情 。

Even in your private life, thinking is expensive. If you had to think about each bite of food you ate, or each time you crossed the street, you'd have little time for anything else. So you routinize your life in order to avoid thinking and save your time for other things—possibly for thinking about things that require thinking.

这同样适用于编程。如果我们确实碰巧发现了一些简单的规则，它总是有效并且避免了思考的必要性，那么我们应该应用该规则。把思想留到需要的地方。

The same applies to programming. If we do happen to find some simple rule that always works and avoids the necessity for thinking, then we should apply the rule. Save the thinking for where it's needed.

例如，PL/I 和 COBOL 允许对某些关键字使用缩写，但缩写是可选的。这意味着每次编写这些单词之一时，您可能都必须考虑是使用缩写形式还是非缩写形式。尽管您可以在双方争论不休，但只要您始终如一地使用特定关键字做一件事或另一件事，这真的无关紧要。因此，我总是通过一劳永逸地决定是否缩写特定关键字来消除不必要的思考。因此，我从不拼出 CORRESPONDING 或 ENVIRONMENT，我总是拼出 CHARACTER 和 PICTURE。这是一个愚蠢的习惯，但它是有目的的。

For example, PL/I and COBOL allow the use of abbreviations for certain keywords, but the abbreviations are optional. This means each time you code one of these words, you might have to think about whether to use the abbreviated or unabbreviated form. Although you can muster arguments on both sides, it really doesn't matter much as long as you do one thing or another consistently with a particular keyword. Therefore, I always eliminate unnecessary thinking by deciding once and for all whether to abbreviate a particular keyword. Consequently, I never spell out CORRESPONDING or ENVIRONMENT, and I always spell out CHARACTER and PICTURE. It's a stupid habit, but it serves a purpose.

当然，如果我将一些材料作为系统的一部分对这些关键字进行不同的标准编码，我会愿意调整我的习惯。但这会花费我一些努力。我的一些想法将不得不转移到记住要遵循的系统上。自然地，我会很高兴有一个系统可以让我选择，但我不会浪费任何更有价值的想法来哀叹它的缺席。

Of course, if I were coding some material as part of a system with a different standard for those keywords, I'd willingly adjust my habits. But it would cost me some effort. Some of my thought would have to be diverted to remembering which system to follow. Naturally, I would appreciate having a system sparing me the choice, but I'm not going to waste any more valuable thought bemoaning its absence.

这引出了人们不喜欢思考的另一个原因：

This brings up another reason why people don't like to think:

3. 思考很累，可能妨碍其他思考。

3. Thinking is tiring and may prevent other thinking.

当一个程序员第一次开始编写结构化程序时，很多省心的习惯都被抛弃了。（“这是我写循环的方式”，“这是我处理三向决策的方式。”）过去这些习惯是省心的，但现在用其他习惯代替它们会 耗费心思 . 在过渡期间，我们所感受到的只是额外的思想成本和很少的思想节省。

When a programmer first starts to write structured programs, a lot of thought-saving habits have to go out the window. ("This is the way I write a loop," "This is the way I handle a three-way decision.") In the past these habits have been thought-saving, but now it will cost thought to replace them with other habits. During the transition, all we feel is the extra thought-cost and very little of the thought-saving.

但“禁止 GOTO”规则实际上是另一种节省思想的习惯（至少对我而言）。当我发现自己开始写 GOTO 时，我将它用作触发词而不是摇篮曲词。我对自己说： “Weinberg，过去当你在类似情况下不假思索地写了一个 GOTO 时，你已经陷入了很多额外的思考。所以，为什么不现在就想一想，也许以后需要的时候省去很多思考。”

But the "no GOTO'' rule is actually another thought-saving habit (for me at least). When I find myself starting to write a GOTO, I use it as a trigger word rather than a lullaby word. I say to myself: "Weinberg, you've gotten into a lot of extra thinking in the past when you unthinkingly wrote a GOTO in similar situations. So why not think a little now and perhaps save a lot of thinking later, when you'll need it."

结构化编程的所有其他规则——或任何良好的编程风格——都是这种类型的触发规则。他们说：“当你认识到这种情况时，停止睡觉并开始思考。”

All of the other rules of structured programming—or of any good programming style—are this type of trigger rule. They say: "When you recognize this situation, stop sleeping and start thinking."

你不能一直全神贯注地工作，即使你在做像开车这样危险的事情。所以当事情变得危险时，你积累了一组触发器来唤醒你。当你开车时，触发器是诸如红灯和黄灯、警报器、滚到街上的球、孩子们玩耍或前面的司机来回穿梭等事情。

You can't operate on full consciousness all the time, even when you're doing something as dangerous as driving a car. So you accumulate a set of triggers to wake you up when things are getting dangerous. When you are driving, the triggers are such things as red and yellow lights, sirens, balls rolling into the street, children playing, or drivers ahead weaving from side to side.

在编程中，代码中存在触发器，例如 GOTO 语句、错综复杂的 IF-THEN-ELSE 逻辑、不适合的同源部分、乱码接口以及任何需要注释多于代码的代码。

In programming, there are triggers in the code, such as GOTO statements, tangled IF-THEN-ELSE logic, homologous parts that don't fit, garbled interfaces, and any code requiring more comments than code.

在我们的工作坊中，我们将“触发按钮”分发给需要学习触发他们说出的某些让他们陷入麻烦的词的参与者——他们用来哄自己或其他人入睡的词。例如，我们最喜欢的按钮之一是

In our workshops, we pass out "trigger buttons" to participants who need to learn to trigger on certain words they utter that get them into trouble—words they use to lull themselves or others to sleep. For instance, one of our favorite buttons is

不可能。

THERE'S NO WAY.

显然（！），当你​​说出这句话时，你实际上是在说，“考虑那个是没有意义的，因为这是不可能的。” 当我们听到“There's no way”时，我们会立即奖励肇事者必须佩戴的按钮，直到学会不说出这首摇篮曲——或者至少学会在它出现时抓住它并将其用作思想触发器。

Obviously (!), when you utter this sentence you're saying, in effect, "There's no sense thinking about that, since it's impossible." When we hear "There's no way," we immediately award a button the perpetrator has to wear until learning not to utter this lullaby phrase—or at least learning to catch the phrase as it emerges and use it as a thought trigger.

我们按钮上另一个最喜欢的摇篮曲是

Another favorite lullaby phrase on our buttons is

什么可能出错？

WHAT CAN POSSIBLY GO WRONG?

这直接引出了大卫信中的第二部分：

This leads directly to the second part of David's letter:

对于您的宗教信仰，我可以建议“怀疑设计”吗？关键概念是您应该在进行时检查您的假设和设计。作为你的第一本神圣文本，我建议伯特兰罗素的建议：“无论你相信什么；不要 完全相信它。” 当然，拉塞尔有更大的问题。

For your religion may I suggest "Skeptical Design"? The key concept being that you should examine your assumptions and designs as you proceed. As your first sacred text I suggest Bertrand Russell's advice: "Whatever you believe; do not altogether believe it." Russell had rather larger questions in view, of course.

“怀疑设计”是新编程宗教的超级名称，尽管 Russell 可能会在坟墓中旋转以听到他的建议被用作神圣的文本。下次当您对刚刚完成的设计感到特别满意时，不要问自己 “ 可能会出什么问题？” 而是问“可能会出什么 问题 ？”

"Skeptical Design" is a super name for the new programming religion, though Russell would probably spin in his grave to hear his advice used as a sacred text. Next time you're particularly satisfied with the design you've just completed, don't ask yourself "What can possibly go wrong?" but instead ask "What can possibly go wrong?"

而且，当然，这种想法可能导致人们不认为的最重要原因：

And, of course, this thought leads to perhaps the most important reason of all that people don't think:

4.如果我想太多，我可能会发现它不对劲，然后我会在哪里？

4. If I think about it too much, I might discover something wrong with it, and then where will I be?

再一次，这不完全是一个愚蠢的想法。几十年来，在学校里，我们被教导“老师没抓到，就不算错”。那么，当我们知道老师不会真的有时间看我们的作品时，为什么要给自己找麻烦呢？

Once again, this isn't entirely a stupid idea. For dozens of years, in schools, we're taught"if the teacher doesn't catch it, it isn't wrong." So why make trouble for ourselves, when we know the teacher won't really have time to look at our work?

但是计算机编程与学校作业几乎没有相似之处。“老师”——电脑——看着 所有 的作品，任何错误都会被放大成百上千倍。在学校里，把头埋在沙子里是值得的——大多数时候——那么我们为什么要期望人们在为计算机编写程序时表现得不一样呢？

But computer programming bears very little resemblance to schoolwork. The "teacher"—the computer—looks at all of the work, and whatever is wrong is magnified hundreds or thousands of times. In school, it pays to bury your head in the sand—most of the time—so why should we expect people to behave otherwise when they're writing programs for computers?

总而言之，我提出了四个人们不思考的“明显”原因：

In sum, I've come up with four "obvious" reasons why people don't think:

1. 有人希望他们不要思考。

1. Somebody wants them not to think.

2. 没人在乎他们想不想。

2. Nobody cares whether or not they think.

3. 想太多可能会破坏大脑用于其他目的。

3. Thinking too much may destroy the brain for other purposes.

4. 我们从来没有在学校里学会思考。

4. We never learned to think in school.

显然， 这个列表不可能是错误的或不完整的。想接受挑战吗？

Obviously, there's no way this list can possibly be wrong or incomplete. Want to take up the challenge?

你是哪种思想家？

What Kind of Thinker Are You?

这里有一个叫做“岛屿之谜”的问题。它被广泛讨论为衡量不同思维方式的标准。它最初由 Robert Karplus 于 1970 年左右出版，已被用于培训教师识别不同的问题解决方式。对于大学生来说，这可能是一个挑战，但对于专业的程序员来说，应该是小菜一碟。还是应该？试一试，但要小心。写下你的答案和推理，然后看看我的笔记，看看你对它们的反应。

Here's a problem called the Island's Puzzle. It's been much discussed as a measure of different styles of thinking. It was originally published by Robert Karplus around 1970 and has been used in training teachers to recognize different problem-solving styles. For college students, it may be quite a challenge, but for professional programmers, it should be quite a snap. Or should it? Have a go at it, but be careful. Write down your answers and reasoning, then look at my notes and see how you react to them.

群岛之谜

The Islands Puzzle

谜题是关于海洋中的岛屿 A、B、C 和 D。多年来，人们一直乘船在这些岛屿之间穿梭，但最近一家航空公司开始营业。仔细阅读有关可能的飞机旅行的线索。这些旅行可能是直接的，也可能包括在岛上停留和换机。如果可以旅行，可以在岛屿之间的任一方向进行。您可以在地图上做笔记或标记以帮助使用线索。

The puzzle is about islands A, B, C, and D in the ocean. People have been traveling among these islands by boat for many years, but recently an airline started in business. Carefully read the clues about possible plane trips. The trips may be direct or include stops and plane changes on an island. When a trip is possible, it can be made in either direction between the islands. You may make notes or marks on the map to help use the clues.

第一条线索： 人们可以乘飞机往返于 C 岛和 D 岛之间。

First Clue: People can go by plane between islands C and D.

第二条线索： 人们 不能 乘飞机往返于 A 岛和 B 岛之间，即使是间接的。

Second Clue: People cannot go by plane between islands A and B, even indirectly.

使用这两条线索回答问题 1。先不要阅读下一条线索。

Use these two clues to answer question 1. Do not read the next clue yet.

问题一： B岛和D岛之间可以坐飞机吗？

Question 1: Can people go by plane between islands B and D?

Yes or No or Can't 从这两条线索中分辨出来。

Yes or No or Can't tell from the two clues.

请解释你的答案。

Please explain your answer.

线索三：（现在不要改问题1的答案。）B岛和D岛之间可以坐飞机。

Third Clue: (Do not change your answer to question 1 now.) People can go by plane between islands B and D.

使用所有三个线索回答问题 2 和 3。

Use all three clues to answer questions 2 and 3.

问题二： B岛和C岛之间可以坐飞机吗？

Question 2: Can people go by plane between islands B and C?

Yes or No or Can't 从三个线索判断。

Yes or No or Can't tell from the three clues.

请解释你的答案。

Please explain your answer.

问题三： A岛和C岛之间可以坐飞机吗？

Question 3: Can people go by plane between islands A and C?

Yes or No or Can't 从三个线索判断。

Yes or No or Can't tell from the three clues.

请解释你的答案。

Please explain your answer.

岛屿拼图笔记

Notes on the Islands Puzzle

1. 问题陈述说行程“可能是直接的或包括停靠点”。显然，这个谜题中的术语不同于标准的航空公司术语，因为直飞航班可能包括经停。我最好小心——可能还有其他我不理解的术语。

1. The problem statement says a trip "may be direct or include stops." Evidently, the terminology in this puzzle is different from standard airline terminology, as a direct flight may include stops. I'd better be careful—there may be other terms I don't understand.

2. 我对航空旅行了解很多。考虑到术语可能存在的困难，我可以在这个谜题中使用这些知识吗？也许我比拼图的创造者更了解航空旅行，在这种情况下，我可能会看到人们看不到的解决方案。当我与旅行社合作时，这种情况经常发生。他们应该知道很多，但我比他们去过更多的地方，去过世界上许多不同的地方。

2. I know a lot about air travel. Can I use any of that knowledge in this puzzle, in view of the possible difficulty in terminology? Perhaps I know more about air travel than the creator of the puzzle, in which case I might see solutions that person couldn't see. That happens often when I work with travel agents. They're supposed to know a lot, but I've travelled much more than they, to many different parts of the world.

3. 第一条线索很简单——你可以查看 航空公司指南 ，看到飞机从 C 飞到 D。但是第二条线索看起来很可疑。你怎么能看出你不能从一个地方去另一个地方？这种信息的来源是什么？必须有一个推理过程，例如：

3. The first clue is straightforward enough—you can look in the Airline Guide and see that planes go from C to D. But the second clue looks suspicious. How can you see that you cannot go from one place to another? What can be the source of this kind of information? There must be a reasoning process involved, such as:

一个。没有人被允许飞往 A 岛，要么是因为没有机场，要么是因为有法律限制，或者诸如此类的事情。

a. Nobody is allowed to fly to island A, either because there is no airport or because there are legal restrictions, or some such thing.

b. 旅行社查了也没办法。

b. The travel agent has checked and hasn't been able to find a way.

C。可能有办法，但旅行社认为停留时间太长（我经常遇到这种情况），所以只说“不可能”。

c. There may be a way, but the travel agent thinks that layovers will be too long (this has happened to me often) and so just says it's "impossible."

d. 可能会有限制，例如隔离，禁止任何从 B 开始的人在 A 结束，如果他们乘飞机去的话。

d. There may be restrictions, such as quarantines, forbidding anyone starting in B to end up in A, if they go by plane.

4.还有很多其他的可能性，但是3(d)让我重新审视了线索的陈述：“人们不能在A岛和B岛之间乘飞机，即使是间接的。” 这听起来绝对像是一个传染病问题，或者可能是一个政治问题。如果是这样，通常有办法解决它——贿赂、疫苗接种证书、高级政府官员的介绍信、接受搜身或其他任何方式。因此，虽然我们没有足够的信息，但我们确实有充分的理由怀疑我们线索的来源。他们可能不知道；他们可能会误解；他们可能有误导我们的动机。这里有很多比满足眼睛。

4. There are lots of other possibilities, but 3(d) made me look again at the statement of the clue: "People cannot go by plane between islands A and B, even indirectly." That definitely sounds like a contagious disease problem, or perhaps a political problem. If so, there are usually ways around it—bribes, vaccination certificates, letters of introduction from high government officials, submission to body search, or whatever. So although we don't have nearly enough information, we do have good reason to suspect the source of our clues. They may not know; they may misunderstand; they may have motives for misleading us. There's a lot more here than meets the eye.

5、关于问题1，目前我们对两条线索的了解肯定不够。我们确实知道飞机可以去 D，但也许飞机根本不能去 B。不过，这不太可能。我曾经被告知我们不能飞往塔斯马尼亚的玛丽亚岛，所以我们租了一架飞机飞往那里。B 看起来像是最大的岛屿。它可能是多山的，但玛丽亚岛也是，我们找到了一块小平地可以降落。尽管如此，最好是安全地说“不能从两条线索中分辨出来”，即使除了标记为“线索”的东西之外还有许多其他线索——岛屿的大小、相对于距离的大小、乘船旅行的知识（我们采取了浮桥船开往礁岛），关于我们的线人缺乏知识的信息，等等。

5. As to Question 1, we certainly don't have enough information in the two clues so far. We do know that planes can go to D, but perhaps planes cannot go to B at all. Still, that's pretty unlikely. I was once told that we couldn't fly to Maria Island in Tasmania, so we rented a plane and flew there. B looks like the biggest of the islands. It might be mountainous, but so was Maria Island, and we found a little flat field to land on. Still, best to be safe and say "Can't tell from the two clues" even though there are many other clues than the things labeled "clues"—size of islands, size relative to distances, knowledge there was boat travel (we took pontoon boats out to the reef islands), information about lack of knowledge of our informant, and so on.

6、我们来看第三条线索。啊哈！这是否意味着有人总是可以从 B 到 D，或者现在有新的服务？首先，我们的线人并没有完全不告诉我们。其次，我们了解到这家岛屿航空公司的情况可以迅速改变。所以这是一个充满信息的线索。

6. Let's look at the third clue. Aha! Does this mean someone could always go from B to D, or that there is now new service? In the first instance, our informant wasn't very thorough not to tell us. In the second, we've learned things can change rapidly with this island airline. So it's a clue full of information.

7. 在尝试回答问题 2 时，如果航空公司时刻表发生变化，我们可能会遇到危险，正如线索 3 可能暗示的那样。如果他们没有，您很可能能够通过 D 从 B 到 C，但可能会有隔离限制等。我想我最好给出的答案是“从3条线索看不出来”。我什至不知道这个问题指的是哪三个线索，或者更早的线索是否仍然有效，如果它们曾经有效的话。

7. In trying to answer question 2, we could be in danger if things have changed on the airline schedules, as clue 3 might imply. If they haven't, you are likely to be able to make it from B to C via D, but there could be quarantine restrictions and the like. The answer I think I'd better give is "Can't tell from the 3 clues." I don't even know which three clues the question refers to, or if earlier clues are still valid, if they ever were.

8. 关于问题 3，我们仍然不知道 A 是否有飞机，但我们仍然可以租到一架飞机。如果线索 2 绝对正确，并且在航空公司更改航班时刻表或旅行社了解更多信息后仍然有效，那么我想你可以得出结论，从 A 到 C 不可能乘飞机。但这不是我环游世界的经历，所以我当然不想说“不”。在概率的基础上，“是”似乎是可能的，如果我的生活取决于给出正确的答案，我不得不说“不能说”。但是，如果我的工作取决于从 A 到 C，我肯定不会因为目前所见而放弃。我想我会打电话给包机公司，也许会打电话给另一家旅行社。如果经验有意义的话，我

8. As to question 3, we still don't even know if A is served by planes at all, yet we still might be able to rent one. If clue 2 was absolutely true, and was still valid after the airline had changed its schedule or after the travel agent had learned more, then I suppose you could conclude that going from A to C by plane was impossible. But that's not been my experience in traveling all over the world, so I'd certainly not want to say "no." On a probability basis, "yes" seems likely, if my life depended on giving the right answer, I'd have to say "can't tell." But if my job depended on getting from A to C, I sure wouldn't give up on the basis of what I've seen so far. I think I'd call a charter company and perhaps call another travel agent. If experience means anything, I'd probably find a flight from A to C and get a saving on my fare as well.

反应

Reactions

真正的问题是：“你对我的分析有何看法？”

The real question is this: "How did you feel about my analysis?"

一个。我觉得你在拉我的腿。

a. I felt you were pulling my leg.

b. 我觉得你错过了问题的重点。

b. I felt you missed the point of the question.

C。我觉得我错过了问题的重点。

c. I felt I missed the point of the question.

d. 我觉得你在方法上是对的，但在推理上是错误的。

d. I felt you were right in approach, but wrong in reasoning.

e. 我觉得你的方法和推理与提出问题的人的预期推理一样有意义。

e. I felt your approach and reasoning made as much sense as the intended reasoning of the people who made up the problem.

F。我觉得以上都是真的，也都是假的。

f. I felt all of the above were true, and false as well.

G。我觉得以上都不是真的。

g. I felt none of the above were true.

H。我觉得我不会标记这个愚蠢问题的任何答案。我从不允许自己有感情，尤其是选择题和谜题。

h. I felt I wouldn't mark any answer to this stupid question. I never allow myself to have feelings, especially about multiple-choice questions and puzzles.

一世。我不确定这一切的意义何在，只是为了让我和你对一些我们认为理所当然的事情产生想法。尤其是我们如何将学校作为生活的典范，而生活确实比学校的谜题复杂得多——即使是那些旨在展示如何在现实生活中更好地思考的谜题。

i. I'm not sure what is the point of all this, except to joggle my thinking and yours about some of the things we take for granted. Especially how we take school as a model of life, when indeed life is infinitely more complex than school puzzles—even those intended to show how to think better in real life.

有人建议，如果你“正确”地解决了 Isl​​ands Puzzle，你可能是一个优秀的程序员，而如果你或多或少地像我那样做，你可能是一个优秀的系统分析师（尽管不一定是一个糟糕的程序员）。至于我，几十年来我已经了解了分析师和程序员以及他们的经理的头号问题。他们假设太多了。他们特别假设他们知道他们正在处理什么样的问题。对他们来说，这是一个 难题 ，而不是 问题。

Someone has suggested that if you get the Islands Puzzle "right," you may be a good programmer, whereas if you did it more or less the way I did, you may be a good systems analyst (though not necessarily a bad programmer). As for me, over many decades I've learned the number-one problem of both analysts and programmers—as well as their managers. They assume too much. They especially assume they know what kind of problem they're working on. To them, it's a puzzle and not a problem.

是专注还是强迫？

Is It Concentration or Compulsion?

每个职业都有它的秘密。当然，我们的秘密必须 保密 ，但来自其他职业的任何秘密都会吸引我们好色的天性。在所有的秘密中，医学秘密必须是最有趣的。与大多数人不同，我很幸运有一个姐夫马文，他是一名医生，而且是一个相当愤世嫉俗的人。马文向我保证，医学的一大秘密是 90 % 的疾病都可以自行治愈——完全不需要医生的干预。因为 这个 天大的秘密，医生需要做的就是避免伤害病人。好吧，几乎所有。一位成功的医生还必须让病人相信正在采取一些措施来治愈这种疾病——这只能来自医生大量深奥的医学知识。否则，很快就会有医生在排队等候救济。

Every profession has its secrets. Naturally, ours must be kept secret, but any secret from another profession appeals to our prurient nature. And of all the secrets, medical secrets have to be the juiciest. Unlike most people, I was blessed with a brother-in-law, Marvin, who was a doctor, and a rather cynical one at that. One of the great secrets of medicine, Marvin assured me, is that 90 percent of all illness cures itself—with absolutely no intervention from the doctor. Because of this great secret, all the doctor needs to do is avoid harming the patient. Well, almost all. A successful doctor must also convince the patient that something is being done to cure the disease—something that could only come from the doctor's vast store of esoteric medical knowledge. Otherwise, there would soon be doctors on the breadlines.

90%的病能自愈的原因在于身体的智慧。虽然“智慧”听起来很神秘，但它只是对数千代破坏性测试的最终结果的诗意总结，这些测试在数以亿计的平行复制中进行，每次复制持续数十年。这些世代和测试中的大多数都没有现代医学的好处，因此任何缺乏自我治疗智慧的身体设计都被立即从人群中移除。毕竟，我们每个人都是无数不间断的幸存者的直系后裔。

The reason 90 percent of all illness cures itself lies in the wisdom of the body. Although "wisdom" sounds mysterious, it's merely a poetical summary of the end result of thousands of generations of destructive testing carried on in thousands of millions of parallel replications, each lasting several decades. Most of those generations and tests were without benefit of modern medicine, so any body design lacking the wisdom to cure itself was summarily removed from the population. Each of us, after all, is the direct descendant of innumerable unbroken lines of survivors.

不幸的是，这个小小的医学秘密对计算机人员没有太大帮助。正如我们所知，“程序的智慧”几乎没有（如果有的话）。每个计算机程序几乎没有祖先。不管它经历过什么样的测试，它的生命周期都很短，所以几乎没有时间和空间来进行数百代、数百万次的测试。这就是计算机编程是一个比医学要求更高的职业的原因之一。以及为什么我们永远不会陷入困境。

Unfortunately, this little medical secret isn't much help to computer people. As we know, there's very little, if any, "wisdom of the program." Each computer program has few if any ancestors. Whatever testing it has survived has been in its own short lifetime, so there's hardly been the time or space to perform hundreds of generations of thousands of millions of tests. That's one of the reasons computer programming is a much more demanding profession than medicine. And why we'll never be on breadlines.

作为一个要求很高的职业，计算机程序员需要来自其他职业的所有可能的帮助。尽管医学的大秘密帮不上什么忙，马文还是教了我一些你可能会用到的其他秘密。首先是青霉素。在 10% 的无法自行治愈的疾病中，青霉素或其他一些抗生素可以轻松治愈另外 90% 的疾病。然而，与流行的看法相反，仅靠抗生素是不够的。它们必须是使用过的财产，这就是医生登场的地方。

Being in a demanding profession, the computer programmer needs all possible help from other professions. And even though the big secret of medicine won't help much, Marvin taught me a few other secrets you just might be able to use. First of all, there's penicillin. Of the 10 percent of illnesses that don't cure themselves, penicillin or some other antibiotic handily dispatches another 90 percent. Contrary to popular belief, though, antibiotics alone aren't sufficient. They must be used property, and that's where the doctor comes on stage.

例如，每次感冒时不分青红皂白地吐出青霉素药片会造成真正的伤害。首先，感冒是 90% 可以自愈的疾病之一，因此青霉素没有任何好处。这可能是心理上的帮助，但一颗惰性药丸也能起到同样的作用。无论如何，青霉素都不是惰性的。虽然它不影响感冒，但它会影响其他事情。至少，它会影响您的身体对青霉素的敏感性，所以有一天当您真的需要一些青霉素时，它可能几乎没有效果或没有效果。更糟糕的是，它可能会引起过敏反应。

For instance, indiscriminate popping of penicillin pills every time you have a cold can cause real harm. First off, the cold is one of the 90 percent of illnesses that will cure itself, so the penicillin does no good whatsoever. It might be of psychological assistance, but an inert pill would do that just as well. Penicillin, in any case, is not inert. Though it's not affecting the cold, it is affecting other things. At the very least, it's affecting your body's sensitivity to penicillin, so someday when you really need some, it may have little or no effect. Even worse, it may provoke an allergic reaction.

青霉素的另一个常见医学问题与滥用正好相反。也许是因为所有关于爆破药片危险的警告，人们经常过早地停止服用抗生素药片。如果最明显和最不舒服的症状没有迅速消失，他们就不会完成规定的疗程，而是停止治疗。在细菌感染的情况下，即使有害生物得到控制，这些症状可能仍然存在。但如果治疗停止得太早，疾病又会卷土重来。而这一次，它可能对抗生素产生了耐药性。

Another common medical problem with penicillin is just the opposite of indiscriminate use. Perhaps because of all the warnings about the dangers of popping pills, people frequently stop taking their antibiotic pills too soon. Rather than complete the prescribed course of treatment, they stop if the most obvious and uncomfortable symptoms don't quickly disappear. In the case of bacterial infections, these symptoms may remain even though the offending organisms are being brought under control. But if the treatment stops too soon, the disease springs back. And this time, it's probably resistant to the antibiotic.

你看到与编程的平行吗？在解决棘手问题时，您是否曾过早地放弃了一条有前途的攻击路线——仅仅因为您不得不投入过多的精力才能看到​​任何明确的结果？大多数程序员都熟悉这种痛苦的经历。这就是为什么他们能够专注于一个问题而排除所有世俗的担忧。给我看一个从未在咖啡休息时间工作的程序员，我会告诉你一个平庸的程序员。给我看一个从不抱怨被重要思路分心的程序员，我会给你看一具程序员的尸体。

Do you see the parallel with programming? When attacking a tough problem, have you ever given up a promising line of attack prematurely—merely because you had to invest too much concentrated effort before seeing any definite results? Most programmers are familiar with this bitter experience. That's why they're able to concentrate on one problem to the exclusion of all worldly concerns. Show me the programmer who's never worked through a coffee break, and I'll show you a mediocre programmer. Show me a programmer who's never complained about being distracted from an important train of thought, and I'll show you a programmer's corpse.

不过，现在请允许我分散您对注意力问题的注意力。我想分享马文的另一个医疗秘密。事实上，马文不仅仅是一名医学博士，而是一名精神科医生。（不，这不是秘密。）在所有医学八卦中，没有比疯子的故事更引人入胜的了。然而，这个故事不是关于疯子的，而是关于精神病医生的——每个人都知道他们不可能是疯子，尽管他们可能不是很聪明。

For the moment, though, allow me to distract you from the question of concentration. I want to share another of Marvin's medical secrets. Actually, Marvin was not a mere M.D. but a psychiatrist. (No, that's not the secret.) Of all the medical gossip, none is more fascinating than the stories about crazy people. This story, however, is not about crazy people, but about psychiatrists—who everyone knows can't possibly be crazy, though they may not be very bright.

每个月一次，马文都会开车去州立精神病院，就他们最顽固的病例咨询工作人员。这种咨询是他最轻松的工作，马文说，因为他真的根本不需要懂任何医学或精神病学。每当他们拿出一个棘手的案例时，马文只是问他们一直在使用什么治疗方法。如果他们说治疗 A，他告诉他们改用治疗 B。如果他们告诉他 B，他说改用 A。哦，他用合适的胡言乱语包围了这一切（医生是他们自己药物的最大吸盘），但是原则很简单：无论他们一直在做什么，告诉他们停下来做一些不同的事情。

Once a month, Marvin drove down to the state mental hospital to consult with the staff on their most intransigent cases. This kind of consulting was his easiest work, Marvin said, because he really didn't have to know any medicine or psychiatry at all. Whenever they brought out one of their tough cases, Marvin merely asked them what treatment they'd been using. If they said treatment A, he told them to switch to treatment B. If they told him B, he said switch to A. Oh, he surrounded all this with suitable mumbo jumbo (doctors are the greatest suckers for their own medicine), but the principle is simple: Whatever they've been doing, tell them to stop and do something different.

很容易看出马文的系统为何有效。因为他是顾问。他看到的唯一案例是医院医生不能自己解决的问题。因此，他总结道，他唯一确定的事情是：无论他们做什么都是不对的。他们会被困在一种方法上，无法下车。只是因为他们付给他很多钱，这个系统才能让他们摆脱困境。他这么贵，肯定知道自己在做什么！

It's easy to see why Marvin's system works. Because he was a consultant. the only cases he saw were the problems the hospital doctors weren't solving by themselves. Therefore, he concluded, the one thing he knew for sure was this: Whatever they were doing wasn't right. They'd become stuck on one approach and couldn't get off. Only because they were paying him a lot of money did this system work to get them unstuck. If he's so expensive, he must know what he's doing!

如果你是一个优秀的程序员，你已经知道这个秘密了。有没有灵魂如此死寂的程序员，他们从未在一个问题上工作两天，只是因为同事的意外提示而摆脱困境？甚至是随机中断或事故？是的，如果他们只分享秘密，那么这些行业可以相互学习很多东西。

If you're a good programmer, you already know this secret. Are there programmers with souls so dead they never worked two days on a problem, only to get unstuck by an accidental hint from a colleague? Or even from a random interruption or accident? Yes, there's much the professions could learn from one another, if they only shared secrets.

但是，如果我们并排检查一个行业的秘密集合， 我们可以学到更多。例如，考虑一下我们刚刚公开的这两个：

But even more can be learned if we examine a profession's collection of secrets, side by side. For instance, consider these two we've just exposed:

1.不要过早放弃治疗。

1. Don't give up the treatment too soon.

2.不要坚持一种治疗太久。

2. Don't stick with one treatment too long.

好吧，毕竟医生赚这么多钱也许是有原因的。他们的秘诀不在于秘诀本身，而在于知道 何时 应用每一个秘诀。 也许我们花钱买的不是“知道如何” ，而是“知道什么时候”。

Well, perhaps there's a reason, after all, that doctors make so much money. The secret of their secrets lies not in the secrets themselves, but in knowing when to apply each one. Maybe it's not know-how we're paying for, but "know-when."

在编程中，我们的大部分秘密也是以互补或矛盾的方式出现的。如果我们只练习一个，我们就会被另一个所破坏。作为程序员，我们失败的一种方式是在问题解决之前无法集中精力解决问题。另一条通向失败的道路是过于沉迷于一个问题，以至于我们错过了一些“显而易见”的解决方案。

In programming, too, most of our secrets come in complementary or contradictory pairs. If we practice just one, we're clobbered by the other. One way we fail as programmers is being unable to concentrate on a problem until it cracks. Another road to failure is being so obsessed with a problem we miss some "obvious" solution.

我从马文那里学到了另外一课——关于疯狂意味着什么的一课。直到精神病学家开始研究“正常”人时，他们才真正开始了解疯子。在大多数情况下，“疯狂”行为似乎只是走向极端的“正常”行为。

There's one other lesson I've learned from Marvin—a lesson about what it means to be crazy. Psychiatrists didn't really begin to understand crazy people until they began to study "normal" people. For the most part, it seems, "crazy" behavior is just "normal" behavior carried to extremes.

我相信这一课也适用于程序员——以及各种想成为问题解决者的人。我们最糟糕的解决问题的行为只不过是超出其有用范围的最佳行为。走得太远，注意力会变成强迫症。多才多艺变成了摇摆不定。最好的问题解决者和最坏的问题解决者之间的界限可能比我们想象的要细得多。这条细线应该鼓励最坏的情况，并为最好的情况提供一些发人深省的时刻。正如威尔·罗杰斯 (Will Rogers) 曾经对猴子所说的那样：“我们认为它们如此有趣的原因是它们非常像我们。”

I believe this lesson, too, applies to programmers—as well as to all sorts of would-be problem solvers. Our worst problem-solving behavior is merely our best behavior carried beyond its useful range. Carried too far, concentration turns to compulsion. Versatility turns to vacillation. The line separating the best problem solvers from the worst is perhaps much finer than we think. This thin line should encourage the worst and provide a few sobering moments for the best. As Will Rogers once remarked about monkeys, "The reason we think they're so funny is that they're so much like us."

大脑会不健康吗？

Can a Brain Be Unhealthy?

我不是那种在夜总会闲逛的人。我记得最近的一次夜总会是 1957 年在迈阿密海滩，当时我正在参加 IBM 百分百俱乐部。俱乐部有几件值得纪念的事件，但只有一件适合印刷。我也不太确定那个，但我需要它来说明一点。

I'm not the kind of person who hangs out in nightclubs. The most recent nightclub I can remember was in Miami Beach in 1957, when I was attending the IBM Hundred Percent Club. There were several memorable events at the Club, but only one is suitable for printing. I'm not so sure about that one, either, but I need it to make a point.

我记得聚光灯下的单口相声，他完美无瑕的燕尾服丝毫没有掩饰他内心的邋遢。在用一些相当粗俗的话温暖了听众之后，他停了下来，直起身子，开始讲述他的人生故事。“我并不总是这样，”他抱怨道，“但在我生命的早期，我就学会了我从那以后一直奉行的座右铭：健全的思想；健全的身体……做你的选择！ ”

I recall the stand-up comic in the spotlight, his immaculate tuxedo in no way concealing his inner sleaziness. After warming the audience with some rather gross remarks, he stopped, pulled himself into an upright posture, and began the story of his life. "I wasn't always like this," he whined, "but early in life I learned the motto I've lived by ever since: Sound mind; sound body . . . Take your choice!"

说得这么清楚很有趣，但我们大多数人在生命的早期确实做出了这样的选择。不知何故，我们给人的印象是运动员是愚蠢的，而程序员是软弱的——我们必须选择成为其中之一。如果你在学校选择了松弛的道路，你就应该把所有的业余时间都花在图书馆、自习室或计算机中心。如果你想动摇，你会被那些用最贬义的词语随意谈论运动员的同事们鼓舞——当时酒吧里没有运动员。

It's funny when articulated so clearly, but most of us did make such a choice early in life. Somehow we get the impression athletes are stupid and programmers are flabby—and we must choose to be one or the other. If you chose the flabby path in school, you were expected to spend all your spare time in the library, study hall, or computer center. If you were tempted to falter, you were buoyed up by colleagues who freely spoke of athletes in the most derogatory terms—when there were none present in the pub.

以前，当我写 J. Gerald Simmons 的成功“个人化学”时，我强调了在不影响大脑的情况下，你的身体不能被推到的极限。我们可以如图 1 所示绘制这种关系。我们可以看到，良好的健康水平可以提高工作效率，从而产生更多的闲暇时间，可以在其中追求健康的做法。可以分析这个“即时效果图”（例如，参见我的质量软件系列书籍。通过该分析，我们注意到遍历循环的总体效果是积极的，因此，例如，身体健康倾向于产生更好的健康。

Previously, when I wrote about J. Gerald Simmons's "personal chemistry" for success, I emphasized the limits beyond which your body could not be pushed without affecting your brain. We could have diagrammed that relationship as in Figure 1. There we see that a good level of health increases work effectiveness and thus produces more slack time in which healthy practices can be pursued. This "diagram of immediate effects" can be analyzed (see, for example, my Quality Software series of books. Through that analysis, we notice that the overall effect of traversing the loop is positive, so that, for instance, good health tends to produce better health.

图 1. 健康与工作效率的正反馈循环

Figure 1. The Positive Feedback Cycle of Health and Work Effectiveness

然而，这种“正反馈”循环无论哪种方式都有效。健康状况不佳往往会导致健康状况不佳。为什么？通过分析循环，我们发现健康状况不佳会降低工作效率（部分是通过降低大脑效率），这反过来又会导致工作堆积，进而导致我们过度劳累、匆忙吃垃圾食品，并且通常会忽视我们的健康。最后，我们的健康状况会变得更糟，因为这个循环会继续螺旋上升——除非我们能通过适时的休假或理解管理来打破它。

This kind of "positive feedback" loop works either way, however. Poor health tends to produce poorer health. Why? By analyzing the loop we see that poor health diminishes work effectiveness (partly through diminished brain effectiveness), which in turn causes work to pile up, which in turn causes us to overwork, consume junk food in haste, and generally ignore our health.
