He remembers them all, and this can save the university thousands of dollars in mistakes—like cutting into a water pipe when they're digging a trench. I'm sure he earns his salary many times over just because of the information he has in his head."

作为父母，我不能在不吸取教训的情况下让这堂课过去。我用最慈父般的语气对克里斯说：“这就是世界之道。你所知道的 比 你所做的 要多。你可以努力工作一千倍，却永远得不到老板所拥有的工作保障只要知道所有的管道都埋在哪里。”

As a parent, I was unable to allow this lesson to pass without drawing a moral. I said to Chris in my most fatherly tone, "This is the Way of the World. You're paid more for what you know than for what you do. You could work a thousand times harder and never have the job security your boss has just from knowing where all the pipes are buried."

计算领域的情况也不例外。不幸的是，许多计算组织的管理层似乎并不知道大多数重要的文档都在人们的脑海中。经理们一想到付钱给一个唯一的功能就是记住事情过去的样子或为什么会变成现在这样的人，就会感到非常沮丧。管理层希望为代码行或其他一些有形的努力标志付费。

The situation is no different in computing. Unfortunately, management in many computing organizations doesn't seem to know most of the important documentation is being carried around in people's heads. Managers get very upset at the idea of paying someone whose only function is remembering how things were or why they are the way they are. Management wants to pay for lines of code or some other tangible sign of effort.

管理人员对这类员工的概念性问题源于他们对文档和文件的混淆。在这方面，景观美化和编程之间存在着非常严格的平行关系。在景观美化中，基本文件在地面上。如果您的地图显示某个地方没有管道，而您的铲子碰到了管道，那么您必须相信铲子。如果地图与老弗雷德的记忆不符，情况也是如此。Fred 比地图更可能是正确的。但铲子才是最终的评判者。

The conceptual problem managers have with this type of worker stems from their confusion between documentation and documents. In this respect, there's a very strict parallel between landscaping and programming. In landscaping, the basic documentation is in the ground. If your map says there's no pipe in a certain place and your shovel hits a pipe, you have to believe the shovel. The same is true if the map disagrees with old Fred's memory. Fred is more likely to be right than the map. But the shovel is the final judge.

在编程中，代码是基础。可能还有很多其他的纸质文档在撒谎，但大多数时候他们撒谎的是代码。每个优秀的维护程序员都知道这一点，而且实际上很少查看本应记录正在维护的系统的文档。当维护程序员自己的头脑没有直接回答问题时，第一个信息来源是几年前在这个系统上工作的老乔治。十分之九，George 可以提供您需要的信息。

In programming, the code is the ground. There may be lots of other paper documents lying about, but what they're lying about most of the time is the code. Every good maintenance programmer knows this and, indeed, rarely looks at the documents that are supposed to document the system under maintenance. When a question isn't answered directly out of the maintenance programmer's own head, the first source of information is old George who worked on this system a couple of years ago. Nine times out of ten, George can provide the information you need.

十分之一的其他时间，乔治很可能能够回答这个问题，“还有谁可能知道？” 也许他会把你介绍给莎莉，而莎莉有十分之九的机会知道答案。George 或 Sally 偶尔会向您推荐一些文件，但该文件很可能已被其他一些文件取代，这些文件是最新的，但恰好没有您想要的信息。

The other one time out of ten, George is likely to be able to answer the question, "Who else might know?" Perhaps he refers you to Sally, and Sally has nine chances out of ten of knowing the answer. Once in a while, George or Sally will refer you to some document, but that document is likely to have been superseded by some other document, which is more up-to-date but doesn't happen to have the information you want.

先前的描述并非旨在作为编辑评论，而只是描述。编程经理会很好地研究我的描述，然后将其与他们自己组织中实际发生的过程进行比较。管理是一项困难的工作。经理们害怕从现实出发思考在他们的组织中要做什么，这让事情变得更加困难。如果您想改善您工作的文档情况，那么从清楚地了解当前的情况开始不是一个好主意吗？

The previous description was not intended as an editorial comment, simply a description. Programming managers would do very well to study my description and then compare it with the process actually taking place in their own organizations. Management is a difficult business. It's made more difficult by managers who are afraid to start from the base of reality in thinking about what to do in their organization. If you would like to improve the documentation situation where you work, wouldn't it be a good idea to start with a clear picture of what the situation is right now?

改进文档计划的下一步是在尝试引入人工方法之前，看看可以做些什么来帮助文档的自然过程。例如，既然代码是所有文档的基础，为什么不采取措施提高代码作为文档的质量呢？这种代码改进计划的第一步是确保没有代码在没有被一个或多个人阅读和理解的情况下进入库。如果代码是文档，那么按理说只能通过阅读来测试它的文档功能。一旦您的组织开始定期阅读代码，关于如何提高代码可读性的许多其他想法就会涌现。

The next step in a program of improved documentation is to see what can be done to assist the natural processes of documentation before trying to introduce artificial methods. For instance, since the code is the basic ground upon which all documentation is based, why not take steps to improve the quality of the code as documentation? The first step in such a code-improvement program is to be sure that no code goes in the library without having been read and understood by one or more people. If the code is a document, it stands to reason it can be tested for its documentation power only by being read. Once your organization starts reading code on a regular basis, many other ideas will spring to life about how to improve the code's readability.

当您将代码作为文档进行改进时，您可能还会环顾四周，看看可以做些什么来提高个人作为文档 的质量。作为第一步，您应该注意到这一点：当个人离开组织时，他们将失去大部分用处，就像文件一样。因此，任何减少员工流动率的政策都可能提高活文档的质量。

While you're improving the code as document, you might also look around to see what can be done to improve the quality of individuals as documents. As a first step, you should notice this: When individuals leave an organization, they lose most of their usefulness, just as documents do. Therefore, any policies reducing employee turnover are likely to improve the quality of the living documentation.

在某种程度上，您可以通过在录音中捕捉一些这种动态文档来保护自己免受人员流失。录音带很好，但录像带更好。为什么不让系统每个部分的设计人员在贵公司的视频工作室中花几分钟时间来记录设计背后的思考过程——在编码开始几个月后就看不到思考过程了？在短时间内，您将积累一个不错的视频文档库，至少可以用来向新人介绍您的项目。他们不仅会看到项目背后的想法，还会被介绍给他们在必要时会参考的活文件中的人物。

To some extent, you might protect yourself from turnover by capturing some of this living documentation on a recording. Audiotape is fine, but videotape is even better. Why not have the designers on each part of the system take a few minutes in your company's video studio to record the thought process behind the design—the thought process lost to view a few months after coding begins? In a short time, you'll accumulate a nice library of video documents, which at the very least can be used to introduce new people to your projects. They'll not only see the thinking underlying the project, but they'll also be introduced to the personalities who are the living documents they will refer to when necessary.

如果您没有录像带，或者即使有，您可能想要创建其他形式的索引来引导有问题的人找到有答案的人。例如，每段代码都可能包含一个序言，该序言累积地列出了所有接触过该代码的人。另一种经常使用的方法是让每一行代码都包含最后一个编写它的人的姓名首字母。那样的话，如果维护程序员在某条生产线上遇到了一些困难，那么就可以毫无困难地找到拥有最新直接知识的人。

If you don't have videotape, or even if you do, you might want to create other forms of indexing to guide people with questions to people with answers. For instance, each piece of code might contain a prologue cumulatively listing all the people who ever laid a hand on the code. Another method often used is to have each line of code contain the initials of the last person who worked on it. That way, if the maintenance programmer is having some difficulty with a particular line, there's no trouble locating the person who has the most recent direct knowledge.

即使是您的常规纸质文档也应该包含一个适应性索引，以供处理或使用它们的人员使用。在大学里，有 70 年前的校园地图。如果没有一位老计时器的博学评论，这些地图就毫无用处，他们记得 1957 年使用这张地图时有一个错误。果然，即使他们在地下做了正确的事情，他们也从未纠正过错误。事实上，文档方案越强大，必须使用它的普通人更新的可能性就越小。没有场地管理员会在建筑师于 1940 年绘制的精美图画上留下肮脏、丑陋的笔迹。

Even your regular paper documents should contain an adaptive index to the people who worked on or used them. At the university, there are maps of the grounds dating back seventy years. These maps are useless without the learned commentary of one of the old timers who remembers an error in this map when they used it in 1957. And sure enough, they never did correct the error even though they did the right thing underground. Indeed, the more imposing the document scheme, the less likely it is to be updated by the ordinary mortals who have to use it. No groundskeeper is going to place dirty, ugly handwriting on the beautiful drawing made by the architect in 1940.

同样，没有程序员会破坏我们神圣系统的设计者留下的文档。但是任何尝试使用文档的程序员都会清楚地记得理解某个段落需要多长时间。程序员会非常乐意帮助现在正试图理解难以理解的段落的可怜的新手。如果您在每份文档上都提供一个位置供人们在阅读和理解文档后进行签名，那么以后的读者将可以参考那些最有可能提供帮助的人。

In the same way, no programmer is going to despoil the documents left by the designers of our holy system. But any programmer who tries to use the documents will remember vividly how long it took to understand a certain paragraph. The programmer will be more than happy to help the poor novice who's now trying to understand the incomprehensible paragraph. If you provide a place on each document for people to initial when they've read and understood it, later readers will have a reference to those people who are most likely to be of assistance.

我可以举出更多关于如何增强您自己的动态文档系统的示例，但最好您了解并研究您自己的系统并提出您自己的建议。只有这样，我的建议才会与你自己的问题完全相关。我从已经这样做的组织那里得到了关于这个主题的任何想法——研究他们自己的非正式文档系统并寻找帮助它的方法。

I could give many more examples of how you could enhance your own living documentation system, but it's better if you know and study your own system and develop your own suggestions. Only then will my suggestions be completely relevant to your own problems. I've gotten any ideas I have on the subject from organizations who have done just that—studied their own informal documentation system and looked for ways to help it along.

所以，让那些说大学从不教任何东西的人上一课吧。大学教很多东西。如果你回忆起你自己的大学岁月——假设你有过这样的岁月——并且如果你对自己诚实的话，你会发现你也在大学里学到了很多东西。可能，您不知道自己学到了什么，因为您正专注于大学正式部分的学习——就像您专注于文档计划的正式部分一样。大学的大部分学习都是在课堂之外进行的，就像编程商店中的大部分文档都是在正式的文档系统之外进行的一样。

So let that be a lesson to all of you who say that the university never teaches anything. The university teaches many things. If you recall your own university years—assuming you had such years—and if you're honest with yourself, you'll realize you, too, learned many things at the university. Possibly, you didn't know what you'd learned because you were concentrating on the learning taking place in the formal part of the university—just as you concentrate on the formal part of your documentation schemes. Most of the learning at the university takes place outside the classroom, just as most of the documentation in the programming shop takes place outside the formal system of documents.

老鼠和铁：一个寓言

The Mouse and the Iron: A Fable

一个星期二，当他碰巧爬上熨衣板时，一只老​​鼠正在厨房里探索。板上有一个电熨斗，它的表面闪闪发亮，他可以在上面看到自己的倒影。由于熨斗向后倾斜了一点，他的倒影似乎是另一只比自己矮一点的老鼠。由于他是一只孤独的老鼠，他根据反射的大小来判断这只新老鼠是一只女孩。

One Tuesday, a mouse was exploring the kitchen when he happened to get on top of the ironing board. On the board was an electric iron whose face was so shiny he could see his reflection in it. As the iron was tilted a bit backward, his reflection seemed to him to be another mouse who was a bit shorter than himself. As he was a lonely mouse, he took the size of the reflection to mean this new mouse was a girl.

害羞地，他向陌生人靠近了一点。她同样害羞地向他走去。小心翼翼地笑了笑。她同样小心翼翼地回以微笑。可以想象，有了这样一个反应灵敏的伴侣，他很快就坠入爱河。

Shyly, he moved a bit closer to the stranger. With equal shyness, she advanced toward him. Cautiously, he smiled. Just as cautiously, she smiled back. As can be imagined with such a responsive partner, he quickly fell head over heels in love.

他们坐了一会儿，充满爱意地凝视着对方的眼睛，直到女主人打开厨房的门。“跑，”他命令他的心上人，他们从熨斗边跑开。回头看了一眼，他发现她确实是在逃跑，但在另一个方向。“她一定住在那个街区，”他想。

They sat for a while, gazing into each other's eyes in loving rapture, until the lady of the house opened the kitchen door. "Run," he commanded his sweetheart, and they scampered away from the iron. Glancing back for a moment, he saw that she was indeed running away, but in the other direction. "She must live over in that neighborhood," he thought.

接下来的整个星期，他都在厨房的对面寻找她，但她无处可寻。周二，然而，熨衣板又被安上了，熨斗放在上面并插上了插头。女主人一离开房间，他就在熨衣板上飞快地爬了起来。果然，铁里藏着他的真爱。当他跑到她身边时，他无法掩饰自己的情绪。他看出她也无法掩饰自己的。他向她伸出手，她也向他伸出手。他们摸了摸爪子。他们接吻了。他情绪激动，尽管他能控制住自己的感官，看到她也同样被征服了。他又吻了她一下，她的吻似乎越来越热了。

All the next week he looked for her on the opposite side of the kitchen, but she was nowhere to be found. On Tuesday, however, the ironing board was set up again and the iron was put on top and plugged in. As soon as the lady of the house left the room, he scooted up on the board. Sure enough, there in the iron was his true love. As he ran up to her, he could not conceal his emotions. He saw she could not conceal hers either. He reached out to her, and she reached out to him. They touched paws. They kissed. He was overcome with emotion, though enough in control of his senses to see she was likewise overcome. He kissed her again, and it seemed her kiss was growing warmer.

他一次又一次地吻她。现在她越来越温暖是明白无误的。的确，他变得太热了，他不得不离开她一点才能冷静下来。他微笑着告诉她关于他自己的事情。虽然她没有回答（他喜欢善于倾听的女人），但由于她的微笑，他觉得她是在回应他的话。终于，他再也抵挡不住她的魅力，再次扑上去亲吻她。

Again and again he kissed her. Now her growing warmth was unmistakable. Indeed, he was becoming so warm he had to move away from her a bit to cool off. He smiled and told her things about himself. Though she did not answer (he liked women who were good listeners), because of her smiles, he felt she was responding to what he said. At last, he could resist her charms no longer, and he rushed forward to kiss her once again.

到这个时候，当然，熨斗已经完全加热了。“嗷呜！” 他哭着往后跳，嘴巴和爪子都烧焦了。“你为什么要那样做 ？”还没 等她回答，女主人就进来了，两只老鼠只得逃跑。

By this time, of course, the iron had reached its full heat. "Eeeow!" he cried, jumping back with burned mouth and paws. "Why did you do that?" But before she could reply, the lady of the house came in, so both mice had to run away.

整个星期他都在为自己做了什么冒犯了他的爱人而苦思冥想。也许他太前卫了。或者，也许还不够前卫。另一方面，他 花 了很多时间谈论自己。也许她觉得他的自负令人反感。“下次，”他下定决心，“我会让她告诉我她自己的事。我会请求原谅。”

All week he brooded about what he had done to offend his sweetheart. Perhaps he had been too forward. Or, perhaps, not forward enough. On the other hand, he had spent a lot of time talking about himself. Perhaps she found his ego offensive. "Next time," he resolved, "I will let her tell me about herself. I will beg for forgiveness."

下周二，熨衣板又出来了。他急忙赶去见他的爱人，他的心怦怦直跳，生怕她不来。但她在那儿，因为熨斗没有插上电源，她以友好但有点冷淡的态度接待了他。他们度过了愉快的一个小时，亲吻和握着爪子，对他们之前的麻烦只字未提。他还没来得及提起这件事，厨房的门就开了，他们又要分开一周了。

Next Tuesday, the ironing board came out again. He rushed to see his love, and his heart was pounding for fear she would not come. But she was there, and as the iron was not plugged in, she received him in a friendly, though somewhat cool, manner. They passed a pleasant hour, kissing and holding paws, and not a word was said about their previous trouble. Before he had a chance to bring it up, the kitchen door opened, and they had to part for another week.

对于老鼠来说，这证明又是一个星期的沉思。尽管他很高兴她把他带回来了，他仍然记得她以前没有表现出的冷静。他最终决定在他们下次见面时必须非常小心。

For the mouse, it proved another week of brooding. Delighted as he was she had taken him back, he could still recall the coolness which she had not shown before. He finally decided he must be very careful on their next meeting.

那次会面耽误了一个多小时，因为女主人在熨斗热的时候一直呆在厨房里，直到熨完熨斗拔掉插头才离开。她一出房间，老鼠就跳上了熨衣板，跑进了他亲爱的伸出的双臂。“嗷呜！” 他尖叫着跑进了灼热的熨斗中。“你为什么要 那样做？”

That meeting was delayed for more than an hour, because the lady of the house stayed in the kitchen while the iron was warming and did not leave until the ironing was finished and the iron unplugged. No sooner was she out of the room than the mouse leapt up on the ironing board and raced into the outstretched arms of his darling. "Eeeow!" he screamed as he ran right into the searing iron. "Why did you do that?"

他质问她，恳求她，甚至向她坦白他所有的缺点。尽管他恳求，她不会告诉他他做错了什么。然而，最后，他开始察觉到她态度的变化，尽管她什么也没说。“也许，”他想，“她已经原谅我了，因为我受到的惩罚已经够多了。” 他走向她，果然，她以他们第二次见面时的所有温暖回应了他的吻和拥抱。

He questioned her, pleaded with her, even confessed to her all of his shortcomings. Despite his pleadings, she would not tell him what he had done wrong. At last, however, he began to detect a change in her attitude, even though she had not said anything. "Perhaps," he wondered, "she has forgiven me, seeing that I have been punished enough." He moved forward to her and, sure enough, she returned his kiss and embrace, with all the warmth of their second meeting.

就这样从周二走到了周二，时而炎热时而寒冷。可怜的老鼠很快就被熨斗烫得遍体鳞伤。更糟糕的是，他变得全神贯注于试图了解他女朋友的行为。他开始缺餐和减肥。终于，一个星期二，就在见到她之后，他心烦意乱，又饿得不小心掉进了一个捕鼠器，结束了他那不幸的爱情的痛苦。

And so it went from Tuesday to Tuesday, sometimes hot and sometimes cold. The poor mouse was soon covered with scars from being branded by the iron. Worse than that, he became preoccupied trying to understand his girlfriend's behavior. He began missing meals and losing weight. Finally, one Tuesday, right after seeing her, he was so distracted and hungry he blundered into a mousetrap, which ended the misery of his ill-starred love.

寓意：如果你愚蠢到认为铁会为你忽冷忽热，那么你就是愚蠢到会被烧伤。

Moral: If you are foolish enough to suppose the iron turns hot and cold for you, you are foolish enough to get burned.

换句话说：沟通总是涉及两个人，而不是一个人加铁。

In other words: Communication always involves two people, not one plus iron.

第六章 我如何在官僚主义中生存？

Chapter VI How Can I Survive in a Bureaucracy?

围绕中城三角区的工作轮换

Job Rotation Around the Mid-City Triangle

你听说过永恒三角——人类性欲和婚姻安排的永恒交织。您听说过百慕大三角——幽灵船和食尸鬼水手的无尽谜团。但直到现在，只有我知道程序员在美国中城三巨头之间的奇特流通

You've heard of the Eternal Triangle—the perpetual intertwining of human libidos and marital arrangements. You've heard of the Bermuda Triangle—the unending mystery of ghost ships and ghoulish sailors. But until now, only I have known of the curious circulation of programmers among the Big Three of Mid-City, U.S.A.

这是我第三次或第四次访问中城时，我意识到我在之前访问时遇到的许多程序员都有一个共同点。Mid-City 拥有三个主要的数据处理设施：Amalgamated Egg Sucking、Central Cane Testing 和 United Cigar Rental。其中，他们雇用了中城 70% 或 80% 的程序员，总共可能有 600 人。在我遇到的程序员中，那些拥有十年或更多经验的人似乎在所有三个安装中都工作过。事实上，有些人第二次出现在我后来称之为“中城三角”的地方。

I was visiting Mid-City for the third or fourth time when I became aware of a peculiarity shared by many of the programmers I had met on previous visits. Mid-City has three principal data processing installations: Amalgamated Egg Sucking, Central Cane Testing, and United Cigar Rental. Among them, they employ 70 or 80 per cent of the programmers in Mid-City, perhaps 600 in all. Of the programmers I met, those with ten or more years' experience seemed to have worked at all three installations. Some, indeed, were on their second time around what I came to call the Mid-City Triangle.

在大城市，我永远不会注意到这种现象，因为在大城市，程序员的选择太多了。在一个较小的城镇，似乎总是“在 Big Daddy's 工作或搬出去”。然而，在中城，循环是纯粹而完美的。

In a larger city, I would never have noticed the phenomenon because in a larger city the programmers' choices are too varied. In a smaller town, it always seems to be "work at Big Daddy's or move out." In Mid-City, though, the cycle was pure and perfect.

事情是这样的：Brent Bleary 从大学毕业并加入了 Amalgamated 的新员工培训计划，尽管它同样可以在其他两家公司之一工作。在完成为期六个月的 COBOL 课程后，他得到了一个小应用程序来编写。他受到挑战，他很高兴。他整天都在编码、提交作业、研究错误并进行更改。终于，在预定日期后几周，他交付了他的杰作，老板非常高兴。

It went something like this: Brent Bleary graduated from college and joined the new employee training program of Amalgamated, though it could equally well have been at one of the other two companies. Having completed his six-month COBOL course, he was given a small application program to write. He was challenged and he was happy. All day long he coded, submitted jobs, pored over bugs, and wove in changes. Finally, only a few weeks after the scheduled date, he delivered his masterpiece, and the boss was mightily pleased.

布伦特获得了更具挑战性的新应用程序作为奖励，他开始高兴地对自己吹口哨。但是在新项目开始几周后，他被一个小烦恼打断了——有人想要对他的第一个程序做一些小改动。布伦特从容应对，尽管他的文件对他已经冷淡了，很快他又回到了申请二。在接下来的几个月里，这些小小的打扰或多或少有规律地出现，但它们只不过是让他从当下的主要任务中转移注意力而已。

Brent was rewarded with an even more challenging new application, and he set to work whistling to himself with joy. But a few weeks into the new project, he was interrupted by a minor annoyance—someone wanted a small change in his first program. Brent took it in stride, even though his documentation had gone cold on him, and soon he was back to application two. In the following months, these little interruptions came more or less regularly, but they never amounted to more than an irritating diversion from his main task of the moment.

当申请二只晚了一周才交付时，布伦特被夸了一千次，筹集了一千美元。他甚至在附近湖边的小木屋里度过了一个短暂的假期来奖励自己。不幸的是，他的假期被缩短了，因为一位老头从镇上给他带来了一封紧急电报：他的一个应用程序崩溃了！

When application two was delivered only a week late, Brent was praised a thousand times and raised a thousand dollars. He even rewarded himself by taking a short vacation in a cabin on a nearby lake. Unhappily, his vacation was cut short when an old geezer brought him an urgent telegram from town: One of his applications had crashed!

然而即便如此，如果布伦特对他缩短的假期感到遗憾，他们就会沉浸在他认为在解决问题时成为关注中心的重要性中。当他收到第三份申请时——他一直希望得到的工作——所有关于过去、现在和未来假期的想法都烟消云散了。

Yet even then, if Brent had regrets about his abbreviated vacation, they were drowned in the importance he felt at being the center of attention while the problem was being fixed. And when he was given application three—the very job he had been hoping for—all thoughts of past, present, and future vacations dissolved.

应用程序三的工作进展顺利——至少当布伦特没有被应用程序一和二的小修复和增强、问题和澄清以及手持时打断。当他的经理询问申请三的时间表时，布伦特以自己的询问回答。他什么时候才能从这些烦人的维护工作中解脱出来，以便专注于手头的重要工作？不会太久的，他放心了。就在其中一名新学员完成 COBOL 课程后。

The work on application three went well—at least when Brent wasn't being interrupted by little fixes and enhancements and questions and clarifications and hand-holding on applications one and two. When his manager inquired about, the schedule of application three, Brent answered with a query of his own. When was he going to be relieved of some of this pesky maintenance work so he could concentrate on the important job at hand? It wouldn't be long, he was reassured. Just as soon as one of the new trainees completed the COBOL course.

但是课程结束了，没有学员愿意来。有紧急的工作要处理，但没有足够的时间让布伦特将一两个申请转交给​​没有经验的人。事实上，布伦特自己处理少数几个请求所花的时间，比教一些受训者他所知道的应用程序的微妙之处所花费的时间要少。布伦特不得不同意这个论点，因为他肯定忙于应用程序三和他的维护工作，没有时间训练新手。

But the course ended and no trainee was forthcoming. There were urgent jobs to be handled and not enough time to have Brent turn application one or two over to someone inexperienced. Indeed, it would take Brent less time just to handle the few requests himself than it would to teach some trainee all he knew about the subtleties of the applications. Brent had to agree with this argument, for he was certainly too busy with application three and his maintenance chores to find time to train some greenhorn.

就这样又过了一年，布伦特现在是五胞胎的骄傲父亲——申请一、二、三、四和五。他有一个申请 6 正在路上，但它的酝酿期越来越长，因为布伦特每周只有不到几个小时的时间来处理它。他的经理曾多次承诺免除维护工作。曾经非常接近，但后来他的经理被提拔了，新经理在事情稳定下来之前不能承担任何风险。

And so another year passed, and Brent was now the proud father of quintuplets—applications one, two, three, four, and five. He had an application six on the way, but its gestation period was growing longer and longer, since Brent had less than a few good hours a week to work on it. His manager had promised relief from the maintenance several times. Once it had been very close, but then his manager was promoted and the new manager just couldn't afford any risks until things had settled down.

然后，一天晚上，在计算机与人协会地方分会的会议上，布伦特听说 Central Cane 迫切需要一些有经验的程序员来从事一个令人兴奋的新开发项目。他进行了一些询问，安排了一次面试，并参加了程序员能力测试。他得到了一份工作，薪水略有增加，但附带福利最高。如果他在 Central Cane 工作，他将不再需要维护任何合并程序。他所要做的就是开发一个很棒的 新 程序。这就像用一辆全新的跑车取代旧的老爷车——而且每月还款减少了！

Then, one evening, at the meeting of the local chapter of the Society for Computers and People, Brent heard Central Cane was desperate for some experienced programmers to work on an exciting new development project. He made a few inquiries, arranged an interview, and took his Programmer Aptitude Test. He was offered a job, at a moderate increase in pay, but with the greatest fringe benefit of all. If he worked at Central Cane, he would no longer have to maintain any of the Amalgamated programs. All he would have to do is develop a wonderful new program. It was like replacing the old jalopy with a brand new sports car—at reduced monthly payments!

但如果布伦特有什么的话，他是忠诚的，所以他给了他的经理最后一次机会。事实上，经理对布伦特的困境充满了同情。他对几个月后即将到来的解脱充满信心，并充满了他刚刚谈判让布伦特在此期间开心的脂肪加薪的消息。布伦特感谢经理的加薪，悄悄离开了办公室，并立即打电话给 Central Cane 的人事经理接受了这份工作。当他的经理发现时，他完全不知所措。一个人得到如此好的加薪和如此热情的同情，他怎么能辞职呢？

But if Brent was anything, he was loyal, so he gave his manager one last chance. And, indeed, the manager was overflowing with sympathy for Brent's plight. He welled with confidence about the relief coming in a few months, and brimmed with news of the fat raise he had just negotiated to keep Brent happy in the interim. Brent thanked his manager for the raise, quietly left his office, and immediately called the personnel manager at Central Cane to accept the offer. When his manager found out, he was completely befuddled. How could someone quit just when he been given such a nice raise and such warm sympathy?

好吧，长话短说，布伦特在 Central Cane 的逗留与他在 Amalgamated 的逗留几乎遵循相同的剧本。在与他的处子申请一起度过了光荣的蜜月之后，他很快就背上了一个越来越胖、越来越烦人的负担，以维持他以前的胜利。最终，他听说 United Cigar 搬进了新的领域，在办理了一些手续后，他发现自己在镇对面一间粉刷一新的办公室里，永远摆脱了 Central Cane 繁重的程序维护工作。

Well, to make a long story short, Brent's stay at Central Cane pretty much followed the same script as his stay at Amalgamated. After a glorious honeymoon with his virgin application, he was soon saddled with an ever fatter, nagging burden of maintenance of his previous triumphs. Eventually, he heard United Cigar was moving into new territory, and after a few formalities he found himself across town in a freshly painted office, freed forever of the oppressive program maintenance at Central Cane.

但两年后，当循环完成另一个转弯时，布伦特在中城已经无处可去。在哥谭市，他可能会永远去新公司，但在这里——他该怎么办？几个月过去了，他开始感到绝望，甚至考虑在某个新领域开展工作，比如套牛犊。然后，一个偶然的机会，他遇到了他在Amalgamated的老经理。

But after two years, when the cycle had completed another turn, Brent had run out of places to go in Mid-City. In Gotham City, he might have kept on going to new firms forever, but here—what was he to do? As the months wore on, he began to despair, even considering a career in some new area, like calf-roping. Then, by chance, he ran across his old manager from Amalgamated.

布伦特担心可能会有一些残留的苦涩，但在将近五年的时间里，所有的一切都被遗忘和原谅了。此外，Amalgamated 目前正在对几个大型新应用程序进行自动化处理，因此经理无权冒犯任何有编程经验的人。很快，布伦特就打包好了他的模板和工作控制面板，并将它们运回了 Amalgamated。不过，不是在他的旧办公桌前，因为现在他是一名非常资深的程序员，并且有一个半私人的办公室可以闲逛。但更重要的是，甚至没有人记得他在那些年前与应用程序 1 到 6 有任何关系。或者至少他们太客气了，没有提及。

Brent was worried there might be some residual bitterness, but in almost five years all had been forgotten and forgiven. Besides, Amalgamated was currently in the process of automating several large new applications, so the manager wasn't in any position to offend anyone who had programming experience. In a short time, Brent had packed up his templates and his job-control decks and shipped them back to Amalgamated. Not to his old desk, though, for now he was a very senior programmer and had a semiprivate office to hang out in. But more important, nobody even remembered he had anything to do with applications one through six all those years ago. Or at least they were too polite to mention it.

我在中城多呆了几天，只是为了采访布伦特的一些同时代人，比如苏、拉里。贝蒂安妮、艾尔玛、沃尔夫冈和塞尔玛。尽管略有不同，但所有人都有相同的故事要讲。事实上，Wolfgang 已经绕过 Mid-City Triangle 两次，并且正在谈判他的第三次巡回赛。这一切会在哪里结束？我想知道在飞机上回来。怎样才能打破这个铁三角对这么多生命的控制？或者是这些人控制了三角？当我回忆起每次采访时，我意识到这些都是快乐的程序员，也许比一般人快乐得多。我想知道是谁在进行所有这些维护工作？

I stayed a few extra days in Mid-City, just to interview some of Brent's contemporaries, like Sue, Larry. Betty Anne, Irma, Wolfgang, and Thelma. With minor variations, all had the same story to tell. Wolfgang, in fact, had been around the Mid-City Triangle twice and was in the process of negotiating his third circuit. Where would it all end? I wondered on the plane back. What would it take to break the grip this iron triangle had on so many lives? Or was it these people who had the grip on the triangle? As I recalled each interview, I realized these were all happy programmers, perhaps far happier than the average. I wondered who's getting stuck with all that maintenance?

大型组织、小型计算机和独立程序员

Large Organizations, Small Computers, and Independent Programmers

我一直让自己的生活受到几本好书的影响——《圣经》、《 梦的解析》、 《甘地 自传》、 《爱丽丝历险记》 和 《猎蛇》。 在 Snark 教给我的许多事情中，我听到三遍的任何事情都必须是真实的。利用这种洞察力，我可以坐在美国粮仓的办公桌前，掌握整个国家甚至全世界的脉搏。

I've always allowed my life to be influenced by a few great books—the Bible, The Interpretation of Dreams, Gandhi's Autobiography, Alice's Adventures, and The Hunting of the Snark. Among the many things the Snark taught me was anything I hear three times must be true. Using this insight, I can sit at my desk in the Breadbasket of America and take the pulse of the entire nation, even the world.

这是它是如何完成的。如果在任何一周内我收到三封关于同一趋势的信件和/或电话，那么我就知道它真的发生了。这样我就可以知道什么时候裙子在涨，什么时候库存在跌。我不必看报纸或看电视，因为他们总是迟到几天或几周才能看到新闻。

Here's how it is done. If in any one week I get three letters and/or telephone calls on the same trend, then I know it's really happening. In this way, I can know when skirts are going up or stocks are going down. I don't have to read newspapers or watch the tube, for they're always days or weeks late in sensing the news.

最近，我发现了一个新趋势，我将与读者分享。我的第一个线索来自克劳德周一的一封信，克劳德以前是一名学生，现在为印第安纳波利斯的一家大型食品公司编程。在他写的信的结尾，

Recently, I spotted a new trend I'm going to share with my readers. My first clue came in a letter on Monday from Claude, a former student now programming for a large food company in Indianapolis. Toward the end of the letter he wrote,

“我和我的妻子最近买了一台 Mac，我们玩得很开心。她是一名退休的程序员，所以当孩子们不在身边时，她把所有的时间都花在开发漂亮的软件上。我下班回家的那一刻，她就去到厨房，我接管机器。孩子们上床后，我们一起工作。我们已经开发了三个小应用程序，我们在当地销售，并希望进入全国分销。当你在城里时，你得过来看看我们的产品线。如果这些卖得好，我可能会从公司退休。事实上，我每天大部分时间都在办公室锻炼，晚上尝试我回家了。没有人比我更聪明——他们永远不会让我在这里忙碌。”

"My wife and I recently bought a Mac and we're having a marvelous time. She's a retired programmer, so when the kids aren't around she spends all her time developing nifty software. The minute I get home from work, she goes into the kitchen and I take over the machine. And once the kids are in bed, we work together. We've already developed three small apps we're selling locally, and hope to get into national distribution. When you're in town, you'll have to come over and take a look at our product line. If these sell well, I might retire from the company. As it is, I spend most of my day in the office working out routines to try at night when I get home. Nobody's the wiser—they never could keep me busy here."

同一天下午，我接到南加州一位老朋友的电话。Joanna 已经为一家大型制造商编程了大约 16 年，我们正在安排对她的公司进行咨询访问。“当你在这里时，”她说，“你必须和我一起去买电脑。我决定买一台新电脑，但我要慢慢来，这样我才能买到合适的系统。”

The same afternoon I received a call from an old friend in southern California. Joanna has been programming for a large manufacturer for about sixteen years, and we were arranging a consulting visit to her firm. "And when you're here," she said, "you'll have to go computer shopping with me. I've decided to buy a new PC, but I'm taking my time so I get the right system."

生性保守的我问道：“你用了大机器的设施，怎么能容得下这么小的机器呢？”

Being conservative by nature, I asked, "How are you able to tolerate such a small machine after having been spoiled by the facilities of the big ones?"

“不用担心。我在一台更小的机器上工作过，我发现我在工具和能力方面的不足，我可以弥补，因为我对情况有完全的控制。这或多或少是相同的设置当我开始的时候，我就和我一起工作，回到我最初迷上这个行业的时候。”

"Not to worry. I've worked on an even smaller machine, and I've discovered whatever I lack in tools and capacity, I can make up because of the complete control I have over the situation. It's more or less the same setup I worked with when I started, back when I got hooked into this business in the first place."

“生活 更 简单，那时候……”

"Life was simpler, back then . . ."

“我唯一担心的是，当我不用去办公室就能满足我的瘾时，我还需要大爸爸做什么？如果我能在家解决问题，我可能再也不会上下班了。但我不在乎。有什么好玩的这将是！”

"My only worry is that when I can satisfy my addiction without going to the office, what do I need Big Daddy for? If I can get my fix at home, I might never commute again. But I don't care. What fun it will be!"

但是两种通讯方式并没有形成一种趋势，尤其是如果其中一种来自南加州的一个瘾君子，那里是橘子和坚果的故乡。星期四我才接到下一个电话——来自华盛顿的大卫。

But two communications don't make a trend, particularly if one of them is from a junkie in southern California, home of oranges and nuts. It was Thursday before I got my next call—from David in Washington.

大卫一直是我们的得奖学生之一。他去了我最早的工作室之一，并在我们的心中永垂不朽。每隔几年，当我在国家首都时，我都会去拜访他，但这是他第一次打电话。到现在为止，他已经从程序员晋升为系统开发经理，我一直认为他是一个太忙而无暇打电话的人。不过，显然他只是想交换八卦和消息。

David was one of our prize pupils of all time. He went to one of my earliest workshops and immortalized himself in our hearts and minds. Every few years, when I'm in the nation's capital, I pay him a visit, but this was the first time he'd ever called. By now he'd advanced himself from programmer to manager of systems development, and I'd always imagined him to be a person too busy for idle phone calls. Apparently, though, he just wanted to exchange gossip and news.

办公室传来的消息平淡无奇，但当大卫开始谈论他的新事业时，他的声音变得生动起来。“晚上，只要我能溜出办公室，我就会在咨询的基础上为镇上的五六家小企业做系统分析。我制定出他们需要的规格，然后再转给他们交给拥有大量计算机容量和良好网络访问权限的服务局。”

News from the office was resoundingly dull, but David's voice became animated when he started to talk about his new venture. "In the evenings, as early as I can slip out of the office, I'm doing systems analysis on a consulting basis with five or six small businesses here in town. I work out the specs for what they need, then I turn them over to a service bureau with plenty of computer capacity and excellent network access."

“我想你在一个完整的工作日结束时会厌倦那种工作，”我提出。

"I'd think you'd be tired of that kind of work at the end of a full workday," I offered.

“恰恰相反。我几乎再也 没有 机会在办公室做任何分析工作了。当我有一个好主意时，实施它需要很长时间和很多麻烦，它会吸走所有的乐趣。对于小企业，我开始着手解决所有问题，他们听我的，我开始看到结果，通常在几天内。这真的很令人欣慰——就像过去一样。”

"Just the opposite. I almost never get to do any analysis work at the office anymore. And when I do have a good idea, it takes so long and so much aggravation to get it implemented, it sucks all the joy out of it. With the small businesses, I get to work on the whole problems, they listen to me, and I start seeing results, usually in a few days. It's really gratifying—just like the old days."

“办公室怎么看待这次活动？”

"What does the office think of this activity?"

“哦，他们不知道这件事。事实上，你是我觉得我唯一可以谈论这件事的人。我想如果他们发现我在兼职，拿着我的薪水，我会惹上麻烦的。但我“我做这件事不是为了钱——我的常规工作可以很好地照顾到这一点。咨询给了我一些我在工作中无法再得到的东西。我真的感觉又活了。”

"Oh, they don't know about it. In fact, you're the only one I feel I can talk to about it. I suppose I'd get in trouble if they discovered I was moonlighting, at my salary. But I'm not doing it for the money—my regular job takes good care of that. Consulting gives me something I just can't get any more at work. I really feel alive again."

“你有没有机会退出并全职工作？”

"Any chance you'll quit and go into it full time?"

“我不这么认为——尽管服务局一直求我给他们发更多的工作。他们有很多潜在客户，但除了我和其他几个处于相同情况的人之外，无法获得良好的系统工作。但我认为不值得冒这个风险。我为什么要这么做？我在这里找到了一份终生工作，薪水丰厚，有医疗保险——而且他们没有提出太多要求。我想如果他们发现并提出大惊小怪，我不得不裁掉咨询，但这不太可能发生。无论如何，他们不会解雇我。他们从不解雇任何人， 而且 我的工作仍然是他们专家的两倍。”

"I don't think so—though the service bureau keeps begging me to send them more work. They've got lots of potential customers, but can't get good systems work except from me and a few others in the same situation. But I don't think it's worth the risk. Why should I? I've got a lifetime job here, at good pay, with medical insurance—and they don't make many demands. I suppose if they found out and made a fuss, I'd have to lay off the consulting, but it's not likely to happen. In any case, they wouldn't fire me. They never fire anybody, and my work is still twice as good as they expert."

大卫挂断电话的时间还不够长，我还没来得及反思他的处境，这时又打来了一个电话，这个电话是索耶打来的，他在硅谷的一家电脑公司工作。Sawyer 是我大学时代的学生，现在已经成为一名相当成熟的程序员。离开学校后，他曾为三个不同的制造商工作，大约两年前找到现在的工作。

David hadn't been off the phone long enough for me to reflect on his situation when another call came in, this one from Sawyer, who works for a computer company in Silicon Valley. Sawyer was a student of mine way back in my university days and now has become quite a mature programmer. He worked for three different manufacturers since he left school, before landing his present job about two years ago.

事实证明，索耶正在寻找有关如何与他的两个朋友组建公司的信息。“我们正在做合同编程，”索耶解释说，“我们赚了很多钱，我们认为我们最好变得更像一个真正的企业。”

As it turned out, Sawyer was seeking some information on how to form a corporation with two of his friends. "We're doing contract programming," Sawyer explained, "and we're making so much money that we thought we'd better become more like a real business."

“我以为你有一份固定的工作。”

"I thought you had a regular job."

“是的，但他们给了我一个网络连接，这样我就可以在家工作，而且我每天可以在不到一个小时的时间内完成他们所有的工作。剩下的时间——当我们不骑自行车的时候——我致力于改进本地企业购买的打包软件。”

"Yes, but they've given me a network connection so I can work at home, and I can do all their work in less than an hour a day. The rest of the time—when we're not riding our bikes—I work on improvements to packaged software local businesses have bought."

“你在卖包裹吗？”

"Are you selling the packages?"

“不，我们只是定制它们。在这些人付了熨斗的钱后，制造商都不会理会他们，所以我们进去了，每小时 90 美元，我们按照他们想要的方式修理它们。”

"No, we just customize them. None of the manufacturers pay any attention to these people after they've paid for the iron, so we go in and for ninety dollars per hour, we fix them up any way they want them."

“那样你永远不会致富。制造商的想法是正确的。大量生产，进行销售，然后消失。这就是所有利润所在。”

"You'll never get rich that way. The manufacturers have the right idea. Mass-produce, make the sale, then disappear. That's where all the profit is."

“好吧，我们真的不想致富，但我们做得很好。一方面，我们都有固定的工作，为我们提供了良好的基础。客户喜欢我们。他们会支付我们的任何要求，因为他们被供应商抛弃了，不知道还能去哪里。此外，我们开始开发可以卖到多个地方的小东西。我们只向每个人收取开发成本这对他们来说是新的，尽管我们可能只需要对我们在其他地方做过的事情做一些调整。”

"Well, we don't really want to get rich, but we're doing all right. For one thing, we all have regular jobs to give us a nice base. And the customers love us. They'll pay whatever we ask, because they've been abandoned by the vendors and don't know where else to turn. Besides, we're beginning to develop little things we can sell to more than one place. We charge each one just what it would cost to develop it new for them, even though we might only have to make a few adjustments to something we did somewhere else."

“听起来不错，”我说，“如果你能一直逍遥法外的话。”

"Sounds good," I said, "if you can keep getting away with it."

“没关系。他们对这里的程序员如此绝望，以至于他们永远不会质疑我在做什么。嘿，你愿意和我们一起做生意吗？”

"No sweat. They're so desperate for programmers out here that they'll never question what I'm doing. Hey, would you like to go into business with us?"

你知道的，我很受诱惑。我想我会接受这个提议，如果我在成为独立资本家的同时有一份固定的工作来支付我的工资和福利的话。想一想，我为什么坐在这里埋头苦干键盘？阁楼里挨饿的作家在这个物美价廉的时代已经不合时宜了。

And you know, I was sorely tempted. I think I would have accepted the offer, if only I had a regular job to pay my salary and benefits while I was becoming an independent capitalist. Come to think of it, why am I sitting here slaving over a keyboard? The starving writer in the garret is out of fashion in this era of cheap hardware and costly people.

如果我 真的 想要独立，我的第一步就是回答其中一个诱人的广告——你知道，那种用大部分空间告诉你该地区的假期、员工福利和娱乐机会的广告。然后我就可以回到我的办公室，拿到我的手册和我的网络连接，钉上我的漫画，并开始计划什么时候我可以在不被发现的情况下开展我的新业务。让我们看看，我把那些广告放在哪里了？

If I really want independence, my first step is to answer one of those tempting ads—you know, the kind that devote most of the space telling you about vacations, employee benefits, and recreational opportunities in the area. Then I can settle into my office, get my manuals and my network connection, tack up my cartoons, and start planning when I can work on my new business without being spotted. Let's see, where did I put those ads?

管理层月光下看世界

Management Views the World by Moonlight

前段时间，我发表了上一篇关于专业程序员兼职趋势的文章。这篇文章讲述了 Claude、Joanna、David 和 Sawyer 的故事——这些都是我真正的朋友的化名，他们出于各种原因从事兼职工作。因为这篇文章是在英国发表的，所以我并不十分担心会给任何特定的人带来麻烦。但当我决定更广泛地出版它时，我把副本寄给了克劳德、乔安娜、大卫和索耶，以确保我已经充分隐藏了他们的身份。他们被逗乐了。他们受宠若惊。但他们也有些着急。正如克劳德所说，“你想对我们吹口哨吗？”

Some time ago, I published the previous essay about the trend toward moonlighting by professional programmers. The essay told the stories of Claude, Joanna, David, and Sawyer—pseudonyms for real friends of mine who had taken up moonlighting for a variety of reasons. I wasn't terribly concerned about getting any particular person in trouble because the essay was published in England. But when I decided to publish it more widely, I sent copies to Claude, Joanna, David, and Sawyer to make sure I had sufficiently concealed their identities. They were amused. They were flattered. But they also were a bit anxious. As Claude put it, "Do you want to blow the whistle on us?"

我怀疑我会吹口哨，因为我相信这种广泛存在的现象不会长期逃脱人们的注意。也许管理层已经知道了。我决定在与雇用 Claude、Joanna、David 和 Sawyer 的公司类似的公司中进行民意调查。我想知道经理是否知道。如果他们知道，我想知道他们做了什么。

I doubted I would be blowing the whistle, for I was confident this widespread phenomenon couldn't escape notice for long. Perhaps management already knew about it. I decided to take a poll among firms similar to those employing Claude, Joanna, David, and Sawyer. I wanted to know if the managers knew. And if they knew, I wanted to know what they did about it.

有两种反应。一种是愤怒和恐惧，一位经理用这样的话表达：“你不应该发表这个。我有一种令人讨厌的感觉，这个寓言可能会被逐字理解。”

There were two kinds of reactions. One was outrage and fear, expressed by one manager in these words: "You shouldn't publish this. I have a nasty feeling this parable may be taken literally."

我或多或少预料到这种可怕的反应，但坦率地说，另一种反应让我感到惊讶。用克劳德公司另一个部门的一位经理的话来说，

I more or less expected this fearful reaction, but the other type of response frankly surprised me. In the words of one manager in another division of Claude's company,

“三年来我一直知道我们的程序员有这种活动。当然我们不能公开承认，但我们的政策很简单。只要他们的名字不被公开使用，只要当他们在这里的工作完成时，我们一点也不介意。事实上，在我看来，自从这种活动开始以来，这里的人们快乐多了。我们很大。我们很官僚。我们没办法可以丰富这些工作，足以满足我们最优秀的 10% 的员工。

"I've been aware of this kind of activity among our programmers for three years. Naturally we can't make a public acknowledgment, but our policy is very simple. As long as their names aren't used in public, and as long as their work here gets done, we don't mind at all. In fact, in my perception, people around here are a lot happier since this sort of activity began. We're big. We're bureaucratic. There's no way we can enrich these jobs enough to satisfy the top 10 percent of our people.

“但如果我们的高层人员感到无聊，我们就会失去他们。我们需要他们的专业知识，但不是每天都需要他们。所以我们转过头来，不会注意到他们在做什么。如果我曾经受到高层的挑战管理层，我认为员工花在外部事务上的时间应该被视为培训。并且比我们设计的更有效和高效的培训。我的一位新经理在与外部部门合作两年后获得晋升。期间那个时期，我看着他在几个个人层面上成长。他在这里的工作任务中没有任何东西可以给他那种经历。我敢肯定是他的外部工作做到了这一点。”

"But if our top people get bored, we lose them. We need them for their expertise, but not all day every day. So we turn our heads and don't notice what they're doing. If I were ever challenged by upper management, I'd argue that the time the employees spend working on outside things should be considered training. And more effective and efficient training than we can devise. One of my new managers was promoted after two years of working with an outside bureau. During that period, I watched him grow in several personal dimensions. There was nothing in his job assignment here that could have given him that kind of experience. I'm sure it was his outside work that did it."

另一位经理解释了他是如何无意中在他相当稳重和传统的金融公司开始这种做法的。

Another manager explained how he had accidentally started this kind of practice in his rather staid and traditional financial firm.

“我的壁球伙伴问我一些关于为他的汽车零部件业务购买电脑的建议。我告诉他他需要一个可以长期担任顾问的好人。我警告他所有没有经验、不可靠的孩子谁正在从事这项业务，但我无法就他如何做得更好提出任何建议。同一天下午，我最资深的程序员正在等着见我。他威胁要接受更有利可图的工作，但是我们的政策是不可能比得上他的。他本来赚的比我多！他其实是值得的，但我们公司永远不会接受一个技术人员收入超过他的经理。

"My racquetball partner asked me for some advice about getting a computer for his auto parts business. I told him that he needed someone good who could act as a consultant over a long period of time. I warned him about all the inexperienced, unreliable kids who were getting into this business, but I couldn't come up with any suggestions about how he could do better. That same afternoon, my most senior programmer was waiting to see me. He was threatening to take a more lucrative offer, but there was no way with our policies that I could match it. He would have been making more than me! He was actually worth it, but our company just would never accept a technical person earning more than his manager.

现在办公室里的其他人都在做同样的事情，我很难反对。但这确实让我更仔细地观察他们，看看他们在这里完成工作，而不是仅仅投入时间。我确实希望我们的公司能够接受这样一个事实，即技术人员可能会超出通常的薪资范围，但我怀疑这种情况永远不会发生。所以我们可能会在这段时间内继续使用这个闪避。”

"I offered him a promotion into management, something he'd turned down many times before. It just wasn't his bag, and I admired him for being able to say no. As he walked out of my office, for some reason I flashed on my racquetball conversation. I phoned my friend and asked him what he'd pay for one of my best people to put in a few hours a week as a consultant. It was more than enough to match the difference between what I could offer and what my programmer had been offered at the other job. I called the programmer back into my office and rather tentatively asked him if he'd consider such an arrangement. He was delighted. He really likes his job here, and he wasn't looking forward to moving out of town for the new job. So I kept my best technical person and made a friend happy at the same time. Of course, now that other people in the office are doing the same thing, I can hardly object. But it does make me watch them more carefully to see that they are getting the job done here, rather than just putting in the time. And I do wish our firm would accept the fact that a technical person could fall outside the usual salary scales, but I doubt that will ever happen. So we'll probably keep using this dodge for the duration."

另一位经理告诉我他个人是如何从愤怒转变为接受的：

Another manager told me how he personally had moved from outrage to acceptance:

“当我在我们店里发现第一个这样的案例时，我想直接走到那个人的办公桌当场解雇他。我一定是气得满脸通红，幸好是下班时间。我整晚都在冷静下来，我也没有睡太多。到了早上，我意识到我把这整件事当成了对我权威的挑战。我决定推迟几天。然后我和我的老板，作为一个假设的案例。她用一个问题让我走上正轨：“关于你在你的部门创造的环境，这告诉你什么？” 我惊呆了，然后受到挑战。

"When I discovered the first such case in our shop, I wanted to walk right out to the guy's desk to fire him on the spot. I must have been red with rage, but fortunately it was after office hours. I had the whole night to cool off, and I didn't do much sleeping. By morning, I realized that I was taking the whole thing personally, as a challenge to my authority. I decided to hold off for a few days. Then I discussed the matter with my boss, as a hypothetical case. She put me on the right track with a single question: 'What is this telling you about the environment you've created in your department?' I was stunned, then challenged.

“由于这一切，我在我的部门开始了一系列变革，以及我对部门人员的回应方式。我们已经扭转了长期形成的不健康趋势。我不会说没有人月光不再——我知道他们有——但幅度要小得多。刚好让我保持警觉。这只是一种症状，不是疾病。我们管理部门的方式就是疾病。”

"As a result of all this, I started a series of changes in my department and the way I respond to people in it. We've reversed an unhealthy trend that had been building for a long time. I won't say that nobody moonlights any more—I know they do—but the magnitude is much less. Just enough to keep me on my toes. It's only a symptom, not a disease. The way we ran our department was the disease."

我告诉他我认为他仍然把这件事看得太个人化了。“不是真的，”他回答说：

I told him I thought he was still taking it too personally. "Not really," he replied:

“我是经理，对这类事情负责是我的工作。我们确实有一个人最终自愿离开，全职从事他的小型计算机业务。几天来，我接受了他的离开是个人的失败，但每当有人离开时我都会这样做。不过，当我反思时，我知道一家公司不可能对所有人都是万能的。我认为这个人在他的小企业中真的很开心他在这里永远不会快乐。不是每个人都注定要成为跨国公司的程序员。”

"I'm the manager, and it's my job to take responsibility for this type of thing. We did have one guy who finally left of his own accord to work full-time in his small computer business. For a few days, I took his leaving as a personal failure, but I do that whenever anybody leaves. When I reflect upon it, though, I know that a company can't be all things to all people. I think this guy is really happy in his small business in a way he never could have been happy here. Not everybody is destined to be a programmer in a multinational company."

我无法改进他的结束语。

I can't improve on his closing line.

生产力测量：我们可能已经倒退了

Productivity Measurement: We've Probably Got It Backwards

正如任何程序员通过帮助其他程序员进行调试所了解的那样，通过检查我们倾向于做出的未经检查的假设可以收获很多。

As any programmer knows from helping other programmers debug, there are worlds to be gained from examining the unexamined assumptions we're inclined to make.

在美国，指出“assume”是“-u-”和“-me”的“ass-”是一种常见的文字游戏。每当有人带着程序来找我们并说：“你不必看那里。我 知道 那部分是正确的，”我们确切地知道在哪里寻找问题。

In the States, it's a common word-play to point out that "assume" makes an "ass-" of "-u-" and "-me." Whenever someone comes to us with a program and states, "You needn't look there. I know that part's right," we know precisely where to look for the problem.

但是，我们的生活受未经检验的假设支配的不仅仅是这么小的范围。我们赖以生存的许多假设都是用没有人会怀疑的短语表达的，但其中许多不仅是错误的，而且与事实恰恰相反。

But it's not only on this small scale that our lives are dictated by unexamined assumptions. Many of the assumptions we live by are couched in phrases nobody even considers doubting, yet many of these are not only false, but just the opposite of the truth.

我曾经听到一位广播布道者重复着古老的火与硫磺线“罪恶的工价就是死亡”。刹那间，我突然想到，与这个未经检验的陈述相反，罪的工价是 出生。 啊哈！我们可以在编程中做同样的事情吗？

I once heard a radio evangelist repeat the old fire-and-brimstone line "The wages of sin is death." In a flash, it struck me that, contrary to this unexamined statement, the wages of sin is birth. Aha! Could we be doing the same thing in programming?

从长期的经验来看，我知道我们的术语中有一些非常混乱的对立面。就拿“浮点数”和“定点数”来说吧——我总是有最糟糕的时间来记住哪个是哪个。

From long experience I know we have some terribly confusing opposites in our terminology. Take "floating point" and "fixed point"—I always had the darndest time remembering which was which.

然后有一天，在一节课中，它突然来了，所以我告诉细心的学生，“你总能通过以下观察记住哪个是浮点数，哪个是定点数：当小数点 固定 在单词，所以它永远不会移动，这就是 浮点数 ；但是当位置在单词中 浮动时 ，根据执行的操作和操作数中的位置，那就是 固定 点！” 从那天到现在，我从来没有遇到过解释差异的问题。

Then one day, in the midst of a course, it came in a flash, so I told the attentive students, "You can always remember which is floating point and which is fixed point by the following observation: When the decimal point is fixed in the word, so it never moves, that's floating point; but when the position floats in the word, according to the operations performed and the position in the operands, that's fixed point!" From that day to this, I've never had a problem explaining the difference.

最近在讨论程序员工作的评价问题。一位健谈的经理主动提出了他的方法：“从我的办公桌上，我可以看到我所有程序员隔间的入口。我所要做的就是看看哪些人经常到其他隔间提问。”

Recently, I was discussing the problem of evaluating the work of programmers. One talkative manager volunteered his method: "From my desk, I can see the entrances to the cubicles of all my programmers. All I have to do is see which ones are constantly visiting other cubicles to ask questions."

房间里一片寂静，因为每个人都在考虑这种评估技术的含义。最后有人说，“你知道，我真的认为你有一些东西。编程是一项如此复杂的业务，以至于任何认为他知道所有答案并且从不查找任何东西或去问的人必须制造比他值得的更多的麻烦”

There was silence in the room as everyone considered the implications of this evaluation technique. Finally somebody said, "You know, I really think you've got something there. Programming's such a complex business that anyone who thinks he knows all the answers and never looks anything up or goes to ask has got to make more trouble than he's worth."

第一次在研讨会上，健谈的经理似乎不知所措。最后他开始结结巴巴地说：“嗯……嗯……你不明白。为什么，如果他们不知道 所有 的答案，我为什么要付给他们那么多钱？” 有一些激烈的讨论，但最后这位健谈的经理从未质疑过他对一个无所不知的程序员的高价值的假设。

For the first time in the seminar, the talkative manager seemed at a loss for words. Finally he started sputtering, "Um . . . hmmnh . . . you don't understand. Why, if they don't know all the answers, why am I paying them all that money?" There was some heated discussion, but in the end the talkative manager never did question his assumption of the high value of a know-it-all programmer.

后来在同一个研讨会上，我们讨论了程序员生产力的更多量化指标。有很多人对计算每天生成的代码行数有很多看法，而且大多数争论都集中在什么应该算作一行代码上。最后，我告诉他们最近的研究表明，基于 Halstead 在软件科学领域的工作，编码解决方案的长度与该解决方案的质量之间存在反比关系。

Later in the same seminar, we discussed more quantitative measures of programmer productivity. There was a lot of sentiment for counting lines of code produced per day, and most of the argument centered on just what should be counted as a line of code. Eventually, I told them about recent studies showing an inverse correlation between the length of a coded solution and the quality of that solution, based on Halstead's work in software science.

他们很困惑。“如果我们不能计算代码行数，我们还能计算什么？” “即使它们是负相关的，计算它们不是比什么都不计算更好吗？”

They were befuddled. "If we can't count lines of code, what can we count?" "Isn't it better to count them, even if they are inversely correlated, than to count nothing at all?"

在我草率地回答那个问题之前，我考虑过一个旧的假设是如何变成一个新的谎言的。 “也许，”我说，“你可以奖励每天编写更少代码行的程序员。” 他们明显地颤抖着，直到我继续推理，使他们摆脱痛苦。

Before I made a hasty answer to that question, I considered how an old assumption becomes perverted into a new falsehood. "Perhaps," I said, "you could reward programmers for producing fewer lines of code per day." They shuddered visibly until I put them out of their misery by continuing the line of reasoning.

“但这很快也会变成一个错误的假设。为什么不把生产 1,000 行质量稳定的代码来解决标准难度问题所需的天数算作生产率（实际上是它的倒数）？”

"But that would soon become a false assumption, too. Why don't you count as productivity (actually its inverse) the number of days required to produce 1,000 lines of code of constant quality working on a problem of standard difficulty?"

“但我们无法衡量质量！”

"But we can't measure quality!"

“还是困难！”

"Or difficulty!"

“哦，”我回答说，又被难住了。然后我想起了倒退原则。“那么也许你应该首先研究这些问题，而不是研究恰好容易回答的不相关问题。”

"Oh," I replied, stumped again. Then I remembered the backwards principle. "Then perhaps you should be working on those questions first, rather than on irrelevant questions that happen to be easy to answer."

轮到他们“哦”了一声。

It was their turn to say "Oh."

幽默可以提高生产力吗？

Can Humor Be Productive?

1923 年，当英国曼彻斯特的情况相当惨淡时，我当时 19 岁的父亲收拾了他为数不多的财产，从他的出生地移民到前殖民地。虽然他最终失去了大部分英国口音，但他从未失去过英国人的幽默感，这让他在美国惹来了无穷无尽的麻烦。他被资本家称为共产主义者，被共产主义者称为资本家，只是因为他的笑话不被认为是笑话。

When things were pretty bleak in Manchester, England, in 1923, my father, then nineteen, packed up his few possessions and emigrated from his birthplace to the former colonies. Although he eventually lost most of his British accent, he never lost his British sense of humor, which caused him no end of trouble in the United States. He was called a communist by the capitalists and a capitalist by the communists, merely because his jokes were not recognized as jokes.

我有一个英国父亲和一个极端美国化的母亲（也从不理解他的笑话），我是在一种没人能理解 的幽默感中长大的。当其他人都在哭泣或睡觉时，我经常发现自己在剧院里独自大笑。尽管我从来没有被认真地称为共产主义者或资本家，但我时常被误解，尤其是当我试图写一些有趣的东西时。

Having a British father and an extremely American mother (who never understood his jokes, either), I was brought up with a sense of humor nobody understood. I often find myself laughing alone in the theater when everyone else is crying or sleeping. Though I've never been seriously called either a communist or a capitalist, I have been misinterpreted from time to time, especially when I try to write something funny.

显然，我在写前一篇文章时失误了，因为 DA Martin 责备我提倡将代码行数作为程序员生产力的衡量标准。实际上，我认为我在做的是说测量代码行没有任何意义， 除非： （1）所有工作的质量是恒定的，并且（2）所解决的问题都具有相同的难度。而且，由于 没有人 知道如何衡量这些东西，我建议也许我们应该首先研究这些问题。

Evidently, I slipped when I wrote the preceding essay, because D. A. Martin has taken me to task for advocating lines of code as a measure of programmer productivity. Actually, what I thought I was doing was saying there's no sense whatsoever in measuring lines of code unless: (1) the quality of all pieces of work is constant, and (2) the problems worked on are all of the same difficulty. And, since nobody knows how to measure those things, I suggested that perhaps we should be working on those questions first.

如果我没看错 Martin 的信（也许我没看出 他的 幽默），他就是同意我的观点，但详细说明了这两项有用措施可能涉及的内容。他说：

If I read Martin's letter correctly (and perhaps I don't see his humor), he's agreeing with me but elaborating on what might be involved in those two useful measures. He says:

一个程序可能由两个不同的程序员在同一时间段内实现。一个程序包含 200 行，另一个程序包含 600 行。谁的生产力更高？Halstead 观察到 200 行解决方案可能具有更高的“质量”……是正确的，但仍然具有误导性。毫无疑问，任何有意义意义上的“质量”都是根据可靠性、可维护性和性能来表达的。

A program may be implemented by two different programmers in the same period of time. One program contains 200, and the other program 600, lines of rode. Who is the more productive? Halstead's observation that the 200 line solution is likely to have greater "quality" ... is true, but is nonetheless misleading. Surely "quality" in any meaningful sense is expressed in terms of reliability, maintainability, and performance.

准确地说，除了我不同意“可能”这个词。大卫·科恩 (David Coan) 在回应同一篇文章时谈到了“质量”，我对此深表同情。他说，所有编程标准都必须以某种方式与“这个程序是否足以满足它的需求？”这个问题相关。

Precisely, except that I can't agree with the word "likely." David Coan, in responding to the same article, speaks of "quality" in terms with which I can be extremely sympathetic. He says that all criteria for programming must somehow be related to the question "Is this program good enough for what it's wanted for?"

这很像我们向每一次正式技术审查提出的问题：这个产品能完成它应该做的工作吗？该问题可以应用于代码或我们想要衡量其“质量”的任何其他产品。

This is much like the question we put to every formal technical review: Will this product do the job it's supposed to do? The question can be applied to code or to any other product whose "quality" we want to measure.

我相信这是顶级问题，比 Martin 建议的措施（例如“可维护性”）高出一步。我一直主张可维护性，甚至在人们指责我因为不知道“程序与硬件不同，不需要维护”而无知的日子里也是如此！（由 IBM 经理在 1961 年的 IBM Bald Peak 编程会议上说。）但是对于某些程序来说，“可维护性”不是“它应该做的工作”的一部分。

I believe this is the top-level question, one step above the measures Martin suggests, such as "maintainability." I've always argued for maintainability, even back in the days when people accused me of being ignorant for not knowing "programs, unlike hardware, don't require maintenance"! (Said by IBM managers at the IBM Bald Peak Programming Conference in 1961.) But there are some programs for which "maintainability" is not part of the "job it's supposed to do."

不，我不会愚蠢到相信发誓这个 程序将“只运行一次” 的用户。但是当这样的人出现时，我会为该程序提供两个价格：x 美元，我将在程序运行一次后销毁它，由我亲自销毁；一个能够由我或其他人运行 两次 或更多次的程序需要3美元。如果人们真的不想要可维护性，那么向他们收费是没有意义的。在我看来，一个不需要该功能的程序是可维护的（因此成本是原来的几倍），这不是一个高质量的程序。

No, I'm not so foolish as to believe the user who swears this program will be run "only once." But when such a person shows up, I offer two prices for the program: x dollars for a program I will destroy after it has been run once, by me personally; and 3x dollars for a program capable of being run twice, or perhaps more, by me or somebody else. There's no sense charging people for maintainability if they really don't want it. A program built to be maintainable (and thus costing several times as much) when there was no requirement for that feature, is not, to my thinking, a quality program.

换句话说，质量与手头的问题有关。劳斯莱斯通常被认为是优质汽车。如果我在内布拉斯加州林肯市拥有一辆，它不符合我的要求，原因如下：

In other words, quality is relative to the problem at hand. A Rolls-Royce is generally understood to be a quality car. If I owned one out in Lincoln, Nebraska, it would not meet my requirements for several reasons:

1. 它不适合我的车库。

1. It wouldn't fit in my garage.

2. 我很难获得零件和/或服务。

2. I'd have difficulty getting parts and/or service.

3. 由于这些部位的独特性，很可能被偷窃或骚扰。

3. It would likely be stolen or molested because of its uniqueness in these parts.

（但不要气馁，如果你们中有人想在我生日时送我劳斯莱斯。我总能建一个新车库。）

(But don't be discouraged, if any of you were thinking of sending me a Rolls for my birthday. I can always build a new garage.)

我相信 Martin 接近这个观点，他在信的后面说：

I believe Martin is close to this point of view when he says, later in his letter:

重点是：代码行是解决方案的衡量标准，而不是问题所在。估算人员的目标应该是评估解决给定问题所需的人工天数，从而达到可接受的质量水平。为此，他应该尝试量化问题的组成部分，而不是像后一种情况那样量化解决方案 (LOC)——他不可避免地要对“最佳”解决方案的性质做出假设。

The major point is this: Lines of code are a measure of the solution and not the problem. The estimator's objective should be to assess the man-effort days required to solve a given problem resulting in an acceptable level of quality. To do this, he should attempt to quantify the problem components, not the solution (LOC), as in the latter case—he is inevitably making assumptions about the nature of the "best" solution.

当然，这里他说的是估算工作，而不是评估工人的绩效。如果我们有兴趣衡量工人的生产率，那么我们大概想要比较工人的实际努力与根据问题的“难度”估计的努力。

Of course, here he's talking about estimating work, rather than evaluating the performance of the worker. If we were interested in measuring the productivity of the worker, then we would presumably want to compare that worker's actual effort with the effort estimated on the basis of the problem's "difficulty."

相反，在实际估算中——而不是为特定任务设置标准工作单位——我们必须考虑实际工人的生产率。根据比我们可以分配给工作的能力更强的工人的可用性来进行估算是没有意义的。也许这就是我们的编程估计经常错误的原因之一。

Conversely, in actual estimating—rather than in setting standard work units for particular tasks—we would have to take the actual worker's productivity into account. There's no sense making an estimate based on availability of workers more capable than we can assign to the job. Perhaps this is one reason we're often so far wrong in our programming estimates.

一个简单的事实是我们不知道如何评估任何有意义的问题中固有的“困难”。在迄今为止执行的每个有用的编程实验中，在几个程序员或团队处理“相同”问题的情况下，性能差异为 10:1 或更多。通常 30:1 或 50:1 是比较典型的数字。我自己的结论：在许多情况下，“问题难度”的概念作为衡量标准没有任何意义。困难似乎是 问题与解决问题的方法之间的关系。

The simple fact is we don't know how to assess the "difficulty" inherent in any meaningful problem. In every useful experiment on programming so far performed, where several programmers or teams worked on the "same" problem, there have been variations of 10:1 or more in performance. Usually 30:1 or 50:1 is a more typical figure. My own conclusion: in many cases the concept of "problem difficulty" makes no sense as a measurement. The difficulty seems to be a relationship between the problem and the approach to solving it.

可以肯定的是， 在大多数情况下，有些问题在统计上比其他问题更容易。 但这是有用的措施吗？想一想在程序中查找错误的问题。我们的测试表明，某些植入的错误需要一个人十五分钟才能发现， 另一个人需要十五小时， 第三个人需要十五秒。十五分钟左右又有几个人进来，但后来我们找到了无论他们搜索多久都找不到错误的人。这种变化很难构成估计的基础，即使平均时间，甚至是典型时间，大约是 15 分钟。

To be sure, some problems are statistically easier than others, most of the time. But is this a useful measure? Think of the problem of finding an error in a program. Our tests have shown certain implanted errors take fifteen minutes for one person to find, fifteen hours for another, fifteen seconds for a third. A few more people come in at around fifteen minutes, but then we find people who can't find the error no matter how long they search. This kind of variation hardly forms the basis for estimating, even though the average, and even the typical, figure is around fifteen minutes.

一些作者针对这种可变性提出了解决方案，即只雇用“最好的”程序员——在 15 秒内发现错误的人。或者，如果不可能找到这样的人，他们建议剔除十五小时的人和从未发现错误的人。尽管在编程行业中有一些被证明不称职的人，但“十五秒内发现错误的程序员”是不存在的。在一个错误上花费 15 秒的人在下一个错误上花费了 15 分钟，而且根本找不到第三个错误！

Some authors, reacting to this kind of variability, have suggested the solution lies in hiring only the "best" programmer—the one who finds the error in fifteen seconds. Or, if finding such a person is not possible, they propose weeding out the fifteen-hour person and the one who never finds the error. Although there are some certified incompetents in the programming business, there is no such thing as "the programmer who finds the error in fifteen seconds." The person who takes fifteen seconds on one error winds up taking fifteen minutes on the next, and not finding the third at all!

每当我写关于编程的文章时，这些​​关于人类可变性的事实最重要，我想我仍然是无辜的马丁的指责：

Having these facts concerning human variability uppermost in my mind whenever I write about programming, I think I remain innocent of Martin's accusation:

温伯格的“问题倒置”策略听起来像是一种横向思维的方法论。它可能导致问题过于简单化。程序员的生产力不是一个恰好容易回答的“无关紧要的问题”——它是制造软件业务中所有人员的核心问题。

Weinberg's strategy of "problem inversion" sounds like a methodology for lateral thinking. It can result in a seductive oversimplification of a problem. Programmer productivity is not an "irrelevant question" which happens to be easy to answer—it is a central issue to all those in the business of manufacturing software.

虽然我很欣赏被称为诱人，但我相信我被误读了——事实上是颠倒了。我说“无关紧要的问题”是“程序员每天生产多少行代码？” 虽然它提出了一些小困难，但这个问题相对容易回答——但我觉得它无关紧要。我根本不把这个问题等同于“什么是程序员的生产力？”这个问题。这就是我上一篇文章的全部要点。“问题倒转”的策略不是“横向思维”的方法，而是一种思想长期落后时被人嘲笑的准备。通过展示我们犯 180 度错误的频率，我曾希望让我的读者做好准备，以了解我们又犯了同样的错误——计算代码行数。

Although I appreciate being called seductive, I believe I've been misread—inverted, in fact. I said the "irrelevant question" was "How many lines of code per day does a programmer produce?" Although it presents some minor difficulties, this question is relatively easy to answer—but, I feel, it is irrelevant. I don't at all equate this question with the question "What is a programmer's productivity?" That was the entire point of my previous essay. The strategy of "problem inversion" is not a method of "lateral thinking," but a preparation for being laughed at when your thinking has been backwards for a long time. By showing how frequently we have been 180 degrees wrong, I had hoped to prepare my readers for the revelation that we're doing it again—in counting lines of code.

但遗憾的是，我的英国/美国幽默/幽默在一些读者身上消失了，比如马丁，我认为他 100% 同意我的看法。不过，经过深思熟虑，我开始认为这可能不是我的错（什么时候是 程序员 的错了？）。作为 NCR Ltd. 的质量保证经理，Martin 几乎每个工作日都必须深入研究这个生产力问题，不像许多 DP 经理只有在他们周围的世界崩溃时才绝望地求助于它。因此，他对这个问题的思考必然比一般DP经理的思考更深刻、更中肯。

But alas, my British/American humour/humor was lost on some readers, like Martin, who I thought were 100 percent in agreement with me. Upon reflection, though, I've come to think it may not be my fault (when is it ever the programmer's fault?). Martin, as quality assurance manager of NCR Ltd., must be deeply engaged in this productivity question almost every working day, unlike many DP managers who turn to it in despair only when their world is collapsing around them. As a consequence, his thinking on the question is bound to be more profound and more on target than the thinking of the average DP manager.

不幸的是，无论是 Martin 还是一般绝望的 DP 经理，当他们想到生产力问题时，都没有心情开玩笑。我能理解，我很感激。但我不能推荐它作为解决问题的方法。如果我们对如此困难的问题过于认真，我们可能会对“荒谬”的建议不屑一顾，例如反转问题。

Unfortunately, both Martin and the average despairing DP manager, when they think about the productivity problem, are not in the mood for jokes. I can understand that, and I appreciate it. But I can't recommend it as a problem-solving method. If we're too serious about so difficult a problem, we're likely to shrug off "ridiculous" suggestions, such as inverting the problem.

为什么这些“荒谬”的建议如此重要？这没什么神秘的。如果“明智”的建议可以解决衡量生产力的问题，那么我和马丁以及其他数百人早就解决了这个问题。多年未解决的问题证明了其内在的困难。或者，正如我刚才所说，我们试图应用的方法存在固有的困难。

And why are these "ridiculous" suggestions so important? There's nothing mysterious about it. If "sensible" suggestions could have solved the problem of measuring productivity, then both Martin and I, and a few hundred other people, would have solved it years ago. A problem remaining unsolved for years bears witness to its inherent difficulty. Or, as I just said, to the inherent difficulty in the methods we're trying to apply.

所以当我拿生产力测量开玩笑时，并不意味着我没有认真对待这个问题。这意味着我认为这个问题太难了，太重要了，不能一直认真对待。

So when I make jokes about productivity measurements, it doesn't mean I don't take the problem seriously. It means I think the problem is too difficult, and far too important, to be taken seriously all the time.

想想看，或许衡量程序员能力的最佳标准不是代码行数 (LOC)，而是幽默感 (SOH)。我们处境艰难。这很难做到，也很难衡量。你也许可以在不产生大量 LOC 的情况下生存。但是当 IMS 将 OC3 SVC 放在您的 TSO VDU 上并且 IBM 说没有 ZAP 所以您需要一个 RPQ 时，您最好有充足的 SOH 供应。否则你很快就会成为 DOA。

Come to think of it, perhaps the best measure of a programmer's ability is not lines of code (LOC) but sense of humor (SOH). We're in a tough business. It's tough to do and it's tough to measure. You might be able to survive without turning out oodles of LOC. But when IMS puts an OC3 SVC on your TSO VDU and IBM says there's no ZAP so you'll need an RPQ, you'd better have a good supply of SOH. Otherwise you'll soon be DOA.

玛丽亚特蕾莎勋章

The Order of Maria Theresa

我严厉批评了 Paul Watzlawick 关于处理恐怖分子绑架的幼稚建议。我想通过从他的书的第一部分发展出一种洞察力来平衡平衡 。 其实前半部分比后半部分好多了——也许最后他赶时间，没来得及批评自己的想法。此外，错误的想法和愚蠢的想法之间有着天壤之别。只要一个想法能产生其他想法，就有希望从中产生一些好东西。 真实的真实程度 充满了刺激的想法，有些是对的，有些是错的。

I've taken some hard licks at Paul Watzlawick for his naive suggestion about handling terrorist kidnappings. I'd like to even the balance by developing an insight from the first part of his book How Real Is Real? Actually, the first part is much better than the second—perhaps he was in a hurry at the end and didn't have time to criticize his own ideas. Besides, there's a world of difference between a wrong idea and a dull one. As long as an idea generates other ideas, there's hope something good might come out of it. And How Real Is Real is full of stimulating ideas, some right and some wrong.

我想讨论的想法体现在玛丽亚·特蕾莎女皇在位期间在奥地利设立的一枚勋章——玛丽亚·特蕾莎勋章。Watzlawick 谈到这个奖项时说：

The idea I wish to discuss is embodied in a medal established in Austria during the reign of Empress Maria Theresa—the Order of Maria Theresa. Watzlawick says of this award:

直到第一次世界大战结束，它一直是奥地利最高的军事勋章。. . 令人耳目一新的荒谬之处在于，它专门留给那些通过自己动手和主动违抗命令来扭转战局的军官。当然，如果出现问题，他们不会受到勋章，而是会因不服从而被送上军事法庭。

It remained Austria's highest military decoration until the end of World War I. . . . With refreshing absurdity it was reserved exclusively for officers who turned the tide of battle by taking matters into their own hands and actively disobeying orders. Of course, if things went wrong, they were not decorated but courtmartialed for disobedience.

Watzlawick 不满足于仅仅描述这个来自世界上最著名的官僚机构的具有洞察力的奖项，他继续发表社论：

Not content with mere description of this perceptive award from the world's most famous bureaucracy, Watzlawick goes on to editorialize:

玛丽亚·特蕾莎勋章也许是官方反悖论的最高典范，值得一个国家对待命运的明箭，其态度始终以座右铭为特征：形势无望，但并不严重。

The Order of Maria Theresa is perhaps the supreme example of an official counter-paradox, worthy of a nation whose attitude toward the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune has always been characterized by the motto: The situation is hopeless but not serious.

也许 Watzlawick 应该一个人呆着就好了。玛丽亚·特蕾莎 (Maria Theresa) 勋章是官僚发明的奇迹，但很难称其为悖论，更不用说反悖论了。 每个 成功的组织——国家、企业或社区风筝俱乐部——都有打破自己规则的规则。玛丽亚特蕾莎勋章唯一不同寻常的地方在于，这条规则被写下来并得到官方承认。

Perhaps Watzlawick should have left well enough alone. The Order of Maria Theresa is a marvel of bureaucratic invention, but it hardly deserves to be called a paradox, let alone a counter-paradox. Every successful organization—nation, business, or neighborhood kite club—has rules for breaking its own rules. The only unusual aspect of the Order of Maria Theresa is that the rule was written down and officially recognized.

杰斐逊在起草美国宪法的时候，自然而然地写了一篇关于修正案的文章。但是当被要求写一些东西来授予人民完全抛弃宪法并重新开始的权利时，杰斐逊拒绝了。他争辩说——我认为这是正确的——人民拥有这样的权利，无论它是否写入宪法。这是一种取代任何政府和任何政府成文规则的权利。实际上，这是同义反复，因为没有被统治者的同意，就没有政府。一个影子，也许，但没有政府。

When Jefferson was drafting the United States Constitution, he naturally wrote an article concerning amendments. But when asked to write something granting the people the right to throw out the Constitution entirely and start afresh, Jefferson refused. He argued—correctly, I think—that the people had such a right whether or not it was written in the Constitution. It was a right superseding any government and any written rules of government. It was, in effect, a tautology, for without the consent of the governed, there is no government. A shadow, perhaps, but no government.

在任何现代官僚机构中也是如此。规则不是为了被打破而制定的，但它们也不是为了 不被 打破而制定的。制定规则是为了使组织更有效地运作。高于所有其他规则的规则是“做有效运作所必需的事情”。你最终会因为没有有效运作而受到惩罚，但不会因为违反规则而受到惩罚。

The same is true in any modern bureaucracy. Rules are not made to be broken, but neither are they made to be not broken. Rules are made so that the organization operates more effectively. The rule above all other rules is "Do what is necessary to operate effectively." You ultimately get punished for not operating effectively, but not for breaking the rules.

在我看来，官僚主义的问题在于：这枚硬币的正面并不那么闪亮。如果你遵守规则，结果很糟糕，你通常不会受到惩罚。在战争中，问题可能更容易解决，因为如果事情变得糟糕，你可能已经死了，根本不必面对女皇。在 XYZ Pork and Bean Factory，您的生命通常不会受到威胁——即使您的顾客 每次拿起叉子时都在拿自己的生命做准备。

It seems to me the problem with bureaucracies is this: the obverse side of this coin isn't so shiny. If you obey the rules and things turn out badly, you usually don't get punished. In war, the problem may be easier, because if things turn out badly you may be dead and not have to face the Empress at all. In the XYZ Pork and Bean Factory, your life is not usually at risk—even if your customers are taking their lives in their hands every time they pick up a fork.

在玛丽亚·特蕾莎 (Maria Theresa) 获奖者获得奖牌后， 我有兴趣研究他们的传记。我知道在美国——荣誉勋章通常是在类似的情况下颁发的——许多获奖者最终以平民身份在典当行为他们的勋章赚取几美分。在最好的情况下，即使获得奖牌也只是昙花一现。

I'd be interested in pursuing the biographies of Maria Theresa winners after they won the medal. I know that in the United States—where the Medal of Honor is often given under similar circumstances—many winners wind up, as civilians, trying to get a few cents for their medals in a pawn shop. Even medal-winning is a short-lived glory in the best of circumstances.

当我开始写这篇文章时，我希望通过建议每个组织建立玛丽亚特蕾莎勋章来抵消即使是管理最好的组织也会感染的循规蹈矩的倾向。但随着我的想法的发展，我意识到奖牌并不是答案。如果你处在一个大型组织金字塔的顶端，并且想要保护自己不受自己错误命令的影响，那么你将不得不比玛丽亚特蕾莎更加努力地工作。

When I started to write this essay, I hoped to conclude by recommending each organization install an Order of Maria Theresa to counteract the conformist tendencies infecting even the best-managed organizations. But as my thoughts developed, I realized medals are not the answer. If you're on top of a large organizational pyramid and want protection from your own mistaken orders, you're going to have to work harder than Maria Theresa.

您可以首先确保没有人仅仅因为 讨论 您的特定订单的优点而受到惩罚。即使你不惩罚讨论，你也需要很长时间才能克服人们在 其他 组织长期职业生涯中习得的恐惧。但漫长的等待是值得的，因为那时你将摆脱完美的负担——任何人和国家都无法长期承受的负担。

You can start by ensuring nobody is punished merely for discussing the merits of a particular order of yours. Even if you don't punish discussion, you'll need a long time to overcome the fears people have learned throughout their long careers in other organizations. But the long wait will be worth it, for then you will be relieved of the burden of perfection—a burden no person and no nation can long endure.

你可能认为你的下一步是鼓励人们不服从他们认为错误或愚蠢的命令，但如果谈话的气氛合适，他们就不需要任何鼓励。至少他们中的一些人不会，而其他人会关注先驱们会发生什么。因此，当有人不服从并失败时，你的第二个问题就来了！现在你有完美的机会来玩“我早就告诉过你了”，但如果你这样做了，就不会再有任何游戏了。相反，您必须说服此人告诉您不服从命令的原因。这可能是一个愚蠢的命令，即使执行了也注定要失败。或者它可能被误解了——一个最有可能的选择。

You might think your next step would be to encourage people to disobey orders they think are wrong or foolish, but they won't need any encouragement if the climate for talking is right. At least some of them won't, and the others will be watching to see what happens to the pioneers. So your second problem comes when someone disobeys—and fails! Now you have the perfect opportunity to play "I told you so," but if you do, there won't be any further games. Instead, you must convince the person to tell you why the order was disobeyed. It might have been a stupid order, destined to fail even if it had been carried out. Or it might have been misunderstood—a most likely alternative.

一旦你明白了不服从的原因，就放下这件事！每个人都有权偶尔犯错误。如果人们从不犯错，那就意味着他们从不尝试，从不思考，这是官僚主义所能想到的最可怕的命运。只有当同一个人一而再、再而三地违抗命令时，你才需要采取任何行动——到那时你的行动方针应该是显而易见的。

And once you've understood the reasons for the disobedience, drop the whole matter! Everyone is entitled to make a mistake now and then. If people never make mistakes, it means they're never trying and never thinking, which is the most horrible fate a bureaucracy can contemplate. Only if the same person disobeys orders over and over will you have to take any action—and by then your course of action should be obvious.

但屡次失败岂不是酿成大祸？也许吧，但是你可以从奥地利的格言中得到安慰：情况是绝望的，但并不严重。

But won't the repeated failures create a disaster? Perhaps, but then you can take comfort from the Austrian motto: The situation is hopeless but not serious.

在编程业务中，我们在所做的事情中拥有巨大的安全缓冲垫。我们犯了很多错误，但我们有专门的程序来检测它们并在它们造成太大伤害之前将其删除。如果这些程序运作良好，它就会给我们一些犯错的喘息空间——我们需要同样的空间来学习。在这种情况下，我们不应该需要勋章来让我们不服从愚蠢的命令。

In the programming business, we have the comfort of a large cushion of safety in what we do. We make many mistakes, but we have procedures designed to detect them and remove them before they cause too much harm. If those procedures are working well, it gives us some breathing room in which to make mistakes—the same room we need in order to learn. In such situations, we shouldn't need medals to keep us disobeying foolish orders.

福克斯和野鸡：寓言

The Phox and the Pheasants: A Phable

一个晴朗的日子，一只狐狸搬进了野鸡区。当野鸡站在远处看着货车卸货时，其中一只野鸡评论说：“这真是太棒了，一只福克斯就在隔壁移动。”

One fine day, a fox moved into the pheasant neighborhood. As the pheasants stood at a distance and watched the van being unloaded, one of them remarked, "A phine thing this is, a phox moving in right next door."

“确实如此，”其他人之一同意道。“只要有那只火狐，phlock 里的野鸡就不会安全。”

"Indeed," one of the others agreed. "No pheasant in the phlock will be safe, as long as that phox is there."

“不用担心，”最小的菲利普说。“只要我们在一起，世界上就没有可以伤害我们的 phox。我认为我们应该召开会议，看看我们是否可以向 phox 展示一个联合的 phront。”

"No need to be aphraid," said Philip, the youngest. "As long as we stay together, there isn't a phox in the world who could harm us. I think we should call a meeting, to see if we can present a united phront to the phox."

虽然他们不愿意效仿这样一只年轻的野鸡，但鸟群中年长的成员无法真正否认他所提出的建议的智慧，所以当晚就召集了一次会议。在会议上，大家一致认为必须明确警告狐狸：玻璃下的野鸡绝对不在菜单上，除非他想成为地下狐狸。但随后出现了关于如何 告知 他的问题。菲利普提议对野鸡大会的决议进行唱名表决，这样狐狸就可以准确地看到谁投了赞成票。

Although they were reluctant to follow the lead of such a young pheasant, the older members of the flock couldn't really deny the wisdom of what he had proposed, so a meeting was called for that very night. At the meeting, agreement was universal that the fox had to be warned in no uncertain terms: pheasant-under-glass was strictly off the menu, unless he wanted to be fox-under-ground. But then the question arose as to how he would be told. Philip proposed that a roll-call vote be taken and attached to the resolution of the pheasant assembly, so the fox could see precisely who had voted to back it up.

“你们看，”他向集会者解释说，“我们必须站起来接受计数，这样狐狸就知道我们没有恐慌症。否则他会一次把我们抓走一个，把我们当成幻象。”

"You see," he explained to the assembly, "we have to stand up and be counted, so the phox knows we are not aphraid. Otherwise he will pick us off one at a time, and make a phancy pheast of us."

但年长的野鸡们并不服气。正如其中一位所说，“青春的花言巧语只是花言巧语，但每次都给我老年的智慧。” 在这种情况下，根据年龄的智慧，狐狸很可能会被个人的名字激怒，并导致对那些签名的人采取不理智的行为。“更好，”他争辩说，“避免面对面的冲突。一个简单的展示翅膀的投票将承担这个集会的重量。如果我们年轻的 phasethered 朋友想要 phace phox，我建议他被指定交付决议。”

But the older pheasants were not convinced. As one of them said, "The phlowery phrases of youth are just phine, but give me the wisdom of age every time." In this instance, the wisdom of age said the fox was likely to be angered by individual names and caused to act irrationally toward those who had signed. "Better," he argued, "to avoid phace-to-phace conphrontations. A simple show-of-wings vote will carry the phull weight of this assembly. Iph our young pheathered-phriend wants to phace the phox, I move that he be designated to deliver the resolution."

动议和决议通过了，但没有唱名，尽管小野鸡最后请求其他人站起来接受点名。当他把决议交给狐狸时，他知道自己被赋予了这份危险的工作，作为对挑战长老们的智慧和勇气的惩罚。“我当然害怕，”他一边敲着狐狸的前门，一边自言自语道，“但我已经做好了面对恐惧的准备。”

The motion and the resolution carried, but without a roll call, in spite of a final plea by the young pheasant for the others to stand up and be counted. As he carried the resolution to the fox, he knew he had been given this dangerous job as a punishment for having challenged the wisdom and courage of the elders. "Of course I'm aphraid," he said to himself as he knocked on the front door of the fox, "but I'm phully prepared to phight phor my phreedom."

狐狸打开门，看到来访者，着实吃了一惊。“我的天哪，”他叫道，“这是一个幻影还是真的是一个飞来访者？”

The fox opened the door and was truly surprised to see his visitor. "My goodness," he cried, "is this a fantom or is it really a feasant come to visit?"

“我叫菲利普，”来访者说，无视主人奇怪的口音。“我是受野鸡会派来找你的，特意向你下达了这个决议，我们可以互相理解，做个好邻居。”

"My name is Philip," said the visitor, ignoring his host's strange accent. "I've been sent by the pheasant assembly to phind you and to deliver this resolution to you, so that we can be good neighbors based on mutual understanding."

“我的名字叫弗雷迪，”狐狸说。“在我阅读你的这份决议时，你能不能进来，这样我就可以给你一个答复？你为什么不坐在 fonograf 旁边？”

"And my name's Freddy," said the fox. "Won't you come in while I read this resolution of yours, so I can give you a reply? Why don't you just sit there by the fonograf?"

当菲利普坐在那里试图掩饰他的颤抖时，弗雷迪读了决议。当他完成后，他说，“好吧，菲利普，它充满了优美的段落，但为什么个别成员不签名呢？”

While Philip sat trying to conceal his trembling, Freddy read the resolution. When he finished, he said, "Well, Filip, it's full of fine frases, but why didn't the individual members sign it?"

“我真的不能说，弗雷迪，”菲利普回答，但弗雷迪知道为什么。他看得出来，如果野鸡集会的成员害怕让他单独注意到他们的名字，事实上，如果他时不时地带他们中的一个成员吃点心，他们就不会提出任何反对意见。除了菲利普以外的所有人，也就是这只雏雉，虽然明明很害怕，但遇袭也会反抗。归根结底，弗雷迪不想被人啄眼睛，尤其是周围显然有这么容易被啄的地方。

"I can't really say, Phreddy," Philip replied, but Freddy knew why. He could see that if the members of the pheasant assembly were afraid to have their names brought to his attention individually, they would not, in fact, raise any opposition if and when he picked up one of their members for a snack now and then. All except Philip, that is, for this young pheasant, though he was obviously afraid, would fight if attacked. In the final analysis, Freddy had no desire to get pecked about the eyes, especially when there were obviously such easy pickings around.

因此，野鸡社区的生活安定下来，变成了菲利普所说的“phiphty phrightened pheasants and one phat phox”。

And so, life in the pheasant neighborhood settled down to what Philip called "phiphty phrightened pheasants and one phat phox."

寓意：站起来被算计好过躺下被吃掉。

Moral: Better to stand up and be counted than to lie down and be eaten.

换句话说：害怕并不是不专业。做胆小鬼是不专业的。

In other words: It's not unprofessional to be afraid. It is unprofessional to be a coward.

第七章 编程职业的下一步走向何方？

Chapter VII Where Is the Programming Profession Going Next?

一百年后的编程会是什么样子？

What Will Programming Be Like in One Hundred Years?

和大多数人一样，我对未来充满好奇。也和很多人一样，我 对过去不是很好奇。 但随着我对未来的好奇心越来越大，我不得不去了解历史。除了研究过去，我想不出任何其他方法来满足我对未来的好奇心——那时候的现在还处于未来。

Like most people, I'm curious about the future. Also like many people, I'm not very curious about the past. But as my curiosity about the future has grown, I've been forced to get acquainted with history.
