I'm unable to think of any other way to satisfy my curiosity about the future than by studying the past—the time when the present was still in the future.

这是我的意思的一个例子。我的一个朋友给我看了一本 1884 年的书，是在内布拉斯加州 Prairie Home 附近一座农舍的阁楼里找到的。这本书专门讨论妇女就业问题。介绍大体上谈到了新时代，在这个时代，女性正在离开她们作为家庭主妇的传统角色——这一变化“肯定永远不会逆转”。

Here's an example of what I mean. A friend of mine showed me a book dated 1884, found in the attic of a farmhouse near Prairie Home, Nebraska. The book was devoted to the subject of employment for women. The introduction spoke generally about the New Age, in which women were leaving their traditional roles as homemakers—a change that would "surely never be reversed."

这本书的大部分内容描述了女性最有前途的工作，用整整一章的篇幅介绍每个最重要的工作，例如医学。奇怪的是，秘书的工作并没有被突出提及。那时它被称为“amanuensis”，商业办公室不被认为是适合女性的环境。

The bulk of the book described the most promising jobs for women, devoting an entire chapter to each of the most important, such as medicine. Curiously, the job of secretary wasn't prominently mentioned. It was called "amanuensis" then, and a business office wasn't considered a suitable environment for women.

当然，打字机改变了这一切，不是吗？好吧，不是马上，因为当打字机问世时，它自然是由男人操作的。只有男人才能使用机器工作——这种假设根深蒂固，以至于书中没有提到“机械”工作。而且，当然，只有男人是 amanuenses。

Of course, the typewriter changed all that, didn't it? Well, not right away, for when the typewriter was introduced, it was naturally operated by men. Only men could work with machines—the assumption ran so deep that in the book no "mechanical" jobs were mentioned. And, of course, only men were amanuenses.

有两项主要工作引起了我的注意。第一个是很有前途的图片调色职业，一项由新兴的摄影技术创造的工作。摄影变得如此流行，以至于工作室跟不上年轻女士对照片着色的需求。任何有艺术天赋的人都可以学习这个专业，从而确保终生工作。

Two of the major jobs caught my attention. The first was the promising profession of picture tinter, a job created by the burgeoning technology of photography. Photography was growing so popular that studios couldn't keep up with the demand for young ladies to tint photographs. Anyone with an artistic bent could learn this profession and thus be assured of lifelong employment.

另一个有前途的新职业是电报员。这项高科技工作确实涉及到机械，但作者煞费苦心地指出，现代发明已经简化了使用电报机的任务。在最近的试验中，女士们经常被证明在使用编码钥匙方面与男士们一样熟练。

The other promising new profession was telegraph operator. This high-technology job did involve machinery, but the author took great pains to point out that modern inventions had simplified the task of using the telegraph machines. In recent trials, ladies had often proved as adept as gentlemen at using the coding key.

当然，如果作者更了解她那个时代的技术发展，她可能不会对电报事业做出如此热情的承诺。不过，她很有可能会将这些发展解读为西联汇款的一名官员在十年前所做的，当时实验表明可以通过电线直接传输人类的声音。 《科学美国人》的 一篇文章引用了这位官员的话说（1874 年），新发现 “迈出了完全取消操纵仪器（即电报键）的第一步……随着时间的推移，操作员将传送声音他们通过电线发出自己的声音，互相交谈而不是发电报。”

Of course, if the author had been more aware of the technical developments of her time, she might not have made such glowing promises about careers in telegraphy. Most likely, though, she would have interpreted these developments as one Western Union official had done ten years earlier when experiments showed the possibility of transmitting human voices directly by wire. A Scientific American article quoted this official as saying (in 1874) that the new discoveries had "taken the first step toward doing away with manipulating instruments (i.e., telegraph keys) altogether. . . . In time, the operators will transmit the sound of their own voices over the wire, and talk with one another instead of telegraphing."

我们的作者，如果她是一个真正的未来主义者，应该告诉年轻女士们通过语音训练为将来成为电报员做准备！这将被认为是一个令人震惊和大胆的未来主义预测。尽管如此，它最终可能会被接受为深刻的建议。

Our author, had she been a proper futurist, should have told the young ladies to prepare for their future as telegraphers by taking voice training! That would have been considered a shocking and daring futuristic prediction. Still, it might ultimately have been accepted as profound advice.

但假设她或西联汇款的官员暗示几乎每个人 家里都会有一部电话。 更糟糕的是，假设他们预测到每个家庭的电话都将在没有熟练接线员在场的情况下使用？没有人会相信他们，他们会被避开到被遗忘的未来主义者的土地上。

But suppose she or the Western Union official had hinted that almost everyone would have a telephone at home. Even worse, suppose they had predicted that the telephone in each home would be used without the presence of a skilled operator? Nobody would have believed them, and they would have been shunned into the land of forgotten futurists.

并正确地回避！为什么？因为人们并不是真的想知道未来一百年，甚至五十年会是什么样子。他们想知道下周可以在哪里找到工作，或者可以在哪里投资直到明年。他们不想知道 1884 年的未来，他们在 1984 年也不想知道。我会伸出我的脖子并预测他们在 2084 年也不会。

And rightly shunned! Why? Because people don't really want to know what one hundred years in the future, or even fifty, will be like. They want to know where they can get a job next week or where they can invest their money until next year. They didn't want to know about the future in 1884, and they didn't in 1984. And I'll stick my neck out and predict they won't in 2084, either.

事实上，预测未来是非常容易的。以下是您需要适用的一些法律：

Actually, it's extremely easy to predict the future. Here are some laws you will need to apply:

1. 从短期来看，有些事情会和现在差不多。

1. In the short run, some things will be pretty much the same as they are now.

2. 从长远来看，有些事情会与现在大不相同，无法预测。

2. In the long run, some things will be so different than they are now that there's no way to predict them.

3. 但从长远来看，我们都会死去，所以我们当然不会对一百年前某人的预测对或错感兴趣。

3. In the long run, though, we'll all be dead, so we certainly won't be interested in what someone predicted one hundred years earlier, right or wrong.

4. 我们都在短期内谋生，有些人比其他人短一点，但都一样短。

4. We all do our living in the short run, some a bit shorter than others, but short all the same.

这些定律允许你以任何你喜欢的方式做出长期预测。例如，我预测到 2084 年“计算机”的概念将不存在，除了像“amanuensis”这样的古老词。我们将使用“情感器”代替计算机。情绪将是半生命的、人造的生物系统，通过让我们不担心它们而不是通过现在这个词的“解决”它们来消除问题。

These laws allow you to make long-run predictions in any way you like. For instance, I predict that in 2084 the concept of "computer" won't exist, except as an archaic word like "amanuensis." Instead of computers, we'll have "emoters." Emoters will be semi-living, manufactured biological systems that eliminate problems by making us not worry about them rather than by "solving" them in the present sense of the word.

自然不会再有程序员了。他们将重蹈照片调色师的覆辙。（是的，我知道今天有一些人给照片上色来创造那种老式的外观。可能会有一些 PASCAL 程序员在主题公园工作——我们肯定还会有一些主题公园，不是吗？）

Naturally there won't be any more programmers. They will have gone the way of the photo tinters. (Yes, I know there are a few people tinting photographs today to create that old-fashioned look. There probably will be a few PASCAL programmers working in theme parks—we'll surely still have some theme parks, won't we?)

我们将拥有“游泳者”，而不是程序员。他们的工作将是通过将自己浸入情绪化者工作的红花油大桶中并在情绪化者的全身擦拭自己来与情绪化者进行交流。 （哦，是的，我能听到你们中的一些人说，“分布式表情包 怎么样？还记得电话吗？”但是去表情包旅行将是一次宗教朝圣，所以没有人愿意在家里拥有自己的个人表情包。此外，情绪会闻起来很难闻。）

Instead of programmers, we'll have "swimmers." Their job will be to enter into communion with the emoters by submerging themselves in the giant vats of safflower oil in which emoters work and by rubbing themselves all over the emoters' bodies. (Oh, yes, I can hear some of you saying, "What about distributed emoters? Remember the telephone?" But traveling to the emoter vats will be a religious pilgrimage, so nobody would want to have their own personal emoter at home. Besides, emoters will smell awful.)

哎呀，这个预测业务很有趣！我可以继续写几页——但你不会感兴趣的。因为你和我一样，在短期内谋生。

Gee, this predicting business is fun! I could go on for pages—but you wouldn't be interested. Because you, like me, do your living in the short run.

如果您不想考虑自己的短期前景，您就会感兴趣。 这就是为什么我在飞往澳大利亚的 27 小时航班上阅读科幻小说的原因。但是，如果您正在考虑作为一名程序员的职业前途，那么如果我建议您学习在红花油中游泳，您将不会高兴。

You would be interested if you didn't want to think about your own short run prospects. That's why I read science fiction on twenty-seven-hour flights to Australia. But if you're thinking about your professional future as a programmer, you won't be pleased if I advise you to learn to swim in safflower oil.

好吧，对于最近的未来——比如你的职业生涯，我能告诉你什么？这里有一些想法：

Well, what can I tell you for the more immediate future—for, say, your professional life? Here are a few ideas:

尽管短期内事情可能会线性推断，但您可以忘记那些推断，“按照目前的速度，到 2035 年美国将有 5 亿程序员。”

Although things may extrapolate linearly in the short run, you can forget about those extrapolations saying, "at present rates there will be 500 million programmers in the United States by the year 2035."

事实上，由于这样的推断，受惊的企业家们正在筹资以减少对程序员的需求。同样的事情也发生在电话接线员身上。如果每次通话都有接线员协助，按照我们目前的通话率，美国的每个人都必须是电话接线员——那么谁来拨打电话呢？事实上，除非找到某种方法来减少每次通话的接线员数量，否则我们甚至不会拥有目前的电话系统。

Indeed, because of such extrapolations, frightened entrepreneurs are financing ways of cutting down the need for programmers. The same thing happened with telephone operators. With operator assistance on every call, our present rate of calling would require everyone in the United States to be a telephone operator—and then who would make the calls? The fact is we wouldn't even have the present telephone system unless some way had been found to reduce the number of operators per call.

如果目前的趋势继续下去，编程中肯定会发生 同样的事情。一些减少编程需求的方法会奏效，但很难确定是哪些。但是请注意，今天的电话接线员仍然比五十年前多，比一百年前多得多。

The same kind of thing must happen in programming, if present trends continue. Some of the methods of reducing programming needs will pay off, though it is hard to say with certainty which ones. But notice there are still more telephone operators today than there were fifty years ago, and lots more than there were one hundred years ago.

今天仍有一​​些 1401 Autocoder 工作可用，二十年后可能会有更多 360/370 Assembler 和 COBOL 工作。但是，您可能不想要这些工作。

There are still a few 1401 Autocoder jobs available today, and twenty years from now there will probably be more 360/370 Assembler and COBOL jobs. However, you may not want these jobs.

我还可以做出其他预测，但我认为信息很明确。在你的职业生涯中会有大量的编程工作，但你最感兴趣的可能与你现在的编程工作有很大不同。要为这样的未来做好准备，您必须为改变做好准备。

There are other predictions I could make, but I think the message is clear. There will be programming jobs aplenty throughout your professional life, but the ones you'll be most interested in will probably be very different from the programming job you now have. To prepare for such a future, you'll have to prepare for change.

一个人如何为改变做准备？我将在其他地方对此进行更多讨论，但只要我们处于笼统概括的水平，这里还有一个：

How does one prepare for change? I'll have more to say about that elsewhere, but as long as we're on the level of sweeping generalities, here's one more:

5. 无论我们在哪里看历史，我们都找不到一次活过一天以上的人。我们有时确实会发现生活较少的人 。

5. No matter where we look in history, we never find anyone who lived more than one day at a time. We do sometimes find people who lived less.

这些一次活不到一天的人是谁？他们中的大多数人不是活在当下，而是梦想着生活在未来。但是为未来的生活做准备的方法就是充分活在当下！

Who were these people who lived less than one day at a time? Most of them were people who, instead of living in the present, dreamed about living in the future. But the way to prepare for living in the future is to live fully in the present!

所以不要问“一百年后编程会是什么样子？” 相反，看看你 现在在做什么。 问问自己，“我今天学到了什么？” 如果答案是“很少或没有”，那么您作为专业程序员的前途并不比现在光明多少。这就是为什么你的梦想被投射到遥不可及的未来吗？

So don't ask "What will programming be like in one hundred years?" Instead, take a look at what you're doing now. Ask yourself, "What have I learned today?" If the answer is "little or nothing," then your future as a professional programmer is not much brighter than your present. Could that be why your dreams are projected into the unreachable future?

编程生涯应该有多长？

How Long Should a Programming Career Be?

在其最原始的形式中，类型学思维认为“普通”个体存在一些现实。例如，假设我们调查了在星期六日场观看芭蕾舞的观众。它恰好卖给了当地的共济会寺庙，该寺庙的成员正带着他们年幼的女儿来体验一下文化。在这样的听众中，我们可能有身高约 3 英尺、体重 50 磅的 5 岁女孩，以及同等数量的身高约 6 英尺、体重 200 磅的 35 岁男性。从这样的调查中，我们可以很容易地得出结论，芭蕾舞的“典型”爱好者是一个 20 岁的胖侏儒，身高 4 英尺 6 英寸，体重 125 磅，并且是雌雄同体。-温伯格和温伯格，被动调节：通用系统设计原则

In its crudest form, typological thinking imagines that there is some reality to the "average" individual. For example, suppose we surveyed the audience attending the ballet at a Saturday matinee. It happens to be sold out to the local Masonic temple whose members are taking their young daughters for a bit of culture. In such an audience, we might have 5-year-old girls about 3 feet tall and weighing 50 pounds, plus an equal number of 35 year-old men about 6 feet tall and weighing 200 pounds. From such a survey, we could easily conclude that the "typical" aficionado of the ballet was a 20-year old fat midget, four-feet-six tall and weighing 125 pounds—and a hermaphrodite, to boot.—Weinberg and Weinberg, Passive Regulation: General Systems Design Principles

关于“程序员倦怠”这个主题，已经写了很多类型学上的废话。这种假设现象的特征是图 4 所示的生产力和经验之间的关系。

Much typological nonsense has been written on the subject of "programmer burnout." This supposed phenomenon is characterized by a relationship between productivity and experience indicated in Figure 4.

 

 

根据这张图片，三年后，额外的几年经验似乎不会显着增加程序员的生产力。坚持这种模式的管理者自然不愿意为多年的经验支付溢价。通常，他们会在就业市场上寻找具有一两年经验的程序员。

According to this picture, after three years, additional years of experience don't seem to add significantly to a programmer's productivity. Managers who hold to this model naturally are unwilling to pay a premium for many years of experience. Usually, they will seek programmers in the job market with one or two years of experience.

一个问题：这个模型可能没有考虑到问题的难度。在大多数商店中，平均而言，经验越丰富的程序员编写的程序越难编写。如果生产力的衡量标准没有考虑问题的难度，那么更有经验的程序员自然会低估他们的生产力。在某些情况下，更现实的模型如图 5 所示。

One problem: this model may fail to consider problem difficulty. In most shops, the more experienced programmers are given, on the average, more difficult programs to write. If the measures of productivity fail to consider problem difficulty, the more experienced programmers will naturally have their productivity underestimated. In some cases, a more realistic model would be like Figure 5.

这个稍微不那么悲观的曲线得到了编程心理学的一些研究结果的支持。当不同经验的程序员被要求执行相同的任务时——编码、查找错误、开发测试数据——平均性能与经验曲线通常如图 5 所示。即便如此，研究图 5 的经理可能仍希望遵循雇用经验很少的程序员以利用曲线急剧上升部分的策略。相反，程序员通常在第一年或第二年容忍低薪工作，以便在一家公司支付高薪是为了长寿而不是为了实际产出。

This slightly less pessimistic curve is supported by the results of a number of studies in the psychology of programming. When programmers of varying experience are asked to perform the same task—coding, finding bugs, developing test data—the average performance versus experience curve frequently looks like that of Figure 5. Even so, a manager studying Figure 5 may still wish to follow the strategy of hiring programmers with very little experience in order to take advantage of the steeply rising segment of the curve. Conversely, programmers often tolerate low-paying jobs in their first year or two in order to be in a firm paying well for longevity rather than for actual output.

图 4 和图 5 都代表了 普通 程序员的模型。在雇用数百或数千名程序员的真正大公司中，人事政策可能会迫使管理人员在招聘和设定工资时遵循平均水平。然而，较小的公司可能有更多的自由裁量权。如果他们有洞察力，他们可以通过注意每个程序员与假定的平均水平之间的差异来获利。

Both Figures 4 and 5 represent models of the average programmer. In really large firms, employing hundreds or thousands of programmers, personnel policies may force managers to follow the averages in hiring and setting wages. Smaller firms, however, may have more discretion. It they are perceptive, they can profit by noting the difference between each individual programmer and the presumed average.

生成图 5 的相同编程研究支持经理通过评估每个候选人的体验 质量而做得很好的想法 。程序员真的有十年的经验，或者更准确地说是一年的经验，十次？如果我们将每项研究中的程序员分为两组——高性能组和低性能组——我们通常会发现经验曲线如图 6 所示。

The same studies of programming producing Figure 5 support the idea a manager does well by appraising the quality of each candidate's experience. Does the programmer really have ten years of experience, or is it more accurately characterized as one year of experience, ten times? If we divide the programmers in each study into two groups—high performance and low performance—we generally find the experience curves look like those in Figure 6.

我们在图 4 或图 5 中看到的曲线可能是将这两条曲线混合成一条曲线。

The curve we see in Figure 4 or Figure 5 is probably a mixing of these two curves into a single curve.

这两条曲线代表的是真实的东西，还是对数据的人为操纵？我在此类研究和工作中的亲身经历告诉我，这里有一个重要的真理。要理解它，假设我们能够跟随 6 年前一起开始的一百名程序员实习生的职业生涯。每年，他们中的一些人都会退出编程，因为他们不喜欢它或不能做得很好。这些辍学率在一开始会很高，然后随着薪水上涨以克服任何残留的工作不满而下降。

Do these two curves represent anything real, or are they artificial manipulations of data? My own experience with such studies and on the job tells me there is an important truth here. To understand it, pretend we are able to follow the careers of one hundred programmer trainees who started together six years ago. Each year, some of them will drop out of programming because they don't like it or can't do it very well. These dropouts will be high at the beginning, then decline as salaries rise to overcome any residual job dissatisfaction.

一两年后，一些表现较好的人将获得编程以外的晋升机会。有些人会接受。有些人会拒绝，更喜欢他们喜欢并且做得很好的工作。不过，一般来说，晋升将主要提供给那些优秀的程序员——无论他们是否最有资格成为分析师、经理或数据库管理员。

After a year or two, some of the better performers will be offered promotions outside of programming. Some will accept. Some will decline, preferring the work they like and do well. Generally, though, the promotions will be offered principally to those who are the better programmers—whether or not they are the most qualified to be analysts, managers, or data-base administrators.

下表显示了这些假设的 100 名受训人员的分配在六年内可能如何演变：

The following table shows how the allocation of these hypothetical one hundred trainees might evolve over a six-year period:

这些数字并不意味着准确，而只是暗示趋势。

The figures are not meant to be exact, but only suggestive of trends.

现在假设我们将这张表分成两张表，每张表有五十名受训者。首先，我们有“能力最差”的五十人：

Now suppose we break down this table into two tables, each starting with fifty of the trainees. First, we have the "least able" fifty:

 

 

现在考虑“最能干”的五十人：

Now consider the "most able" fifty:

换句话说，根据这个模型，六年后，剩下的 30 名程序员中约有 77% 来自能力最低的 50%。最差的人早就退学了。另一方面，大多数更好的人已经被提拔出来，以满足对非编程工作中经验丰富的人员快速增长的需求。

In other words, according to this model, after six years about 77 percent of the thirty remaining programmers come from the 50 percent lowest in ability. The very worst have dropped out early. On the other hand, most of the better ones have been promoted out to meet rapidly growing demands for experienced personnel in non-programming jobs.

如果我们假设程序员的原始能力不是唯一或最关键的因素，则可以应用相同类型的建模。无论我们考虑什么因素，我们都必须避免假设我们看到的人口在某种程度上是静态的。这种假设导致了类型学谬误。

The same kind of modeling can be applied if we assume that the programmers' original ability is not the only or most crucial factor. Whatever factors we consider, we have to avoid assuming the population we see is somehow static. That assumption leads to typological fallacies.

你在人群中看到的是许多选择力的结果，所以当你真正测量两个或更多因素的组合时，很容易认为你在测量一件事。例如，我们可能实际上衡量的不是晋升年限，而是晋升年限和拒绝晋升年限的组合，而不是衡量经验年限。

What you see in a population is a result of many selective forces, so it's easy to think you are measuring one thing when you're really measuring a combination of two or more factors. For instance, instead of measuring years of experience, we may actually be measuring a combination of years passed over for promotion and years refused to take a promotion.

管理层犯这种类型错误是有害的，但通常不会致命。但是，当一个人犯同样的错误时，可能会导致个人悲剧。个人不会相信类型神话，而是希望根据真实的 人做出个人选择。

It's harmful when management makes this kind of typological mistake, but it's usually not fatal. But when an individual makes the same mistake, it can lead to personal tragedy. Instead of believing typological mythology, the individual will want to base personal choices on actual persons.

三年后你必须精疲力竭吗？不要看“普通”的程序员！看看你能不能找到一个十年的老手，他仍然很坚强。然后找出是什么让那个人打勾。找几个其他人，并以他们中最好的人为榜样。无论你做什么，都不要以平均值为榜样——除非你是一个肥胖的雌雄同体侏儒！

Do you have to burn out after three years? Don't look at the "average" programmer! See if you can find a ten-year veteran who's still going strong. Then find out what makes that person tick. Find a few other people and model yourself after the best in each of them. Whatever you do, don't model yourself on the average—unless you're a fat hermaphroditic midget!

我应该在编程领域呆多久？

How Long Should I Stay in Programming?

在我写了类型学思维应用于编程生涯的长度和生产力的问题后，几位记者很高兴看到“三年倦怠”的谬论被揭露，但他们对这篇文章表示不满。正如有人观察到的那样，“您从未真正回答过标题中的问题：编程生涯应该有多长？”

After I wrote about typological thinking applied to the question of the length and productivity of a programming career, several correspondents were happy to see the fallacy of the "three-year burnout" exposed, but they expressed dissatisfaction with the essay. As one observed, "You never really answered the question in the title: How long should a programming career be?"

我没有回答，因为我不知道。或者，更确切地说，我不知道如何回答这样一个普遍的社会学问题。我更愿意接受个人的、轶事的想法，所以我更愿意重新表述这个问题：我应该在编程领域呆多久？

I didn't answer because I didn't know. Or, rather, I didn't know how to answer such a general, sociological question. I'm a lot more comfortable with personal, anecdotal thinking, so I'd prefer to rephrase the question: How long should I stay in programming?

这个问题让我开始思考细节。如果我让自己的思绪沉浸在具体细节中，通常会出现一些东西，之后我可以对其进行清理、润色，并将其打包为一般原则。

This question starts me thinking in terms of specifics. If I let my mind wallow in specifics, something usually emerges, after which I can clean it up, polish it, and package it as a general principle.

出于某种原因我当时并不欣赏，这个编程题让我想起了我的阅读强迫症。我一定很早就养成了这个习惯，因为我记得我四岁时在早餐时阅读麦片盒。旅行时我最害怕的是在书店关门后被困在机场。然而最近，我学会了阅读电话簿的乐趣，从而克服了对机场的恐惧。

For some reason I didn't appreciate at the time, this programming question reminded me of my reading compulsion. I must have acquired this habit early, for I recall reading cereal boxes at breakfast when I was four years old. My greatest fear when traveling was to be stranded in an airport after the bookstore had closed. Recently, however, I overcame my fear of airports by learning the pleasures of reading telephone directories.

我相信我对电话簿的兴趣始于冰岛。由于其幅员辽阔和与世隔绝，冰岛融合了过去和未来，一定会让美国和欧洲的游客感到高兴。例如，在地 热 变得时髦之前很久，整个首都都被地热能供暖——现在仍然如此。

I believe my interest in phone directories started in Iceland. Because of its size and isolation, Iceland contains a mixture of past and future that is sure to delight American and European travelers. For instance, the entire capital was heated by geothermal energy—and still is—long before geothermal became chic.

冰岛也有一个现代电话系统，包括一个目录，但该目录包含一些过去的惊喜。如果你想在目录中查找某人，你很快就会发现名字是按字母顺序排列的——但是是名字！

Iceland also has a modern phone system, including a directory, but the directory contains a few surprises from the past. If you want to look up somebody in the directory, you quickly discover that the names are arranged alphabetically—but by first name!

直到十四世纪，欧洲很少有人有姓氏。随着人口越来越多、城市化程度越来越高、流动性越来越强，名字不再适合官僚主义的目的。然而，在冰岛，现代化进程缓慢，我们欧洲过去的系统一直保留着。

Until the fourteenth century, few people in Europe had last names. As population grew larger, more urban, and more mobile, first names were no longer adequate for bureaucratic purposes. In Iceland, however, the modernization has been slow, and the system from our own European past has been retained.

当采用姓氏时，使用了几种不同的系统。在冰岛等北部地区，通常通过参考父亲的名字来区分两个同名的人。为了按姓氏分类，这个系统成为永久性的，因为官僚机构不能容忍每一代人都从奥拉夫森到西格蒙德奥拉夫森再到伊瓦尔西格蒙德森。（不要问我为什么同样的官僚机构可以容忍女性名字随着婚姻的变化而改变。）

When family names were adopted, several different systems were used. In northern areas, such as Iceland, two people with the same name were commonly distinguished by referring to the father's name. For classifying by family name, this system was made permanent, for the bureaucracy couldn't tolerate changing each generation from Olafson to Sigmund Olafson to Ivar Sigmundson. (Don't ask me why the same bureaucracies can tolerate the change in women's names with marriage.)

在冰岛，该系统尚未成为永久性的。父亲的名字列在目录中，但它不是按字母顺序排列的基础。为什么会这样？它仅用于区分相同的名字。职业也用作区分目录中人员的另一种帮助，就像在普遍采用姓氏之前使用的那样。

In Iceland, the system hasn't been made permanent. Father's name is listed in the directory, but it's not the basis for alphabetical order. Why should it be? It's only used to distinguish between identical first names. Occupation is also used as another aid in distinguishing between people in the directory, just as it was used before last names were generally adopted.

我们在美国名录中有数百个职业名称，尽管我们很少考虑它们的来源。对于史密斯和富勒等许多名字来说，原来的职业几乎消失了。我注意到林肯电话簿上有一家 Wagoner Auto Repair。我不知道 Waggoners 有没有想过他们姓氏的由来。或许他们的家族只是从货车工作转为汽车工作，因为他们将行业代代相传。

We have hundreds of occupation names in the United States directories, even though we rarely think about their source. For many names, such as Smith and Fuller, the original occupation has all but disappeared. I noticed in the Lincoln phone book there is a Waggoner Auto Repair. I wonder if the Waggoners ever think about the origin of their family name. Perhaps their family simply converted from wagon work to auto work as they passed the trade down from generation to generation.

有些人争辩说编程不会持续足够长的时间来遗传。我从来没有在目录中找到程序员，尽管我找到了很多编码员。编码已经达到顶峰，现在要走锻造之路了吗？

Some people argue that programming won't last long enough to become hereditary. I've never found a Programmer in a directory, though I have found quite a few Coders. Has coding seen its peak, now to go the way of blacksmithing?

人们不再使用马匹，自然也就不需要那么多的铁匠了，史密斯这个名字也成了一种无力的回音。程序是当今的主力军，尽管程序员可能还不必担心忍受史密斯一家的命运。

As people stopped using horses, they naturally didn't need as many blacksmiths, and the name Smith became something of a feeble echo. Programs are today's workhorses, though programmers may not have to worry just yet about enduring the fate of the Smiths.

但这并不是传统行业的唯一命运。自中世纪以来人口一直在增长，我们仍然消耗大量的面粉。那么曾经居住在每个小村庄的磨坊主发生了什么事呢？我们每个人使用的烛光比我们的祖先多数千倍。那么千倍多的钱德勒在哪里呢？

But that wasn't the only fate of traditional trades. The population has grown since the Middle Ages, and we still consume generous quantities of flour. So what has happened to the Miller who used to inhabit every little village? Each of us uses thousands of times more candlepower than our ancestors. So where are the thousands of times more Chandlers?

钱德勒夫妇的案例与编程有启发性的相似之处。因为我们现在使用了太多的光，所以我们不能再依赖蜡烛了。便宜的灯导致需求增加，需求增加导致更便宜的灯。

The case of the Chandlers is an instructive parallel to programming. Because we now use so much light, we can no longer depend on candles. Cheap light led to increased demand, and increased demand led to cheaper light.

同样，编程的市场将取决于编程的成本。如果成本太高，市场可能会下跌。或者，更有可能的是，市场将开始寻找更便宜的替代品。

In the same way, the market for programming will depend on the cost of programming. If the cost goes too high, the market may decline. Or, more likely, the market will begin to look for cheaper substitutes.

在传统职业中，这些变化往往需要一生以上的时间，而且往往跨越几代人。在编程中，我们已经在一生中看到过很多这样的变化，这种情况必然会给个人带来很大的压力，就像以前的变化给家庭带来压力一样。

In the traditional occupations, these changes often took more than a lifetime and frequently they spanned generations. In programming, we've already seen many such changes within one lifetime, a situation that's bound to cause great stress on the individual, just as the former changes caused stress on families.

许多程序员通过个人避免改变来应对变化的压力，要么找到一份仍然使用“传统”方法的工作，要么放弃编程以从事一些非技术性工作，如管理或行政。

Many programmers have reacted to the stress of change by personally avoiding change, either by finding a job where "traditional" methods are still used or by abandoning programming for some nontechnical work like management or administration.

人类内部一定有某种非常强大的力量，使他们一代又一代地坚持交易。改变一个人的工作可能比预言即将到来的技术乌托邦的先知所建议的更困难。一方面，它可能涉及个人身份的丧失，就像以前意味着家庭身份的丧失一样。另一方面，也许这种损失是为“进步”付出的微小代价。

There must be some very strong force within human beings making them hang on to trades generation after generation. Changing one's work may well be more difficult than suggested by the prophets who predict an impending technological Utopia. For one thing, it may involve loss of personal identity, just as it formerly meant loss of family identity. On the other hand, perhaps this loss is a small price to pay for "progress."

三年多的职业生涯是基于一个谬论。更糟糕的是，这是一个自我实现的预言。如果你相信它，你就会停止尝试改进并开始考虑如何逃避到其他工作领域。

The three-years-and-out career is based on a fallacy. Worse than that, it's a self-fulfilling prophecy. If you believe it, you stop trying to improve and start thinking about how to escape to some other line of work.

也许是时候探究决定人们在编程中停留多长时间以及“适当”职业的形象如何影响他们作为程序员的工作的潜在人类过程。作为第一个近似值，我们应该考虑（1）当人们感到安全时的停滞，无论他们是否学到任何东西，以及（2）当人们觉得他们不会在交易中停留足够长的时间时的停滞费心学习任何东西。

Perhaps it's time to probe the underlying human processes that determine how long people stay in programming and how the image of a "proper" career affects their work as programmers. As a first approximation, we should consider the balance between (1) stagnation when people feel they're secure, whether they learn anything or not, and (2) stagnation when people feel they aren't going to be in the trade long enough to bother learning anything.

第一种趋势在大学教授中很明显，尤其是那些拥有终身教职的教授。第二种在程序员中尤其普遍。然而，有许多教授和程序员不断更新自己。他们与其他人有何不同？

The first tendency is evident among university professors, especially those who have tenure. The second is especially widespread among programmers. Yet there are many professors and programmers who continually renew themselves. How are they different from the others?

如果我们能回答这个问题，我们就可以回答一个人应该在编程中停留多长时间的问题。首先我们把问题改成这种形式：我怎么知道什么时候该停止编程了？

If we can answer that, we can answer the question of how long one should remain in programming. First we change the question to this form: How do I know when it's time to quit programming?

答案很简单。我称之为专业到期测试：

The answer to that one is easy. I call it the Professional Expiration Test:

学习完成后， 您就 完成了！

When learning's finished, you're finished!

这让我转了一圈，回到阅读电话簿。如果你能从在机场“失去”的时间中得到一些有用的东西，那么你肯定可以从在大学或编程工作中“失去”的时间中得到一些有用的东西。如果没有，说明你没有强迫症，是时候逃避了。

Which brings me full circle, back to reading telephone directories. If you can make something useful out of "lost" time in airports, surely you can make something useful out of "lost" time in a university or programming job. If not, you haven't got the compulsion and it's time to escape.

我如何为未来做好准备？

How Can I Prepare Myself for the Future?

“请你告诉我，我应该从这里走哪条路？”

"Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?"

“这在很大程度上取决于你想去哪里，”猫说。

"That depends a good deal on where you want to get to," said the Cat.

“我不太关心在哪里——”爱丽丝说。

"I don't much care where—" said Alice.

“那你走哪条路都无所谓了，”猫说。

"Then it doesn't much matter which way you go," said the Cat.

「——只要我到达某个地方，」爱丽丝解释道。

"—so long as I get somewhere," Alice added as an explanation.

“哦，你肯定会那样做，”猫说，“只要你走得足够远。”

"Oh, you're sure to do that," said the Cat, "it you only walk long enough."

——刘易斯卡罗尔爱丽丝梦游仙境

—Lewis Carroll Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

过去几十年的计算机行业非常活跃，任何早早开始走路的人几乎肯定能到达 某个地方。 尽管今天机会仍然很多，但未来的专业人士可能会比柴郡猫能够给爱丽丝更多的指导。

The computer business over the past few decades has been so dynamic that anyone who started walking early enough was almost sure to get somewhere. Although opportunities are still very great today, the would-be professional might be able to use a bit more direction than the Cheshire Cat was able to give Alice.

对爱丽丝来说幸运的是，适当的教养使她为在仙境中的冒险做好了准备。无论爱丽丝偶然遇到什么特殊问题，她都可以利用一般原则来挽救局面——或者至少让她远离太多麻烦。

Fortunately for Alice, a proper upbringing had prepared her for her adventures in Wonderland. Whatever peculiar problem Alice chanced to encounter, she could draw upon general principles to save the day—or at least to keep her out of too much trouble.

例如，就在她掉进兔子洞之后，她就看到了一个奇特的小瓶子，上面写着“喝我”。爱丽丝毫不气馁，想出了正确的行为方式：

For instance, right after she tumbled down the rabbit hole, she was faced with that peculiar little bottle with the tag reading "Drink me." Undismayed, Alice worked out the proper course of behavior:

说“喝了我”是件好事，但聪明的小爱丽丝不会仓促行事。“不，我先看看，”她说，“看看它有没有标明‘毒药’”；因为她读过几个有趣的小故事，讲的是孩子被烧伤、被野兽吃掉，以及其他不愉快的事情，都是因为他们不记得朋友教给他们的简单规则：比如，烧红的火如果你坚持太久，扑克会烧伤你；还有，如果你用刀把手指切得很深，通常会流血；她从来没有忘记，如果你从标有“毒药”的瓶子里喝多了，几乎可以肯定迟早会有人反对你。

It was all very well to say "Drink me," but the wise little Alice was not going to do that in a hurry. "No, I'll look first," she said, "and see whether it's marked 'poison' or not"; for she had read several nice little stories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts, and other unpleasant things, all because they would not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that, if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, if you drink much from a bottle marked "poison," it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.

爱丽丝的规则肯定对我们这些在编程世界寻求冒险的人有用：不要把烧红的扑克牌放得太久；不要用刀割得太深；并且不要从标有“毒药”的瓶子里喝太多。尽管未来是一片混浊的玻璃，但我们当然可以从过去的观察中做出一些推断，

Alice's rules would certainly be useful to those of us seeking adventures in Programmingland: Don't hold red-hot pokers too long; don't cut yourself too deeply with a knife; and don't drink too much from a bottle marked "poison." Even though the future is a cloudy glass, we can certainly make some extrapolation from observing that, in the past,

1. 没有一个程序员因为身体健康而吃过太多苦头。

1. No programmer has ever suffered too much from being in good health.

提醒你这一点似乎没有必要，但很多专业的程序员在谈到自己的身体时就像是拿着烧红的扑克牌的小孩子。因此，如果你想在编程中“有所作为”，那么如果你设法找到一些保持健康的方法，你的运气将会大大提高。或者为了获得健康，如果你现在不健康的话！

It may seem unnecessary to remind you of this, but many professional programmers are like little children with red-hot pokers when it comes to their own bodies. So if you want to "get somewhere" in programming, your luck will be greatly enhanced if you manage to find some way to stay healthy. Or to get healthy, if you're not right now!

我们还能从过去汲取哪些智慧之言？考虑到我认识的许多专业人士，我可以公平地说，

What other words of wisdom can we glean from the past? Thinking over the many professionals I've known, I can fairly say,

2，没有一个程序员的职业生涯会因为过度的自知而受到严重阻碍。

2, No programmer's career was ever severely retarded by an excess of self-knowledge.

这并不是说没有 自知之明就无法在编程中取得成功。如果那是真的，我就不会在这里写这篇文章了。我早期职业生涯的特点是个人盲点大到足以让银河黯然失色。我希望我能说我后来的职业生涯有幸拥有更深刻的洞察力，但似乎我学得越多，对自己的了解就越少。我现在确实明白，如果我偶尔能够走出自己，我早期的机会会如何增加。我浪费了多少桶午夜的油来解决我的一个盲点后面的问题！

That's not to say you can't get ahead in programming without self-knowledge. If that were true, I wouldn't be here writing this. My early career was characterized by personal blind spots broad enough to eclipse the Milky Way. I wish I could say that my later career was blessed with greater insight, but it seems that the more I've learned the less I know about myself. I do now see how my early chances would have been improved had I occasionally been able to get outside myself. How many barrels of midnight oil I've wasted over problems that rested squarely behind one of my blind spots!

我一直善于发现别人的盲点。当我最终开始意识到自己的失明程度时，我注意到其他人在看到我看不到的东西方面很有天赋。这导致我寻求别人眼睛的帮助，以换取我帮助他们。

I had always been adept at noticing the blind spots of other people. When I eventually began to realize the extent of my own blindness, I noticed other people were talented at seeing what I couldn't see. This led me to seek the help of others' eyes, in exchange for my helping them with mine.

获得和给予这种个人愿景并不总是像我预期的那么容易，但它教会了我另一个重要的教训：

Getting and giving this kind of personal vision wasn't always as easy as I expected it to be, but it taught me another great lesson:

3. 没有一个程序员会因为与他人相处的能力而受到严重阻碍。

3. No programmer has ever been seriously hindered by an ability to get along with other people.

请注意，我说的是“相处”，而不是“一起”。这是一个很好的区别，但计算机迫使我们做出区分。计算机永远不会“前进”。有些人被这种“直箭”行为激怒，但这样的人不会成为程序员。最终，专业人士开始意识到计算机不会说谎来赢得它的观点——因为它的观点是简单的事实。它也不会试图操纵你让你如愿以偿——因为它没有办法。

Notice that I said "get along," not "go along." It's a fine distinction, but one the computer forces us to make. The computer never "goes along." Some people are infuriated by this "straight-arrow" behavior, but such people don't last as programmers. Eventually, professionals come to realize that the computer doesn't tell lies to win its point—because its point is simple fact. Nor does it try to manipulate you to get its way—because it has no way.

人们学会与计算机坦诚相待，因为计算机与他们坦诚相待。人们学会对不正当的系统做出不正当的反应，这导致了另外三个成功原则：

People learn to be straight with computers because the computer is straight with them. People learn to be crooked in response to crooked systems, which leads to three more principles for success:

4. 没有程序员会因为直截了当地面对计算机或直截了当的人而变得残废。

4. No programmer has ever been maimed by being straight with a computer or with straight-dealing people.

5. 很多程序员曾因为试图直截了当地与弯腰的人打交道而受到伤害，但他们都康复了。

5. Many programmers have been hurt by trying to deal straight with bent people, but they've all recovered.

6. 许多程序员因为试图与弯曲的人打交道而弯曲了，弯曲往往是永久性的，并且会导致瘫痪。

6. Many programmers have been bent by trying to deal crooked with bent people, and often the bending is permanent and crippling.

我想这一切都归结为 善于处理分歧 并 愿意在有限的时间内忍受苦难 。如果您的工作不在一线，或者您有其他选择，它会有所帮助：

I guess it all comes down to being skilled at disagreement and willing to endure hardship for limited periods. It helps if your job is not on the line, or if you have alternatives:

7. 没有程序员会因为个人银行账户里有钱或有工作机会而放弃职业立场。

7. No programmer ever backed down from a professional stance because there was money in the personal bank account or a job offer in the wings.

但如果你明白问题不仅仅是问题，而是 学习的机会，这也会有所帮助。 离职是一种避免麻烦的方法，但是

But it also helps if you understand that problems aren't merely problems, but opportunities for learning. Leaving a job is a way of avoiding a mess of trouble, but

8. 没有一个程序员遇到过麻烦，而这些麻烦不提供一些机会来增加自我知识和与他人成功相处的能力。

8. No programmer ever got into a mess of trouble that didn't offer several opportunities for increasing self-knowledge and the ability to get along successfully with other people.

如果你不相信这一点，你只需要读一读发生在爱丽丝身上的故事，或者其他成千上万的文学冒险主角中的任何一个。

If you don't believe this, you need only read what happened to Alice, or to any of the thousands of other protagonists of literary adventures.

我自己在 Programmingland 的冒险经历告诉我，为不确定的未来做准备的秘诀不是学习新的 COBOL 动词，而是获得广泛应用的新问题解决技能。我自己作为顾问的工作也发生了这种转变，深受卡尔罗杰斯作品的影响。 罗杰斯在他的《论个人权力》 一书中解释说：

My own adventures in Programmingland have taught me the secret of preparing for an uncertain future is not in learning new COBOL verbs, but rather in acquiring new problem-solving skills of broad application. My own work as a consultant has taken this turn, heavily influenced by the work of Carl Rogers. In his book On Personal Power, Rogers explains:

个人而非问题才是重点。目的不是解决一个特定的问题，而是帮助个人成长，使他能够以更好的综合方式处理当前的问题和以后的问题。

The individual and not the problem is the focus. The aim is not to solve one particular problem but to assist the individual to grow, so he can cope with the present problem and with later problems in a better integrated fashion.

这引出了我的最终原则：

Which leads to my final principle:

9. 任何持续成长的程序员都不需要害怕未来。

9. No programmer who continues to grow need fear the future.

乌龟和头发：寓言

The Tortoise and the Hair: A Fable

一个秋天的傍晚，一只老乌龟在自家前廊欣赏落日余晖，一边回忆着过去最伟大的胜利，一边聆听着音响中美妙的莫扎特圆号协奏曲。突然间，他的遐想被一只年轻的野兔骑着摩托车隆隆而过的声音粗鲁地打断了，他正在听他的晶体管上的摇滚乐队。兔子第二次经过他的街道后，乌龟受够了。

One autumn evening, an old tortoise was enjoying the sunset on his front porch, reminiscing about his greatest victories of the past, and listening to an exquisite Mozart Horn Concerto on the stereo. All of a sudden, his reveries were brusquely interrupted by the sound of a young hare rumbling by on his motorcycle, listening to a rock group on his transistor. After the hare had passed down his street a second time, the tortoise had enough.

“嘿，你这个年轻的鞭子，”他喊道。“你为什么不关掉那个‘yeh-yeh’并听一些安静而有教养的东西呢？”

"Hey there, you young whippersnapper," he called out. "Why don't you turn off that 'yeh-yeh' and listen to something quiet and cultivated?"

兔子吱吱嘎嘎地把他的自行车停在了乌龟的门廊前。“爸爸，听着，”他回答，尽量表现出尊重。“我不是告诉你该听什么，你为什么要告诉我？再说了，你是‘鲷鱼’，不是我，我是兔子，不是乌龟。”

The hare screeched his bike to a stop in front of the tortoise's porch. "Look here, Pops," he answered, trying to be as respectful as possible. "I'm not telling you what to listen to, so why should you tell me? Besides, you're the 'snapper,' not me. I'm a hare, not a tortoise."

“我会说你是一根头发，”乌龟厉声说，他的听力变得有点重了。“你看看你， 满身 是毛。你为什么不能像我一样，把头发留得很长呢？”

"I'll say you're a hair," snapped the tortoise, who was becoming a bit hard of hearing. "Just look at you; you're covered with hair. Why can't you keep your hair to a respectable length, as I do?"

“你看，乌龟先生，我想解释一下。我有这头发是因为我是兔子。你秃得像乌龟是因为你是乌龟。但我不是为了折磨你出去成长一些头发，那为什么不给我同样的服务呢？”

"Look. Mister Tortoise, I'm trying to explain. I have this hair because I'm a hare. You're bald as a tortoise because you're a tortoise. But I'm not torturing you to go out and grow some hair, so why not pay me the same service?"

但是乌龟对他的无毛壳很敏感，所以他转移了话题。“还有一件事——那辆摩托车！你为什么不能像任何受人尊敬的公民一样开车呢？”

But the tortoise was rather sensitive about his hairless shell, so he switched topics. "And another thing—that motorcycle! Why can't you drive a car, like any respectable citizen?"

“我买不起车。”

"I can't afford a car."

“那是胡说八道，”乌龟告诫说。“首先，如果你能找到一份工作并做一些诚实的工作，你 负担 得起……”

"That's poppycock," the tortoise admonished. "In the first place, if you'd get a job and do some honest work, you could afford it . . ."

“可是我有工作，只是薪水不高……”

"But I have a job, only it doesn't pay much . . ."

“……其次，”乌龟说，它不喜欢被人反驳，“你想要那台机器只是为了在高速公路上飞驰，杀死无辜的旁观者。好吧，我给你看一件事，或者二。当我在你这个年纪的时候，我是州公路赛车冠军。打败了你自己的祖父，我做到了！它被写在所有的报纸上。现在你骑上你的小摩托车，因为我要下我的车，让你来一场 真正的 比赛，而不是儿童游戏！”

" . . and in the second place," said the tortoise, who did not like to be contradicted, "you only want that machine so you can go racing around the highways killing innocent bystanders. Well, I'll show you a thing or two. When I was your age, I was road-racing champion of the state. Beat your own grandfather, I did! It was written up in all the papers. Now you get on your little motorcycle, because I'm going to get out my car and have you a real race, not a children's game!"

“嘿，爸爸，”兔子对离去的乌龟说，“我不想和你比赛。爷爷告诉我你曾经是这些地方最炙手可热的车手，我相信他。但你有点老了现在为了那种事……”

"Hey, Pops," called the hare to the departing tortoise, "I don't want to race you. Grandpa told me you used to be the hottest driver in these parts, and I believe him. But you're a little old for that kind of thing now . . ."

但这完全是错误的说法，只会进一步激怒乌龟，此时乌龟已经在车道上狂奔了。不幸的是，他的视力大不如前，尤其是他不喜欢戴着龟甲眼镜出现在公众面前。当他咆哮着冲上街时，他侧面撞上了一辆警察巡逻车，这辆巡逻车正停下来告诉野兔不要开着他的摩托车在这个漂亮的街区闲逛。虽然没有人受伤，但乌龟的车完全毁了——这对他来说并不重要，因为他的驾照因不戴眼镜驾驶而被吊销了。

But that was exactly the wrong thing to say and only served to further enrage the tortoise, who was by this time already racing down the driveway. Unfortunately, his eyesight was not what it used to be, especially since he didn't like to be seen in public with his tortoise-shell glasses. As he roared out into the street, he crashed broadside into a police cruiser just pulling up to tell the hare not to be loitering around this nice neighborhood with his motorcycle. Though nobody was injured, the tortoise's car was a total wreck—which didn't matter very much to him, since his driver's license was revoked for driving without his glasses.

寓意： 无论青春多么浮躁，无论多么喧闹，多么没有修养，头发多么稀疏或长长，到头来，年龄总是会输的。

Moral: No matter how impetuous youth may be, no matter how noisy, how uncultivated, how poor or long of hair, in the end, age always loses.

换句话说：专业人士的最终行为是优雅地退休。

In other words: The ultimate act of a professional is a gracious retirement.

第八章结语

Chapter VIII Epilogue

结语是“任何文学作品末尾的简短补充或总结部分，通常涉及其角色的未来”。这本书可能是文学作品，也可能不是文学作品，它只有一个角色——职业程序员。除此之外，您可能刚刚读完有关未来的文章。那么为什么要有结语呢？

An epilogue is "a short addition or concluding section at the end of any literary work, often dealing with the future of its characters." This book may or may not be a literary work, and it has but one character—the professional programmer. Besides that, you've probably just finished reading about the future. So why have an epilogue at all?

我不太确定这个问题的答案，但有几种可能性：

I'm not really sure of the answer to that question, but there are several possibilities:

1. 当我没有以足够的戏剧性结束时，我的编辑对我大吼大叫。

1. My editor yells at me when I don't end with sufficient drama.

2. 有些读者在尝试先阅读本书的最后部分时可能会受挫，这可能是为了避免阅读整个无聊的烂摊子。

2. Some readers can be thwarted when they try to read the last part of the book first, possibly to avoid reading the entire boring mess.

3. 不知何故，我觉得还有很多话要说。

3. I feel somehow that there's more to be said.

这些都不是写结语的特别好的理由，尽管它们加在一起可能是一个可以接受的理由。一定有更强大的力量在驱使着我，这不知为何与下面的故事有关。

None of these is a particularly good reason for writing an epilogue, though perhaps taken together they sum up to one passable reason. There must be something stronger driving me, which for some reason is related to the following story.

这位伟大的天文学教授半夜被前门的一声巨响惊醒。当他把头探出卧室的窗户时，他看到噪音的来源是一个年轻人，他正在上他的宇宙演化课程。

The great professor of astronomy was wakened in the middle of the night by a loud pounding on his front door. When he stuck his head out the bedroom window he saw the source of the noise was a young man who was a student in his course on the evolution of the universe.

“大半夜的这个时候你想要什么？” 教授抱怨道。

"What do you want at this hour of the night?" the professor complained.

“很抱歉吵醒你，先生，但我一直非常沮丧和激动。我睡不着，我怕我会伤到自己。”

"I'm sorry to waken you, sir, but I've been terribly depressed and agitated. I can't sleep, and I'm afraid I might do myself some injury."

“听到这个我很难过，但这跟我有什么关系？”

"I'm sorry to hear that, but what can that have to do with me?"

“这是因为你的演讲，”学生解释道。“所有关于宇宙末日的讨论都让我感到非常不安。”

"It's because of your lecture," the student explained. "All that talk about the end of the universe has upset me something awful."

“我几乎不认为你需要难过，”教授责备他。“毕竟，我告诉过你，宇宙末日要一千亿年才会到来！”

"I hardly think you need to be upset," the professor chided him. "After all, I told you that the end of the universe wouldn't come for 100 billion years!"

“哦！呼！我还以为你说的是​​一亿呢！”

"Oh! Whew! I thought you said 100 million!"

现在，当我正在为一本关于专业程序员的书写结语时，为什么我会想到这个故事呢？我有过不止一次的经历，因为一些“紧急情况”在半夜被叫醒，并不比这个学生的请求更紧急。我认为许多专业程序员都有过相同的经历，以及其他一些很容易使他们高估自己所做事情的重要性的经历。

Now why should that story come to my mind when I'm writing an epilogue to a book for and about the professional programmer? I've had the experience, more than once, of being awakened in the middle of the night for some "emergency" no more urgent than this student's plea. I think that many professional programmers have had the same experience, as well as other experiences which could easily make them overestimate the importance of what they're doing.

在过去的几十年里，编程业务一直很不错。在接下来的几年里，它承诺会一样好，甚至更好。任何热爱编程的人都生活在一个幸运的时代，但事实仅此而已——运气。五十年前，我们的服务一文不值，五十年后可能更糟。五十年后得知程序员被绞死我不会感到惊讶。

The programming business has been a good one over the past few decades. In the next few, it promises to be just as good, perhaps better. Anyone with a bent for programming is living in a lucky time, but that's really all it is—luck. Fifty years ago, our services weren't worth a nickel, and fifty years from now it might be worse. I wouldn't be surprised in fifty years to learn programmers were being hanged.

但是你作为一个人的自身价值与你作为一种劳动商品的价值并没有多大关系。毕竟，婴儿有什么用？因为你的薪水很高而且很受追捧，你很容易忘记你作为程序员的技能以外的有价值的品质。如果我们的业务出现下滑，您就会遇到裂痕，这会让 Humpty Dumpty 看起来很顽固。

But your own worth as a person is not much related to your worth as a labor commodity. After all, of what use is a baby? Because you're well paid and much sought after, you could easily forget about your worthy qualities other than your skill as a programmer. Should our business ever take a tumble, you'd be in for a cracking that would make Humpty Dumpty seem hard-boiled.

我在 20 世纪 70 年代初看到这种情况发生在我的一些朋友身上。它不漂亮，它可能会再次发生。（注意：这一预测在上一版之后的几年里确实实现了。）受伤害最严重的是那些骑得最高的人——不一定是那些拥有最好工作的人，而是那些不知何故炸毁了自己的人不成比例。

I saw this happen to some of my friends in the early 1970s. It wasn't pretty, and it could happen again. (Note: This prediction did come true in the years since the previous edition.) The ones who were hurt most were the ones who had been riding highest—not the ones who necessarily had the best jobs, but the ones who had somehow blown themselves up all out of proportion.

但如果事情永远不会 为你崩溃，实际上可能会更糟。你的自我形象会不断膨胀，直到最后，你会成为所有家人、朋友和邻居眼中令人难以忍受、自负的讨厌鬼。我知道每当我的一本书受到好评时，我都会遇到这种情况，而且我知道我的朋友们试图让我回到现实是多么困难。

But it could actually be worse if things never crash for you. Your self-image will keep inflating until, at last, you'll be an insufferable, pompous bore to all your family, friends, and neighbors. I know that's what happens to me whenever one of my books is well received, and I know how hard it is for my friends who attempt to bring me back to earth.

所以我担心我写一本关于专业程序员的整本书可能会做什么，我可能会增加一些程序员已经拥有的自我重要性的膨胀感。如果他们像我一样，那种感觉会产生很多不快乐——觉得 我的 问题比常人的问题更大、更重要、更难解决。

So I worry what I might be doing by writing an entire book about the professional programmer, what I might be adding to an inflated feeling of self-importance that some programmers already possess. If they're like me, that feeling can generate much unhappiness—feeling that my problems are bigger, more important, and harder to solve than the problems of ordinary people.

下次你有这种感觉时，试着想想天文学生和剩下的 1 亿或 1000 亿年。或者想想现在生活在这个星球上的另外 50 亿人。或者在宇宙中的 1000 亿个星系中，每个星系大约有 1 万亿颗恒星，每颗恒星很可能还有另外 50 亿“人”依附在它们身上。

Next time you're feeling that way, try thinking of the astronomy student and the 100 million or 100 billion years left. Or think of the 5 billion other people now living on this planet. Or of the 100 billion galaxies in the universe, each with perhaps 1 trillion stars, each of which could well have another 5 billion "people" attached to them.

这些“人”中的许多人可能是程序员，其中数十亿人可能正在经历与您相同的错误，就在此时此刻。当我被困在某事上时，我发现这种天文数字般的陪伴是最令人欣慰的。这就是我想告诉你的，作为本书的结语：

Many of those "people" are probably programmers, and a few billion of them are probably experiencing the same bugs you are, right at this very moment. When I'm stuck on something, I find this thought of astronomic companionship most comforting. And that's what I wanted to tell you, as an epilogue to this book:

如果你对自己在宇宙中的位置有一个合理的看法，你会睡得更好。

You'll sleep much better if you have a reasonable perspective on your place in the universe.

第九章专业书目

Chapter IX A Professional Bibliography

以少数属于你自己的真正好书开始生活是一件很棒的事情。——阿瑟·柯南·道尔爵士

It's a great thing to start life with a small number of really good books which are your very own.—Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

认真的程序员当然应该从“少量真正的好书”开始职业生涯。不幸的是，真正好的编程书籍数量一开始就很少，而与此同时，不太好但必不可少的书籍（例如参考手册）的数量却在不断增加。然后，似乎也永远没有足够的时间阅读。

The serious programmer should certainly start professional life with a "small number of really good books." Unfortunately, the number of really good books in programming is rather small to begin with, while at the same time the number of not-so-good, but essential, books—such as reference manuals—is always increasing. Then, too, there never seems to be enough time for reading.

速读可能会有帮助，但我有自己的系统，速度更快。我努力只读最好的书，并给予他们最大的关注。这种策略也提高了我的阅读乐趣水平，为那些我必须阅读但可能写得不太好的书建立了情感储备。

Speed-reading may help, but I have my own system that's even faster. I try hard to read only the very best books, and to give them my utmost attention. This tactic also raises my level of reading enjoyment, building up an emotional reserve for those books I must read that may not be so nicely written.

以下是一份带注释的精选书籍清单，这些书籍影响了我对专业程序员可能取得的成就以及如何实现这一成就的印象。

The following is an annotated, highly selective list of books which have influenced my image of what a professional programmer might achieve and how that achievement might be realized.

列表中很少有书籍与编程有任何直接联系，但不要为此担心。程序员可能是独一无二的，但到目前为止，他们仍然是人类的一部分。

Few of the books on the list have any direct connection with programming, but don't let that worry you. Programmers may be unique, but they are, so far, still part of the human race.

博尔丁，肯尼斯。 图像：生活和社会中的知识。 安娜堡：密歇根大学出版社，1956 年。

Boulding, Kenneth. The Image: Knowledge in Life and Society. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1956.

这篇经典的文章是任何关注新专业人士和新职业塑造的人的必读之作。在您吸收了这本获奖书籍的信息后，您的思维过程将永远不同。

This classic essay is required reading for anyone who is concerned about the shaping of new professionals and a new profession. Your thinking process will never be the same after you've absorbed the message of this prize-winning book.

Freedman、Daniel P. 和 Gerald M. Weinberg。 演练、检查和技术审查手册，第 3 版。

Freedman, Daniel P., and Gerald M. Weinberg. Handbook of Walkthroughs, Inspections, and Technical Reviews, 3rd Ed.

您一直想知道的关于程序员如何通过正式技术审查技术互相帮助改进的所有信息。

Everything you always wanted to know about how programmers can help each other improve through the technique of formal technical reviews.

肯尼迪，尤金。 关于成为辅导员。 纽约：Continuum Publishing Corp.，1980 年。

Kennedy, Eugene. On Becoming a Counselor. New York: Continuum Publishing Corp., 1980.

这本书只字未提计算机编程，却说了很多关于成为专业人士为他人服务的内容。聪明的读者知道跳过哪些部分不会有任何困难。 我认为在阅读这本书之前先阅读卡尔·罗杰斯 (Carl Rogers)的《论个人力量》 一书可能会更好。但是，如果您正在考虑离开技术工作或担任监督职位，那么在做出决定之前花时间阅读这两本书是非常值得的。

This book says not a single word about computer programming, but it says many words about being a professional in the service of other people. The intelligent reader won't have any trouble knowing which parts to skip. I think it might be better to read the Carl Rogers book On Personal Power before reading this one. But if you're considering an offer to leave technical work or to take a supervisory status, it will be well worth your time to read both of these books before making a decision.

Kernighan、Brian W. 和 PJ Plauger。 编程风格的要素。 纽约：麦格劳-希尔出版社，1974 年。

Kernighan, Brian W., and P. J. Plauger. The Elements of Programming Style. New York: McGraw-Hill, 1974.

这是一本小书，读起来并不难，但对工作的程序员来说充满了微妙的教训。在你读完它后的第一周，你会通过避免工作中的一些讨厌的问题来赚回阅读所花费的几个小时。作者的另一部作品 Software Tools 也值得加入你的书架，但在你读完这部经典之后再读。

This is a little book and not hard to read, but full of subtle lessons for the working programmer. In the first week after you read it, you'll earn back the few hours consumed in the reading by avoiding some nasty problem in your work. The author's other work, Software Tools, is also a worthwhile addition to your bookshelf, but read it after you've read this classic.

Knuth, Donald E. 计算机编程艺术，卷。3、排序和搜索。马萨诸塞州雷丁：Addison-Wesley，1973 年。

Knuth, Donald E. The Art of Computer Programming, vol. 3, Sorting and Searching. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley, 1973.

Knuth 雄心勃勃的系列中的任何一本书都可以放在专业程序员的书架上，但这些著名作品的太多副本只是放在书架上。也许它们在厚度和密度上都太强大了，所以我只推荐一个作为入门。我之所以选择这个，是因为它是我提到最多的一个，而且对于大多数专业人士来说，它可能是最容易与之相关的。在目前的背景下，Knuth 的书的要点不是任何特定的技术材料，而是正如 Knuth 所说的那样，“讨论各种一般问题的理想框架”，例如“一个人如何在不同的算法之间进行理性选择”同一个申请？” 与 Knuth 一起度过的每一个小时都会改善专业程序员的思维过程。

Any of the books in Knuth's ambitious series would sit well on the shelves of the professional programmer, but far too many copies of these prestigious works merely sit on shelves. Perhaps they are too imposing in thickness and density, so I'm recommending only one as a starter. I've chosen this one because it's the one I refer to most and perhaps it is easiest for the largest number of professionals to relate to. The point of Knuth's books, in the present context, is not any particular technical material but, as Knuth puts it, "an ideal framework for discussing a wide variety of general issues," such as "How can a person choose rationally between different algorithms for the same application?" Every hour spent with Knuth will improve the thought processes of the professional programmer.

Linger、Richard C.、Harlan D. Mills 和 Bernard I. Witt。 结构化编程：理论与实践。 马萨诸塞州雷丁：Addison-Wesley，1979 年。

Linger, Richard C., Harlan D. Mills, and Bernard I. Witt. Structured Programming: Theory and Practice. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley, 1979.

如果专业程序员只读一本关于“结构化程序设计”的书，那应该就是这本了。这不是一本可以略读的书，但也不是不必要的困难。本书的风格和内容为未来的专业编程定下了基调。

If a professional programmer were to read only one book on "structured programming," this should be it. This is not a book to be skimmed, but it's not unnecessarily difficult either. The style and content of this book set the tone for professional programming of the future.

莫里森、菲利普和艾米丽，编辑。 查尔斯巴贝奇和他的计算引擎。纽约：多佛出版社，1961 年。

Morrison, Philip, and Emily, eds. Charles Babbage and His Calculating Engines. New York: Dover, 1961.

任何专业人士都必须对这一切是如何开始感兴趣的。巴贝奇是第一个真正的计算机专业人士，他的许多问题与当今专业人士面临的问题相似。阅读他的生活和时代，他的成功和失败，应该有助于创造每个专业人士都需要的那种观点。

Any professional has to be interested in how it all got started. Babbage was the first real computer professional, and many of his problems are similar to the problems faced by professionals today. Reading about his life and times, his successes and failures, should help to create the kind of perspective every professional needs.

派，大卫。 工艺的本质和艺术。 纽约：Van Nostrand Reinhold，1968 年。

Pye, David. The Nature and Art of Workmanship. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1968.

每个专业的程序员都应该对做工有浓厚的兴趣，每个对做工有浓厚兴趣的人都应该读一读 Pye。

Every professional programmer should be intensely interested in workmanship, and everyone intensely interested in workmanship should read Pye.

罗杰斯，卡尔。 论个人力量：内在力量及其革命性影响。纽约：戴尔出版公司，1977 年。

Rogers, Carl. On Personal Power: Inner Strength and Its Revolutionary Impact. New York: Dell Publishing Co., 1977.

这本书适合所有想在职业生涯和自己身上发展权力而不发展对他人的权力的人。任何一个能把罗杰斯吸进血液的程序员，都会成为两倍的专业，十倍的人。

A book for all those who would like to develop power over their professional life, and over themselves, without developing power over other people. Any programmer who can absorb Rogers into the blood will become twice the professional and ten times the person.

Schneider, Ben Ross, Jr. 在 Computerland 旅行。 马萨诸塞州雷丁：Addison-Wesley，1974 年。

Schneider, Ben Ross, Jr. Travels in Computerland. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley, 1974.

这是尝试使用我们服务的人从外部对我们业务的看法。它可能有助于让内部人员保持平稳，而且阅读起来非常有趣。

This is a view of our business from the outside, by someone who tried to use our services. It may help to keep insiders on an even keel, and it's great fun to read.

舒特，内维尔。 工具室的受托人。 纽约：William Morrow & Co.，1960 年。

Shute, Nevil. Trustee from the Toolroom. New York: William Morrow & Co., 1960.

芭芭拉·沃克 (Barbara Walker) 向我推荐了这本迷人的小说，以回应本书中的一篇文章。任何真正的工匠都会为这个关于专注于专业工作的回报的故事而高兴。

This charming novel was recommended to me by Barbara Walker in response to one of the essays in this book. Any true craftsperson will be delighted with this story of the rewards of dedication to professional work.

特克尔，螺柱。 在职的。 纽约：雅芳图书公司，1975 年。

Terkel, Studs. Working. New York: Avon Books, 1975.

这本畅销书汇集了来自各种背景、从事各种工作的员工的个人陈述。阅读起来既有趣又感人，一定会有助于洞察您自己对工作的态度。

This best seller is a compendium of personal statements by workers from all sorts of backgrounds in all sorts of jobs. It's fun and moving to read, and is sure to contribute insight into your own attitudes toward work.

第十章延伸阅读

Chapter X Further Reading

Below are book titles and links to web pages where you can sample Jerry's books at no cost and, if you'd like, buy them at low eBook prices in formats for all e-reading devices, or your computer.

新生谋杀案：

Freshman Murders:

天真的数学家能挫败老练的罪犯吗？

Can naive mathematicians foil a sophisticated master criminal?

第一纵梁

First Stringers

六个特殊的年轻人组成一个团队来击败一个武装的分裂主义民兵。

Six special young people become a team to defeat an armed secessionist militia.

第二纵梁

Second Stringers

First Stringers 应对来自南美的危险 Stringer。

First Stringers cope with a dangerous Stringer from South America.

上帝之手

The Hands of God

一个年轻女子的才华能否为她赢得失去双手时失去的自由？

Will a young woman's talent win her the freedom she lost when she lost both hands?

阿雷马克项目

The Aremac Project

两位年轻的发明家面临着名声带来的问题。

Two young inventors confront the problems accompanying fame.

阿雷马克动力

Aremac Power

成功的发明家协助保护受虐待的纳瓦霍发明家。

Successful inventors assist in protecting an abused Navajo inventor.

Jigglers：一个世纪后的Aremac

Jigglers: Aremac a Century Later

（免费书籍，Aremac Power 续集）

(FREE BOOK, Aremac Power sequel)

分子的情妇

Mistress of Molecules

两个来自不同文化的人，每个人都拥有不可思议的力量，联手合作。

Two people from different cultures, each with incredible powers, team up.

地球的无尽努力

Earth's Endless Effort

地球上最聪明的生物体与人类交朋友，以保护自己免受其他人类的伤害。

Earth's smartest living entity befriends humans to save itself from other humans.

关于封面

About the Cover

为了

for
